requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 122 or equivalent or sophomore standing.
name: Survey of Accounting
description: Survey of accounting topics related to business decisions including financial reporting, managerial accounting, and other special topics.

name: Introduction to Financial Accounting
description: User-oriented approach to the study of financial accounting and reporting topics related to business decisions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ACCT 225.
name: Introduction to Managerial Accounting
description: User-oriented approach to the study of managerial accounting topics related to business decisions.

name: Survey of Commercial Law
description: Basic legal concepts and the judicial system, with emphasis on business law.

name: Survey of Federal Taxation
description: Federal tax law and preparation of individual income tax returns. Not allowed as an upper-division elective by accounting majors and not open for students who received credit for ACCT 403.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ACCT 226.
name: Financial Accounting I
description: Accounting theory and practice as it relates to preparation of financial statements.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ACCT 226.
name: Cost/Managerial Accounting
description: Internal managerial and cost accounting, including budgeting, cost determination, and analysis.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ACCT 401.
name: Tax I
description: Overview of individual, corporate, and partnership taxation. Emphasis is on sole proprietorships.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ACCT 401 and MGSC 290.
name: Accounting Information Systems I
description: Accounting systems for business decision-making and effective control of the business enterprise.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ACCT 401.
name: Financial Accounting II
description: Additional accounting theory and practice as it relates to preparation of financial statements.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: ACCT 404.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: ACCT 405.
name: Auditing I
description: Principles of auditing necessary to evaluate the integrity of accounting systems and financial reporting.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ACCT 225, ACCT 226, and FINA 363.
name: Financial Statement Analysis
description: This course focuses on the analysis of financial statements for profitability and risk assessment and for firm and segment valuation. Restricted to finance majors.

name: Introduction into Aerospace Engineering
description: Historical overview of air and space flight. Principles of flight and characterization of the atmosphere and space. Vehicle concepts, and an introduction to aerodynamics, materials, structures, propulsion, flight mechanics, control, aircraft systems, and design.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in MATH 242; D or better in EMCH 201 or ENCP 201.
name: Aerodynamics I Incompressible Flow
description: Fundamentals of inviscid, incompressible flow. Derivation of basic equations for lift, drag and aerodynamic moments through dimensional analysis. Two dimensional flow over airfoils. Airfoil characteristics. Thin airfoil theory, finite wing theory. Wing and body interactions. Aerodynamic drag characteristics. Boundary layers.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 290 or ENCP 290.
name: Energy Power and Propulsion
description: Introduction to aircraft and rocket engines with emphasis on the performance and characteristics of various types of propulsion systems, including turbojet, turbofan, turboprop, ramjet, scramjet and liquid & solid propellant rockets.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in AESP 101, ENCP 101.
name: Aerospace Systems
description: Fundamentals of flight control systems, engine control systems, fuel systems, hydraulic systems, landing gears, electrical systems, environmental control systems, emergency systems, avionics and rotary wing systems. Aerospace systems design and development methodology.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in STAT 509 and AESP 265.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in EMCH 371; D or better in EMCH 310 or ENCP 210.
name: Aerospace Laboratory I
description: Aerospace component experiments: drag polar and Cm-alpha curve for an airfoil; fuselage and landing gear drag; compliance matrix of an isotropic and a laminated composite; mechanical and thermal properties of various aerospace materials; reporting.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: AESP 361.
name: Aerospace Laboratory II
description: Introduction to experimental determination of structures, propulsion and systems aspects of aerospace engineering. Oral and written presentations and reports.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: AESP 265.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: AESP 350 and AESP 314.
name: Aircraft Design Part I Basics
description: Aircraft mission analysis; Conceptual aircraft design; Weight estimation; Wing design; Payload compartment design; Stabilizer and control surface design; engine selection; aircraft systems design; performance analysis; trade studies; design verification; design documentation and presentation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 310 or ENCP 210.
name: Flight and Orbital Mechanics
description: Derivation of the general equations of motion (EoM) for aircraft and space flight. Solution of Aircraft EoM for cruise flight and flight maneuvers including coordinated turns, takeoff and landing. Solution of EoM for orbital mechanics problems including transfer trajectories. Calculation of required specific impulses. Design of interplanetary trajectories.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in AESP 350 and EMCH 577.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in AESP 314.
name: Design I
description: Techniques for managing, planning and executing engineering projects. Computer based analysis and synthesis techniques. Manufacturing and assembly techniques. Statistical methods to support manufacturing, safety and reliability based design. Engineering Ethics. Social impact of engineering decisions and projects. Effective written and oral communication.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EMCH 330 or ENCP 330, AESP 420.
name: Flight Dynamics and Control
description: Flight Dynamics and Control is a three-credit course that covers the dynamics of aircraft motion, methods of analysis and design for stability and control, longitudinal motions, lateral-directional motions, and coupled longitudinal and lateral-directional motions.

requisiteText: Corequisite: AERO 101L
name: US Air Force Heritage and Values I
description: Survey course introducing students to the U.S. Air Force and AFROTC. Topics include mission and organization of the Air Force, officership, professionalism, military customs and courtesies, and officer career opportunities.

requisiteText: Corequisite: AERO 101.
name: Leadership Laboratory 101
description: Provides cadets the basic skills/knowledge to be functional members of the cadet corps, and activities to build camaraderie and esprit-de-corps. Includes mandatory physical fitness program.

requisiteText: Corequisite: AERO 102L.
name: US Air Force Heritage and Values II
description: Continuation of AERO 101. Additional topics include Air Force core values, leadership principles, group leadership dynamics, and an introduction to verbal and written communications skills.

requisiteText: Corequisite: AERO 102.
name: Leadership Laboratory 102
description: Continuation of AERO 101L. Exposure to additional information on an Air Force career. Scenarios and problems teach followership and leadership skills. Includes mandatory physical fitness program.

requisiteText: Corequisite: AERO 201L.
name: Team and Leadership Fundamentals I
description: Fundamental introduction to leadership and team-building.

requisiteText: Corequisite: AERO 201.
name: Leadership Laboratory 201
description: Preparation of students for summer training at an Air Force base; teaching drill and other leadership experiences. Includes mandatory physical fitness program.

requisiteText: Corequisite: AERO 202L.
name: Team and Leadership Fundamentals II
description: Continuation of AERO 201. This course continues to build fundamental leadership and team building skills.

requisiteText: Corequisite: AERO 202.
name: Leadership Laboratory 202
description: Continuation of AERO 201L. Focuses on AFROTC Honor Code, Field Training Manual/procedures, and expeditionary skills required at field training. Includes mandatory physical fitness program.

requisiteText: Corequisite: AERO 301L.
name: Leading People and Effective Communication
description: Tools and strategies for effective leadership. Topics include improving writing and public speaking skills used for briefing as well as ethics training.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Corequisite: AERO 301.
name: Leadership Laboratory 301
description: Provides cadets opportunities to develop leadership and followership skills, as well as sharpen their planning, organization, and communication ability. Includes mandatory physical fitness program.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: AERO 301.
Corequisite: AERO 302L.
name: Leading People and Effective Communication II
description: Continuation of AERO 301. Advanced ethics and leadership skills designed to prepare the cadet to be an officer and a leader.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: AERO 301L.
Corequisite: AERO 302.
name: Leadership Laboratory 302
description: Continuation of AERO 301L. Allows intermediate cadet leaders to further develop leadership and management skills essential in Air Force officers. Includes mandatory physical fitness program.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in AERO 302 and AERO 302L.
Corequisite: AERO 401L.
name: National Security/Leadership Responsibilities/Commissioning Preparation
description: Study of U. S. Constitution, the Armed Forces, civilian control of the military, elements of national security, USAF doctrine, Total Force, the Joint environment, terrorism, and regional and cultural studies.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in AERO 302 and AERO 302L.
Corequisite: AERO 401.
name: Leadership Laboratory 401
description: Provides senior cadet leaders opportunities to develop leadership and supervisory skills, and to effectively manage resources toward mission accomplishment. Includes mandatory physical fitness program.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in AERO 401 and AERO 401L.
Corequisite: AERO 402L.
name: National Security / Leadership Responsibilities / Commissioning Preparation II
description: Continuation of AERO 401. Topics include national security policy and process, air and space power operations, roles of the military in society and current domestic and international issues affecting the military profession.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in AERO 401 and AERO 401L.
Corequisite: AERO 402.
name: Leadership Laboratory 402
description: Continuation of AERO 401L. Allows senior cadet leaders advanced opportunities to hone their leadership in preparation for entering active duty. Includes mandatory physical fitness program.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: AERO 402L.
name: Extended Cadet Leader Leadership Laboratory
description: Provides extended cadet leaders opportunities to continue developing leadership, managerial, and communication skills, and to mentor junior cadet corps members. Includes mandatory physical fitness program.

name: Freedom Papers: Narratives of Race and Nation
description: A study of the United States founding documents that emphasizes how the experiences of African American citizens throughout history and culture shape the country�€�s values, norms, and ideals.

name: Introduction to African American Studies: Social and Historical Foundations
description: Introduction to the key debates, figures, and concepts that are fundamental to the interdisciplinary study of the historical, political, and social development of black life in America.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Introduction to African-American Studies
description: Introduction to the analysis and discussion of creative works and traditions by and about African Americans through folklore, music, art, dance, and literature.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Introduction to African American Religions
description: The variety of religious traditions of African Americans, with emphasis on the contexts in which they developed.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Convergence and Divergence in African American and Jewish Relations: Historical and Contemporary
description: An examination of African American and Jewish American inter-ethnic, historical and contemporary connections and disconnections. Implications for educational, social, and social settings are considered.

name: African-American Cultures
description: An examination of African-American cultures in the New World.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: African-American Feminist Theory
description: An interdisciplinary survey of the contributions of African-American women to feminist theory.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Psychology and the African-American Experience
description: Psychological theory and research as it applies to African Americans. Explores Africentric and other perspectives and roles of culture, racism, and historical phenomena.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Black Experience in the United States to 1865
description: The social, cultural, economic, and political life of black people in the United States to 1865.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Black Experience in the United States since 1865
description: The social, cultural, economic, and political life of black people in the United States since 1865.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: The American Civil Rights Movement
description: Examination of the origins of Jim Crow and the multi-faceted struggle against it, and other forms of racial inequality, in the American South and the rest of the US since the early 20th century.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Religions of the African Diaspora
description: Explore development/theologies of African/African Diaspora religions; examine misunderstandings; arrive at a more sophisticated and nuanced vision of these religions and the people who hold them.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Environmental Racism and Justice
description: History of the environmental justice movement and the unequal distribution of environmental harms on low income, minority, and historically marginalized groups.

name: Antiracist Education
description: Basic concepts, issues, and practices of antiracist education. Topics include individual and institutional racism, overt and covert racism, curriculum, textbooks, power relationships, teacher-student relationships, and privacy.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Introduction to U.S. Racial and Ethnic Politics
description: Survey of theories of the impact of race, ethnicity, and racism on American politics, and analysis of major policies and racial group experience regarding American citizenship.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Race and Ethnic Relations
description: Theoretical and empirical approaches related to race/ethnicity and the current state of race relations in American, with some attention to global issues.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: African-American Politics
description: African-American politics from the colonial period to the present. Emphasis on voting rights and strategies to advance black representation.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Medical Experimentation and the Black Body
description: A cross-disciplinary study of how the bodies of Africans and African Americans were used in medical experimentation, starting in the late 18th century and continuing to the present.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Medicine, Disease, and Slavery
description: An interdisciplinary study of the health of enslaved African Americans during the nineteenth century by focusing on the conceptions, experiences, and dynamics of the relationship between slaves, medicine, healing, and their masters in the Antebellum American South.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Cultural History of Hip Hop Music
description: Roots of rap/hip hop music from African bardic tradition to African American vernacular traditions and development as a musical genre; rap�€�s musical and verbal traits and political ideologies; hip hop�€�s influence on mainstream American society and global youth.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Race and Science Fiction
description: Draws on science fiction to understand the contemporary history of American racial and ethnic politics and to speculate about the significance of race in America�€�s political future.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Special Topics in African American Society and History
description: Reading and research on selected social and historical topics in African American studies. May be repeated as content varies by title.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Special Topics in African-American Arts and Cultures
description: Reading and research on selected arts and cultural topics in African-American studies. May be repeated as content varies by title.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: African American Political Thought
description: Survey of many of the major schools of historic and contemporary African American political thought.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Slavery, Literature & Culture
description: Interdisciplinary analysis of how the experiences of enslaved people are represented through fiction, autobiography, film, art, and new media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: African-American Literature I: to 1903
description: Representative works of African-American writers to 1903.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101, ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270 - ENGL 292.
name: African-American Literature II: 1903 �€“ Present
description: Representative works of African-American writers from 1903 to the present.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101, ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270 - ENGL 292.
name: African Literature
description: Authors and literary forms representative of Africa.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101, ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270 - ENGL 292.
name: Caribbean Literature
description: Authors and literary forms representative of the Caribbean.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270-ENGL 292.
name: African-American English
description: Linguistic examination of the structure, history, and use of African-American English, as well as literary presentations, language attitudes, and issues relating to education and the acquisition of Standard English.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Jim Crow: Histories & Revivals
description: This course critically examines the continuities and discontinuities between Jim Crow and our current historical and political moment.

name: Black Activism
description: Critical review of theories of community organizing, grassroots activism, and social movements, and examination of contemporary forms of black activism.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: WGST 111 or WGST 112 or ANTH 102.
name: African-American Rhetoric
description: African-American rhetoric as manifested in speeches, essays, and other rhetorical artifacts.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101, ENGL 102.
name: Black Women Writers
description: An examination of literature by and about black women, including fiction, poetry, drama, and autobiography. This study will focus on issues that emerge from the creative representations of black women and the intersections of race, gender, sexuality, and class that interrogate what is both particular and universal experiences.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Seminar in African-American Studies
description: Graduation with Leadership Distinction: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Seminar in African-American Studies
description: Graduation with Leadership Distinction: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Race, Gender, and Graphic Novels
description: Representations of race and gender in comics with a special emphasis on the experiences of African Americans.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: An Anthropological View of Blacks in Film
description: Cultural representations, constructions, production, and consumption of African-American identity in the popular culture medium of feature films.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101, ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270 - ENGL 292.
name: African American Theatre
description: The major movements, figures, plays, and critical strategies that have marked the development of African American theatre in the 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Culture and Identity in the African Diaspora
description: Students will explore the African Diaspora as a social, cultural, and historical formation with Africa at its center, focusing on US, Latin American, and Caribbean African-descended communities.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Elementary American Sign Language
description: Introduction to basic vocabulary and common grammar structures of ASL. Focus on communication and familiarization with aspects of deaf culture.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ASLG 121.
name: Basic Proficiency in American Sign Language
description: Practice and further development in the language and culture of the American deaf community.

name: Primates, People, and Prehistory
description: An exploration of human origins, human evolution, human prehistory, and cultural existence from its less complex forms to early civilizations. An introduction to the concepts, methods, and data of physical, biological, and archaeological anthropology.

name: Understanding Other Cultures
description: An exploration and comparison of selected contemporary cultures, including their languages. An introduction to the concepts, methods, and data of socio-cultural anthropology and anthropological linguistics.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Human Origins: An Introduction to Biological Anthropology
description: An introduction to the science of biological anthropology, a sub-field of anthropology that emphasizes a focus on humanity and its origin from a biological perspective, employing laboratory components to complement and reinforce lecture materials.

name: Anthropological Inquiry in Undergraduate Research
description: Introduces research-based learning in anthropology from a four-field perspective. To encourage self-reflective, professional thinking and provide experience and practice in professional skills and applications in anthropology.

name: Comparing Cultures Through Film
description: Human behavior in differing cultural contexts through ethnographic films of social relations in selected societies.

name: Plagues Past and Present
description: An overview of how plagues and epidemics have shaped human prehistory and history. How large-scale social transformations have produced forms of human/disease interactions. How infectious disease has been conceptualized at different times and by different cultural groups and treated as a threat to the social order.

name: Anthropology of Magic and Religion
description: A comparative examination of such topics as ritual, cosmology, revitalization movements, magic, witchcraft, myth, and possession.

name: Gender and Culture
description: Anthropological study of gender, with emphasis on cross-cultural investigation of the interaction of biological, cultural, and environmental factors including intersections of race, social class, and sexuality as influences gender behavior.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Anthropology of Globalization and Development
description: Examine cross-cultural definitions and experiences of globalization and development, through topics including colonial legacies of inequality, migration, land use, economic restructuring, media, consumption, tourism, health, and participatory development.

name: Introduction to Folklore
description: Folk expression as shaped by various cultures; fieldwork methodology and anthropological theory.

name: Human Life Cycles in Different Cultures
description: Childhood, maturity, old age, and gender socialization within the family.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Learning Across Cultures
description: Classroom ethnography, bilingualism, cultural minorities, communication across cultural boundaries. Films, videotapes, and fieldwork in classroom settings.

name: Food and Culture
description: Biological and cultural interactions affecting foodways around the world, and associated ethical issues.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Ethnobotany: Plants and Peoples
description: Anthropological overview of the interactions between cultures around the world and the plants that affect them, from cultural, biological, archaeological, and linguistic points of view.

name: Drinking in Culture: Anthropology of Alcohol
description: Cultures of alcohol production and consumption from ancient times to the present, including relationships among social roles of alcohol, technological innovations, agriculture, and economy in an anthropological perspective.

name: Violence and Peace: Anthropological Perspectives
description: Violence and peace in current events, cultural practices, historical periods, and everyday experiences. The ethics shaping violence and peace-making strategies. Classroom discussions and lectures analyzing harm and wellbeing. Themes addressing the Values, Ethics, and Social Responsibility (VSR) Carolina Core component, including colonialism, environmental exploitation, bondage, mass extinctions, and racism.

name: Great Discoveries in Archaeology
description: Survey of key archaeological discoveries from around the world.

name: Forensics of Sherlock Holmes
description: Forensic methods of Sherlock Holmes within the context of modern forensic science. Aspects of forensic science including history of the discipline, forensic pathology, entomology, print analyses, crime scene analysis, forensic anthropology, early scientific theory, and anthropological theory of Holmes.

name: Modernity Archaeology and the Recent Past
description: Explores the last five centuries of world history, using artifacts and archival sources. Evidence such as probate records, bottles, and geophysical maps are analyzed to discover the age of sites and answers to questions about topics such as colonialism, race, technology, piracy, class, Native Americans, industrialization, slavery, inequality, capitalism, and gender.

name: Indigenous Caribbean Archaeology
description: Historical archaeology and ethnography of the Casimiroid, Ortoiroid, Saladoid, Ostionoid, Taino and Carib indigenous culture of the Caribbean from 4,000 BC to 1524 AD. Emphasis on social complexity, religion, art and political organization to illustrate the diversity and richness of Amerindian Caribbean life until their rapid decline after European contact.

name: Archaeology in Film and Popular Culture
description: Archaeological images and ideas in modern popular culture, including film and fiction.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Biblical Archaeology
description: The fundamental elements of human culture as it relates to biblical archaeology. The defining characteristics of different kinds of society through interdependency of language and culture. The affects of modern world interests in defining / redefining this area.

name: Forbidden Archaeology: Fantasies, Frauds, and Mysteries of the Human Past
description: History and basis of several popular �€�fringe�€? ideas about the human past that utilize archaeological information: giants, Ice Age civilizations, and pre-Columbian transoceanic contact.

name: Southeastern Archaeology
description: Major cultural milestones and lifeways experienced by Indians in the archeological record of the southeastern U.S., including colonization, religion, trade, invention of pottery, and place-making.

name: Diversity in the United States
description: Application of techniques and insights of social and cultural anthropology to selected cultural settings in contemporary USA.

name: Contemp Cultures of South Carolina
description: Application of the methods & techniques of socio-cultural anthropology to the contemporary cultures of SC. Examination of contrasts such as low country and up country, black and white, and rich and poor as they are manifested in cultural patterns.

name: Caribbean Cultures
description: Ethnographic approach to Caribbean cultures and societies. Topics include colonial histories and experience, gender and race relations, beliefs and religious life, verbal arts, literature, and Creole language.

name: Cultures of Africa
description: A comparative study of ethnographic data on African cultures with emphasis upon its significance for broader anthropological theory.

name: Cultures of Islam
description: Diversity of lifestyles and institutions of Islam from Morocco to Indonesia, with attention to everyday life in small communities.

name: Middle Eastern Cultures
description: A consideration of selected problems in the social and cultural life of peoples in the Middle East with emphasis on non-Arab populations.

name: South Asian Cultures
description: Society and culture in South Asia; economic and political institutions, kinship, and religion as they pertain to the daily lives of people in the Subcontinent. Emphasis on India. Bangladesh, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka also included.

name: Southeast Asian Cultures
description: Social and cultural patterns of the region and how they influence current developments, especially Indonesia, Thailand, Vietnam, and the Philippines.

name: Chinese Popular Culture
description: An overview of Chinese popular culture with an introduction to broad anthropological frameworks concerning popular culture.

name: Japanese Cultures
description: An exploration of Japanese values and the institutions that shape Japanese behavior through analysis or rural and urban community studies and how Japanese people present themselves.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: American Indian Nations Today: From Hard Times to Hard Rock
description: Contemporary Indian Country in anthropological, historical, cultural, economic, and political contexts.

name: Planet of the Apes: Behavior and Biology
description: A survey of field and laboratory investigations of the comparative anatomy and behavior of nonhuman primates.

name: Human Variation
description: The biocultural processes of human variation.

name: Basic Forensic Anthropology
description: Survey of the basic scientific methods and applications of forensic anthropology.

name: Medical Experimentation and the Black Body
description: A cross-disciplinary study of how the bodies of Africans and African Americans were used in medical experimentation, starting in the late 18th century and continuing to the present.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Anthropology of Nonverbal Communication
description: Body language, facial expressions, gestures, use of interpersonal space, and other nonverbal systems of communication and behavior in terms of pertinent theories, research methodology, findings, and cross-cultural implications.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Language and Popular Culture
description: Linguistic anthropological study of forms of language through the lens of popular culture. Explore the ethnography of communication through play and performance, discursive and semiotic practices, and varieties of language invoked in popular cultural forms that provide resources for cultural reproduction and contestation.

name: Cross-Cultural Communication
description: This course introduces students to the fields of interactional sociolinguistics and linguistic anthropology. Students will learn how they approach the study of cross-cultural and intercultural forms of (mis)communication within the context of globally interconnected people, places, and systems of communication.

name: Humans Going Nuclear: Atomic Bombs, Cold War, and the Fallout
description: Ethnographic study of the Cold War, nuclear culture, and its aftermath.

name: Selected Topics in Anthropology
description: Topics of special interest. May be taken more than once as topics change.

name: Disease, Health, and Social Inequities
description: Course focuses on political and economic processes contributing to the unequal access to health and social inequalities.

name: Latin American Cultures
description: Comparative study of selected Latin American cultures with emphasis on their significance for a broader anthropological theory.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: African-American Cultures
description: An examination of African-American cultures in the New World.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Ethical Dilemmas in Anthropology
description: An examination of ethical decision-making encountered in the practice of anthropology.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Material Culture
description: Material aspects of cultures from artifact production in historical societies to contemporary industrial crafts; the cultural context of artifacts; fieldwork; relevant anthropological theories.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Principles of Archaeology
description: Introduction to principles, methods, and theory of archaeology, including prehistoric and historic case studies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ANTH 319.
name: Archaeology Theory
description: This course charts the history of ideas in archaeology, over the past century, as a means of understanding current directions in archaeological thinking and current applications in archaeological practice.

name: South Carolina Archaeology
description: Prehistoric and historic archaeology of South Carolina.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ANTH 319.
name: Field School in Archaeology
description: Archaeological field techniques, laboratory analysis and data interpretation.

name: Field School in Ethnography
description: Designing and carrying out ethnographic research including project design, data collection, analysis and description.

name: Ethnoarchaeology
description: Current research on use of modern material culture in archaeological analysis.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Prehistoric Civilizations of the New World
description: Study of Mesoamerican and South American civilizations, particularly the Mayan, Aztec, and Inca states. Processes of state formation as reflected in archaeological data.

name: Ancient Civilizations
description: Causes for the rise and fall of several civilizations; ideological and ecological factors, unique events, and personalities versus general processes.

name: Mesoamerican Prehistory
description: Cultural development and variation in Mesoamerica from the first arrival of man to the arrival of Europeans. Particular attention to cultural continuities from prehistoric times.

name: Environmental Anthropology: Cross-cultural Perspectives on Environmental Change
description: Cross-cultural perspectives on environmental issues.

name: Anthropology of Work
description: Techniques, customs, verbal expressions, and expressive styles of workers in a variety of occupational cultures.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Anthropology & Development
description: An examination of political and economic change in contemporary peasant communities.

name: The Family in Cross-Cultural Perspective
description: Kinship, systems of descent, marriage, and domestic organization in different cultures. Variations in childrearing practices, gender, and other aspects of social relations in kin groups.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Anthropology of Law and Conflict
description: Understanding human behavior through the examination of cultural norms, mechanisms of social control, and social conflict.

name: Language, Culture, and Society
description: Language in its social setting. The relationship between linguistic categories and culture categories. Language and cognition.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Anthropology of Art
description: Sculpture, drama, ceramics, weaving, music, and other arts from tribal societies will be discussed in terms of the religious, social, and aesthetic principles that underlie their production, use, and interpretation.

name: Psychological Anthropology
description: Cultural differences and pan-cultural similarities in such psychological features as personality and cognition.

name: Theories of Culture
description: Theory and practice of ethnology/sociocultural anthropology, based on a wide range of simple and complex societies.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Anthropology of Sex
description: An overview of human sexuality in different cultures in regions across the globe; an examination of anthropological frameworks for sexuality that draws on historical and modern cultural conceptions.

name: Becoming Human
description: The processes of homonoid development with a review of the basic principles of physical and behavioral evolution using the fossil record and the evolving ecological and psychosocial contexts.

name: Medicine, Disease, and Slavery
description: An interdisciplinary study of the health of enslaved African Americans during the nineteenth century by focusing on the conceptions, experiences, and dynamics of the relationship between slaves, medicine, healing, and their masters in the Antebellum American South.

name: Ethnography of Communication
description: Ethnographic analysis of communication in human groups and institutions.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Introduction to Language Sciences
description: Introduction to the linguistic component of human cognition. Properties of speech, the organization of language in the mind/brain, cross-linguistic universals, child language acquisition, and aspects of adult language processing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ANTH 102 or WGST 112.
name: Gender and Globalization
description: Examines the dialectic between globalization and the social construction of gender. Topics include the global assembly line, transnational markets for domestic labor and sex workers, and global feminist alliances.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Cultures, Pregnancy, and Birth
description: Anthropological study of pregnancy and birth with a cross-cultural focus comparing the United States to other nations. Examination of cultural factors such as prenatal care, dietary practices, taboos, birth location, practitioners, and birthing styles.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Selected Topics in Anthropology
description: Topics of special interest. May be taken more than once as topics change.

name: Global Women's Health
description: This course examines health concerns important in the lives of women around the world through an overview of contemporary issues and challenges in the field of global health, broadly construed.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Independent Study
description: Graduation with Leadership Distinction: GLD: Research

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270-ENGL 292.
name: African-American English
description: Linguistic examination of the structure, history, and use of African-American English, as well as literary presentations, language attitudes, and issues relating to education and the acquisition of Standard English.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GPA of 3.00.
name: Senior Thesis
description: Directed research resulting in a written report.

name: In the Tradition of Anthropology
description: A seminar synthesizing the major with an examination of anthropology as a field of inquiry.

name: Gender Issues in China
description: Anthropology of gender in Chinese-speaking cultures in Chinese-speaking Asia.

name: Anthropological Ethnobotany
description: Survey of how each anthropological subfield studies the interrelationships between plants and peoples. Application of methods, including interviewing and data analysis.

name: Tradition and Transformations in Islamic Cultures
description: Islam as a dynamic cultural tradition: emphasis on the tension between Islamization and the larger Islamic tradition.

name: An Anthropological View of Blacks in Film
description: Cultural representations, constructions, production, and consumption of African-American identity in the popular culture medium of feature films.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Visual Cultures
description: Survey of visual anthropology including theoretical frameworks of ways of seeing, ethnographic photography and filmmaking, contemporary technologies, and their effects on culture.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Field Problems in Ethnology
description: A two-semester class and field session. Research design, field methods, interpretation of data, and the development of theory from the data.

name: Ethnoecology
description: Seminar exploring human-plant-animal-natural interactions within an anthropological framework.

name: North American Archaeology
description: Prehistoric and historic archaeology.

name: Prehistoric Archaeology of South America
description: Prehistoric archaeology of the South American continent.

name: Conflict Archaeology
description: Anthropological and archaeological theories and methods in the study of conflict, war, and warfare. Causes, effects, outcomes of sustained social acts of violence of groups, tribes, states, and nations. Evolutionary, biological, social origins of warfare. History, strategy, and tactics, battlefield archaeology.

name: Public Archaeology
description: Philosophy and mechanics of modern archaeological Cultural Resource Management (CRM). CRM legislation, regulation, and process. Contemporary issues and problems in Public Archaeology including Native American reburial negotiations, conflict resolution, ethics, looting, business practices, standards, contexts and protection.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ANTH 320.
name: Field Problems in Archaeology
description: Archaeological field methods and techniques such as excavation, flotation, sampling, surveying, photography, and remote sensing.

name: Forensic Archaeological Recovery (FAR)
description: Introduction to Forensic Archaeological Recovery (FAR). Concepts, methods, and contemporary issues.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ANTH 319 or ANTH 322.
name: Archaeological Laboratory Methods
description: Laboratory on basic prehistoric and historic artifact analysis, including analytical methods, laboratory equipment, and data interpretation. May be repeated.

name: Medical Anthropology: Fieldwork
description: Application of observation techniques, field notes, informant interviewing, and secondary data analysis to interpreting differential perceptions of health problem solving in the community and clinic.

name: Medical Anthropology
description: Socio-cultural factors in health, illness, healing, and in medical systems. Cross-cultural and ethnographic evidence for public health research and program applications.

name: Anthropological Approaches to Narrative and Performance
description: The ways people from various cultures reflect on, reinforce, and construct their social realities through narrating, which will be considered as both artistic expression and social action.

name: Language and Gender
description: Approaches to gender and language emphasizing the social grounding of both; how language reflects sociocultural values and is a tool for constructing different types of social organization.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Language and Globalization
description: Anthropological approach to issues of language and globalization. Linguistic consequences of globalization under consideration include communicative patterns, linguistic change, and language and political economy.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Psychological Anthropology
description: Psychological aspects of behavior from a cross-cultural perspective.

name: Human Osteology
description: An intensive examination of the human skeleton and techniques for anthropological interpretation.

name: Health and Disease in the Past
description: Varieties and effects of disease patterns among past populations illustrating biological, environmental, and cultural interrelationships.

name: Human Identification in Forensic Anthropology
description: Theories and methodologies necessary for the identification of human skeletal remains in a forensic setting.

name: Nutritional Anthropology
description: Nutritional problems in developing nations. Measures of nutritional status. Social, economic, and environmental aspects of food consumption and nutrition. Biocultural responses to food deprivation and undernutrition.

name: International Development and the Environment
description: Intersections of international development and environmental change; study of general theoretical perspectives balanced with case studies from the Global South.

name: Ethnographic Film
description: Problems in conveying and interpreting ethnographic information on film or tape. Includes syntax, suitability of subject matter to the medium, irrelevant or distracting information, and observer bias.

name: Temporal Processes in Culture
description: Clocks, cycles, and contingencies as they affect human societies now and have done so in the past. Theories and models from biology and the other natural sciences will be used to interpret the history of culture.

name: Economic Anthropology
description: A cross-cultural study of the economic behavior of pre-literate and literate societies.

name: Archaeology of the African Diaspora
description: Foodways, architecture, crafts, and narrative of African-American cultures.

name: Advanced Topics in the Anthropological Study of Social Organization
description: Selected recent theoretical and methodological developments in the study of social organization.

name: Cultural Ecology
description: An interdisciplinary approach to prehistoric, historic, and contemporary relationships between the development of socio-cultural configurations and ecosystems.

name: Culture and Identity in the African Diaspora
description: Students will explore the African Diaspora as a social, cultural, and historical formation with Africa at its center, focusing on US, Latin American, and Caribbean African-descended communities.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Globalization and Cultural Questions
description: This course examines cultural understandings of and responses to globalization, examining topics such as its history and theories, migration, economic integration and inequality, identity, social movements, and the environment.

name: Discourse, Gender, and Politics of Emotion
description: Anthropological approach to issues of discourse, gender, and emotion. Issues under consideration include the social control, force, and forms of emotional discourse and the relationship between emotion and culture from gender-oriented perspectives.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Selected Topics
description: Topics of special interest. May be taken more than once as topics change.

name: Survey of Linguistics
description: Survey of core areas of linguistics and extensions to closely related disciplines. Introduction to the linguistic component of human cognition. Formal description and analysis of the general properties of speech and language, the organization of language in the mind/brain, and cross-linguistic typology and universals.

name: Elementary Arabic
description: Grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Assumes no prior experience in the language. Offered only in fall.

name: Basic Proficiency in Arabic
description: Practice and further development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills. Admission only by successful completion of Arabic 121. Offered only in spring.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARAB 122.
name: Intermediate Arabic
description: Continuation of reading, writing, and speaking Arabic.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARAB 201.
name: Intermediate Arabic
description: Increased emphasis on reading and writing skills in Arabic.

name: Introduction to Modern Arab Culture
description: Introduction to Arab culture (literature, music, film, and art) from the 19th century to the present.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARAB 202 or equivalent.
name: Advanced Arabic Language I
description: This course builds on grammar and vocabulary by reading and listening to authentic Arabic materials. By semester�€�s end, the student will be able to write in detail and comprehend and use advanced vocabulary grammar and syntax in all forms of expression.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARAB 301 or equivalent.
name: Advanced Arabic Language II
description: This course is a continuation of ARAB 301 and builds on grammar and vocabulary by reading and listening to authentic Arabic materials. By semester�€�s end, the student will be able to write in detail and comprehend and use advanced vocabulary grammar and syntax.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARAB 202.
name: Conversational Arabic
description: Practical drills in aural-oral skills to develop facility in the spoken language.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARAB 310 or equivalent.
name: Colloquial Arabic II
description: Continued instruction in colloquial (spoken) Arabic with a focus on oral and aural competencies, discussing aspects of the local culture, and working with media produced in the local variety of Arabic. Course may be repeated as the variety of Arabic may change.

name: Introduction to Modern Arab Literature in Translation
description: Introduction to dominant trends and genres in nineteenth and twentieth century Arabic literature.

name: Selected Topics
description: Selected literary topics of the Arab world. May be repeated for credit under different titles. Taught in English.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARAB 302 or equivalent.
name: Advanced Arabic I
description: Acquisition of advanced grammar and vocabulary. Increased focus on reading, writing, and discussion in Modern Standard Arabic.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARAB 401 or equivalent.
name: Advanced Arabic II
description: Continued acquisition of advanced grammar and vocabulary. Increased focus on reading, writing, and discussion in Modern Standard Arabic.

name: Intensive Readings in Arabic
description: Intensive reading for non-majors. Graduate students fulfill their foreign-language requirement with successful completion of the course. Undergraduates may take the course as an elective only. Grades S/U for graduates and undergraduates.

name: Introduction to Art
description: Introduction to art appreciation. Elements and principles of the visual arts, with examples from the history of art.

name: Special Topics in Art Education
description: Topics selected by the instructor for specialized study. Course content may include a variety of new, contemporary, and emerging art-related issues that are not regularly included in the general art education curriculum. May be repeated.

name: Interdisciplinary Relationships in the Arts
description: The study of relationships among visual arts, music, theatre, and dance.

name: Art Evaluation
description: The language of art is taught through viewing, interpreting, producing, and appreciating art. Historical and contemporary art criticism; methods of teaching art criticism to children and young adults.

name: Art for Elementary Schools
description: Methods of teaching art to elementary and preschool children. Major emphasis will be given to relevant studio experiences.

name: Elementary Methods for K-12 Art Certification
description: Curriculum, methods, and materials for teaching art to elementary and preschool children.

requisiteText: Corequisite: ARTE 525.
name: Elementary Methods for K-12 Art Certification Practicum
description: Experiential practice and learning in elementary schools.

name: Art of Children
description: A study of historical and contemporary theories of child art. Students will also engage in field experiences with children and adolescents to observe and evaluate the significance of art making in young people's lives.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTE 520.
name: The School Art Program
description: An introduction to art education as a profession. The history, curricular development, and current issues are examined. Students practice proven teaching techniques.

requisiteText: Corequisite: ARTE 540.
name: Practicum in Art Education
description: A sequence of supervised practicum experiences in middle and secondary school art education settings. Seminars and group discussions.

name: Incorporating Digital Media in Art Education
description: Applications of media literacy theories and current digital media platforms for K-12 art classrooms.

requisiteText: Corequisite: ARTE 560P.
name: Secondary Methods for K-12 Art Certification
description: Curriculum, methods, and materials for teaching art to secondary school students.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in ARTE 525 and ARTE 525P.
Corequisite: C or better in ARTE 560.
name: Secondary Methods for K-12 Art Certification Practicum
description: Curriculum, methods, and materials for teaching art to secondary school students. Note: ARTE 560 and ARTE 560P cannot be taken simultaneously with ARTE 540 and 540P.

name: Field Experience Seminar
description: Corequisite: EDSE 471.

name: Directed Teaching in Art
description: Students seeking K-12 certification in art participate in directed teaching in elementary and secondary art programs while being supervised by an art education faculty member. Students are evaluated using a state-mandated assessment tool. Completion of course work in art education, admission to professional program, College of Education, and FBI check are required.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Art Education Workshop
description: A workshop especially for teachers and prospective teachers, featuring practical art experiences and projects for elementary and secondary school. Topic varies by title.

name: History of Western Art I
description: The visual arts from Paleolithic times to the Renaissance.

name: History of Western Art II
description: The visual arts from the Renaissance to the present.

name: History of Asian Art
description: Art and culture of India, China, and Japan from prehistory to the present.

name: History of Roman Art
description: An examination of the development of architecture, painting, and sculpture until the end of the Roman Empire.

name: History of Medieval Art
description: A survey of architecture, painting, and sculpture in Europe during the Middle Ages.

name: History of Italian Renaissance Art
description: The origins and development of Renaissance painting, sculpture, and architecture in Italy during the 15th and 16th centuries.

name: History of Northern Renaissance Art
description: The arts of Northern Europe during the 15th and 16th centuries with particular emphasis on the developments in the Low Countries, Germany, and France.

name: History of Southern Baroque Art
description: The art and architecture of Italy and Spain in the 17th century.

name: History of Northern Baroque Art
description: The art and architecture of Holland, Flanders, France, England, Germany, and Austria in the 17th century.

name: History of 18th-Century European Art
description: A survey of eighteenth-century European painting and sculpture, following the lives and works of major artists, changes in style and taste against the backdrop of a broader cultural and historical context.

name: History of 19th-Century European Art
description: A survey of nineteenth-century European painting and sculpture, following the lives and works of major artists, changes in style and taste against the backdrop of a broader cultural and historical context.

name: Art, Anatomy, and Medicine, 1700-Present
description: Considers anatomical instruction in artistic training; anatomy and ideas of beauty and morality; role of art in dissemination of anatomical/medical information; why artistic representations of medicine and anatomy feature in popular culture; role of art in medical training; how art has imagined anato-medical improbabilities that are now reality.

name: History of 20th Century Art
description: A survey of architecture, painting, and sculpture in the 20th century.

name: History of Modern Architecture
description: Architecture from the turn of the century until the present.

name: History of American Art I
description: A survey of the history of art in America from colonial times to 1860.

name: History of American Art II
description: A survey of art in America from 1860 to the present.

name: Contemporary American Art
description: Recent trends in painting and sculpture.

name: History of Asian Art
description: A survey of the visual arts of India, China, and Japan from prehistory to the present.

name: African Art
description: Sculpture, painting, architecture of Sub-Saharan Africa.

name: History and Theory of Art Criticism
description: Art criticism from antiquity to the present.

name: History of Cinema II
description: Survey of the international cinema from 1945 to the present.

name: Topics in Art History
description: Topic varies by title.

name: Independent Study
description: Graduation with Leadership Distinction: GLD: Research

name: Independent Study
description: Graduation with Leadership Distinction: GLD: Research

name: Methodologies of Art History
description: A seminar for art history majors and graduate students in the history and various methodologies of the discipline.

name: Internship in Art History
description: Supervised experience in the field of art history, including museums, galleries, art dealers and auction houses. Requires a university internship contract and is subject to approval by advisor. May be repeated.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Etruscan Art and Archaeology
description: Seminar in the art and civilization of the pre-Roman Etruscan peoples of Italy. Slide lectures, discussion sessions, and some examination of archaeological field methods and pottery classification.

name: Topics in Ancient Art
description: Topic varies by title.

name: Topics in Medieval Art
description: Topic varies by title.

name: History of Renaissance Painting
description: An analysis of the paintings and painters of importance during the period of the Renaissance in Europe.

name: History of Renaissance Sculpture
description: A survey of the major developments in the art of sculpture associated with the European Renaissance.

name: History of Renaissance Architecture
description: European architecture and architectural theory during the 15th and 16th centuries.

name: Florentine Art
description: The artistic development of Florence from the age of Giotto to that of Michelangelo as seen in the context of social and cultural developments.

name: Topics in Renaissance Art
description: Topic varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTH 106 or ARTH 325 or ARTH 326.
name: History of Baroque Painting
description: 17th-century European painting.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTH 106 or ARTH 325 or ARTH 326.
name: History of Baroque Sculpture
description: 17th and 18th-century European sculpture.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTH 106 or ARTH 325 or ARTH 326.
name: History of Baroque Architecture
description: The architecture of Europe in the 17th century with special attention to the major architects of Italy, France, Germany, and England. Topics to be included are: the church, the palace, the garden, and city planning.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTH 106 or ARTH 327.
name: Topics in 18th-Century Art
description: Topic varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTH 106 or ARTH 330.
name: Topics in 19th-Century Art
description: Topic varies by title.

name: History of Modern Painting
description: A detailed examination of 20th century painting.

name: History of Modern Sculpture
description: The development of sculpture in the 19th and 20th centuries with special attention to contemporary tendencies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTH 106 or ARTH 337.
name: Topics in Modern Architecture
description: Topic varies by title.

name: Topics in Modern Art
description: Topic varies by title.

name: History of American Painting
description: Important aspects of American painting with emphasis on the 19th and 20th centuries.

name: History of American Architecture
description: A consideration of the evolution of architecture in America including aspects of town and city planning.

name: The History of American Antiques and Decorative Arts
description: A survey of our material culture concentrating upon the evolution of styles.

name: Topics in American Art
description: Topic varies by title.

name: Special Topics in Modern Chinese Art
description: Topics in modern Chinese art selected for specialized study. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Special Topics in Asian Art
description: Topics in Asian art selected for specialized study. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Topics in Non-Western Art
description: Topic varies by title.

name: Trends in Art History
description: A critical examination of the development of the discipline of art history and an analysis of its major trends and theoretical positions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FAMS 240.
name: Special Topics in Film and Media Studies
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in film and media studies. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: History of Printmaking
description: Technical, aesthetical, and historical study of the development of printmaking.

name: Museology I
description: The history and theory of museums and an introduction to museum practices in the setting of a multi-disciplinary institution. Practical experience provided through the various units of the University Museums.

name: Museology II
description: Museum practices emphasizing the conservation, installation, and interpretation of the object in the context of an art museum. Practical experience provided through the Columbia Museum of Art.

name: Art Conservation
description: History, theory, practices, ethics, and procedures of modern art conservation. Practical experience provided through the South Carolina Institute of Archaeology and Anthropology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in FAMS 300.
name: Special Topics in Film and Media Histories
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in film and media history. May be repeated as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTH 105 or ARTH 106 or any ARTH 300.
name: Topics in Art History
description: Topic varies by title.

name: Independent Study
description: Independent study for advanced undergraduate majors and graduate students in art history. Approved independent study contract required for enrollment. May be repeated, but no more than 12 credits of Independent Study may be applied to the degree.

name: Design Technology and Concepts
description: Fundamental methods of solving visual problems found in the design arts with an emphasis on clarity and immediacy of solutions for a general audience.

name: Fundamentals of Art
description: Introduction to visual thinking and principles of two-dimensional design.

name: 3-Dimensional Design I
description: Introduction to visual thinking and principles of three-dimensional design.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTS 103.
name: Color and Composition
description: Color, color theory, and compositional systems.

name: Basic Drawing I
description: Introduction to the materials and basic techniques of drawing.

name: Introduction to Painting
description: An introductory course in the materials and techniques of painting.

name: Beginning Painting II
description: Exploration of materials and techniques of painting with emphasis on individual creative expression.

name: Introduction to Printmaking
description: An introductory course in printmaking with emphasis on monotype, relief, and intaglio prosesses.

name: Beginning Ceramics
description: An introduction to the materials and techniques of ceramics through hand-building and throwing on the wheel.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 104.
name: Introduction to Three-Dimensional Studies
description: An introductory course in the concepts, materials, and techniques of three-dimensional media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 111.
name: Introduction to Drawing
description: Building on foundational skills acquired in ARTS 111, this course further develops skills in observation, composition, spatial awareness, drawing technique and critical language.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 230.
name: Figure Structure I
description: The structural nature of figure, with emphasis on the translation of form in space onto a two-dimensional surface.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 230.
name: Figure Structure II
description: Drawing from the human figure.

name: Introduction to Fiber Arts
description: An introductory course in the materials and processes of fiber arts.

name: Color for Design
description: Color theory, systems, and applications in visual communications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 102.
name: Typographic Design I
description: Fundamental concepts in graphic design with a focus on formal issues, employing fundamental visual communication principles, image development, and traditional and modern relevant digital applications.

name: Typographic Design II
description: Fundamental concepts in typography with a focus on long form text, hierarchy of emphasis, anatomy, pairings and exploration of grid systems using traditional and modern relevant digital applications.

name: Introduction to Jewelry Making
description: Introduction to concepts and design of jewelry objects in a variety of metals and other materials.

name: Photography for Non-Majors
description: Photographic history, theory, and practice with emphasis on developing a personal vision through the use of digital still cameras.

name: Introduction to Photography
description: A thorough grounding in 35mm black and white photography using both digital and traditional output, as well as the aesthetics of the photograph as a personal artistic expression.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 102 and ARTS 111.
name: Illustration I
description: Beginning illustration projects emphasizing principles of visual communication, development of resource material, composition and preparation of sketches, comprehensives, and finished illustrations in a variety of media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 265.
name: Illustration II
description: Intermediate illustration projects emphasizing principles of visual communication, development of resource material, composition and preparation of sketches, comprehensives, and finished illustrations in a variety of media.

name: Intermediate Painting I
description: An exploration of painting as a means of multi-sensory expression through visual experience.

name: Intermediate Painting II
description: An exploration of the depiction of space and form in painting with a continued emphasis on materials and techniques combined with individual creative expression.

name: Intermediate Printmaking I: Relief
description: Linoleum, woodblock printing, and other relief techniques including the execution of original works in these media.

name: Intermediate Printmaking II: Screen
description: Screen printing techniques including the execution of original works in these media.

name: Intermediate Ceramics I
description: Concentration on development of throwing skills. Experimentation with clay and glaze chemistry.

name: Intermediate Ceramics II
description: Concentration on hand-building skills. Glaze experimentation and ceramic materials will be researched.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 225.
name: Intermediate Three-Dimensional Studies I
description: Contemporary principles in various three-dimensional media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 225.
name: Intermediate Three-Dimensional Studies II
description: Further study of various three-dimensional media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 230.
name: Intermediate Drawing I
description: Enhancing graphic richness in drawings with intellectual and visual perception as content.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 230.
name: Intermediate Drawing II
description: Contemporary cultural stimuli as the content for drawing projects. Emphasis on intellectual and emotive approaches.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better ARTS 235.
name: Intermediate Fiber Arts I
description: Exploration of fiber constructions such as weaving, spinning, and feltmaking.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 335.
name: Intermediate Fiber Arts II
description: Exploration of fiber surface design techniques such as batik, tie dye, and block printing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 145, ARTS 245 and ARTS 246.
name: Visual and Verbal Interaction
description: Intermediate level exploration of current issues in type and image through complex design problems employing a variety of media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 345.
name: Process and Systems
description: Advanced design course in the development of a range of self-directed content and emphasizing creation of cohesive messaging systems covering a wide range of media. Creation of identity systems based on research and appropriate to content, context, and audience. Media may span environmental, motion, print, web, and packaging. Discussion of current design issues and trends.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 145, ARTS 245 and ARTS 246.
name: Interaction Design
description: Investigation and practice of user interface and user experience design for digital products as a contemporary fine art and communication medium.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 255.
name: Intermediate Jewelrymaking I
description: Jewelry fabrication using the centrifugal casting methods.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 355.
name: Intermediate Jewelrymaking II
description: Jewelry fabrication using the electroforming method.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 261.
name: Advanced Black & White Photography
description: Continuation of black and white photographic techniques introduced in ARTS 261. Introduction to advanced exposure and film development, exhibition quality printing and presentation, medium and large-format cameras, b&w digital output and darkroom experimentation.

name: Digital Photography
description: Exploration of digital imaging techniques including image adjustment and printing methods with an emphasis on color photography.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 310 or ARTS 311.
name: Advanced Painting I
description: Advanced development of individual direction in painting the human figure from a live model. Special emphasis on material selection and formal principles of painting as applied toward individual goals.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 310 or ARTS 311.
name: Advanced Painting II
description: Advanced development of individual direction in painting and skills in the representation of the human figure working observationally from the live model. Special emphasis on material selection and formal principles of painting as applied toward individual goals.

name: Advanced Printmaking I: Intaglio
description: Intaglio techniques, such as drypoint, etching and collagraph, including the execution of original works in these media.

name: Advanced Printmaking II: Lithography
description: Lithography techniques, including the execution of original works in these media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 320 or ARTS 321.
name: Advanced Ceramics I
description: Further development of throwing and hand-building skills. Introduction to kiln firing and continued glaze and clay experimentation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 420.
name: Advanced Ceramics II
description: Further development of throwing and hand-building skills. Continued development of kiln-firing methodology. Research in clay and glaze technology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 325 or ARTS 326.
name: Advanced Three-Dimensional Studies I
description: The development of fabrication skills and creative expression in various three-dimensional media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 325 or ARTS 326.
name: Advanced Three-Dimensional Studies II
description: Further development of fabrication skills and creative expression in various three-dimensional media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 330 or ARTS 331.
name: Advanced Drawing I
description: Development of a thematic approach to drawing in a series of individual and group generated artworks.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 430.
name: Advanced Drawing II
description: Development of highly individualized content in a series of drawings.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 336.
name: Advanced Fiber Arts I
description: Advanced study of materials and techniques of fiber arts with emphasis on individual creative expression.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 435.
name: Advanced Fiber Arts II
description: Advanced study of materials and techniques of fiber arts with emphasis on individual creative expression.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 246 or MART 371.
name: Time and Sequence
description: Advanced motion projects involving time and sequencing with both visual and verbal elements using a variety of media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 104 or ARTS 246.
name: Structures
description: Advanced exploration of 3D graphic design projects.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 445.
name: Senior Project I
description: Individual final project in graphic design.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 346.
name: Portfolio Studio
description: Preparation of students for professional practice and job seeking. Development of online and print portfolios, and other collateral. Contemporary design and illustration practices through discussions, reading, writing, guest speakers, and studio visits. Emphasis on assisting each student in preparing for their unique future.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 345 or ARTS 346.
name: Graphic Design Practicum
description: Practical design experience for students through design or publicity problems in non profit organizations.

name: Intermedia Studio I
description: Advanced intermedia; formal and conceptual problems associated with combining multiple forms of imaging processes.

name: Intermedia Studio II
description: Advanced intermedia; creation of portfolio work combining multiple forms of imaging processes.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 356.
name: Advanced Jewelrymaking I
description: Advanced problems and individual investigation in jewelrymaking techniques.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 455.
name: Advanced Jewelrymaking II
description: Advanced problems and individual investigation in jewelrymaking techniques.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 360 or ARTS 361.
name: Photography Portfolio
description: Advanced techniques and career practices in photography. The development of personal vision through the production of a fine arts portfolio. Students may work with any photographic process (digital or analog) towards the completion of a cohesive body of work.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 360 or ARTS 361.
name: Photography Exhibition
