description: Advanced concepts in photography. The development of personal vision culminating in a collaborative exhibition. Students may work with any photographic process (analog or digital).

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 266.
name: Advanced Illustration I
description: Projects exploring aspects of visual narrative through illustration. Further development of style, media, and technique.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 465.
name: Advanced Illustration II
description: Capstone projects in commercial illustration. Further development of style, media, and technique with emphasis in development of commercial portfolio and promotion.

name: Independent Study
description: Graduation with Leadership Distinction: GLD: Research

name: Visual Meaning
description: The analysis, structuring, and production of individual works of art using traditional and non-traditional approaches.

name: Art Business
description: Business practices for the studio artist. Contracts, portfolio preparation, promotion, alternate professions, museums, galleries, copyright, and shipping will be discussed.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTS 210, ARTS 211, ARTS 310, and ARTS 311.
name: Painting I
description: BFA Painting Capstone course stressing focus on further development of individual approaches to painting culminating in a cohesive body of work and a written thesis defense.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTS 510.
name: Painting II
description: BFA Painting Capstone course focusing on further development of individual approaches to painting culminating in a BFA Senior Thesis Exhibition and defense.

name: Introduction to Watercolor
description: Introduction to traditional and experimental transparent watercolor technique. Encompasses field work at off campus locations.

name: Advanced Watercolor
description: Advanced study of watercolor and water-based media with emphasis on individual creative expression. Encompasses field work at off campus locations.

name: Workshop: Painting
description: Advanced study in various painting problems, content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTS 416.
name: Printmaking I
description: Further development of individual approaches to printmaking.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTS 215 and one ARTS 300 - ARTS 400 level print course.
name: Capstone Printmaking I: Professional Practices
description: Professional development practices including preparing a portfolio and oral presentation of work, researching career options, and preparing applications for exhibition and funding opportunities.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTS 215 and one ARTS 300 - ARTS 400 level print course.
name: Capstone Printmaking II: Exhibition
description: Preparing for an exhibition.

name: Workshop: Printmaking
description: Advanced investigation and analysis of various printmaking techniques. Topic varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 421.
name: Ceramics I
description: Further development of a personal approach to the ceramic process, supported by an investigation of ceramic history.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 520.
name: Ceramics II
description: Further development of a personal approach to the ceramic process, supported by an investigation of ceramic history.

name: Workshop: Ceramics
description: Advanced investigation and analysis of problems and methods in ceramics. Topics vary by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or Better in ARTS 425 or ARTS 426.
name: Three-Dimensional Studies I
description: Personal concepts and expressions in various three-dimensional media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 425 or ARTS 426.
name: Three-Dimensional Studies II
description: Personal concepts and expressions in various three-dimensional media.

name: Workshop: Three-Dimensional Studies
description: Investigation and analysis of various three-dimensional concepts, processes, and techniques. Content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTS 431.
name: Drawing Capstone I
description: Further development of individual approaches to drawing with emphasis on intellectual and visual perception as content.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTS 530.
name: Drawing Capstone II
description: Further development of individual drawing with emphasis on intellectual and emotive approaches.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTS 232 or ARTS 233.
name: Advanced Life Drawing
description: Human anatomy and instruction in drawing and painting the model from life in a variety of media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTS 436.
name: Fiber Arts I
description: Advanced study in the processes and materials of fiber arts.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTS 535.
name: Fiber Arts II
description: Advanced study in the processes and materials of fiber arts.

name: Papermaking
description: The art and techniques of handmade paper.

name: Workshop: Fiber Arts
description: Advanced study in various technical aspects of fiber arts. Topic varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 246.
name: Internship in Graphic Design
description: Experiential course focused on relevant work experience within the business of graphic design, visual communication, and/or illustration. Students are required to obtain and complete an internship, then reflect on the experience. Graduation with Leadership Distinction: Professional and Civic Engagement.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 346.
name: Advanced Process and Systems
description: Advanced design course in the development of a range of self-directed content and emphasizing creation of cohesive messaging systems that cover a wide range of media. Creation of identity systems that are based on research and appropriate to content, context, and audience. Media may span environmental, motion, print, web, and packaging.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 456.
name: Jewelrymaking I
description: The development of individual directions in jewelrymaking.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ARTS 555.
name: Jewelrymaking II
description: The development of individual directions in jewelrymaking.

name: Crafts
description: Contemporary applications of traditional craft media, emphasizing the design and conceptual development of works of art.

name: Workshop: Jewelrymaking
description: Advanced study in various technical aspects of jewelrymaking. Topic varies by title.

name: Photography Thesis: Portfolio
description: Further development of individual approaches to photography.

name: Photography Thesis: Exhibition
description: Further development of individual approaches to photography.

name: Workshop: Photography
description: Advanced investigation and analysis of problems in photography. Topic varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ARTS 102.
name: Special Topics in Graphic Design
description: Specialized investigation into relevant current trends in graphic design.

name: Video Art: Theory and Practice
description: Television as a medium; small format video systems are used in the creation of individual projects.

name: Independent Study
description: Independent study for advanced undergraduate majors and graduate students in art studio. Approved independent study contract required for enrollment.

name: Introduction to Astronomy
description: An introduction to the solar system and universe accomplished with interactive lectures, demonstrations, and laboratory experience. Designed primarily for the non-science major.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ASTR 101 or SCHC 115.
name: Introduction to Astronomy II: The Dark Universe
description: Astronomical topics including stellar death, black holes, dark matter, dark energy and cosmology. Astronomical techniques and application of the scientific method in astronomy.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ASTR 211, MATH 115 or equivalent, and PHYS 202, PHYS 212.
name: Introduction to Radio Astronomy
description: Nature of the sun, planets; galactic and extragalactic sources at radio wavelengths; quasars; techniques, detectors, and telescopes.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ASTR 211 and MATH 115 and PHYS 202 or PHYS 212.
name: Introduction to Relativistic Astrophysics
description: Final states of stellar evolution; white dwarfs, neutron stars, black holes. Cosmology.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Introduction to and application of the methods of research. A written report on work accomplished is required at the end of each semester.

name: Advanced Observational Astronomy
description: Development of a combination of observational techniques and facility at reduction of data. A maximum of eight hours per week of observation, data reduction, and consultation. Offered each semester by arrangement with the department.

name: Advanced Observational Astronomy
description: A continuation of ASTR 533. Up to eight hours per week of observation, data reduction, and consultation.

name: Topics in Astronomy
description: Readings and research on selected topics in astronomy. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

requisiteText: Corequisite: ATEP 300L.
name: First Aid and CPR
description: Knowledge and skills necessary to meet the needs of situations when emergency care is critical. Includes American Red Cross CPR/AED and First Aid certification. Encompasses skills for adult, child, and infant CPR/AED, breathing emergencies, and first aid procedures for emergency situations.

requisiteText: Corequisite: ATEP 300.
name: First Aid and CPR Lab
description: Skill development to meet guidelines for certification. Skills include AED, adult, child, and infant CPR, breathing emergencies, and first aid.

requisiteText: Corequisite: ATEP 310L.
name: Emergency Medical Response
description: Knowledge acquisition necessary to work as an emergency medical responder (EMR) to help sustain life, reduce pain and minimize the consequences of injury or sudden illness until more advanced medical help takes over. Appropriate decisions about the care to provide in a medical emergency. Understanding the role of an EMR as a crucial link in the emergency medical services (EMS) system.

requisiteText: Corequisite: ATEP 310.
name: Emergency Medical Responder Lab
description: Clinical applications necessary to work as an emergency medical responder (EMR) to help sustain life, reduce pain and minimize the consequences of injury or sudden illness until more advanced medical help takes over. Appropriate decisions about the care to provide in a medical emergency. Skills an EMR needs to act as a crucial link in the emergency medical services (EMS) system.

name: Biological Principles I
description: Introductory survey of macromolecules, cell structure and function, genetics, and molecular biology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 101L.
name: Biological Principles I
description: Introductory survey of macromolecules, cell structure and function, genetics, and molecular biology. Three lecture hours per week. Restricted to students who have credit for BIOL 101L but lack the lecture.

name: Biological Principles I Laboratory
description: (Recommended concurrent with BIOL 101). Experimental examination of basic principles of cell biology, genetics and metabolism. Three hours per week.

requisiteText: Corequisite: BIOL 102L.
name: Biological Principles II
description: Introductory survey of plant and animal development, physiology, ecology, and evolution.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 102L.
name: Biological Principles II
description: Introductory survey of plant and animal development, physiology, ecology, and evolution. Three lecture hours per week. Restricted to students who have credit for BIOL 102L but lack the lecture.

requisiteText: Corequisite: Recommended concurrent with BIOL 102.
name: Biological Principles II Laboratory
description: Experimental examination of structure and function of plant and animal systems, biodiversity, ecology. BIOL 101, BIOL 102, BIOL 101L and BIOL 102L must be completed prior to enrolling in 300-level or above Biology courses.

name: General Biology
description: Basic biological concepts and issues for non-biology majors. Credit may not be given for both this course and BIOL 120. Three lecture, two laboratory hours per week.

name: General Biology (Audio-Tutorial)
description: Addendum to BIOL 110.

name: Human Biology
description: Fundamental principles of human biology. Credit may not be given for both BIOL 110 and BIOL 120. Three lecture hours per week. Not for major credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: BIOL 120.
name: Laboratory in Human Biology
description: Exercises dealing with basic concepts of human biology. Not for major credit.

name: Plant Science
description: An introduction to plant science for the non-major. This course does not carry major credit, and is not designed as a prerequisite for other biology courses. Plant development, physiology, genetics, evolution, and ecology will be considered. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: BIOL 200.
name: Plant Science Laboratory
description: Laboratory exercises, demonstrations, and audio-visual supplements to BIOL 200. Not for major credit. Two hours per week.

name: Genetics and Society
description: (Designed for non-major students.) Genetic principles, emphasizing human heredity. Relevance of recent advances in genetics. Three lecture hours per week.

name: Our Hungry World from Malthus to McDonalds
description: Scientific and social issues concerning the interrelationship of culture and agricultural biotic diversity and technology, climate change, resources management, food security, and human health.

name: Elementary Life Science
description: This course will ensure that elementary education majors will understand the fundamental concepts of Biology. Cannot be used for biology major credit.

name: Anatomy
description: Functional anatomy of the human body and its relation to disease processes. Not for biology major credit.

requisiteText: Corequisite: BIOL 232.
name: Anatomy Laboratory
description: The principles of anatomy as demonstrated by microscopic studies and animal dissection. Three hours per week.

name: Applied Human Physiology
description: Fundamentals of functional human biology and knowledge of contemporary medical problems. Not for major credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 232.
name: Human Physiology
description: Functional biology of organ systems in the maintenance of the whole organism; homeostatic relationships. Not available for biology major credit. Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week.

name: Human Anatomy and Physiology I
description: Functional anatomy and physiology of the human body, including the integumentary, skeletal, muscular, and nervous systems. Not available for biology major credit. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: BIOL 243.
name: Human Anatomy and Physiology Laboratory
description: The principles of anatomy and physiology as demonstrated by microscopic studies, animal dissection, and physiological experiments. One three-hour laboratory per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 243.
name: Human Anatomy and Physiology II
description: Functional anatomy and physiology of the human body, including the cardiovascular, endocrine, excretory, reproductive, digestive, and respiratory systems. Not available for biology major credit. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Corequisite: BIOL 244
name: Human Anatomy and Physiology Laboratory
description: A continuation of BIOL 243L. One three-hour laboratory per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: College-level Biology and Chemistry.
name: Microbiology
description: An introduction to bacteria and viruses, emphasizing structure, metabolism, and pathogenesis. Discussion of infectious diseases, antigen-antibody relationships, and anti-microbial agents in chemotherapy. Not available for biology major credit. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: BIOL 250.
name: Microbiology Laboratory
description: Not available for biology major credit. Three hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 102.
name: Physiology
description: Physiology of human systems especially susceptible to disturbance: immunobiology, circulation, excretion, metabolism, endocrinology, and muscle physiology. Not for biology major credit. Intended for pharmacy students.

name: Introduction to Environmental Biology
description: Basic ecological principles and the impacts of human population growth and technology. Not for major credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: BIOL 270.
name: Introduction to Environmental Biology Laboratory
description: Demonstrations, data analyses, discussions, and films relating to human ecology, resource use, and environmental impact. Not for major credit. Two hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 102 or MSCI 311.
name: Ecology and Evolution
description: Concepts of evolution, populations, and population interactions; communities and ecosystems. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: BIOL 301.
name: Ecology and Evolution Laboratory
description: Experiments, exercises, and demonstrations. Three hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BIOL 101; C or better in BIOL 102 or MSCI 311; C or better in CHEM 112 or CHEM 142.
name: Cell and Molecular Biology
description: Principles of eukaryotic cell structure, molecular organization, and physiology. Genome organization and expression. Cell growth, division, and cell-cell interactions.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: BIOL 302.
name: Cell and Molecular Biology Laboratory
description: Experiments, exercises, and demonstrations. Three hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BIOL 101 and BIOL 102 or a C or better in MSCI 311.
name: Fundamental Genetics
description: Basic principles of transmission and molecular genetics; quantitative inheritance; recombination; biochemical aspects of gene function and regulation; developmental genetics and population genetics. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BIOL 102.
name: Introduction to Animal Science
description: Exploration of current careers in the animal industry including a brief overview of the sciences involved in animal production such as genetics and selection, behavior, physiology, reproduction, and nutrition of cattle (beef and dairy), horses, swine, sheep, poultry, and others.

name: Laboratory Teaching Experience
description: Participation in preparation and teaching of undergraduate biological sciences laboratories.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department head is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302.
name: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology
description: Cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the development and functions of the nervous system, such as nervous system patterning, neuronal differentiation/migration, formation of neuronal projections, development of synapses, apoptosis, refinement of neuronal circuits, and how cells and neurons respond to signals from the environment.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 102 or MSCI 311.
name: Comparative Vertebrate Anatomy
description: Phylogenetic and comparative aspects of anatomy, reproduction, and embryology of the vertebrates. Three lecture hours and one three-hour laboratory period per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BIOL 301.
name: Survey of the Plant Kingdom
description: Phylogenetic survey of the major plant divisions; consideration of the structure and development of flowering plants.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: BIOL 420.
name: Survey of the Plant Kingdom Laboratory
description: Three hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302.
name: Plant Form and Function
description: Basic introduction to plants, including cellular biology, energetics, structure-function relationships, development, nutrition, and diversity.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: BIOL 425.
name: Plant Form and Function Laboratory
description: Illustration of principles of introductory botany and plant physiology using experiments, exercises, and demonstrations. Three laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MSCI 311, BIOL 301.
name: Principles of Biological Oceanography
description: Principles and methods of measuring production in the sea. Emphasis on the ocean�€�s role in the global carbon budget. Three lecture hours per week. Scheduled field trips are required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BIOL 302 or MSCI 311.
name: Advanced Human Physiology
description: Functional physiology of human organ systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: BIOL 460 (with a grade of D or better if used as a prerequisite).
name: Advanced Human Physiology Laboratory
description: Experiments on organ system functions using different animal models.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in any two of the following: BIOL 301, BIOL 302, or BIOL 303.
name: Advanced Human Anatomy
description: Structure, function, and development of human anatomy.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: BIOL 461 (with a grade of D or better if used as a prerequisite).
name: Advanced Human Anatomy Laboratory
description: Practical exercises in structure, function, and development of anatomy using digital and animal models.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302.
name: Domestic Animal Nutrition
description: Elements of nutrition and animal feeding in veterinary practice. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301, BIOL 302, and BIOL 303, or Instructor's Permission
name: Undergraduate Seminar in Biological Sciences
description: Student seminars and a survey of research in the fields of Biological Sciences.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in any BIOL 300-level or higher laboratory course; C or higher in any two of BIOL 301, BIOL 302, and BIOL 303.
name: Introduction to Biological Research
description: Methodologies of biological research with emphasis on hypothesis formation, research design, and data collection, and current issues in biology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MSCI 102 or BIOL 102, CHEM 112.
name: Environmental Microbiology
description: An overview of the microbial world including a survey of the distribution, functioning, and diversity of microorganisms in natural systems. Discusses the crucial roles that microorganisms play in ecosystem function, biogeochemical cycles, and environmental quality.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BIOL 302.
name: Developmental Biology
description: An introduction to how cell-cell communication, gene expression, cell division, cytoskeletal dynamics, and interactions with the extracellular matrix result in the differentiation, pattern formation, morphogenesis, and growth necessary to generate a new individual.

requisiteText: Corequisite: BIOL 505.
name: Developmental Biology Laboratory I
description: Descriptive and experimental exercises related to embryology. One three-hour laboratory per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 505.
name: Developmental Biology II
description: Molecular aspects of development from gamete formation through tissue and organ differentiation in plants and animals. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: BIOL 506.
name: Developmental Biology Laboratory II
description: A series of experimentally oriented laboratory exercises will be performed. One three-hour laboratory per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Invertebrate Zoology
description: Phylogenetic and comparative aspects of anatomy, physiology, reproduction, and embryology of the invertebrates. Three lecture and one three-hour laboratory period per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BIOL 302 and BIOL 303.
name: Plant Development
description: Descriptive and molecular examination of the processes and mechanisms used by plants in organogenesis, differentiation, and morphogenesis. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Corequisite: BIOL 523.
name: Plant Developmental Laboratory
description: Experiments utilizing a genetic approach to the study of plant development. Three laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: Mycology
description: Taxonomy and morphology of fungi; cultivation, life histories, and economic importance; all classes and major orders considered. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Marine Plants
description: Diversity, distribution, physiology, ecology, evolution, and economic importance of marine algal, seagrass, and mangrove communities. Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week. Scheduled field trips are required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: The Fall Flora
description: Two lecture and four laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: The Spring Flora
description: Two lecture and four laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: The Summer Flora
description: Two lecture and four laboratory hours per week.

name: Histology
description: An introduction to the tissues that make up the human body. The microscopic anatomy of tissues is examined and discussed in terms of function and physiology. Three lecture hours and four laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 300 level Biology course or equivalent.
name: Parasitology
description: Parasites of biological, economic, and public health importance. Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Animal Behavior
description: A comparative survey of behavior patterns of animals from protists to humans and the physiological mechanisms underlying behavior.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: BIOL 534.
name: Animal Behavior Laboratory
description: Observational and experimental methods used in classifying animal behavior patterns and in determining underlying control mechanisms. One three-hour laboratory per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: Fishery Management
description: Management and conservation of aquatic and marine resources, with emphasis on fisheries. Data procurement and analysis; commercial and recreational fisheries; sociological, political, legal, and environmental factors that affect fishery management; and fish biodiversity.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Ichthyology
description: Phylogeny, morphology, behavior, and ecology of fishes. Three lecture and 3 laboratory hours plus three field trips to be arranged.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Aquaculture
description: Introduction to the practical and scientific aspects of the commercial culture of freshwater and marine organisms. Three lecture hours per week. One all-day field trip required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 101 and BIOL 102 or MSCI 311.
name: Behavior of Marine Organisms
description: The identification of behavioral adaptations of estuarine and marine organisms: their ecology, physiology, development, and evolutionary history; field observations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 334.
name: Biochemistry
description: Description of biological macromolecules and major metabolic pathways.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or higher in CHEM 550 or BIOL 541 or CHEM 555 or BIOL 545.
name: Biochemistry Laboratory
description: Experiments and demonstrations illustrating the principles of biochemistry. Three laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302 or MSCI 311.
name: Comparative Physiology
description: An integrative and comparative study of the structure, function, and evolution of the physiological systems of animals. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Corequisite: BIOL 543.
name: Comparative Physiology Laboratory
description: Laboratory exercises to illustrate principles from BIOL 543. Three hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 334.
name: Biochemistry/Molecular Biology I
description: Essentials of modern biochemistry. First semester of a two-semester course. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in BIOL 302.
name: Biochemistry/Molecular Biology II
description: Essentials of modern biochemistry and molecular biology. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302 and BIOL 425.
name: Plant Physiology
description: A general survey of the major physiological processes in plants. Two lecture and four laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: BIOL 302 or MSCI 311.
Corequisite: BIOL 550L.
name: Bacteriology
description: Introduction to bacteria and viruses emphasizing ultrastructure, physiology, genetics, and growth. Discussion of public health, industrial, and environmental microbiology. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Corequisite: BIOL 550.
name: Bacteriology Laboratory
description: Three laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Population Genetics
description: An introduction to the principles of population genetics, with emphasis on the origin, maintenance, and significance of genetic variation in natural populations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301, BIOL 303.
name: Genomics
description: Current concepts and applications of genomics, addressing questions from throughout biological inquiry.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C of higher in BIOL 302.
name: Stem Cells and The Physiological Environment
description: Discussion of how physiological factors, like nutritional status, influence systemic signals to alter stem cell activity, and the physiological stimuli that impact stem cell activity in a variety of organisms (from worms to humans).

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Principles of Ecology
description: Interactions of organisms and the environment; ecosystem structure and functions. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: BIOL 570.
name: Principles of Ecology Laboratory
description: Three hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: Conservation Biology
description: Principles of conservation biology. Importance of biodiversity, causes of decline and extinction, and restoration and conversation policy in terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: Freshwater Ecology
description: Quantitative study of the population, community and evolutionary ecology of freshwater habitats (lakes, ponds, rivers, streams, wetlands). Includes mandatory fieldtrips.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: Marine Conservation Biology
description: Exploration of how human activities affect marine natural populations, species, communities and ecosystems, including threats to biodiversity; approaches to marine conservation; and ecological and evolutionary responses to anthropogenic disturbance.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CHEM 111 and BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Marine Ecology
description: Structure, dynamics, and interactions between populations and communities in marine ecosystems. Attendance at designated departmental seminars is required. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: MSCI 575 or BIOL 575.
name: Marine Ecology Laboratory
description: Laboratory and field exercises in coastal environments. Three hours per week plus field trips.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: Marine Fisheries Ecology
description: Interdisciplinary examination of the distribution, reproduction, survival, and historical variation of the principal commercial marine fisheries.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Ecology of Coral Reefs
description: Structure, productivity, and biodiversity of coral reefs, emphasizing their sensitivity, stability, and sustainability. Taught as an extended field experience with daily lectures and guided research activities.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in STAT 201 or higher.
name: Genomic Data Science
description: This course focuses on quantitative knowledge for interdisciplinary applications in genetics as well as hands-on experience in analyzing genetic data. In this course, students will have programming exercises in using analysis tools to conduct genome-wide analysis, annotation, and interpretation of genetic data using R/Bioconductor packages.

name: Topics in Biology
description: Current developments in biological sciences. Readings and research on selected topics. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302 and BIOL 303.
name: Hallmarks of Cancer
description: Survey of current concepts regarding the molecular and genetic factors that regulate the origin and progression of cancer. Readings based on current primary literature.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BIOL 302.
name: Virology - Classical and Emerging Concepts
description: Advanced study of viruses with regard to biochemical, molecular, pathological, epidemiological, and biotechnological aspects. Focus on animal viruses with particular emphasis on human pathogens.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BIOL 302.
name: Stem Cell Biology
description: Focuses on the understanding of how stem cells can be used to make fundamental biological discoveries with a special focus in neuroscience.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302.
name: Immunobiology
description: Basic immunological concepts including antibody structure, function, and genetics; cellular immunology; transplantation; hypersensitivity; autoimmunity; and immunity to infectious diseases.

name: Medical Mycology
description: Advanced study of infectious diseases caused by fungi. Etiology, symptoms, and treatment of fungi related illnesses.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MSCI 102 or MSCI 450 or BIOL 450.
name: Marine Phytoplankton
description: Examines the physiology and ecology of phytoplankton, including environmental controls on community composition, primary productivity, and detection and characterization of water quality (eutrophication) and harmful algal blooms.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301, BIOL 302, and BIOL 303.
name: Biology of Birds
description: Biology of birds at molecular, organismal, and population levels, emphasizing unique adaptations of the class of Aves.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302 and SCHC 330 or BIOL 405.
name: Biology of Neurological Diseases
description: Advances in molecular and cellular neurobiology that bring new understanding for human neurological disease.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302.
name: Neurophysiology
description: Descriptive and experimental aspects of the neural basis of behavior, emphasizing cellular and molecular mechanisms. Two lecture and six laboratory hours per week. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 550 and either BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Microbial Ecology
description: Interactions of microorganisms with each other, with more complex organisms, and with their environments. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301, MATH 141 or MATH 122.
name: Biophysical Ecology
description: This course examines how the mechanisms by which animals and plants interact with their physical environments influence organismal physiology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301, BIOL 302, BIOL 303.
name: Biochemical Evolution
description: Advanced study of related aspects of biological evolution. Rose of life from physical and chemical precursors, biochemical basis of adaptation to ecological pressures, and biochemical aspects of the origins and maintenance of biodiversity.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: Limnology
description: A study of the aquatic environment and its biota. Three lecture and four laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301 and BIOL 303.
name: Evolutionary Biology
description: An advanced course in evolutionary biology, including natural selection, neutral evolution, molecular evolution population genetics, quantitative genetics, sexual selection, speciation, human evolution, and the evolution of disease.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302, BIOL 303.
name: Bioinformatics
description: Studies of the principles of genetics and molecular biology as applied to adaptive evolution of genes and genomes.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BIOL 301 and BIOL 303.
name: Speciation
description: Speciation as the source of biological diversity. Analysis of genetic and ecological models of speciation using primary literature.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302 and BIOL 303.
name: Biotechnology
description: Studies in molecular biology and genetics with emphasis on the use of newly developed techniques in biotechnology. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302, BIOL 302L.
name: Experimental Biotechnology
description: Techniques used in biotechnology will be employed in the context of an experimental project. Twelve laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Biology of Mammals
description: Evolution, systematics, genetics, ecology, and adaptation of mammals. Emphasis on native South Carolina species. Two lectures and one two-hour laboratory per week, plus five field trips to be arranged.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302 and BIOL 303.
name: Signal Transduction and Pathogenesis
description: Signaling pathways involved in human diseases, such as cancer, AIDS, autoimmune diseases and diabetes, and cellular processes involving apoptosis, cell cycle, cell-cell adhesion, growth factors, hormones, G protein-couples receptors, cytokines and immune response.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302 and BIOL 303.
name: Human Molecular Genetics
description: Molecular mechanisms underlying gene action and differentiation in man; the genetic bases for human variability and inborn metabolic errors leading to inherited diseases.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302 and BIOL 303.
name: Molecular and Genetic Mechanisms of Disease Pathogenesis
description: An advanced examination of the molecular mechanisms underlying gene action in humans. Current literature illustrating the genotype-phenotype relationship in human disease pathogenesis will be discussed.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 555/BIOL 545 or CHEM 550/BIOL 541.
name: Metabolic Biochemistry of Human Disease
description: Core concepts of biochemistry as applied to human health and disease.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: Plant Ecology
description: Structure and dynamics of plant populations and communities, including life histories, adaptations, and plant interactions. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: BIOL 670.
name: Plant Ecology
description: Laboratory and field exercises in plant ecology. Four hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302.
name: Plant Responses to the Environment
description: Physiological, molecular, and genetic examination of induced plant responses to various biotic and abiotic environmental stresses.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 302 or MSCI 311.
name: Ultramicroscopy
description: Theoretical and practical aspects of scanning and transmission electron microscopy, digital image acquisition and energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy. Two lecture and one laboratory hour per week, plus a research project to be arranged.

name: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
description: Introduction to topics comprising the field of Biomedical Engineering, including their ethical impacts. Familiarization with resources and basic skills necessary to succeed in this major and field.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CHEM 111 or CHEM 141; C or better in MATH 141.
name: Fundamentals of Biomedical Systems
description: Fundamentals of static equilibrium, free body diagrams, force and momentum balances; viscoelastic mechanical behavior and models of viscoelasticity; introduction to linear circuit analysis.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BIOL 101; C or better in CHEM 111 or CHEM 141.
name: Cellular and Molecular Biology with Engineering Applications
description: Introduction to molecular, cellular, and physical biology principles and concepts and application of engineering principles to further the understanding of biological systems. Protein and nucleic acid structure and function; DNA replication, mutations, and repair; transcription, translation, and post-translational processing; cellular organization; molecular transport and trafficking; and cellular models.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BMEN 212 and PHYS 211.
name: Introduction to Biomechanics
description: Mathematical and theoretical analysis of the mechanical properties and functions of materials, including those of biological origin and clinical relevance. Stress, strain, mechanical properties of materials, axial loading, torsion, bending, and stress/strain transformations. Application of the categories and methodology of solid and fluid mechanics to study biological tissues and events.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in CHEM 333; C or better in BMEN 290 or ECHE 311.
name: Introduction to Biomaterials
description: Properties of metals, ceramics, polymers, natural materials and composites; methods to modify surface and bulk properties of biomaterials; mechanisms of degradation in physiological environments; cell- and tissue-biomaterial interactions; host response to implanted biomaterials; blood-biomaterial interactions; rational design of biomaterials for specific biomedical applications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BMEN 240 and PHYS 211.
name: Thermodynamics of Biomolecular Systems
description: First, second, and third law of thermodynamics; free energy and chemical equilibrium in biological processes; phase equilibrium for biomedical systems; energy and metabolism; membrane potentials and depolarization.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BMEN 101.
name: Professional Development and Ethics in Biomedical Engineering
description: Analysis and discussion of industries, products, patents, industrial inventiveness, and biomedical research. Ethical issues associated with research, introduction of new products, animal subjects, and human subjects.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BMEN 212, C or better in BMEN 240, C or better in MATH 242.
name: Biomonitoring and Electrophysiology
description: Basic electric circuits and equivalent cell model circuits used in biomonitoring and electrophysiology. Ohm�€�s and Kirchoff�€�s Laws. Applications of electrical components, such as operations amplifiers, filter, and Wheastone bridge, in biomonitoring and electrophysiology. Origins of bioelectricity. Biopotential and electrochemistry including Nernst and Goldman-Hudgkin-Katz equations for describing membrane potential of nerve and muscle cells. Ion transport involved in maintaining cell pH, action potential, muscle contraction, sensory perception.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 101.
name: Infectious Disease & Immunology for Biomedical Engineers
description: Qualitative and quantitative aspects of infectious diseases; principles of diagnosis and control. Elements of human immunological response and immune disorders; influence on biomedical engineering of explants and implants.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BMEN 240.
name: Human Anatomy and Physiology for Biomedical Engineers
description: Foundations for biomedical engineering with a focus on human anatomy and physiology. Introduction to the inter-relationships between tissue/organ structure and function; demonstration of how an engineering approach can promote understanding of these relationships. Recent biomedical engineering advances and their relations to underlying anatomy and physiology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in BMEN 240.
name: Medical Microbiology for Biomedical Engineers
description: Qualitative and quantitative aspects of human system based medical microbiology; principles of diagnosis and control of representative human diseases. Elements of human immunological response and immune disorders.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in BMEN 263 and C or better in MATH 242.
name: Biotransport
description: Basics of convective and diffusive transport applied to biological and biomedical systems. The effect of fluid flow and mass transport upon biochemical interactions. Scaling and design of biotransport systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in BMEN 321 or BMEN 360.
name: Biomedical Instrumentation
description: Sensing and measurement of biophysical and biochemical properties and signals in the human body for quantitative molecular, cell, and tissue analysis. Overview on the theory, design and application of common biomedical instrumentation used for diagnosis, treatment, and scientific study of physiological parameters in clinical medicine and biomedical research.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in BMEN 263, D or better in STAT 509.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in BMEN 271.
name: Biomedical Engineering Laboratory I
description: Introduction to laboratory techniques and tools used for physiological measurements in biomedical engineering, with focus on biological, physical, and biomaterial methods. Data processing and analysis, as well as effective communication of results in written and oral form.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in BMEN 321 and BMEN 381.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in BMEN 363.
name: Biomedical Engineering Laboratory II
description: Introduction to laboratory techniques and tools used for physiological measurements in biomedical engineering, with focus on measurement of biosignals and common analytical methods employed in biomedical research and clinical settings. Data processing and analysis, as well as effective communication of results in written and oral form.

name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering for Undergraduates
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated as topic varies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in BMEN 340, CHEM 550, or BIOL 541; C or better in BMEN 290, ECHE 310, EMCH 290, or ENCP 290; C or better in MATH 242.
name: Kinetics in Biomolecular Systems
description: Kinetic theory applied to biomedical systems, including enzymatic reactions, cell growth, and kinetic models of biological systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CHEM 333.
name: Fundamentals of Biochemical Engineering
description: Biological systems are used in chemical industries for a wide variety of applications, including the formation of important products (e.g. pharmaceuticals), sensor technology, degradation, and waste water treatment. This class will provide an overview of materials needed to investigate and model biosystems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BMEN 263, BMEN 271, and BMEN 354 with a minimum grade of D.
name: Modeling and Simulation of Biomedical Systems
description: Introduction to modern computational modeling tools used in biomedical engineering. Analysis, visualization and image processing using engineering software as applied to problems of interest in biomedical engineering.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in all of: BMEN 271, BMEN 345, BMEN 354, BMEN 363, BMEN 381 or BMEN 382.
name: Senior Biomedical Engineering Design I
description: Integrated team work/project management, "voice of the patient", design specifications, design functions, design concepts, economic factors, concept selection and product architecture. The initial feasibility study, selection of the final design approach, and preliminary specifications are required by the end of the semester.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in BMEN 427.
name: Senior Biomedical Engineering Design II
description: Design for manufacturability, ergonomic and aesthetic considerations, prototype construction and testing, fabrication and biological testing of tissue engineered constructs, statistical methods/design of experiments, ethics/product liability and social/environmental impact. The final engineering design (specifications, drawings, bill of materials, including assessment of economics) will be completed by the end of the semester. Both written and oral reports are to be provided.

name: Independent Research
description: Individual investigation or studies of special topics. A maximum of 3 credits may be applied to Biomedical Engineering program requirements. Contract approval by instructor, department, and college is required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in BMEN 345.
name: Delivery of Bioactive Agents
description: Routes of administration; mechanisms of drug absorption and biological barriers; pharmacokinetic modeling of drug distribution; drug excretion and biotransformation; design and evaluation of controlled release systems, targeted release systems, and responsive release systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BMEN 240.
name: Immunoengineering
description: Engineering approaches to study and control immune reactions and their applications in therapy and diagnostics for infectious disease, cancer, allergy, autoimmunity, and transplantation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in BMEN 240.
name: Cardiovascular System: From Development to Disease
description: Survey of cardiovascular development, anatomy, physiology and pathology. Recent advances in our understanding of the basic mechanisms of congenital cardiovascular defects and cardiovascular disease. Engineering principles, detection and treatment of cardiovascular defects.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in BMEN 263.
name: Advanced Biomechanics
description: Mathematical and theoretical analysis of the mechanical properties and functions of soft biological tissues to include arterial vessels.

name: Tissue Engineering
description: Molecular basis of bioregenerative engineering; biomaterial design; biocompatibility assessment; cell isolation and characterization; rapid prototyping, scaffold fabrication, and biofabrication; protein and gene delivery; bioreactor design; transport in biological tissues; applications of tissue engineering in regenerative medicine.

name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated as topic varies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: STAT 205 or equivalent.
name: Introduction to Biostatistical Modeling
description: Statistical modeling, primarily using applications in public health. Measures of agreement, principles of statistical inference, correlation, simple and multiple linear regression, categorical independent variables, interaction, repeated measures, and logistic regression.

name: Independent Study
description: Enrollment and topic to be approved in advance by advisor and instructor. May be repeated.

name: Business Careers in the Global Economy
description: Course outlines job search essentials for business careers in a global economy. Business networking, interviewing, and career planning with an international focus will be covered. Completion of lower division business courses.

name: Independent Study
description: Not to include Business Internship. (See BADM 499) Contract approved by instructor, advisor and undergraduate division head is required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BADM 301.
name: Planning and Managing a Career in Business
description: Course will focus on defining and enhancing life/career goals using leadership assessment, life planning processes, and emotional intelligence discussions, all linked to transition to work.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Cumulative GPA of 2.8.
name: Business Internship
description: Supervised work experience of at least nine hours per week (for 15 weeks in a semester) or minimum 135 hours total; approved by area program director, to include one class meeting a month and individual consultation. Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and undergraduate division head is required.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Introduction to Chemical Engineering
description: Introduction to engineering, with emphasis on chemical engineering. Problem-solving techniques, including the use of computer tools. Basic engineering design methods.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: ECHE 300.
name: Exploring the Chemical Engineering Workplace
description: Identification of career interests and active exploration of careers in chemical engineering.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Research in Chemical Engineering
description: Introduction to research in Chemical Engineering, effective literature search, communication of results, lab safety, and research ethics.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: MATH 141.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: CHEM 112 or CHEM 142.
name: Chemical Process Principles
description: Material and energy balances in the chemical process industry. Properties of gases, liquids, and solids. Two one-hour lectures and one three-hour laboratory period devoted to problem solving.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in ECHE 300.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: MATH 241.
name: Introductory Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
description: First law and second law of thermodynamics. Thermodynamic properties of single component systems. Analysis of power and refrigeration cycles.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ECHE 310, ENCP 290, CHEM 541, BMEN 290, EMCH 290 or PHYS 306.
name: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
description: Mass, energy, and entropy balance analysis of chemical engineering systems; evaluation of thermodynamic property changes of pure materials; solution thermodynamics of single-phase multicomponent systems; phase and chemical reaction equilibrium.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in PHYS 211.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in MATH 241.
name: Chemical Engineering Fluid Mechanics
description: Fluid statics and dynamics with emphasis on chemical engineering applications.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in ECHE 320 or ENCP 360; C or better in MATH 242.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECHE 456.
name: Heat-Flow Analysis
description: Theory of heat transmission; mechanism, generation, distribution, and measurement; use of theory in practical equipment design.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECHE 321.
name: Mass Transfer
description: Molecular diffusion in fluids; diffusion in laminar and turbulent flow; momentum, transport analogies; interfacial mass transfer; design applications including humidification and absorption.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CHEM 112.
name: Introduction to Materials
description: Overview of the fundamental chemical aspects of materials; role of materials in applications in modern society by case studies of advances in new materials and processes.

name: Special Topics in Chemical Engineering
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated as topic varies.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in ECHE 311.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECHE 321 or BMEN 354.
name: Chemical Engineering Kinetics
description: Concepts of chemical kinetics, batch and flow reactors, catalysts and reactor design.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in ECHE 300.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: ECHE 311.
name: Separation Process Design
description: Design of stagewise chemical separation cascades; analysis of binary and ternary systems; multicomponent separations, plate and column specification procedures; distillation, crystallization, extraction, and leaching.

name: Adsorption Fundamentals and Processes
description: Basic principles of adsorption and adsorption processes including adsorbents, thermodynamics, kinetics, fixed bed adsorption and cyclic adsorption processes.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in MATH 242.
name: Computational Methods for Engineering Applications
description: Introduction to advanced computational tools for the analysis of chemical engineering systems. Initial and boundary value problems related to heat and mass transfer, reaction engineering, and parameter estimation.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: ECHE 311, ECHE 321.
name: Chemical Engineering Laboratory I
description: Review of technical-report writing and presentation techniques; topics in heat transfer, fluid mechanics, and thermodynamics; verification of theoretical results and determination of design parameters. One lecture and six laboratory hours.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in ECHE 460.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECHE 430 and ECHE 440.
name: Chemical Engineering Laboratory II
description: Continuation of ECHE 460; topics in mass transfer, kinetics, and process control.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECHE 430 and ECHE 440.
name: Chemical-Process Analysis and Design I
description: Economics of chemical engineering projects related to typical corporate goals and objectives; process-flowsheet development techniques; review of shortcut design techniques; selection of profitability criteria.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in ECHE 430, ECHE 440, ECHE 465.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: ECHE 322, ECHE 567.
name: Chemical-Process Analysis and Design II
description: Continuation of ECHE 465; computer-aided design of chemical processes; written and oral presentation of a comprehensive design project.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Three credit hours of ECHE 499, acceptance into the departmental undergraduate research track, and consent of instructor.
name: Thesis Preparation
description: Completion of the thesis requirements for the departmental undergraduate research track. A maximum of three credits may be applied toward a degree.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: upper division standing.
name: Topics in Chemical Engineering
description: Reading and research on selected topics in chemical engineering. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated two times as topics vary. Pass-Fail grading.

name: Special Problems
description: Individual investigation or studies of special topics. A maximum of six credits may be applied toward a degree. Advance approval of project proposal by advisor and instructor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECHE 320 or ENCP 360.
name: Chemical Engineering Fluid Mechanics
description: Multi-phase pressure drop, phase contacting, flow through porous media, fluidization, mixing, and turbulence.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECHE 320, EMCH 360, ECIV 360, ENCP 360, or AESP 265.
name: Computational Fluid Dynamics for Engineering Applications
description: Introduction to the use of computational fluid dynamics codes to analyze flow, heat, and mass transfer problems of practical engineering applications.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in ECHE 311.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECHE 321.
name: Intermediate Chemical Engineering Kinetics
description: Intermediate concepts of chemical kinetics, batch and flow reactors, catalysts and reactor design, including non-ideal systems.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in ECHE 300.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECHE 311.
name: Intermediate Separation Process Design
description: Intermediate level design of stagewise chemical separation cascades; analysis of binary and ternary systems; multicomponent separations, plate and column specification procedures; distillation, crystallization, extraction, and leaching.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ECHE 300 and MATH 242; D or better in ECHE 456.
name: Chemical-Process Dynamics and Control
description: Fundamental physical and chemical principles in mathematically modeling the dynamic response of chemical processes; feedforward and feedback control systems; design of control schemes for selected chemical processes.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECHE 466.
name: Process Safety, Health and Loss Prevention
description: Reliability, availability, and fault-tree analyses, risk indices, hazard evaluation, vapor cloud modeling, toxicology, material safety classification and regulations, individual/corporate ethical responsibilities.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECHE 311.
name: Corrosion Engineering
description: Basic principles of corrosion engineering developed from a chemical engineering approach to thermodynamics, kinetics, mass transfer, and potential theory.

name: Polymer Processing
description: Industrial polymers with emphasis on their characterization and on the modeling of the major polymer fabrication processes.

name: Next Energy
description: An examination of energy technologies that will enable society to move from an economy based on fossil fuels to one based on sustainable energy.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECHE 430.
name: Combustion
description: Fundamental process and applications related to the broad field of combustion and energy generation including emissions control technologies.

name: Special Advanced Topics in Chemical Engineering
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated as topic varies.

name: Fundamental Chemistry I
description: A science elective surveying inorganic and solution chemistry. First of a terminal two-semester sequence. Three lecture, one recitation, and two laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 1 year high-school chemistry, CHEM 101, CHEM 111, or equivalent.
name: Fundamental Chemistry II
description: An introductory survey of organic and biochemistry. Three lecture, one recitation, and two laboratory hours per week.

name: Chemistry and Modern Society I
description: A conceptual and qualitative approach to chemistry, its evolution, achievements, and goals and its impact on technology, the environment, and modern life and thought. (Specifically designed for non-science majors.) Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 105.
name: Chemistry and Modern Society II
description: A continuation of Chemistry 105. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: CHEM 105.
Corequisite: CHEM 106.
name: Chemistry and Modern Society II Laboratory
description: Laboratory associated with CHEM 106. Three hours of laboratory per week.

name: Introduction to Forensic Science
description: Surveys chemical aspects of criminal investigation and adjudication including drug, arson, DNA, paint, and fiber identification.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or higher in MATH 111, MATH 115, MATH 122, MATH 141 or higher math (or by placement score into MATH 122, MATH 141 or higher math).
Corequisite: CHEM 111L (unless grade of C or higher in CHEM 111L earned previously).
name: General Chemistry I
description: Survey of the principles that underlie all chemistry with applications illustrating these principles. Three lecture and one recitation hours per week.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: MATH 111 or MATH 115 or higher.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: CHEM 111.
name: General Chemistry I Lab
description: Introduction to the principles and techniques of experimental chemistry with emphasis on formula investigations, equations, elementary statistics, and chemical reactivity.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 111 and C or higher in MATH 111, MATH 115, MATH 122, MATH 141 or higher math.
Corequisite: CHEM 112L.
name: General Chemistry II
description: Continuation of CHEM 111. Special emphasis on chemical equilibrium. Three lecture and one recitation hours per week.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 111 and CHEM 111L or CHEM 141.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: CHEM 112.
name: General Chemistry II Lab
description: Continuation of CHEM 111L with emphasis on solution properties, kinetics, equilibrium, acids and bases, and qualitative analysis.

requisiteText: Corequisite: CHEM 112 and CHEM 112L or CHEM 142 (unless a grade of C or higher earned previously).
name: Computational Chemistry I
description: Introduction to the use of computers in solving chemical problems. One discussion and two laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: high-school chemistry; C or higher in MATH 141 or higher math (or by placement score into MATH 142 or higher math).
name: Principles of Chemistry I
description: Advanced general chemistry I. Atoms and chemical bonds. Three lecture hours, one recitation hour, and three laboratory hours per week. Credit cannot be received for both CHEM 111 and CHEM 141.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 141.
name: Principles of Chemistry II
description: Advanced general chemistry II. Chemical kinetics, equilibria, and thermodynamics. Three lecture hours, one recitation hour, and three laboratory hours per week. Credit cannot be received for both CHEM 112 and CHEM 142.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CSCE 145 or CSCE 206 and in CHEM 118.
name: Computational Chemistry II
description: A continuation of CHEM 118, with applications to more advanced chemical problems. One discussion and two laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 112 and CHEM 112L or in CHEM 142.
Corequisite: CHEM 321L.
name: Quantitative Analysis
description: Gravimetric, volumetric, and introductory instrumental analysis. Three lecture and one recitation hours per week.

requisiteText: Corequisite: CHEM 321.
name: Quantitative Analysis Laboratory
description: Three laboratory hours per week. Credit cannot be received for both CHEM 321L and CHEM 322L.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 112 and CHEM 112L (or in CHEM 142) and in MATH 141 or higher MATH.
Corequisite: CHEM 322L.
name: Analytical Chemistry
description: Qualitative analysis, quantitative analysis, fundamental or method analysis, and molecular characterization.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in CHEM 112 and CHEM 112L or CHEM 142.
Corequisite: CHEM 322.
name: Analytical Chemistry Laboratory
description: Laboratory skill building in analytical techniques. Applications of stoichiometry, spectroscopy, phase transfer, electrochemistry and kinetics. Credit cannot be received for both CHEM 321L and CHEM 322L.

requisiteText: Corequisite: CHEM 333 (unless grade of C or higher in CHEM 333 earned previously).
name: Essentials of Organic Chemistry Laboratory I
description: Laboratory safety, syntheses, separation, and purification of carbon compounds. For non-majors.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 331L.
Corequisite: CHEM 334 (unless grade of C or higher in CHEM 334 earned previously).
name: Essentials of Organic Chemistry Laboratory II
description: Continuation of CHEM 331L. Spectroscopic identification of carbon compounds. For non-majors. Three lab hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 112 or in CHEM 142.
name: Organic Chemistry I
description: Contemporary theories, nomenclature, reactions, mechanisms, and syntheses of carbon compounds. Three lecture and one recitation hours per week.

requisiteText: Corequisite: CHEM 333 (unless grade of C or higher in CHEM 333 earned previously).
name: Comprehensive Organic Chemistry Laboratory I
description: Laboratory safety, synthesis, separation, and purification of carbon compounds. Required for chemistry majors. Six laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 333.
name: Organic Chemistry II
description: Continuation of CHEM 333. Three lecture and one recitation hours per week.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 333L.
Corequisite: CHEM 334 (unless grade of C or higher in CHEM 334 earned previously).
name: Comprehensive Organic Chemistry Laboratory II
description: Continuation of CHEM 333L. Spectroscopic identification of carbon compounds. Required for chemistry majors. Six laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 112 and CHEM 112L or in CHEM 142.
name: Elementary Biophysical Chemistry
description: A non-calculus approach to the study of the principles of physical chemistry emphasizing their application to significant biochemical and biological systems. Chemical thermodynamics, kinetics, equilibrium, solution chemistry, the structure of macromolecules, and acid-base properties of biomolecules. Credit for a degree will not be given for both CHEM 340 and CHEM 541.

name: Undergraduate Seminar
description: Student seminars and a survey of biochemical and molecular biology research at the University of South Carolina. Required of all biochemistry majors.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract Required.

name: Industrial Chemistry Capstone Experience
description: Prepares students for future roles in chemical industry or graduate school and provides career-enhancing interpersonal skills, including team-building, public speaking, resume preparation, and interviewing.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Introduction to the methods of chemical research. A written report on work accomplished is required at the end of each semester. Nine hours of library and laboratory per week. Contract Required.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Introduction to the methods of chemical research. A written report on work accomplished is required at the end of each semester. Nine hours of library and laboratory per week. Contract Required.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Introduction to the methods of chemical research. A written report on work accomplished is required at the end of each semester. Nine hours of library and laboratory per week. Contract Required.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Introduction to the methods of chemical research. A written report on work accomplished is required at the end of each semester. Nine hours of library and laboratory per week. Contract Required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 334, PHYS 212, and MATH 241.
name: Inorganic Chemistry
description: Consideration of atomic structure, valence, complex compounds, and systematic study of the periodic table.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 334.
name: Comprehensive Organic Chemistry III
description: Selected organic reactions from synthetic and mechanistic viewpoints. For Undergraduate Credit Only.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 112 (or CHEM 142) and in MATH 241 or higher MATH.
Corequisite: PHYS 212; unless a grade of C or higher in PHYS 212 earned previously.
name: Physical Chemistry
description: Chemical thermodynamics and kinetics. For Undergraduate Credit Only.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 321L or in CHEM 322L or in CHEM 142.
Corequisite: CHEM 541 (unless grade of C or higher in CHEM 541 earned previously).
name: Physical Chemistry Laboratory
description: Applications of physical chemical techniques. Five laboratory hours and one recitation hour per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 112 or in CHEM 142, MATH 241 and PHYS 212.
name: Physical Chemistry
description: Spectroscopy, statistical mechanics, and chemical applications of quantum mechanics.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 321L or in CHEM 142.
Corequisite: CHEM 542 (unless grade of C or higher in CHEM 542 earned previously).
name: Physical Chemistry Laboratory
description: Applications of physical chemical techniques. Five laboratory hours and one recitation hour per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 541 and in CHEM 550 or CHEM 555.
name: Physical Biochemistry
description: A survey of physical methods essential for studies of biomacromolecules. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 334.
name: Biochemistry
description: Description of biological macromolecules and major metabolic pathways. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or higher in CHEM 550 or BIOL 541 or CHEM 555 or BIOL 545.
name: Biochemistry Laboratory
description: Experiments and demonstrations illustrating the principles of biochemistry. Three laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 334.
name: Biochemistry/Molecular Biology I
description: Essentials of modern biochemistry. First semester of a two-semester course. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in BIOL 302.
name: Biochemistry/Molecular Biology II
description: Essentials of modern biochemistry and molecular biology. Three lecture hours per week.

name: Special Topics in Inorganic Chemistry
description: Current developments in inorganic chemistry. Readings and research on selected topics. Course content varies by title and will be announced in the schedule of classes. May be repeated for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 321 or CHEM 322.
name: Instrumental Analysis
description: Chemical instrumentation including electronics, signal processing, statistical analysis, molecular/atomic spectroscopy, electrochemical methods, chromatography, and mass spectrometry. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Corequisite: CHEM 621.
name: Instrumental Analysis Lab
description: Methods, principles and strategies for chemical instrumentation in analysis. Chemical instrumentation laboratory with environmental, forensic, and biotechnology applications. Three laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 321 and CHEM 321L or CHEM 322 and CHEM 322L; C or higher in CHEM 334; C or higher in CHEM 332L or CHEM 334L.
name: Forensic Analytical Chemistry
description: Analytical chemical methods in forensic science, including gathering of evidence, toxicology, drug identification, analysis of trace evidence, arson analysis, and DNA/serology. Three lecture hours and three laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 321, in CHEM 333, and in MATH 142.
name: Introductory Environmental Chemistry
description: Study of the chemical reactions and processes that affect the fate and transport of organic chemicals in the environment. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: CHEM 321, MATH 142.
name: Aquatic Chemistry
description: Study of the chemical reactions and processes affecting the distribution of chemical species in natural systems. Three lecture hours per week.

name: Special Topics in Analytical Chemistry
description: Current developments in inorganic chemistry. Readings and research on selected topics. Course content varies by title and will be announced in the schedule of classes. May be repeated for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 334.
name: Introduction to Polymer Synthesis
description: Special emphasis on the modern synthesis of polymeric materials. Definitions, characterization, and applications of polymers will be briefly presented.

name: Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
description: Current developments in organic chemistry. Readings and research on selected topics. May be repeated as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 541 or CHEM 542.
name: Computational Chemistry
description: This course is designed to familiarize students with theory and use of modern electronic structure codes, as well as to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills and to improve computer literacy.

requisiteText: Corequisite: CHEM 542 (unless a grade of C or higher earned previously).
name: Materials Chemistry
description: Introduction to materials science; structural and electronic description of inorganic-based solids; experimental techniques in materials chemistry; interfacial energetics and optoelectronic processes at metal and semiconductor surfaces.

name: Special Topics in Physical Chemistry
description: Current developments in physical chemistry. Readings and research on selected topics. Course content varies by title and will be announced in the schedule of classes. May be repeated for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 555/BIOL 545 or CHEM 550/BIOL 541.
name: Metabolic Biochemistry of Human Disease
description: Core concepts of biochemistry as applied to human health and disease.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in CHEM 555/BIOL 545 or CHEM 550/BIOL 541.
name: Special Topics in Biochemistry
description: Selected topics in the field of biochemistry. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Introduction to Chinese Calligraphy
description: Five hundred of the most commonly used Chinese characters. Emphasis is on the phonetic and significant elements common to large groups of ideograms.

name: Elementary Chinese Mandarin
description: Grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Assumes no prior experience in the language.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CHIN 121.
name: Basic Proficiency in Mandarin Chinese
description: Practice and further development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills. Admission only by successful completion of Chinese 121.

name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese
description: Continued practice of basic sentence patterns used in modern speech with increased emphasis on reading and acquisition of additional characters.

name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese II
description: Continued practice of basic sentence patterns used in modern speech with increased emphasis on reading and acquisition of additional characters.

name: Chinese Culture, Tradition, and Modern Societies
description: Introduction to Chinese culture, heritage, and modern societies. Readings selected from printed and online sources. Taught in English.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CHIN 222.
name: Advanced intermediate Mandarin Chinese I
description: Provides advanced intermediate training in spoken and written Chinese. By increasing students�€� vocabulary and knowledge of sentence patterns, the course focuses on speaking and writing in coherent, well-formed paragraphs.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CHIN 321.
name: Advanced Intermediate Mandarin Chinese II
description: Continues advanced intermediate training in spoken and written Chinese. Attention is given to complex grammatical patterns, discourse characteristics, and discussions of cultural topics.

name: Women in China
description: Introduces the connection between gender and the Chinese national imagination. Readings include cultural and historical documents that purport to explain the experience of women in China. Readings in English. Taught in English.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Introduction to Premodern Chinese Literature
description: An introduction to the most important works, authors, genres, and themes of Chinese literature from the first millennium B.C.E. to 1911.

name: Modern Chinese Literature
