description: Readings of canonical texts from modern Chinese literature. A focus is on the role of literature and other cultural documents in the imagination of China as a modern nation. Readings and discussion in English.

name: Screening China
description: Survey of Chinese language cinema. Chinese film history and vocabulary with which to discuss film texts. Covers classic leftwing cinema, Hong Kong martial arts films, as well as the Hong Kong, Taiwan, and PRC New Waves. Taught in English. Films subtitled.

name: Selected Topics
description: Intensive study in selected authors or literary movements of China, including cultural aspects. May be repeated for credit under different titles. Taught in English.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CHIN 322.
name: Advanced Chinese I
description: Acquisition of advanced grammar and vocabulary. Emphasis on building oral proficiency in professional settings.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CHIN 421.
name: Advanced Chinese II
description: Continued acquisition of advanced grammar and vocabulary. Emphasis on expanding communicative abilities in a wider variety of interpersonal situations.

name: Advanced Special Topics in Chinese Studies
description: Advanced special topics in Chinese studies. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Introduction to Civil Engineering
description: Fundamental concepts in each of the disciplines of civil engineering are discussed. Critical thinking skills are formally fostered by hands-on experiences and group discussions.

name: Introduction to Engineering Graphics and Visualization
description: Principles and practice of visualization and graphical representation using modern computer-aided design tools.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 141.
name: Statics
description: Fundamentals of engineering mechanics. Equilibrium of particles and rigid bodies. Free-body diagrams, analysis trusses and frames. Distributed forces, centroids, centers of gravity, and friction.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 142 and ECIV 200 or ENCP 200.
name: Computational Methods for Civil Engineering
description: The use of computational tools and techniques for solving civil and environmental engineering problems. Overview of numerical methods including roots of equations, systems of linear equations, interpolation, and integration. Analysis of civil and environmental systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ECIV 200 or ENCP 200; C or better in MATH 142.
name: Dynamics
description: Kinematics of particles and rigid bodies. Vector representation of force and motion. Free-body diagrams, application of energy and momentum methods to solve problems. Rigid body and central force motion.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ECIV 200 or ENCP 200 and in MATH 142.
name: Mechanics of Solids
description: Concepts of stress and strain; stress analysis of basic structural members. Vectors, free bodies, equilibrium and elastic behavior. Combined stress, Mohr�€�s circle. Beams, columns, torsion, and rotation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in MATH 241.
name: Civil Engineering Measurements
description: Theory and application of plane surveying and mapping techniques. Lecture plus laboratory.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ECIV 220 or ENCP 260.
name: Civil Engineering Materials
description: Mechanical and thermal properties of mineral aggregates, cements, concrete, timber, asphalt, metals, and plastics.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in STAT 509 or STAT 511.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECIV 201 or ENCP 201; D or better in ECIV 303.
name: Civil Engineering Materials Laboratory
description: Experiments, exercises, and demonstrations to accompany ECIV 303.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECIV 320, ECIV 330, ECIV 340, ECIV 350, or ECIV 362.
name: Professional Development for Civil Engineers
description: Regulatory permits and scheduling of construction projects. Engineering responsibility and liabilities. Reporting of engineering designs and analysis. Cost estimation of engineering projects including present or future net value.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 201 or ENCP 201; D or better in MATH 242; C or better in ECIV 220 or ENCP 260.
name: Structural Analysis I
description: Equilibrium, shear and moment diagrams, and influence lines for statically determinate trusses, beams, and frames. Energy principles and other methods for displacement calculations. Introduction to indeterminate structural analysis.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ECIV 320.
name: Structural Steel Design
description: Behavior and design of steel beams, columns, and tension members; strength and stability; design of connections using welded, bolted and riveted construction.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ECIV 320.
name: Reinforced Concrete Design
description: Behavior and design of reinforced concrete beams, columns, continuous beams and one way slabs, and footings.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in either ECIV 220 or ENCP 260.
name: Introduction to Geotechnical Engineering
description: Engineering properties of soil and rock; hydraulic conductivity, flow nets, drainage design; consolidation theory, shearing strength of soil.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in STAT 509 or STAT 511.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECIV 201 or ENCP 201; D or better in ECIV 330.
name: Geotechnical Laboratory
description: Laboratory associated with ECIV 330. Soil mechanics experiments, exercises, and demonstrations. Three contact hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 201 or D or better in ENCP 201 and D or better in STAT 509 or D or better in STAT 511.
name: Introduction to Transportation Engineering
description: Transportation design, planning, and operational analysis, including roadway, airway, and railway systems; transportation elements, including traveled way, vehicle, control, terminals, and advanced technology; traffic data collection, interpretation, and analysis.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in STAT 509 or 511.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECIV 201 or ENCP 201; D or better in ECIV 340.
name: Transportation Engineering Laboratory
description: This course covers the principles of distances, elevations and angles that pertain to roadways, basic theories in engineering measurements and surveying calculations, and an introduction to mapping, for transportation engineering applications. Three contact hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in CHEM 111 or CHEM 141; C or better in Math 142
name: Introduction to Environmental Engineering
description: Concepts of environmental engineering, including air and water pollution, solid and hazardous waste disposal, and noise pollution. Qualitative and quantitative development of engineering techniques for pollution control.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in STAT 509 or STAT 511.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECIV 201 or ENCP 201; D or better in ECIV 350.
name: Introduction to Environmental Engineering Laboratory
description: Physical, chemical, and biological analysis of water and wastewater. Three laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in ECIV 200 or ENCP 200; C or better in MATH 142.
name: Fluid Mechanics
description: Principles of fluid statics and dynamics. Conservation of mass, momentum, and energy. Similitude and dimensional analysis, open channel flow, lift and drag forces, and introduction to turbulent flow.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in either ECIV 360 or ENCP 360.
name: Introduction to Water Resources Engineering
description: Application of fluid mechanic principles to water resources engineering problems; pipe systems, pumps, open channel flow, peak runoff, seepage, hydraulic structures.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in STAT 509 or 511.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECIV 201 or ENCP 201; D or better in ECIV 362.
name: Introduction to Water Resources Engineering Laboratory
description: Experiments, exercises, and demonstrations on flow in pipes and open channels, pumps, flow measurement, seepage, and infiltration. Three contact hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 201 or ENCP 201.
name: System Applications in Civil Engineering
description: Systems approach to analysis and design; application of engineering economic principles to the evaluation of design alternatives; deterministic modeling and optimization emphasizing civil engineering applications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 325 or ECIV 327.
name: Structural Design
description: Design of steel structures including elastic and plastic design concepts. Design of concrete structures including continuous members and long columns.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 307 and D or better in two ECIV Distribution Courses.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECIV 111 or ENCP 102.
name: Civil Engineering Design
description: Application of hydraulic, geotechnical, and structural principles in design; project scheduling; cost estimation; ethics; environmental and social impact; design drawings; report documents.

name: Special Topics
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by course title. May be repeated as topic varies. A maximum of twelve credits may be applied towards a degree.

name: Fundamentals of Engineering Preparation
description: Preparation for the Fundamentals of Engineering Exam. Will cover general engineering and civil engineering specific areas. Restricted to Civil Engineering Seniors. Pass/ Fail Grading.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: approval of project proposal by instructor; USC/GPA 2.8.
name: Independent Study in Civil and Environmental Engineering
description: Individual investigation or studies of special topics. A maximum of six credits may be applied toward a degree.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECIV 327.
name: Structural Modeling and Experimental Methods
description: Introduction of structural modeling; strain gauge instrumentation; force, displacement, acceleration, pressure, temperature measurements; concrete and steel modeling; size effects; analysis of experimental data.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 320.
name: Structural Analysis II
description: Advanced methods of structural analysis with emphasis on matrix methods. Development of the generalized matrix force and matrix displacement methods of static analysis, with applications to trusses and frames.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 201 or ENCP 201.
name: Numerical Methods in Mechanics
description: Numerical modeling of typical engineering problems. Numerical solution of linear and nonlinear, boundary and initial value problems. Introduction to optimization.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 320.
name: Structural Vibrations
description: Response of single- and multiple-degree of freedom structurally dynamic systems to impact, harmonic, wind, and seismic excitations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ECIV 320.
name: Timber and Masonry Design
description: Basic engineering properties of timber and masonry materials, design methods and philosophies for timber and masonry structures. Particular attention is paid to current codes, specifications and analysis.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 330.
name: Foundation Analysis and Design
description: Subsurface investigation procedures. Theoretical and practical aspects of the design of earth retaining structures, spread footings, and pile foundations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECIV 330.
name: Design of Earth Structures
description: Geotechnical engineering problems associated with the behavior of earth masses. Soil shear strength, lateral earth pressure, design of retaining structures, slope stability, water flow through soils.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 330.
name: Geosynthetics and Geotechnical Design of Landfills
description: Principles for the design, construction, and performance of waste containment systems. Characterization of barrier materials; geosynthetics; design of liner and leachate collection systems; stability and deformation analyses of landfills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 330.
name: Geotechnical Engineering in Transportation
description: Remote sensing and engineering geology. Field and laboratory testing. Design and maintenance methods for flexible and rigid pavements. Topics in tunnel design and buried conduit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECIV 330, ECIV 330L.
name: Experimental Methods in Geotechnical Engineering
description: Overview of transducers, signal conditioning and data acquisition; test control methods, data analysis and measurement errors; testing systems to measure soil strength, stiffness, and hydraulic conductivity; laboratory projects and examinations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 340.
name: Transportation Systems Planning
description: Fundamental interactions between supply and demand in transportation systems. Modeling transportation demand and trip-making behavior. Evaluation of alternatives for decision making.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 111 or ENCP 102 and D or better in ECIV 340.
name: Highway Design
description: Design of transportation facilities using relevant tools and guidelines with emphasis on physical and operational aspects of arterials, freeways, intersections, and interchanges, including geometry, capacity, control, and safety.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 340.
name: Traffic Engineering
description: Capacity analysis of freeways and arterials. Traffic flow characteristics and basic relationships among traffic flow parameters. Signalized and unsignalized intersection control and signal timing design.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECIV 350.
name: Elements of Water and Wastewater Treatment
description: Unit operations and processes employed in the physical, chemical, and biological treatment of water and wastewater. Design of water and wastewater treatment systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 350.
name: Principles of Municipal Solid Waste Engineering
description: Fundamentals and engineering principles of solid waste generation, characterization, collection and transport, source reduction and recycling, and physical, chemical, and biological treatment strategies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 350.
name: Air Pollution Control Engineering
description: Introduction to the sources of air pollution and the engineering principles used for control and prevention.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 350 and ECIV 570.
name: Sustainable Construction for Engineers
description: Instruction to sustainable engineering design alternatives and principles for construction and site development from preconstruction through design and the construction phase.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better ECIV 350 and MATH 242.
name: Environmental Engineering Process Modeling
description: Modeling fate and transport phenomena in environmental processes with applications in engineered unit operators and natural systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 360 or ENCP 360.
name: Open Channel Hydraulics
description: Steady and unsteady flows in single or multiple-channel systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECIV 362.
name: Engineering Hydrology
description: Applications of hydrologic techniques to design problems; stormwater simulation models; urban stormwater.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 201 or ENCP 201; D or better in ECIV 362.
name: Subsurface Hydrology
description: Hydrologic cycle, subsurface physical properties, equations of groundwater flow, well flow, well design, groundwater resource development, design of dewatering systems, groundwater contamination.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Three from ECIV 320, ECIV 330, ECIV 340, ECIV 350, and ECIV 362.
name: Land Development for Engineers
description: Fundamentals of designing and permitting the conversion of land to new or altered states, including environmental issues, traffic and parking, utility resources, site engineering, ADA, safety, planning, and zoning requirements.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 320, ECIV 330, and ECIV 340.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECIV 303.
name: Railway Engineering I
description: Introduction to the analysis and design of the railway infrastructure for freight and passenger systems to include track and track support systems, grade crossings, special trackwork, construction, inspection, assessment and compliance.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ECIV 340.
name: Operation and Logistics of Railway Systems
description: Principles of rail operations; Network management; Best practices for train planning, performance management and delivery of service; technical elements of a railway from an operations perspective (train controls, signaling, communications, yards, tractive power etc).

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ECIV 330; D or better in ECIV 325 or ECIV 327.
name: Design of Railway Bridges and Structures
description: Introduction to railway infrastructure; Structural design considerations and criteria of railway structures; Bridge types and components; Planning and preliminary design of modern railway bridges; Loads and forces; Structural analysis and design of steel railway bridges and components.

name: Introduction to Classical Mythology
description: Major gods, goddesses, heroes, and heroines of classical mythology as portrayed in major literary works; the function of myth in society and its relevance to modern life.

name: Medical and Scientific Terminology
description: Greek and Latin elements in the formation of medical and scientific vocabulary; designed for students intending to enter the scientific and health professions. No previous knowledge of Greek or Latin required.

name: Sport and Combat in the Ancient World
description: This course is designed to introduce students to the importance of competition in the military and private spheres of the Greco-Roman world, a dominant legacy of antiquity.

name: Ancient Philosophy
description: An introduction to the work of ancient philosophers, with special emphasis on Plato and Aristotle.

name: Greek and Roman Philosophy after Aristotle
description: Problems such as hedonism, providence, belief and evidence, and mysticism, as they appear in the writings of Epicureans, Stoics, Skeptics, and Plotinus.

name: Greece and Rome in Film and Popular Culture
description: Representations of antiquity in cinema, television, and other contemporary media, with emphasis on Hollywood�€�s reception of Greek and Roman history.

name: Sexuality and Gender in Ancient Greece
description: Gender roles, standards of sexual behavior, evidence for women�€�s lives, as manifested in ancient Greek literary and archaeological evidence; attitudes toward homosexuality; the modern media�€�s representation of famous Greeks.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Sexuality, Gender, and Power in Ancient Rome
description: Sexuality as a social construct exemplified in standards of sexual behavior in ancient Rome and their reinforcement of the ruling ideology; feminine virtue, definitions of manliness, attitudes toward homosexuality.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Greek Civilization on Site
description: Introduction to the history and culture of ancient Greece, combined with an excursion of Greece. Topics include: Mycenaean Greece and the world of Homer, Archaic Greece, oikos and polis, interaction with the Near East, Athens in the 5th and 4th centruy BCE, Greek religion, ancient Greek society.

name: Special Topics in Classical Humanities
description: Intensive study of one topic per semester dealing with ancient contributions to Western civilization. Not for Greek or Latin major credit. In English. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Greek Art and Archaeology
description: A survey of ancient architecture, painting, and sculpture 2000-160 B.C.

name: Classical Origins of Western Medical Ethics
description: Examination of ancient Greek and Roman philosophical, medical, and literary works (in English) as sources for the origins of medical ethics. Priority enrollment for Medical Humanities students.

name: Between Magic and Method: Ancient Medicine
description: Introduction to ancient medicine: science and art, theory and practice, healing and predicting. Topics include Medicine before Hippocrates, Hippocratic medicine, holism, naturalism, medicine, religion and magic, medicine and scientific explanation, Hellenistic medicine and methodology, Galenic medicine.

name: Greek and Latin Literature in Translation
description: A comparative survey of Greek and Latin masters.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Classical Drama
description: Representative plays by Greek and Roman dramatists.

name: Rhetoric and the Ancient Roots of Modern Life
description: Classical rhetoric and its ongoing influence in the modern world, emphasizing how the study and use of language in ancient Greece and Rome continue to shape modern communication.

name: Classical Mythology
description: The major Greek and Roman myths, with emphasis on their meaning, functions, and influence on ancient and later Western culture.

name: Classics of Western Literary Theory
description: Problems of literary theory in texts from the ancients to the 17th century, with an emphasis on the classical tradition.

name: Interdisciplinary Special Topics in the Liberal Arts: Social Sciences
description: Interdisciplinary special topics emphasizing the social sciences. May be repeated as content varies by title and section.

name: Internship: Community Engagement
description: Supervised experience in the United States. Contract approval by instructor, advisor, and Assistant Dean for Academic Studies is required for undergraduate students. Minimum GPA of 2.5 required or permission of instructor of record.

name: Internship: Global Community Engagement
description: Supervised experience either while student is studying abroad or when offered an internship by an appropriate entity outside the United states. Contract approval by instructor and Assistant Dean for Academic Studies is required. Minimum GPA requirement of 2.5 or higher or permission of the instructor of record.

name: Interdisciplinary Seminar
description: Advanced reading and research on selected interdisciplinary topics in the liberal arts. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. Open only to juniors and seniors with consent of instructor.

name: Public Health Perspective in Communication Sciences and Disorders
description: Public health issues related to speech, language, and hearing from local, national and global perspective in historical context. Special permission required by department.

name: Directed Study in Speech and Language Pathology
description: Directed readings and/or research in speech pathology.

name: Introduction to Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology
description: Human communication disorders with an overview of prevention and treatment programs.

name: Anatomy and Physiology of Speech and Hearing Mechanisms
description: An intensive study of the anatomy and physiology of the speech and hearing mechanisms.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: COMD 501.
name: Anatomy and Physiology of the Auditory and Vestibular System
description: Detailed examination of the anatomy and physiology of the auditory and vestibular system.

name: Language Theory and Phonetics
description: Study of language theory and international phonetics alphabet transcription.

name: Introduction to Clinical Procedures in Speech Pathology
description: Diagnostic and therapeutic programs for the communicatively handicapped will be observed in the public school and various rehabilitative settings. Discussion and study of basic therapeutic theories and procedures utilized in speech therapy. Introduction to phonetics or equivalent or permission of instructor.

name: Selected Topics
description: Presentation of current experimental or innovative programs in diagnosis and treatment of the communicatively impaired. Course is designed to update the practicing clinician in specific areas of expertise. May be repeated for credit. Individual topics to be announced by title. Permission of instructor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: COMD 501 and COMD 507 or equivalents.
name: Disorders of Articulation: Evaluation and Therapy
description: The diagnosis and treatment of articulation problems in children and adults, including analysis of current research in testing and therapy for articulation disorders.

name: Principles of Audiology
description: Basic anatomy and psycho-physics of hearing, the pathologies of hearing loss, introduction to identification procedures including organization of hearing conservation programs and practice in pure-tone audiometry, and impact of hearing loss on preschool and school-age children and educational, psychological, and medical aspects of habilitation.

name: Observation of Speech Language Pathology
description: Introduction to the clinical process through observation of various diagnostic reports and intervention programs included.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: COMD 501 and COMD 507.
name: Introduction to Language Development
description: The language acquisition process in normal children, including the development of semantics, morphology, syntax, phonology, and pragmatics; American dialects and bilingualism.

name: Introduction to Computer Concepts
description: History, application, and social impact of computers; problem-solving, algorithm development, applications software, and programming in a procedural language.

name: General Applications Programming
description: Introduction to systematic computer problem-solving and programming for a variety of applications.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: MATH 111 or MATH 115.
name: Algorithmic Design I
description: Problem-solving, algorithmic design, and programming. Three lectures and two laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CSCE 145; C or better in MATH 111 or higher (or by Math Placement Test score into MATH 115 or higher math).
name: Algorithmic Design II
description: Continuation of CSCE 145. Rigorous development of algorithms and computer programs; elementary data structures. Three lecture hours and two laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Corequisite: CSCE 145, CSCE 204, CSCE 205, CSCE 206 or equivalent.
name: Computing in the Modern World
description: An introduction to the field of computing: trends in computing technology, the profession, and careers; subdisciplines in computing; the nature of research and development.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: CSCE 101 or CSCE 102 or CSCE 145.
name: Introduction to Computer Security
description: Introduction to the theory and practice of computer security, including security policies, authentification, digital certificates, firewalls, malicious code, legal and ethical issues, and incident handling.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGSC 290 or CSCE 101 or above.
name: Business Applications Programming
description: Introduction to computer applications in business. Programming exercises in COBOL.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 145 or CSCE 206.
name: UNIX System Administration
description: The Unix programming environment: I/O programming, Unix processes, fork, exec, pipes and signals, and tools.

name: Special Topics in Computer Programming
description: Programming and application development using selected programming languages. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in CSCE 145, CSCE 204, CSCE 205, CSCE 206, or CSCE 207.
name: Computer Hardware Foundations
description: Number representation, data formats, CPU and memory organization, assembly language, I/O and peripherals, computer networks. Students may not apply both CSCE 210 and CSCE 212 to any minor or major program of study.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 141.
name: Digital Logic Design
description: Number systems, Boolean algebra, logic design, sequential machines.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in CSCE 211 and D or better in either CSCE 145 or CSCE 206.
name: Introduction to Computer Architecture
description: Computer architecture, components. and organization; memory addressing; Input/Output; instruction sets; interrupts; assembly-language programming. Students may not apply both CSCE 210 and CSCE 212 to any minor or major program of study.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 145.
name: UNIX/Linux Fundamentals
description: UNIX operating system, user-level system commands, and programming tools. UNIX scripting languages.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 215, C or better in CSCE 146.
name: Advanced Programming Techniques
description: Pointers; memory management; advanced programming language structures: operator overloading, iterators, multiple inheritance, polymorphism, templates, virtual functions; Unix programming environment.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CSCE 146.
name: Web Applications
description: Web technologies to support client-server computing. Implementation of client-server applications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CSCE 146.
name: Object-Oriented Programming Techniques
description: Advanced object-oriented concepts and techniques; multiple inheritance; memory management; operator overloading; polymorphism; performance issues.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CSCE 146.
name: Software Engineering
description: Fundamentals of software design and development; software implementation strategies; object-oriented design techniques; functional design techniques; design patterns; design process; source control; testing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CSCE 240.
name: Robotic Applications and Design
description: Design and control of robots. Interactions between robots, sensing, actuation, and computation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 204 or MGSC 298.
name: Applied Problem Solving and Programming
description: Systematic problem definition, solution formulation, and computer implementation for business and related areas. Internet and database applications. Programming exercises in a high-level programming language.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 240; CSCE 210 or CSCE 212.
name: Operating Systems
description: Operating system structure and function; process implementation, scheduling, and synchronization; memory management; security; naming protection; resource allocation; network file systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 211, CSCE 212.
name: Embedded Systems
description: Fundamentals of embedded systems: hardware components, software components, hardware/software interface design, and hardware/software co-design.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 212, MATH 242, STAT 509.
name: Computer Systems Engineering
description: System-level modeling and evaluation of computer systems: requirements elicitation and specification, architectural design, reliability and performance evaluation, Markov modeling, life-cycle cost analysis, project management.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 240; MATH 174 or MATH 374 or MATH 574.
name: Programming Language Structures
description: Formal specification of syntax and semantics; structure of algorithms; list processing and string manipulation languages; statement types, control structures, and interfacing procedures.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in CSCE 240; D or better in MATH 174, MATH 374, or MATH 574; D or better in MATH 141 or MATH 122.
name: Data Structures and Algorithms
description: Techniques for representing and processing information, including the use of lists, trees, and graphs; analysis of algorithms; sorting, searching, and hashing techniques.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 211, CSCE 212, CSCE 350.
name: Foundations of Computation
description: Basic theoretical principles of computing as modeled by formal languages, grammars, automata, and Turing machines; fundamental limits of computation.

name: Professional Issues in Computer Science and Engineering
description: Professional issues in the information technology professions; history and social context of computing; professional responsibilities; privacy; intellectual property; risks and liabilities of computer-based systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ITEC 352 or CSCE 240.
name: Mainframe Systems
description: Introduction to the large scale computer systems used by businesses to support thousands of simultaneous users and process millions of transactions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 146.
name: Introduction to Computer Networks
description: Concepts and components of computer networks and the Internet; network applications; network protocol stack.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in CSCE 240.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in CSCE 350.
name: Capstone Computing Project I
description: Major team-based software design project to be undertaken in a student�€�s final year of study; project planning, software requirements analysis, design, and specification. Written reports and oral presentations in a technical setting.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in CSCE 240, CSCE 313, CSCE 611.
name: Capstone Computer Engineering Project
description: Advanced computer systems engineering. Team projects. Written reports and oral presentations in a technical setting.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in CSCE 240, CSCE 350, and CSCE 490.
name: Capstone Computing Project II
description: Continuation of CSCE 490. Computer system implementation, testing, verification and validation of results. Written reports and oral presentations in a technical setting.

name: Independent Study
description: Individual investigation or study of special topics. At most three credits may be applied toward a degree. Approval of project proposal by instructor and department advisor.

name: Computer Programming and Applications
description: Concepts and properties of algorithms; programming exercises with emphasis on good programming habits. Credit may not be received for both CSCE 500 and CSCE 145. Open to all majors. May not be used for major credit by computer science and engineering majors.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 215, CSCE 240.
name: System Programming
description: System software such as command language interpreters, client-server applications, debuggers; mail systems, browsers, macroprocessors, and revision control systems; file systems, processes, threads, and interprocess communication.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 311, STAT 509 or STAT 515.
name: System Performance Evaluation
description: Measuring, modeling, analyzing, and predicting performance of computer systems and networks; bottleneck analysis; Markovian queuing systems and networks; use of operational and probabilistic models.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 211, CSCE 212.
name: Computer Architecture
description: Design methodology; processor design; computer arithmetic: algorithms for addition, multiplication, floating point arithmetic; microprogrammed control; memory organization; introduction to parallel architectures.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 311.
name: Computer Network Programming
description: Computer networks and communication protocols; socket programming; interprocess communication; development of network software; case studies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: STAT 509 or STAT 515.
name: Computer Networks
description: Structure, design, and analysis of computer networks; ISO/OSI network architecture.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 215.
name: Computer Crime and Forensics
description: Structure, design, and analysis of computer networks; ISO/OSI network architecture.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 215 or previous Linux/UNIX experience.
name: Ethical Hacking
description: Fundamental principles and techniques of ethical hacking, including penetration testing life cycle, planning and scoping, identifying targets and goals, active and passive reconnaissance, enumeration and scanning, exploitation, post-exploitation, and results reporting.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 240 or GEOG 563.
name: Database System Design
description: Database management systems; database design and implementation; security, integrity, and privacy.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 146; MATH 374 or MATH 174.
name: Information Security Principles
description: Threats to information resources and appropriate countermeasures. Cryptography, identification and authentication, access control models and mechanisms, multilevel database security, steganography, Internet security, and intrusion detection and prevention.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 311.
name: Service Oriented Computing
description: Cooperative information systems and service-oriented computing. Techniques for achieving coordinated behavior among a decentralized group of information system components. Distributed databases, multiagent systems, conceptual modeling, Web services, and applications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 240.
name: Compiler Construction
description: Techniques for design and implementation of compilers, including lexical analysis, parsing, syntax-directed translation, and symbol table management.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 240 or previous programming experience with one of the following programming languages (C/C++, Java, Swift, Python, Matlab, Javascript).
name: Mobile Application Development
description: Development of mobile applications, including user interface design for mobile, local and cloud data storage techniques, and application architectures.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 240.
name: Windows Programming
description: Object-oriented methods and tools for application programming with graphically interactive operating systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 240.
name: Building Secure Software
description: Construction of software systems resistant to vulnerabilities and attacks. Cryptographic tools. Language, operating system, and network security. Case studies. Development of best practices through programming assignments.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CSCE 350 or MATH 300.
name: Theory of Computation
description: Basic theoretical principles of computing as modeled by formal languages and automata; computability and computational complexity

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 240, CSCE 350.
name: Computer Game Development
description: Design and development of computer games, with emphasis on the technologies used. Hands-on development of computer games.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 350.
name: Algorithms in Bioinformatics
description: Concepts, algorithms and tools for important problems in Bioinformatics, including nucleotide and amino acid sequence alignment, DNA fragment assembly, phylogenetic reconstruction, and protein structure visualization and assessment.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CSCE 145 or MATH 241, and at least one of CSCE 355, MATH 300 or MATH 374.
name: Introduction to Cryptography
description: Design of secret codes for secure communication, including encryption and integrity verification: ciphers, cryptographic hashing, and public key cryptosystems such as RSA. Mathematical principles underlying encryption. Code-breaking techniques. Cryptographic protocols.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better MATH 520 or in both MATH 242 and MATH 344.
name: Numerical Analysis
description: Interpolation and approximation of functions; solution of algebraic equations; numerical differentiation and integration; numerical solutions of ordinary differential equations and boundary value problems; computer implementation of algorithms.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 240, STAT 509 or STAT 515.
name: Systems Simulation
description: Computer simulation of real systems; principles of system organization; random number generation; programming exercises in a simulation language.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 526, CSCE 146 or CSCE 207 or CSCE 500.
name: Computational Science
description: Parallel algorithms; scientific visualization; techniques for solving scientific problems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 240, MATH 526 or MATH 544.
name: Introduction to Computer Graphics
description: Graphics hardware; graphics primitives; two-dimensional and three-dimensional viewing; basic modeling.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 145 or CSCE 206 or CSCE 207.
name: Visualization Tools
description: Scientific visualization tools as applied to sampled and generated data; methods for data manipulation and representation; investigation of visualization techniques.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: knowledge of programming in a high-level language; C or better in MATH 344 or MATH 544.
name: Parallel Computing
description: Architecture and interconnection of parallel computers; parallel programming models and applications; issues in high-performance computing; programming of parallel computers.

name: Critical Interactives
description: Foundational techniques in multidisciplinary software development, specifically of applications designed to present sensitive, sometimes controversial, materials in ways to engender empathic awareness of the interactor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Undergraduate or graduate standing in CSE or permission of the instructor.
name: Human-Computer Interaction
description: Interdisciplinary approach to interaction design, user-centered design, human abilities, survey development, experimental study methodology, heuristic evaluations, usability testing, universal design, and accessibility.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 211, CSCE 212, CSCE 240.
name: Robotics
description: Design and application of robotic systems; emphasis on mobile robots and intelligent machines.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 330, CSCE 355.
name: Text Processing
description: Text and natural language processing; formal models and data structures appropriate for text processing; selected topics in computational linguistics, stylistics, and content analysis.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 350.
name: Artificial Intelligence
description: Heuristic problem solving, theorem proving, and knowledge representation, including the use of appropriate programming languages and tools.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in either CSCE 106 or CSCE 145 and either STAT 509 or STAT 515.
name: Bayesian Networks and Decision Graphs
description: Normative approaches to uncertainty in artificial intelligence. Probabilistic and causal modeling with Bayesian networks and influence diagrams. Applications in decision analysis and support. Algorithms for probability update in graphical models.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CSCE 240 or CSCE 206.
name: Machine Learning Systems
description: Design and implementation of machine learning systems, Deep learning systems stack, machine learning platforms, scalable and distributed machine learning.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in STAT 301, STAT 509, STAT 513, or STAT 515.
name: Big Data Analytics
description: Foundational techniques and tools required for data science and big data analytics. Concepts, principles, and techniques applicable to any technology and industry for establishing a baseline that can be enhanced by future study.

name: Topics in Information Technology
description: Reading and research on selected topics in information technology. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of courses by title. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.

name: Strategic Management of Information Systems
description: Strategic management and use of information systems in organizations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 212.
name: Advanced Digital Design
description: Design techniques for logic systems; emphasis on higher-level CAD tools such as hardware description languages and functional modeling.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 211.
name: VLSI System Design
description: VLSI design process models, introduction to EDA tools, HDL modeling and simulation, logic synthesis and simulation, benchmark design projects.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ELCT 371.
name: Fundamentals of VLSI Chip Design
description: Design of VLSI circuits, including standard processes, circuit design, layout, and CAD tools. Lecture and guided design projects.

name: Values and Ethics in Literature
description: Analysis of major works of world literature focusing on values, ethics, and social responsibility.

name: World Literature
description: Selected masterpieces of world literature from antiquity to the present.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: any 200-level literature course.
name: What is Comparative Literature
description: Introduction to ways of reading and comparing literatures drawn from diverse languages and cultures.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Great Books of the Western World I
description: European masterpieces from antiquity to the beginning of the Renaissance.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Great Books of the Western World II
description: European masterpieces from the Renaissance to the present.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Great Books of the Eastern World
description: Classical and contemporary poetry and prose of the Middle and Far East.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Epic to Romance
description: Comprehensive exploration of medieval and other pre-Renaissance literature using texts representative of the evolution of dominant literary forms.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: The Renaissance
description: Literature of the Renaissance, in its cultural contexts, explored through representative works.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: The Enlightenment
description: Literature of the Enlightenment in its cultural contexts, explored through representative works.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Romanticism
description: Literature of Romanticism, in its cultural contexts, explored through representative works.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Realism
description: Literature of Realism in its cultural contexts, explored through representative works.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Modernism
description: Literature of Modernism in its cultural contexts, explored through representative works.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Postmodernism
description: Literature of Postmodernism in its cultural contexts, explored through representative works.

name: Topics in Comparative Literary Relations
description: Topics involving two or more national literatures. Topics to be announced in master schedule by title.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Senior Thesis
description: Graduation with Leadership Distinction: GLD: Research

name: Special Topics in Comparative Studies in Film and Media
description: Topics in film and media from an international perspective. National cinematic traditions are compared and contrasted. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Family Counseling
description: A comparative study of the major theories in the field of family counseling.

name: Educators in Industry
description: The course is designed to provide counselors, teachers, and administrators with increased awareness of a wide variety of work experiences.

name: Introduction to Counseling
description: Orientation to the profession of counseling including its historical, social, and cultural foundations. Declaration of the minor in counseling or admission to the Ed.S. in Counselor Education.

name: Wellness and Mental Health
description: An overview of the characteristics of optimal holistic wellness and human functioning. Practical application of theoretically and empirically supported wellness models and interventions to enhance social, emotional, mental, physical, and spiritual well-being.

name: Theory and Practice of College Mentoring
description: Emphasis on current professional approaches to college mentoring and development of leadership and mentoring skills. Students must participate in Minority Assistance Program. Upper division undergraduate standing or admission to a graduate program and consent of instructors.

name: Seminar in Counseling
description: A seminar focusing on current professional issues in counseling.

name: Communication Skills in Counseling
description: Human relations principles applied to the counseling interview.

name: Counseling Student Athletes
description: Issues facing student athletes regarding their personal and career development beyond athletics.

name: The American Criminal Justice System
description: Survey of crime and societal responses to crime, including law enforcement, courts, corrections, and the juvenile justice system.

name: Research Methods in Criminology and Criminal Justice
description: Introduction to the practice of social research in criminology and criminal justice settings.

name: Policing
description: Current and historical perspectives on American policing.

name: Corrections
description: Current and historical perspectives on incarceration and its alternatives.

name: Criminal Courts
description: Structure and organization of the federal and state criminal court systems and personnel.

name: Criminal Law
description: Origin and development of criminal law in America. Basic elements of crimes and defenses.

name: Drugs and Crime
description: Overview of criminal justice system responses to illegal substances. Relationship between substance abuse and crime.

name: Violence in America
description: Historical overview of violence in American society, including theoretical perspectives on the causes and prevention of violence.

name: Sociology of Crime
description: Social factors in the development, identification, and treatment of criminals.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CRJU 101 OR SOCY 101.
name: Juvenile Delinquency
description: Social factors in the development, identification, and treatment of delinquents.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and Office of Academic Programs is required for undergraduate students.

name: Analyzing Homicide
description: Relationships between patterns and trends in homicide, and theoretical explanations for why offenders engage in homicide.

name: Victimization
description: Causes and consequences of criminal victimization and public policy responses to victimization issues.

name: Alternatives to Incarceration
description: Correctional alternatives to imprisonment including probation, parole, and various community correctional programs.

name: Street Gangs: Structure, Activity, and Response
description: Course covers the theoretical and empirical work on gangs, gang members, and gang activity along with insight on these issues from a practitioner perspective. It then examines the variety of policy responses from government and community organizations.

name: Criminal Justice Intelligence
description: An investigation of the motivations to commit crime. The course presents profiles of the targets of crimes and provides strategic and tactical assessments of police investigations and intelligence.

name: Hate Crimes
description: An examination of the causes and responses to hate crimes. The course also provide a foundation for understanding crimes motivated by racial, gender, religious, disability, and sexual orientation biases.

name: Criminal Justice and Mental Health
description: Interface between the mental health sciences and the criminal justice system.

name: Communities and Crime
description: Relationship between criminality and community characteristics, with particular attention to how variation in community structure, organization, and culture impacts crime.

name: Homeland Security and Terrorism
description: The nature of terrorism; its history; its methodology; and its application to criminological theory.

name: Selected Topics in Criminal Justice Policy
description: Public policy responses to crime, its formation, and its impact on society. Individual topics to be announced by title. May be repeated with consent of advisor.

name: Special Topics
description: Topics in criminology and criminal justice. Individual topics to be announced by title. May be repeated once with consent of advisor.

name: Internship
description: A supervised experiential course in a criminal justice agency. Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and Office of Academic Programs is required for undergraduate students.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Critical Incident Management for Criminal Justice
description: Leadership and management strategies for criminal justice agencies during critical incidents and disasters including multi-agency and multi-jurisdictional response.

name: Information-Based Management in Criminal Justice
description: The collection and use of information and data-driven analysis in criminal justice organizations.

name: Inmates and Prisons
description: Examination of issues affecting prisons and the inmates confined within them. Specific topics of study will include the philosophy and goals of imprisonment, institutional crowding, inmate rights, inmate adaptation, and individual and collective misconduct.

name: Adolescent Mentoring
description: Application of skills and theories of adolescent mentoring taught in the classroom to a supervised, structured mentoring field experience.

name: Women, Gender, and Crime
description: Impact of gender-based relations on crime and the criminal justice system.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Crime Over the Life Course
description: Development of criminal and delinquent behavior over time.

name: Race, Crime, and Criminal Justice
description: An historical overview of the intersection between issues of race, crime, and justice. The impact of the criminal justice system on minority groups.

name: Organized Crime
description: Origins and modern day activity of organized crime in the United States and internationally will be investigated. Attention is given to problems of criminal activity and the present day transnational character of criminal organizations.

name: The Death Penalty
description: Overview of the history and evolution of the death penalty. Identification of key legal developments in death penalty jurisprudence.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CRJU 313 or CRJU 314.
name: Law and Criminal Justice Policy
description: Legal and policy responses to crime and criminal justice issues.

name: Computer Applications in Criminal Justice
description: Computing, database systems, and software applications in research and professional practice.

name: Selected Topics in Criminal Justice
description: A seminar for advanced students. Individual topics to be announced by title. May be repeated once with the consent of the advisor.

name: Solving Practical Problems in School Curriculum
description: An introduction to current and promising designs and approaches to curriculum development from grades K-12.

name: Dance Appreciation
description: An eclectic survey of various dance forms including primitive, historic, ballet, modern, and Broadway musical.

name: Ballet Technique I
description: A beginning study of ballet with emphasis on alignment, classical historical traditions, and combinations or movement. This course is for dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

name: Ballet Technique I
description: A beginning study of ballet with emphasis on alignment, classical historical traditions, and combinations or movement. This course is for dance minors and non dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

name: The Dancer's Body
description: Anatomy and movement analysis for dancers.

name: World Dance I
description: World Dance is dance experience in diverse world dance forms. This course is for dance majors and minors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

name: World Dance I
description: World Dance is dance experience in diverse world dance forms. This course is for non dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

name: Contemporary Dance Technique I
description: An introduction to modern dance with the beginning practice of movement technique. This course is for dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

name: Contemporary Dance Technique I
description: An introduction to modern dance with the beginning practice of movement technique. This course is for dance minors and non dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

name: World Dance II
description: World Dance is dance experience in diverse world dance forms. This course is for dance majors and minors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

name: World Dance II
description: World Dance is dance experience in diverse world dance forms. This course is for non dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

name: Introduction to Dance
description: Introduction to dance as art, communication, and cultural expression as it applies to a career in dance. Open to non-majors.

name: Dance Improvisation and Composition
description: An introductory course on dance composition and the creative process. Exploration and improvisation of different dance forms; specific choreographic tools. This course is for dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

name: Dance Improvisation and Composition
description: An introductory course on dance composition and the creative process. Exploration and improvisation of different dance forms; specific choreographic tools. This course is for dance minors and non dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

name: Ballroom Dance I
description: Introduction of six major dances (Foxtrot, Waltz, Tango, Cha Cha, Swing, and Rumba) to students with no dance experience. The emphasis will be on learning dance figures and patterns.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: DANC 170 or equivalent.
name: Ballroom Dance II
description: Intermediate steps will include challenging choreography or patterns. The emphasis in technique will be based on developing speed and elegance while dancing complex patterns.

name: Dance Company I
description: This course is designed for rehearsals leading to dance performances; and including student choreography, on stage productions, the dance touring ensemble and components of dance production. Repeat seven times.

name: Jazz Dance Technique I
description: A beginning level class focusing on coordination, rhythm, alignment, jazz vocabulary, and jazz dance positions. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in DANC 102A.
name: Ballet Technique II
description: Second level of classical ballet technique facilitating skill in allegro and adagio work. This course is for dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in DANC 102B.
name: Ballet Technique II
description: Second level of classical ballet technique facilitating skill in allegro and adagio work. This course is for dance minors and non dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: DANC 202 or equivalent.
name: Pointe II
description: Pointe technique and skills on pointe, an extension of ballet technique at the foundational level. May be repeated four times.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in DANC 112A or placement audition.
name: Contemporary Dance Technique II
description: A second level of contemporary technique, with emphasis on skill refinement and aesthetic elements. This course is for dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in DANC 112B or placement audition.
name: Contemporary Dance Technique II
description: A second level of contemporary technique, with emphasis on skill refinement and aesthetic elements. This course is for dance minors and non dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: DANC 160.
name: Laban Movement Analysis
description: An examination of Laban Movement analysis �€“ a language for understanding, observing, describing and notating all forms of movement. Experiential, analytical and performance teaching methods will be used.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C+ or better in DANC 150 and DANC 160A.
name: Introduction to Dance Education
description: An overview of state and national standards, theoretical and philosophical perspectives that shape current practices for teaching dance in K-12 environments, and arts/dance education advocacy.

name: Pilates I
description: Innovative system of exercises for the mind and body. Teaching posture, body awareness, and easy graceful movement at a beginner�€�s level.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: DANC 178.
name: Jazz Dance Technique II
description: An intermediate level class focusing on coordination, rhythm, alignment, jazz vocabulary, jazz dance positions, and expanded knowledge of theatrical jazz dance. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

name: Dance History I
description: Overview of the development of dance through the 19th century.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: DANC 281.
name: Dance History II
description: Development of dance from the 20th century to the present.

name: Music for Dancers
description: Rhythmic analysis, reading and metric patterns, construction and use of scores from musical theatre to symphonic orchestration with exercises to enhance the knowledge of relationship between dance and music.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in DANC 202A.
name: Ballet Technique III
description: Third level of classical ballet technique. This course is for dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in DANC 202B.
name: Ballet Technique III
description: Third level of classical ballet technique. This course is for dance minors and non dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: DANC 202 or equivalent.
name: Pointe III
description: Pointe technique and skills on pointe, an extension of ballet technique at the intermediate level. Study and execution of female variations from classical repertory. May be repeated four times.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: permission of instructor.
name: Intermediate Tap Dance
description: Advanced fundamentals of tap dance, including intermediate/advanced rhythmic structure and incorporation of alignment and style.

name: West African Dance I
description: The history and practice of indigenous West African dance.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: DANC 281 and DANC 282.
name: Dance Analysis and Criticism
description: Theoretical practices and cultural perspectives of dance making.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in DANC 212A.
name: Contemporary Dance Technique III
description: A third level technique with refinement skills, and complex combinations. This course is for dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in DANC 212B.
name: Contemporary Dance Technique III
description: A third level technique with refinement skills, and complex combinations. This course is for dance minors and non dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: DANC 260; recommend students to have completed at least three semesters of technique.
name: Choreography I
description: An intermediate level choreography and composition course designed to create and adapt work in different dance forms in modern, jazz, and ballet.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C+ or better in DANC 160A or DANC 160B and DANC 360; it is recommended that students have completed at least three semesters of ballet and contemporary technique and world dance.
name: Creative Dance
description: An introduction to motor development, movement concepts, elements, and skills that contribute to lesson planning, instruction, and assessment of creative dance in K-12 education.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: DANC 275 or equivalent.
name: Pilates II
description: Innovative system of exercises for the mind and body. Teaching posture, body awareness, and easy graceful movement at an intermediate level.

name: Historic Dance
description: A course open to all students interested in gaining knowledge of early dances from the 15th Basse, Pavanne and Gaillarde of the Renaissance era to the Baroque dances from the court of Louis XIV.

name: Jazz Dance Technique III
description: Advanced-level jazz dance technique. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

name: Movement and Dance for Musical Theatre
description: Styles of movement and dance in musical theatre from the �€�20s, �€�30s, and �€�40s to modern contemporary musical theatre. Choreographing for musicals, cultural forms of dance, staging for vocal pieces.

name: Dance History
description: A survey of dance from ethnic and social to professional dance, from the time of the Greeks through the twentieth century.

name: Body Conditioning/Gyrokinesis Method
description: Body conditioning technique designed to increase strength, flexibility, and coordination, enhancing the dance students�€� performance ability and body awareness.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 4 semesters of ballet or equivalent.
name: Men's Ballet
description: Study of the art of classical ballet for men with increased emphasis on facilitating skill in allegro and adagio work specific to male technique.

name: Dance Studio Operation
description: Advanced training methods and techniques in all forms of dance. Emphasis on recent research in dance curriculum and operational technique. For experienced dance teachers.

name: Independent Study and Research
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in DANC 302A.
name: Ballet Technique IV
description: Intensive fourth level of classical ballet technique. This course is for dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in DANC 302B.
name: Ballet Technique IV
description: Intensive fourth level of classical ballet technique. This course is for dance minors and non dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

name: Pointe Variations for Intermediate/Advanced Ballet
description: Pointe technique, an extension of ballet technique skills on pointe. Study and execution of female variations from classical repertory. May be repeated four times.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: DANC 307.
name: West African Dance II
description: Study of the development of West African music and dance, emphasizing cultural, social, and physical influences. Exploration of the relationship between dancer and the drummer at an intermediate level.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in DANC 312A.
name: Contemporary Dance Technique IV
description: Intensive advanced level contemporary dance technique. This course is for dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in DANC 312B.
name: Contemporary Dance Technique IV
description: Intensive advanced level contemporary dance technique. This course is for dance minors and non dance majors. May be repeated up to six times for credit.

name: Teaching Methods of Ballet
description: The foundations of ballet technique are analyzed systematically. Students will learn to teach ballet technique and organize course work for all levels. Recommend students to have completed at least four semesters of ballet technique.

name: Teaching Methods of Contemporary Dance
description: The foundations of contemporary dance technique are analyzed systematically. Students will learn to teach contemporary dance technique and organize course work for all levels. Recommend students to have completed at least four semesters of contemporary dance technique.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: DANC 302 or equivalent.
name: Pas de Deux (Partnering)
description: Study of the art of classical ballet pas de deux for men and women. Special attention will include adagio work from classical ballet repertory and contemporary dance.

name: Musical Theatre Workshop
description: Intensive musical theatre training in areas of song interpretation, musical theatre, dance, voice and acting.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: DANC 160 and three semesters of technique courses.
name: Choreography II
description: An intermediate level choreography course to further examine choreographic construction methods.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C+ or better in DANC 160A or DANC 160B, DANC 360 and DANC 370.
name: Dance Pedagogy for Middle and High School
description: Intensive study of content and strategies for teaching dance in middle and high school with particular emphasis on curriculum development, instruction, and assessment.

requisiteText: Corequisite: DANC 479.
name: Internship Seminar in Dance Education
description: Seminar allows students to synthesize content and skills from all previous dance and education coursework in conjunction with their student teaching experience.

name: Inner Mastery Through Movement
description: A mind/body integration course designed for performing artists.

name: Production Design for Dance
description: Technical theatre functions, the structure and purpose of production design, and stage production as it relates to the whole of dance and theatrical performance.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C+ or better in DANC 370 and DANC 470.
name: Integrated Approaches in Dance Education
description: Study and application of strategies for teaching diverse learners, implementation of instructional technology in the dance classroom, and dance/arts integration.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: Must have fulfilled all other program requirements except DANC 471 (and DANC 479), be admitted to the professional program, and approved for student teaching.
Corequisite: DANC 471.
name: Teaching Internship in Dance Education
description: Practical demonstration of pedagogical knowledge, skill, and dispositions necessary to effectively teach in K-12 dance education as defined and measured by CAEP and ADEPT standards.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: DANC 382.
name: Body Conditioning/Gyrokinesis Method II
description: Body conditioning technique that simultaneously stretches and strengthens the body at an intermediate level. Gyrokinesis teaches complete freedom of movement through exercises synchronized with corresponding breathing patterns enhancing aerobic and cardiovascular stimulation and promoting neuromuscular awareness. Restricted to dance majors/minors only.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: DANC 160 and DANC 360.
name: Senior Capstone Dance Project
description: Culmination of the performance/choregraphy dance emphasis. Senior project encompassing a choreographic work or research thesis.

name: Selected Topics in Dance
description: A series of courses, each lasting one-third of a semester. Topics and required courses are announced in the class schedule for each semester.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: graduate standing or three credits in dance.
name: Dancer's Workshop
description: Individual advanced training in movement, improvisation, flexibility, and precision in dance styles including modern and ballet.

name: Dance Performance
description: Rehearsal, choreographic analysis, and dance performance. All components of dance production--including music, costume, lighting, and scenery--will be considered.

name: The Articulate Body
description: Theoretical and experimental exploration of the major body systems and development movements to bring more articulation to the body and more awareness and physical ease in performance.

name: Special Topics in Dance
description: Reading and research on selected topics. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated once as topics vary.

name: Inquiry into Early Childhood Education
description: Inquiry into the roles, programs, history, and culture trends in early childhood education.

name: Play and Early Learning
description: Theory and practice related to children�€�s play and early learning in family, community, and educational settings.

name: Culturally Relevant Pedagogy in Early Childhood Classrooms
description: A study of the theoretical and practical foundations of effective teaching in diverse classroom environments. Ethnicity, gender, social class, religion and other issues are considered from multiple perspectives.

requisiteText: Corequisite: EDEC 340P.
name: The Young Child: Development, Care and Education (Birth to 3 years)
description: Infants�€� and toddlers�€� development and care from an ecological perspective. Assessment of children in various settings is emphasized.

requisiteText: Corequisite: EDEC 340.
name: The Young Child: Development, Care and Education (Birth to 3 years) Practicum
description: Practicum in infants�€� and toddlers�€� development and care observed and assessed from an ecological perspective. Includes service learning.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in EDEC 340 and EDEC 340P.
Corequisite: EDEC 344, EDEC 347 and EDEC 345.
name: The Young Child: Development, Care and Education (3-8 years)
description: Study and practicum in culturally relevant child development, ages 3-8, and applying this knowledge as foundational in early childhood assessment and practice.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: EDEC 340 and 340P.
Corequisite: EDEC 342, EDEC 344, EDEC 347 and EDRD 345.
name: The Young Child: Development, Care and Education (3-8 years) Practicum
description: Practicum in development, assessment, and education of young children with an emphasis on mathematics, science, and social studies.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Corequisite: EDEC 342, EDEC 342P, EDEC 347 and EDRD 345.
name: Supporting Linguistic Pluralism Across Content Areas
description: Introduction to issues, ideas, practices and policies in support of learning and teaching in multilingual classrooms, pre-K to grade 12 for undergraduate early childhood education majors. Early Childhood Majors Only.

requisiteText: Corequisite: EDEC 342, EDEC 342P, EDEC 344 and EDEC 345.
name: Community of Learners and Classroom Management in Early Childhood
description: Methods of building a community of learners including child guidance and group management that foster the development of self-control and learning.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: Admission to Internship I.
Corequisite: EDEC 443.
name: Teaching Mathematics in Early Childhood
description: Methods and materials in teaching and assessment in early childhood mathematics (prekindergarten-grade 3).

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: Admission to internship in early childhood education.
Corequisite: EDEC 443.
name: Teaching Science in Early Childhood Education
description: The study and practice of science education for pre-school and primary students focusing on appropriate content, goals and methods.

requisiteText: Corequisite: EDEC 441, EDEC 442 and EDRD 445.
name: Internship in Integrated Curriculum in Early Childhood Education
description: Internship in developmentally and culturally appropriate content and pedagogy in language and literacy, mathematics, science, social studies, and fine arts for young children through grade 3. Admission to internship in early childhood education.

name: Teaching Social Studies to Early Childhood Education
description: The study and practice of Social Studies education for undergraduate majors in early childhood education. Early Childhood Majors Only.

name: Internship in Curriculum, Assessment, Teaching, and Professional Roles
description: Internship for practice in classrooms appropriate to the level of certification sought (early childhood) related to professional roles. Admission to the Professional Program in Early Childhood Education.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: The Young Child: Behavior and Development in Early Childhood
description: Service-learning and seminar experiences addressing intellectual, physical, social, and emotional development, prenatal through grade three, within an ecological context. Child�€�s critical thinking, creative expression, and diagnosis/assessment emphasized.

requisiteText: Corequisite: EDEC 469.
name: Education of Young Children: An Ecological Approach
description: An ecological study with emphasis on home-school relations, parent involvement, and community resources. Multicultural perspectives and needs of exceptional children addressed.

name: Field Problems: Teaching Mathematics Using Manipulative Materials, Grades K-3
description: Instructional approaches and materials for teaching elementary school mathematics, grades K-3.

name: Internship in Environments for Teaching and Learning
description: Internship for practice in classrooms appropriate to early childhood education related to curriculum design and assessment. Admission to the professional program in early childhood education.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Parent Involvement in Early Childhood Education
description: Analysis of programs and practices for involving parents in early childhood educational settings. Emphasizes objectives, methods, techniques, and materials for program development. Community resources for supporting programs for children in various instructional settings.

name: The American Economy
description: Basic concepts, institutional foundations, structure of the private and public sector, labor markets; major economic problems.

name: Principles of Microeconomics
description: The study of supply and demand, pricing and cost concepts, firm and consumer decision-making, market structure, and government policies.

name: Principles of Macroeconomics
description: The study of gross domestic product, business cycles, economic growth, inflation, unemployment, and monetary and fiscal policy.

name: Introduction to Economics
description: Introduction to economics principles for non-majors. Basics of supply and demand and government and monetary policy are covered in a non-technical manner. Not open to business or economics students. Credit not granted for both ECON 223 and ECON 221 or ECON 222.

name: Introduction to Economics
