description: The study of supply and demand, markets, household and firm decision-making, gross domestic product, inflation, unemployment, and government policies. Open to all students except business administration and economics majors.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Money and Banking
description: The role of money in the market economy. Commercial banks, the Federal Reserve System, and monetary policy. Cannot be used to satisfy major requirements.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 224.
name: The International Economy
description: Survey of international economic issues and institutions, including trade and protectionism, global and regional trade agreements, trade balances and exchange rates, Japan, NAFTA, and the European Union.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Issues in Economics
description: The nature and causes of major economic problems facing the nation and its communities, and policy alternatives designed to solve them. The philosophy and methodology of economics in social problem solving.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224, MATH 122 or MATH 141.
name: Intermediate Microeconomic Theory
description: Analysis of the economic behavior of households and firms. Production, consumption, price determination, and the degree of competition in markets.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224, MATH 122 or MATH 141.
name: Intermediate Macroeconomic Theory
description: Analysis of the national economy as a whole. Money, output, employment, inflation, and international economic linkages.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: American Economic History
description: Growth and development of the American economy; applications of economic theory to economic history.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221, ACCT 225, and 3 hours of statistics at the 200-level.
name: Business Finance
description: The procurement and management of wealth by privately owned profit-seeking enterprises.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Financial Institutions
description: A study of the functions and operations of financial institutions and their relationships to the commercial banking system and the general economy. Attention is devoted to savings institutions, insurance companies, rural and urban real estate credit, consumer credit, and associated topics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Government Policy Toward Business
description: An analysis of public policy toward business in the United States. Emphasis is on the desirability of various policies in light of their consequences for the general welfare.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and undergraduate division head is required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Money, Income, and Prices
description: A study of monetary standards, monetary theory, monetary policy, and the mechanism of international payments. Attention is devoted to questions of monetary problems, employment, and fiscal policy.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Labor Economics
description: A study of labor market institutions, trends in labor market activity, and the effects of government policy on the labor market. (Not open to majors in economics.)

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: History of Economic Thought
description: A survey of economics from the ancient philosophers to the present; with emphasis on the mercantilist, physiocratic, classical, Marxian, Austrian, neo-classical, and institutional schools of economics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Economics of American Industry
description: A study of the structure of selected American industries, of the development and concentration of economic power in the American economy, and of public policy toward industry.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Business Applications of Economic Forecasting
description: Analysis of business cycles and applications of forecasting techniques to project and interpret economic trends.

name: Engineering Economics
description: Decision making with respect to capital goods, with emphasis on such decision making in governmental activities and public utilities. Intended primarily for engineering students, the course emphasizes the types of investment decisions that engineers are often called upon to make.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 224, or ECON 221 and ECON 222; MGSC 291 or STAT 201; and MATH 122 or MATH 141.
name: Introductory Econometrics
description: The use of statistical techniques to analyze economic relationships. The emphasis is on the application of linear regression to real-world economic data.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 211 and ECON 222.
name: Foundations of Capitalism
description: Examines the foundations of capitalism and why it has prevailed over alternative systems. Topics include the justification of private property, distribution of wealth, profit motive, source of wealth creation, and others.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both ECON 321 and ECON 322, and cumulative GPA of 2.75.
name: Internship in Economics
description: Supervised work experience of at least nine hours per week, to include one class meeting a month and individual consultation. Contract approval by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required. Cannot be used to satisfy major requirement.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Urban Economics
description: An analysis of economic forces affecting urbanization and the economic processes influencing urban form and structure. Spatial concepts are considered in addition to traditional micro-economic and macro-economic concepts. Topic coverage includes: the economic origin of cities; urban functions and the urban economic base, land-use structure and urban form, and urban efficiency.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 321.
name: International Trade Economics
description: Theory of international specialization, commercial policy, customs unions, and the effects of trade liberalization and protectionism; economic growth and multinational enterprises.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ECON 322.
name: International Monetary Economics
description: Exchange rate and balance of payments determination; purchasing-power parity; optimum currency areas, absorption, elasticity, monetary approaches, spot- and forward-exchange markets.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: International Development Economics
description: Economic theories of growth in developing countries. Use of factor resources; role of social and economic institutions; use of financial trade policies for growth.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224; ECON 321.
name: Labor Economics and Labor Markets
description: Economics of labor demand, labor supply, wage determination in competitive markets, migration, discrimination, unemployment, and labor unions. Theoretical models and empirical knowledge will be considered.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Comparative Economic Systems
description: An analysis of the organization and operation of the world�€�s major economic systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Law and Economics
description: Economic analysis and interpretation of the law. The economic effect of current law and optimal design of law to meet social objectives.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in the following ECON 221 and ECON 222; or ECON 224; MATH 122.
name: Economics of Sustainable Development
description: Exploration of the basic theory and practice of sustainable economic development. Topics include: environmental legislation, global agreements, sustainable development indicators, and economic strategies and methods to promote environmentally sound development.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in ECON 321.
name: Experimental Economics
description: Exploration of the basic theory and techniques of experimental economics. Topics include: basic game theory, experimental design, and elements of behavioral economic thought.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 321, ECON 322, and ECON 436 with grade of C or higher.
name: Senior Seminar in Economics
description: Philosophy and methodology of economics, perspectives on theory and empiricism, economic policy; individualized guided research.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ECON 321.
name: The Economics of Terrorism
description: Focuses on the following aspects of terrorism: (1) its causes/determinants (historical, social, cultural, economic, political, and religious determinants); (2) the organizational and funding structure of terrorist groups; (3) the tactics and weapons of terrorist groups; (4) mobilization and recruitment within terror networks; and (5) counterterrorism methods. Restricted to: Business Majors and Economics Arts and Sciences Majors.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 321.
name: Industrial Organization
description: This course uses the tools of microeconomics and game theory to examine how firms compete and competition�€�s impact on industry performance. Topics include: price discrimination, product differentiation, and oligopoly behavior.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224; MATH 122, MATH 141, or the equivalent.
name: Introduction to Mathematical Economics
description: Mathematical formulation of economic theories; the use of mathematics in the development and demonstration of economic relationships.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Essentials of Economics
description: A course designed to acquaint the student with the principles of operation of the American economic system. A survey course for social studies teachers in secondary schools.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Managerial Economics
description: A study of the application of the economic theory of profits, competition, demand, and costs to analysis of problems arising in the firm and in decision making. Price policies, forecasting, and investment decisions are among the topics considered.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: The Economics of Education
description: Investment in human capital; the economic value of schooling; internal efficiency of schools; faculty compensation; equity and efficiency of school finance systems; financing higher education.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Health Economics
description: Applications of economic analysis to health care. Structure and behavior of health-care markets. Description of health care policy issues.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Environmental Economics
description: An analysis of the economics aspects of environmental decay, pollution control, and natural resource use. Analysis of the ability of the market system to allocate resources efficiently when economic activity is accompanied by environmental damage. Discussion of alternative public policy approaches to pollution control and natural resource conservation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 321 or MATH 141 and STAT 201 or C or higher in STAT 206.
name: Game Theory in Economics
description: Game theory as used to understand decision making in business, economics, politics and other real-world environments. Topics covered include: basic terminology; strategic, extensive, and combinatorial models; and equilibrium strategy.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in ECON 321.
name: Public Finance
description: Theory and practice of taxation: public revenue, expenditure, and debt.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Topics in Economics
description: Individual topics to be announced with title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ECON 436.
name: Advanced Econometrics
description: Advanced econometric methods including quasi-experimental methods, applications of machine learning to causal inference and economic forecasting, and related topics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Survey of Contemporary Economic Theory
description: Neo-classical value and distribution theory combined with income and employment theory.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Quantitative Foundations for Business and Economics I
description: Calculus and classical optimization methods applied to problems in business and economic analysis; matrices, derivatives, and integrals in the analysis of both univariate and multivariate business and economic models.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224; MGSC 690 or ECON 690.
name: Quantitative Foundations for Business and Economics II
description: Statistics and probability theory applied to problems of business and economic analysis.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Quantitative Methods I
description: Probability and statistics necessary for graduate study in economics and business administration; estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, analysis of variance, and nonparametric methods.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224; ECON 692, mathematics and computer portion of Fundamental Business Skills or equivalent.
name: Quantitative Methods II
description: A study of decision models useful in business administration. Topics covered include linear programming, sensitivity analysis and duality, network models, integer programming, determinate and stochastic dynamic programming, inventory, and queues.

name: Schools in Communities
description: Social, political, and historical aspects of diverse educational institutions in American culture with an emphasis on families, schools, and communities. Sophomore standing.

name: Dynamics of American Public Education
description: Extensive treatment of the social, political, economic, and philosophical influences that have shaped public education. Analysis of the financial, organizational, and legal aspects of education. Library assignments provide a working knowledge of professional standard references and journals. Junior or higher standing.

name: Antiracist Education
description: Basic concepts, issues, and practices of antiracist education. Topics include individual and institutional racism, overt and covert racism, curriculum, textbooks, power relationships, teacher-student relationships, and privacy.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Sociology of Education
description: Analysis of educational institutions, organizations, processes, and their effects in contemporary society.

name: Comparative and International Education
description: Understanding of schooling in a global society. An introduction to comparative and international education and its major theories practices and research methodologies with an examination of educational issues, levels and system in a variety of cultural contexts and countries.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Historical Foundations of American Educational Thought
description: A survey of the history, philosophy, administration, and legal bases of American education.

name: Southern Educational History
description: Development of educational institutions in Southern society with special attention given to South Carolina.

name: USC Teaching Fellows Leadership Seminar
description: A resource for members of the Teaching Fellows Program to successfully complete yearly program requirements. Topics include: qualities of an effective teacher, how to give constructive classroom feedback, students' needs decision making, leadership styles, valuing diversity, and factors that influence/contribute to effective teacher leadership. Restricted to students enrolled in the USC Teaching Fellows Program. Instructor permission only.

name: Global and Multicultural Perspectives on Education in International Settings
description: Study abroad course in which students apply social science knowledge and analytical methods to understand the ways in which culture, society, politics, and global forces affect education and schooling in diverse international settings. May be repeated as content varies by destination.

name: Case Study in Classroom Management
description: Case study in the clinical application of pedagogy and methods related to classroom management, including relational, procedural and instructional aspects of a classroom management approach.

name: Field Problems in Education I
description: Selected educational problems will be identified and explored, and probable solutions developed. Emphasis will be on providing practicing school personnel an opportunity to work cooperatively, under supervision, toward solutions to those problems which are of immediate concern to them. Activities will include seminars, review of literature, observations, case studies, materials development, and other applicable approaches. Emphasis will be placed on the development of a comprehensive proposal designed to alleviate or solve the problems identified.

name: Field Problems in Education II
description: Selected educational problems will be identified and explored, and probable solutions developed. Emphasis will be on providing practicing school personnel an opportunity to work cooperatively, under supervision, toward solutions to those problems which are of immediate concern to them. Activities will include seminars, review of literature, observations, case studies, materials development, and other applicable approaches. Emphasis will be placed on the development of a comprehensive proposal designed to alleviate or solve the problems identified.

name: Field Problems in Education III
description: Selected educational problems will be identified and explored, and probable solutions developed. Emphasis will be on providing practicing school personnel an opportunity to work cooperatively, under supervision, toward solutions to those problems which are of immediate concern to them. Activities will include seminars, review of literature, observations, case studies, materials development, and other applicable approaches. Emphasis will be placed on the development of a comprehensive proposal designed to alleviate or solve the problems identified.

name: Field Problems in Education IV
description: Selected educational problems will be identified and explored, and probable solutions developed. Emphasis will be on providing practicing school personnel an opportunity to work cooperatively, under supervision, toward solutions to those problems which are of immediate concern to them. Activities will include seminars, review of literature, observations, case studies, materials development, and other applicable approaches. Emphasis will be placed on the development of a comprehensive proposal designed to alleviate or solve the problems identified.

name: Introduction to Child Growth and Development
description: Basic course designed to familiarize the prospective teacher with the patterns of social, emotional, physical, and intellectual growth of the individual. Development of these growth patterns from the prenatal stage to the onset of adolescence.

name: Introduction to Adolescent Growth and Development
description: Basic course designed to familiarize the prospective junior and senior high school teacher with the pattern of social, emotional, physical, and intellectual growth of the individual during his adolescent years. Recommendation of the advisor(s) required.

name: Introduction to Educational Psychology
description: Applications of the psychology of learning and development. Special attention to basic statistics and the behavior of the school child.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Learners and the Diversity of Learning
description: Overview of psychological theories and research as it applies to education, including theories of learning, child and adolescent development, cognitive processes, classroom practices, individual differences/student diversity, and motivation.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Practicum: Learners and the Diversity of Learning
description: Field experience integrated with course on lifespan development and learning with an emphasis on individual and group diversity.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Free-Choice Learning and Informal Learning Environments
description: Examines free-choice (or informal) learning and the characteristics of settings and activities outside of formal schooling that effectively promote learning and development.

name: Design and Development Tools I
description: Study of multimedia elements (e.g., graphics, animation, audio, and video) including the creation and editing of materials. Instructional applications, copyright issues, and technology limitations will be explored.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDET 603, EDET 703, and EDET 722.
name: Internship in Educational Technology
description: Supervised field-based experiences in the design, development, evaluation, and implementation of technology-based instructional and training projects.

name: Design and Evaluation of Games and Simulations
description: Application of instructional design criteria to computer and noncomputer interactions. Analyses include requisite cognitive processes, affective outcomes, and ethical standards. Design and formative testing of interactive exercises.

name: Electrical and Electronics Engineering
description: Introductions to: the profession of electrical engineering; the wide range of sub-disciplines that make electrical engineering so valuable in improving the human condition; the role of electrical engineers in society; and the role of electrical engineering students in the university.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: MATH 141
name: Electrical Science
description: Fundamentals of electrical and electronic components. Basic network laws. Mathematical and computer tools for network analysis.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in ENGL 102 and C or better in CSCE 211.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: ELCT 222.
name: Introductory Electrical Engineering Laboratory
description: Laboratory procedures, instrumentation and measurements, report writing, computer use in system design, testing, and troubleshooting. Integrative project-based learning environment including passive, active, electronic and electromechanical systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 142.
name: Electrical Engineering for Non-Majors
description: Fundamentals of electrical engineering for mechanical, chemical, or other engineering disciplines, including electric circuits, measurements, data acquisition, sensors, motors, and controllers.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 142; C or better in either ELCT 102 or AESP 265 or D or better in ELCT 220.
name: Circuits
description: Analysis of linear ac circuits using complex variables. Nodal and mesh analysis, Thevenin and Norton transformations, linearity, superposition, use of math solvers, circuit simulators, and computer-interfaced instrumentation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ELCT 221 and in MATH 242.
name: Signals and Systems
description: Analysis of continuous-time signals and systems in time and frequency domains, Fourier series and transforms, Laplace transforms; introduction to discrete-time signals.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in ELCT 201.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ELCT 371.
name: Electronics Laboratory
description: Design and implementation of analog and digital electronic circuits, with emphasis on developing deep individual understanding of curriculum-spanning concepts.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in ELCT 301.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ELCT 331.
name: Real Time Systems Laboratory
description: Team-oriented application of sensing, measurement, and real time embedded digital control for autonomous vehicular systems. Requirements analysis, system modeling, software/hardware integration, report writing, development of teaming skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ELCT 222.
name: Digital Signal Processing
description: An introduction to analysis, design and applications of discrete time systems; z- and discrete Fourier transforms; frequency and impulse responses, FIR and IIR filters.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ELCT 222.
name: Control Systems
description: Fundamentals of control systems. Analysis and design of control systems using physical system models. State variables, steady-state error, time- and frequency-responses, control system stability. Root locus analysis and controller design �€“ PI, PD, PID, lead-lag compensator. Nyquist stability criterion.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ELCT 222, C or better in CSCE 145.
name: Computer Modeling of Electrical Systems
description: Formulation of physics-based dynamic models of electrical or electromechanical systems. Solving dynamic equations of electrical systems in discrete time. Use of object oriented programming language (e.g., C++) and computer tools (e.g, MATLAB, virtual test bed) for solving dynamic equations of electrical systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PHYS 212 and MATH 241.
name: Electromagnetics
description: Basic concepts of electric and magnetic fields, including electrostatics, magnetostatics, and quasi-statics with computer applications.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in CHEM 111, PHYS 212.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in MATH 241.
name: Introduction to Microelectronics
description: Properties and characteristics of semiconductor materials, p-n and semiconductor-metal junctions. Basic properties, characteristics and operation of diodes and transistors.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ELCT 222.
name: Electronics
description: Introduction to design and analysis of electronic circuits and systems. Applications of amplifiers, op-amps, diodes, bipolar and field-effect transistors in analog and digital circuits.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ELCT 302.
name: Capstone Design Project I
description: Planning, preliminary design, and prototyping. Analysis and specification of system and subsystem requirements, measures of performance, analysis of alternatives, effective team work. Project management and scheduling. Prototype implementation and characterization. This course should be taken during student�€�s penultimate semester.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ELCT 403.
name: Capstone Design Project II
description: Continuation of Capstone Design Project I. Final design and implementation including design iteration, design for reliability, system integration and characterization, business case development.

name: Special Problems
description: Individual investigation or studies of special topics. A maximum of 3 credits total may be applied toward a degree. Advanced approval of project proposal by instructor and department advisor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ELCT 363.
name: Photovoltaic Materials and Devices
description: Fundamentals of photovoltaic solar cell technologies. Design and operation of solar cells, including efficiency analysis and cost benefit. Applications to green and sustainable energy systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ELCT 361 or PHYS 504.
name: Introduction to Microwave Engineering
description: Introduction to plane electromagnetic wave propagation, reflection, transmission, antennas and antenna arrays, wireless link margin; noise, noise figure, noise temperature; switches and phase shifters; microwave modeling.�€‹

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ELCT 331.
name: Digital Control Systems
description: Analysis and design of discrete-time control systems, implementation of control systems using digital electronic systems. Applications to electrical systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ELCT 321 or equivalent.
name: System Health Management
description: Sensing, data acquisition, and data processing for evaluation of performance and system health. Integration and implementation of health management systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ELCT 361, ELCT 363 and ELCT 371.
name: Sensors for Biomedicine
description: Operating principles and design of bioelectric sensors and sensor systems for medical applications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ELCT 331, ELCT 361 and ELCT 451.
name: Electromechanical Energy Conversion
description: Analysis and design of electromechanical energy conversion systems, including electrical machines and electronic drives.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ELCT 551.
name: Integration of Photovoltaics in Modern Power Systems
description: Analysis and design of power systems in presence of photovoltaic generation with focus on protection systems, control, power quality.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ELCT 451.
name: Special Topics in Distributed Energy Resources for Electric Energy Systems
description: Special topics in distributed energy resources for modern electrical energy systems. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated as topics vary.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ELCT 332, ELCT 361.
name: Wireless Communications
description: Fourier techniques and stochastic processes review, multiple access & cellular techniques, signal space representations for signals and noise, baseband modulations and optimal receivers in additive white Gaussian noise, bandpass and higher-order modulations, mobile & wireless propagation channel characteristics, effects of bandlimiting & distortion mitigation, diversity techniques.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ELCT 363.
name: Semiconductor Devices for Power, Communications and Lighting
description: Operational principles and characteristics of electronic and optoelectronic semiconductor devices including MOSFETs and high electron mobility transistors (HEMTs) for power electronics, electric cars and high-speed communications, light emitting diodes and lasers for solid state lighting, displays and optical communication, solar cells for green power generation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ELCT 361.
name: RF Circuit Design for Wireless Communications
description: RF design fundamentals, lumped elements, transmission line theory, transmission lines and waveguides, S-parameters, impedance matching, microwave resonators.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in ELCT 371.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in ELCT 331.
name: Power Electronics
description: Basic analysis and design of solid-state power electronic devices and circuitry.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ELCT 363 or equivalent.
name: Semiconductor Materials and Device Characterization
description: Semiconductor material and device characterization; resistivity, carrier and doping density, contact resistance, Schottky barriers, series resistance, defects, trapped charges, and carrier lifetime.

name: Semiconductor Laboratory
description: Prerequisite: ELCT 363.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDPY 401, EDTE 201.
name: Nature and Management of Elementary Classrooms
description: The learning environment to include diversity of students, instructional materials, classroom management, and communication patterns.

name: Culturally Sustaining Pedagogy for the Elementary Classrooms
description: Theoretical and pedagogical approaches to Culturally Sustaining Pedagogy (CSP)�€”curriculum design tools and instructional strategies that reflect the diversity of students�€� cultural backgrounds and languages in elementary classrooms.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDEL 301.
name: Practicum in Elementary Education
description: Sequence of supervised field experiences in an assigned school setting.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Admission to the professional program and MATH 221.
name: Elementary Mathematics Instruction
description: Approaches, materials, and methods for teaching mathematics in elementary grades. Restricted to students in the BA program in elementary education.

requisiteText: Corequisite: EDRD 430.
name: Introductory Elementary Internship
description: Field experience requiring students to gradually assume the responsibilities of teaching in an assigned classroom under the guidance of an experienced teacher.

description: Teaching and related experiences, including seminars and workshops. Admission to professional teacher certification program and completion of the elementary education core.

description: Internship for practice in classrooms appropriate to elementary education related to curriculum design and assessment. Field experiences emphasize planning lessons that actively engage students in learning.

Prerequisites: Admission to Internship II in Elementary Education.

name: Internship in Elementary Education
description: Internship for practice in elementary classrooms (grades 2-6) related to curriculum design, assessment, interactive teaching, and professional roles.

attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

description: Curriculum and pedagogy for mathematics topics taught in grades 3 through 8.

description: Instructional approaches and materials for teaching elementary school mathematics, grades 4-6. This course cannot be applied to a graduate degree in the elementary education program.

name: Social Studies in the Elementary/ Middle School
description: Fundamentals of social studies education in the elementary/middle school.

description: Internship for practice in classrooms appropriate to elementary education related to curriculum design and assessment.

description: Analysis of the concepts and skills of arithmetic in the school mathematics curriculum; exploration of diagnostic-prescriptive teaching methods.

description: Examine the content, goals, and methods of teaching language arts in elementary and middle school.

description: Field-specific professional development and analytical skills for graduate students in the International Accelerator Program. Restricted to: Graduate Students in the International Accelerator Program.

description: Advanced field-specific professional development and analytical skills for graduate students in the International Accelerator Program. Restricted to Graduate Students in the International Accelerator Program.

name: English for Academic Purposes A

name: English for Academic Purposes B
description: Essential English integrated skill building for students at a high intermediate level of English language proficiency; production and comprehension skills and strategies related to accessing academic content; second in a two-part sequence ENFS 091, ENFS 092.

Restricted to Students in the International Accelerator Program.

name: Course Supplement
description: Strategic competence skill building for low-advanced learners of English; designed to enable students to access course materials and complete university-level assignments successfully. Restricted to: Students in the International Accelerator Program.

requisiteText: Corequisite: ENFS 097.
name: Special Topics in Graduate Communication A

Restricted to Graduate students in the International Accelerator Program. ENFS 096 and ENFS 097 are normally taken in the same semester as consecutive 8-week courses.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: ENFS 096.

Restricted to Graduate Students in the International Accelerator Program. ENFS 096 and ENFS 097 are normally taken in the same semester as consecutive 8-week courses.

name: Service Learning through English to Speakers of Other Languages

Includes application of ESOL principles, exploration of the immigrant experience, and reflective writing addressing the intersection of course concepts and service experiences. International service component may be an option.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Selected Topics
description: Intensive study of selected themes, topics, currents of thought, or interdisciplinary concerns. May be repeated for credit under a different course title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Principles of Modern Literary Theory
description: Major 20th-century approaches to texts, from New Criticism to the present.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Global Contemporary Literature
description: Studies in twentieth- and twenty-first-century global Anglophone literatures.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: LGTBQ+ Literature
description: This course will examine LGBTQ+ (lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans, queer, and other nonnormative sexual identities) literatures and cultures.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Special Topics in Theory
description: Approaches to criticism, such as feminism, Marxism, semiology, deconstruction, New Historicism, cultural materialism, and others; or genre, such as narrative, poetry, drama, and others.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: English Grammar
description: Major structures of English morphology and syntax; role of language history and social and regional variation in understanding contemporary English.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Development of the English Language
description: History of English from the earliest Old English texts through Middle English to Contemporary English. No previous knowledge of Old or Middle English is required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Language in Society
description: Patterns in language use as a reflection of social group memberships or the negotiation of interpersonal relationships; special attention to social dialects and stylistic difference in American English.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270-ENGL 292.
name: African-American English
description: Linguistic examination of the structure, history, and use of African-American English, as well as literary presentations, language attitudes, and issues relating to education and the acquisition of Standard English.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Advanced Writing
description: Extensive practice in different types of nonfiction writing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: The Teaching of Writing
description: Theory and methods of teaching composition and extensive practice in various kinds of writing. Recommended for prospective writing teachers.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Technical Writing
description: Preparation for and practice in types of writing important to scientists, engineers, and computer scientists, from brief technical letters to formal articles and reports.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Business Writing
description: Extensive practice in different types of business writing, from brief letters to formal articles and reports.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ENGL 101 and ENGL 102 or equivalent.
name: Poetry Workshop
description: Workshop in writing poetry.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in both ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Fiction Workshop
description: Workshop in writing fiction.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102. Internship contract and department permission required.
name: Internship
description: Supervised professional experience writing in a workplace or community agency, including analysis and production of documents. Internship contract and department permission required. 6 is the Maximum number of credit hours if course can be taken multiple times.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Topics in Rhetoric
description: Intensive study of selected topics. May be repeated for credit under a different title.

name: Digital Writing
description: Emphasis on writing in digital environments, exploring critically and creatively what it means to compose in emerging genres and media. Students will create multimedia texts that may include digital video, audio podcasts, social networks, and/or blogs and wikis, among other digital modes of expression.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in both ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Creative Nonfiction
description: Explores the various subgenres and techniques of creative nonfiction, such as collage, memoir and literary journalism by reading polished examples and by responding to writing exercises designed to prompt ideas and hone skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Rhetoric of Science and Technology
description: Rhetorical study of science and technology in contemporary culture, emphasizing the ways scientific texts and technologies make their persuasive appeals.

name: Rhetoric and the Ancient Roots of Modern Life
description: Classical rhetoric and its ongoing influence in the modern world, emphasizing how the study and use of language in ancient Greece and Rome continue to shape modern communication.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Rhetoric and Popular Culture
description: Rhetorical study of popular culture, using the methods and theories of cultural analysis to examine how various popular cultural forms work as persuasion.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and 102 or equivalent; ARTH 366.
name: History of Cinema II
description: Survey of the international cinema from 1945 to the present.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Women�€�s Rhetoric
description: Study of rhetoric by and about women as manifested in speeches, essays, and other rhetorical artifacts.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270-ENGL 292.
name: African-American Rhetoric
description: African-American rhetoric as manifested in speeches, essays, and other rhetorical artifacts.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Black Women Writers
description: An examination of literature by and about black women, including fiction, poetry, drama, and autobiography. This study will focus on issues that emerge from the creative representations of black women and the intersections of race, gender, sexuality, and class that interrogate what is both particular and universal experiences.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102; English major, junior or senior standing, or consent of instructor.
name: Topics in Advanced Study
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated as topics vary.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in both ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Advanced Poetry Workshop
description: Students will study poetry writing at an advanced undergraduate level through close readings of professional poetry, composition of original work, and regular practice in the evaluation of peer work.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in both ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Advanced Fiction Workshop
description: Students will study the art and craft of writing literary fiction at an advanced level through close readings and the composition of original short stories.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in both ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Advanced Creative Non-Fiction
description: The art and craft of writing creative nonfiction at the advanced level.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in both ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Advanced Professional Writing Workshop
description: An advanced workshop on the genres, practices, and contexts of professional writing for experienced writers.

name: Thesis
description: Directed research resulting in a project of substantial length. Upper-level English majors; permission of undergraduate director and supervising faculty member.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 450, LING 421, ENGL 680, or LING 600.
name: Advanced English Grammar
description: Practical survey of the syntactic structures of English; usage, social and regional variation emphasis on data.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270- ENGL 292.
name: African American Theatre
description: The major movements, figures, plays, and critical strategies that have marked the development of African American theatre in the 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FAMS 240.
name: Special Topics in U.S. Film and Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in U.S. film and media studies. May be repeated as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270- ENGL 292.
name: Seminar in Verse Composition
description: First half of a year-long course in the writing of poetry taught by a contemporary poet. Limited to 15 students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270-ENGL 292.
name: Seminar in Verse Composition
description: Second half of a year-long course in the writing of poetry taught by a contemporary poet. Limited to 15 students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270-ENGL 292.
name: Fiction Workshop: Short Story
description: Instruction in the writing of short fiction taught by a contemporary prose writer. May be repeated once for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: graduate status in the English department, or permission of instructor for undergraduates.
name: Non-Fiction Prose Workshop
description: Instruction in the writing of the nonfiction essay taught by a contemporary prose writer. May be repeated once for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102 or equivalent; ENGL 565 or equivalent experience in film as determined by the instructor.
name: Seminar in Composition for the Visual Media
description: Writing for the visual arts, the student will write a treatment (prospectus) and one or more multimedia scripts; or one or more teleplays; or a feature-length screenplay. Limited to 15 students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102 or equivalent; ENGL 565 or equivalent experience in film as determined by the instructor.
name: Seminar in Composition for the Visual Media
description: Writing for the visual arts, the student will write a treatment (prospectus) and one or more multimedia scripts; or one or more teleplays; or a feature-length screenplay. Limited to 15 students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: graduate status in the English department, or permission of instructor for undergraduates.
name: Playwriting Workshop
description: Instruction in playwriting taught by a contemporary playwright. May be repeated once for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270- ENGL 292.
name: Fiction Workshop: Book-Length Manuscript
description: Instruction in the writing of book-length manuscripts taught by a contemporary prose writer. May be repeated once for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: graduate status in the English department, or permission of instructor for undergraduates.
name: Writing the Longer Nonfiction Project
description: Instruction in the writing of a book-length nonfiction memoir or literary journalism project taught by a contemporary prose writer. May be repeated once for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270- ENGL 292.
name: Writing Poetry: Traditional and Modern Forms
description: The writing of traditional and modern poetic forms. Exercises will give practice in composing metered and free verse. Representative masterpieces of traditional and modern poetry will also be studied.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: graduate status in the English department, or permission of instructor for undergraduates.
name: Writing the Full-Length Play
description: Instruction in the writing of a full-length, two-act play for publication or production. May be repeated once for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270- ENGL 292.
name: Academic and Professional Writing
description: A workshop course in the development and revision of writing for academic and professional audiences.

name: Writing Children�€�s and Young Adult Literature
description: Critical study and practical crafting of literature for children and/or young adults, exploring the demands of these genres both through the reading of representative works and relevant secondary sources and through the writing of creative works. Undergraduate students must receive permission of instructor.

name: Computer Methods for Humanistic Problems
description: Introduction to data processing concepts suitable for research interests in non-numerical areas such as the humanities.

requisiteText: Corequisite: ENGL 620.
name: Laboratory for Computer Methods for Humanistic Problems
description: Broad but intensive introduction to computer systems and programming for students in the humanities. No mathematical or scientific background is presumed. Laboratory experience with data-processing equipment; introduction to elementary digital computer programming in an appropriate language.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Special Topics in Literature
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.

name: Survey of Linguistics
description: Survey of core areas of linguistics and extensions to closely related disciplines. Introduction to the linguistic component of human cognition. Formal description and analysis of the general properties of speech and language, the organization of language in the mind/brain, and cross-linguistic typology and universals.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Special Topics in Composition
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

name: Teaching of Literature in College
description: Introduction to the methods of teaching literature, with emphasis on current pedagogical practice and theory and applications of electronic media. The course meets during the first seven weeks of the term and provides supervision of graduate students teaching English 101.

name: Teaching of Composition in College
description: Introduction to the methods of teaching composition, with emphasis on current pedagogical practice and theory and applications of electronic media. The course meets during the first seven weeks of the term and provides supervision of graduate students teaching English 102.

name: Introduction to Engineering
description: Engineering problem solving using computers and other engineering tools.

name: Introduction to Computer-Aided Design
description: Principles and practice of visualization and graphical representation using modern computer-aided design tools.

name: Exploratory Topics in Engineering and Computing
description: Introduction to new, contemporary, and emerging issues in engineering and computing that are not regularly included in lower division courses. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes.

name: Professional Development and Ethics in Engineering and Computing
description: Introduction to the field of engineering and computing in a seminar format. Open to first-year students only.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 141.
name: Statics
description: Introduction to the principles of mechanics. Equilibrium of particles and rigid bodies. Distributed forces, centroids, and centers of gravity. Moments of inertia of areas. Analysis of simple structures and machines. A study of various types of friction.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in MATH 142.
name: Introduction to Applied Numerical Methods
description: Introduction and application of linear algebra and numerical methods to the solution of physical and engineering problems. Techniques include iterative solution techniques, methods of solving systems of equations, and numerical integration and differentiation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENCP 200 or ECIV 200 or EMCH 200.
name: Dynamics
description: Kinematics of particles and rigid bodies. Kinetics of particles with emphasis on Newton�€�s second law; energy and momentum methods for the solution of problems. Applications of plane motion of rigid bodies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENCP 200 or ECIV 200 or EMCH 200, MATH 241.
name: Introduction to the Mechanics of Solids
description: Concepts of stress and strain; stress analysis of basic structural members; consideration of combined stress, including Mohr�€�s circle; introductory analysis of deflection; buckling of columns.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in MATH 241.
name: Thermodynamic Fundamentals
description: Definitions, work, heat, and energy. First law analyses of systems and control volumes. Second law analysis.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENCP 210 or ECIV 210 or EMCH 310, MATH 242.
name: Introduction to Vibrations
description: Theoretical and experimental analysis of systems involving one degree of freedom, including measurement methods. Introduction to free vibrations in systems with two degrees of freedom.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in ENCP 200, ECIV 200, EMCH 200, BMEN 212, BMEN 260, BMEN 263, or ECHE 300; D or better in PHYS 211.
name: Fluid Mechanics
description: Basic principles of fluid statics and dynamics; conservation laws of mass, momentum, and energy developed in the context of the control volume formulation; application of dimensional analysis, dynamic similitude, steady-state laminar viscous flow, and turbulent flow.

name: Sustainable Development in Engineering
description: An examination of political, social, technical, and economic issues associated with sustainable development.

name: Special Topics in Engineering and Computing
description: Emerging topics in engineering and computing. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated up to 8 hours as topic varies.

name: Project Management
description: Estimating project time and resources, scheduling, Gantt and pert charts, budgeting, monitoring and tracking results. Upper-division standing,

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: ENCP 481 or ECIV 405.
name: Capstone Design Project I
description: Major team-based design project to be undertaken in a student�€�s final year of study; project planning. Consent of advisor and instructor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENCP 491.
name: Capstone Design Project II
description: System implementation, testing, verification and validation of results. Written reports and oral presentations in a technical setting. Consent of instructor.

name: Interdisciplinary Technical Elective
description: Investigation or studies or special topics, typically in an interdisciplinary team-based environment. A maximum of three credits may be applied toward a degree. Advance approval of proposed project by instructor and academic advisor.

name: Environmentally Conscious Manufacturing
description: Design for the environment; life cycle analysis; environmental economics and global competitiveness; legal and regulatory affairs; and management of technological change. Interdisciplinary collaboration of engineering, science, math, and business majors. Graduate student standing or consent of instructor.

name: Introduction to Engineering Design for Teachers
description: An introduction to computer-aided design with solid modeling for pre-service and in-service teachers. Design process, professional communication and collaboration methods, design ethics, and technical documentation. Non-engineering and computing majors only. Prerequsite: college algebra with trigonometry.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 112 or MATH 115.
name: Gateway to Technology for Teachers
description: Addresses the development of knowledge, skills, and understanding of modern technology. For preservice and in-service teachers. College of Engineering and Computing majors are excluded.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 112 or MATH 115.
name: Principles of Engineering for Teachers
description: Introduces technological processes employed in engineering and engineering technology for K-12 teachers. For pre-service and in-service teachers. College of Engineering and Computing majors are excluded.

name: Introduction to the Environment
description: Analysis of environmental issues and the role of science in their identification and resolution.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: ENVR 101.
name: Introduction to the Environment Lab
description: Demonstrations, field trips, data analyses, and discussion relating to environmental issues, such as sustainability, resource management, and pollution control.

name: Green Explorations
description: Interdisciplinary seminar combining the intellectual exploration of ecological perspectives with the physical exploration of the local environment. First-year students only.

name: Green Engagements
description: Interdisciplinary seminar on designing, researching, and implementing collaborative projects to promote ecological sustainability. First-year students only.

name: Natural History of South Carolina
description: General review of plants, animals, and geological features of South Carolina, with an emphasis on connections to the natural world.

name: Environmental Science and Policy I
description: Introduction to interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary perspectives on environmental issues. Required for majors in the Environment and Sustainability Program. Integrative case studies address ways of understanding nature. Sophomore Standing.

name: Environmental Science and Policy II
description: Continuing interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary exploration of relations between environment and society for majors in the Environment and Sustainability Program. Case studies raise issues, challenges, and strategies to achieving sustainability.

name: Introduction to Sustainability Management and Leadership
description: Introduction to development, establishment, and implementation of sustainability management systems and organizational leadership for achieving environmental, social, and economic goals.

name: Green Technology in Germany
description: Examination of roots and culture of environmentalism and related technological innovation in Germany. Comparison of green practices around the world to practices within Europe and U.S.

name: Environmental Pollution and Health
description: A survey of pollution (chemical, biological, physical) effects on environmental quality and public health with emphases on how each pollutant class behaves and affects individual and community health over acute to chronic exposure periods.

name: Environmental Ethics
description: Examination of principles and arguments surrounding moral issues involving the environment.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Global Environmental Health
description: Concerns in global environmental health, with a focus on toxic pollution and disease burden in developing countries. Investigation of international treaties, corresponding environmental pollution processes, and human health effects.

name: Integrating Sustainability
description: Multidisciplinary approach to interrelated environmental, economic and social problems facing humans at local, regional and global scales.

name: Environmental Anthropology: Cross-cultural Perspectives on Environmental Change
description: Cross-cultural perspectives on environmental issues.

name: Environmental Racism and Justice
description: History of the environmental justice movement and the unequal distribution of environmental harms on low income, minority, and historically marginalized groups.

name: Energy, Society and Sustainability
description: The role of energy in shaping society and geographic settings, as well as how energy production and consumption are shaped by the societal values and norms in which it is extracted, produced, and consumed.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and dean of the School of the Environment is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENVR 201 and ENVR 202.
name: Congaree National Park: Field Investigations in Environmental Science
description: Field research practices and analysis techniques in environmental science. Combines inquiry-based field investigations at Congaree National Park and laboratory sample analysis with integration of data and public policy concepts. Daily field trips required.

name: Special Topics in Sustainability and the Environment
description: Current developments in sustainability and global environmental issues selected to meet faculty and student interests. May be repeated as content varies.

name: Research in Environmental Science
description: Independent student research in collaboration with faculty mentors. Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required.

name: Environmental Practicum
description: Multidisciplinary research projects related to University or community environmental problems (e.g., energy, water conservation, solid waste, recycling).

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENVR 101 or ENVR 201.
name: Special Topics in the Environment
description: An in-depth analysis course of a specific interdisciplinary environmental topic. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

name: Sustainability Management and Leadership Strategies
description: Integrated management system principles and advanced leadership strategies to create sustainable development initiatives.

name: Sustainability Projects Course
description: Research, development and implementation of sustainability projects throughout the campus and community.

name: Global Food Politics
description: Political, social, and cultural landscapes of food and farming around the world; issues of agricultural production, trade, consumption, and food security.

name: Decolonizing the Environment: Race, Nature, Power
description: Critical examination of the ways ideas about nature and racial difference are conceptually and materially entwined with the production of social and environmental inequalities.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Environmental Economics
description: An analysis of the economics aspects of environmental decay, pollution control, and natural resource use. Analysis of the ability of the market system to allocate resources efficiently when economic activity is accompanied by environmental damage. Discussion of alternative public policy approaches to pollution control and natural resource conservation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: Conservation Biology
description: Principles of conservation biology. Importance of biodiversity, causes of decline and extinction, and restoration and conversation policy in terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: Freshwater Ecology
description: Quantitative study of the population, community and evolutionary ecology of freshwater habitats (lakes, ponds, rivers, streams, wetlands). Includes mandatory fieldtrips.

name: Introduction to Global Environmental Health
description: Introduction to global environmental health, with a focus on toxic pollution and disease burden in developing countries. Investigation of international treaties, corresponding environmental pollution processes, and human health effects.

name: Environmental Pollution and Health
description: A survey of pollution (chemical, biological, physical) effects on environmental quality and public health with emphases on how each pollutant class behaves and affects individual and community health over acute to chronic exposure periods.

name: Global Environmental Health
description: Concerns in global environmental health, with a focus on toxic pollution and disease burden in developing countries. Investigation of international treaties, corresponding environmental pollution processes, and human health effects.

name: Environment and Obesity
description: Role of the built environment and environmental toxins in the development and progression of obesity and metabolic syndrome from a public health perspective.

name: Introduction to Public Health Microbiology
description: Public health microbiology and the intersection between microbial disease, the environment, and health, with a particular focus on critical public health issues in the 21st century.

name: Independent Study
description: Enrollment and topic to be approved in advance by advisor and instructor. May be repeated.

name: Special Topics in Environmental Health Sciences
description: Issues and emerging themes in environmental health. May be repeated for a total of 9 credit hours as content varies by title.

name: Disasters and Public Health Emergency Management
description: Introduction to emergency preparedness and response in relation to environmental and public health. Historical context for the emergence of public health emergency preparedness and demonstration of articulation with community response partner agencies in the post-COVID era.

name: Advanced Special Topics in Environmental Health
description: Emerging issues and topics concerning environmental health. May be repeated as content varies by title up to a total of 9 credit hours.

name: Medical Mycology
description: Advanced study of infectious diseases caused by fungi. Etiology, symptoms, and treatment of fungi related illnesses.

name: Concepts of Environmental Health Science
description: Environmental health sciences presenting the earth as a complex system in which people, plants, animals, and non-living physical-chemical components interact.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 300 level Biology course or equivalent.
name: Parasitology
description: Parasites of biological, economic, and public health importance.

name: Industrial Health Programs
description: Analysis, planning, and implementation of programs to protect workers�€� health in industry; legislative and regulatory background.

name: Environmental Genomics
description: "State of the art" molecular techniques that elucidate mechanisms of environmental contaminants in model systems.

name: Biofilms in Environmental Health and Disease
description: Effect of bacterial biofilm process on many diverse areas. Recognition, prevention, and control of biofilm-related problems in the environment, health care, industry, and engineering.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 101 or BIOL 110; CHEM 101 and CHEM 102, or equivalent.
name: Metals and Human Health
description: Trace metal(loid)s, their fate and transport in the environment and their potential impacts on human health.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 101 or BIOL 110; CHEM 101 and CHEM 102.
name: Environmental Pollutants and Human Health
description: Overview of environmental pollutants and their impact on human health; case studies of environmental catastrophes; principles of ecotoxicology; air, water, and land pollution associated with neurotoxicity, toxicology, and carcinogenesis.

name: From Air to Alveoli: Exposure Science
description: A receptor-oriented approach for assessing human exposure to environmental contaminants by inhalation, dermal and ingestion routes. Covers methods for estimating exposures to protect health and well-being, to relate adverse effects to exposures, and to comply with regulations and guidelines.

name: Infectious Disease Ecology
description: Ecological theories as the basis for environmental change and the (re)emergence of infectious agents that ultimately impact human and ecosystem health.

name: Occupational Ergonomics I
description: Introduction to ergonomics: hazards identification and analysis; solution design and implementation; human musculoskeletal characteristics, injuries; effects of work on performance, safety, and health. Application to manufacturing and office environments.

name: Special Topics in Epidemiology
description: Novel and emerging themes in epidemiology. Content varies by instructor and title. May be repeated for a total of 9 credit hours.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: STAT 201 or STAT 205.
name: Principles of Epidemiology
description: Introduction to descriptive and analytical epidemiology. Topics will include the distribution and determinants of disease, surveillance, outbreak investigations, measures of association, screening tests, bias, and causal reasoning.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Instructor Permission.
name: Independent Study
description: Enrollment and topic to be approved in advance by advisor and instructor. May be repeated.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 300 level Biology course or equivalent.
name: Parasitology
description: Parasites of biological, economic, and public health importance. Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week.

name: Introduction to European Studies
description: Team-taught interdisciplinary seminars, lectures, and readings with guest lecturers.

name: Senior Seminar
description: Topics in contemporary European studies. Applicable to EURO major only.

name: Senior Thesis
description: Approval of topic by EURO advisor(s).

name: Understanding the Foundations of Disability
description: The role of historical events, politics, media, race, gender, and other issues in shaping how disability is viewed. A critical framework for understanding how disability is viewed in Western culture and the effects of those views on individuals with disabilities.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Introduction to Inclusion of Students with Mild Disabilities
description: Inclusion strategies and accommodation planning for students with mild disabilities in general education classrooms.

name: Introduction to Exceptional Children
description: Overview of the field of education for exceptional children. Basic course for those entering the field of special education.

name: The Nature of Orthopedic and Special Health Problems
description: Symptomatology, behavioral manifestations, and resources for care and treatment of orthopedic conditions and other types of health problems in children and youth.

name: Introduction to Early Childhood Special Education
description: An overview of early childhood special education for young children with disabilities and their families.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDEX 523 or PSYC 528.
name: Nature of Students with Specific Learning Disabilities
description: Children with average/above average intelligence and specific learning impairments; diagnostic and remedial techniques. Offered by both the College of Education and the Department of Psychology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDEX 523 or PSYC 518.
name: Nature and Needs of the Gifted and Talented
description: Types and characteristics of the gifted and talented.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDEX 523.
name: Direct Instruction in Reading for At-Risk Learners
description: A study of the skills and knowledge required to implement direct instruction procedures when teaching reading, with opportunity for application of skills. Research and theoretical foundations will also be evaluated.

name: Teaching Reading in the Content Area to Adolescents with Reading Disabilities
description: Research, theory, and instructional practices related to providing reading instruction in content areas for youth with disabilities, with a focus on developing disciplinary literacy in inclusive settings.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDEX 523 or EDEX 491.
name: Teaching Mathematics to Students at Risk
description: Research, theory, and instructional practices related to mathematical readiness and instruction for children and youth at risk for mathematical difficulties.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in EDEX 523.
name: Instruction of Students with Severe and Multiple Disabilities
description: Data-based instruction for teaching students with significant disabilities: task and developmental analysis, individualizing instruction, and preparing and implementing instructional programs.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in EDEX 523.
name: Curriculum and Language Instruction for Students with Severe and Multiple Disabilities
description: Design, development, adaptation, and implementation of curriculum, language and communication instruction for students with significant disabilities.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDEX 523, EDEX 531, or EDEX 632 or equivalent.
name: Instruction of Students with Specific Learning Disabilities
description: Theory and application of current evidence-based procedures for teaching children with specific learning disabilities.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: a course in the areas of child psychology or child development.
name: Nature of Students with Intellectual Disabilities
description: Nature and causes of intellectual disabilities, behavior, and potentialities of persons with intellectual disabilities.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDEX 530.
name: Educational Procedures for Early Childhood Special Education
description: An initial course in educational procedures focusing on intervention strategies for serving young children with disabilities in inclusive environments.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in EDEX 523.
name: Nature of Students with Emotional and Behavior Disabilities
description: Characteristics, etiology, and major theoretical models for children experiencing emotional and/or behavioral problems in school; special education curriculum, programming alternatives, assessment, and issues concerning this population.

name: Managing Problem Behavior in the Classroom
description: The development of a workable approach to classroom management through an examination of a research-based synthesis of current knowledge in classroom and behavior management.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDEX 523.
name: Social/Emotional Development and Guidance for Young Children with Developmental Delays
description: DEC Practices in Early Childhood Special Education, Assessing and Monitoring Children's Challenging Behavior, and Preventive Strategies for Challenging Behavior.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDEX 530.
name: Advanced Procedures for Assessment in Early Childhood Special Education (ECSE)
description: Advanced assessment methods for serving young children with and without developmental delays and their families.

name: Introduction to Braille
description: Basic course for mastery of the literary braille code. Transcription of instructional materials in literary braille.

name: Nature of Students with Visual Disabilities
description: The psychological, social, and educational implications for persons with visual disabilities; definitions, incidence, characteristics of, and rehabilitative and educational programs for persons with visual disabilities.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDEX 523 or equivalent.
name: Introduction to Deafness
description: Educational implications of philosophy, theory, and research about deafness.

name: Communication Systems for Students who are Deaf or Hearing Impaired
description: Knowledge and basic skills of finger-spelling and sign forms for communication.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in EDEX 523.
name: Collaborative Partnerships in PK-12 Special Education
description: Communication and collaboration skills and strategies for creating and maintaining effective partnerships with a variety of stakeholders involved in educating students with disabilities in PK-12 settings.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDEX 523.
name: Partnerships in Early Childhood Special Education
description: Strategies for collaborating and communicating with families and other professionals as members of multidisciplinary teams in Early Intervention and Early childhood Special Education.

name: Physical Activity and Health
description: Concepts of exercise, nutrition, behavior changes, and skills to promote lifelong physical activity and health.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in EXSC 223 and EXSC 223L.
name: Introduction to Sports Medicine and Athletic Training
description: Examination of careers and specific practices within sports medicine, specifically athletic training.

name: Foundations of Physical Therapy
description: Introduction to the profession and practice of physical therapy detailing the functions, disorders, and therapies of the major organ systems in applied context.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 102; BIOL 102; CHEM 111; MATH 122 or MATH 141.
name: Anatomy and Physiology I
description: The structure and functions of the human body: tissues, integument, skeletal, muscular, respiratory, and reproductive systems, and regulation of eating and metabolism.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: ENGL 102; BIOL 102, CHEM 111; MATH 122 or MATH 141.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: EXSC 223.
name: Anatomy and Physiology I Laboratory
description: Hands-on activities covering micro- and macroscopic anatomical topics including identification of tissues, bones and markings of the skeletal system, the joints, and the skeletal muscles of the body.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in EXSC 223 and EXSC 223L.
name: Anatomy and Physiology II
description: The structure and functions of the human body: nervous, cardiovascular, digestive, immune, urinary, and endocrine systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both EXSC 223 and EXSC 223L.
name: Anatomy and Physiology II Lab
description: Hands-on activities covering the gross anatomy nervous, cardiovascular, digestive, and muscular systems.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: EXSC 223 and EXSC 223L.
Corequisite: EXSC 275L.
name: Functional Musculoskeletal Anatomy
