description: Human anatomy for allied health professions. Focus on anatomy relevant to providing health services; knowledge and skills of orthopedic anatomy relative to muscle, ligament, and tendon; muscle origins, insertions, innervations, and actions pertaining to joint motion.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: EXSC 223 and EXSC 223L.
Corequisite: EXSC 275.
name: Functional Musculoskeletal Anatomy Lab
description: Clinical application of human anatomy for allied health care professions using discussion, models, and charts. Anatomy relevant to providing health care to individuals.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in both EXSC 224 and EXSC 224L.
name: Perceptual-Motor Development
description: Theoretical foundations and observation of growth and motor development of children, age birth to 10 years. Observation will be provided via video and live subjects provided by the instructor.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in EXSC 224 and EXSC 224L.
Corequisite: EXSC 330L.
name: Exercise Physiology
description: The individual and combined roles of the major organ systems of the body in maintaining homeostasis during muscular exercise.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: EXSC 224 and EXSC 224L.
Corequisite: EXSC 330.
name: Exercise Physiology Lab
description: Laboratory procedures in exercise physiology; measurement of physical fitness components.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in EXSC 224, EXSC 224L, PHYS 201 and PHYS 201L.
name: Biomechanics of Human Movement
description: Kinetic and kinematic principles governing efficient human movement. Selected methods of analyzing human movement will be reviewed.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EXSC 223, EXSC 224.
name: Health Fitness Practicum
description: First hour of a supervised practicum in a clinical setting for the Health Fitness Track.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in EXSC 224 and EXSC 224L.
name: Acquisition of Motor Skills
description: Scientific and behavioral foundation of the learning and performance of motor skills.

name: Special Topics in Exercise Science
description: Novel and emerging themes in exercise science. Content varies by instructor and title. May be repeated for a total of 6 credit hours as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EXSC 223, EXSC 224.
name: Research Seminar in Exercise Science
description: The research process in exercise science; participation in, presentation and discussion of current research.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in EXSC 330.
name: Practicum Preparation
description: Integration of major program of study and general education; issues of transition into senior practicum - EXSC 444.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101.
name: Psychology of Physical Activity
description: Introduction to psychosocial factors in physical activity. Topics include mental health effects of exercise, behavior change theories applied to physical activity, and physical activity determinants and interventions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EXSC 401.
name: Exercise Science Practicum
description: Supervised experience in a field, clinical, or research setting. EXSC majors only.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EXSC 223, EXSC 224.
name: Health/Fitness Programs
description: Design and implementation of health/fitness programs.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both EXSC 224 and EXSC 224L
name: Conditioning Methods in Athletic Performance
description: Students will learn how to perform pre-exercise assessments, develop appropriate exercise training programs based on these assessments, as well as lead and demonstrate safe and effective methods of exercise by the application of the primary theories and principles of exercise science.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EXSC 223, EXSC 224.
name: Independent Study
description: Enrollment and topic to be approved in advance by advisor and instructor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EXSC 223, EXSC 224, EXSC 330, EXSC 330L.
name: Exercise, Sport, and Nutrition
description: The relationship between exercise, sport performance, and nutrient metabolism.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: EXSC 223, EXSC 224, EXSC 330, EXSC 330L.
Corequisite: EXSC 531L.
name: Clinical Exercise Physiology
description: Scientific bases of clinical exercise programming. The fitness instructor�€�s role in encouraging changes in exercise behavior.

name: Clinical Exercise Physiology Lab
description: Prerequisite: EXSC 223, EXSC 224, EXSC 330, EXSC 330L.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in EXSC 330.
name: Physiological Basis for Strength and Conditioning
description: Investigation on the physiological basis for strength and conditioning. Principles of strength and conditioning through lecture based learning, demonstrations, and through laboratory activities.

name: Current Topics in Exercise Science
description: Content varies by title. Course may be repeated for a total of 6 credit hours.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: biology, anatomy, physiology, or the equivalent.
name: Impairments of the Human Motor System
description: Role of motor development in the growth and development of individuals exhibiting impaired motor control.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EXSC 223, EXSC 224, EXSC 351, EXSC 330, EXSC 330L.
name: Physical Activity and the Physical Dimensions of Aging
description: The effects of age and physical activity on physical and motor functions of elderly individuals.

name: Women�€�s Health and Physical Activity
description: Sex differences in diseases, physiological function of sex hormones, hormonal changes in a woman�€�s life, specific women�€�s health issues, and role of physical activity and exercise in prevention and treatment of conditions and diseases specific to women or related to sex hormones. Restricted to 30 students, Special Permission by Instructor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in EXSC 410.
name: Apps, Wearables and Technology for Lifestyle Behavior Change and Weight Loss
description: The course will increase students�€� understanding of the theoretical foundations, scientific evidence and practical application of technology-assisted lifestyle interventions, with an emphasis on behavioral weight control for adults.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EXSC 330.
name: Nutrition and Immunology
description: Examination of the interrelationships that link human nutrition to the immune system in health and disease. Topics will include basic immunology, overview of nutritional sources, deficiencies and excesses, and the impact on public health issues such as exercise, disease and aging.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EXSC 330.
name: Cardiorespiratory Exercise Physiology
description: Examination of the anatomy and function of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems of the exercising human organism, including acute adjustments and chronic adaptations to the systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both EXSC 330 and EXSC 330L.
name: Skeletal Muscle Physiology: Form and Function
description: Skeletal muscle physiology and exercise through select laboratory experiences and discussion of related research literature.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EXSC 224.
name: Writing and Presenting in Research
description: The research process in Exercise Science through participation, presentation, and discussion of current research.

name: Media Culture
description: Introduction to the critical study of film, video, photography, audio, and new media.

name: Film Culture
description: How the film industry developed and the impact the movies have had on global popular culture. Does not count toward the film studies major.

name: Film and Media Analysis
description: Introduction to the critical study of film and media. Students will closely analyze moving images and develop written arguments about film and media.

name: Film and Media History
description: Surveys the development of cinema and related media from the 1820s to the present. Attention to the relations among key technological, cultural, and industrial changes, their causes, and consequences.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in FAMS 240 or FAMS 300.
name: Media, Power & Everyday Life
description: Foundational approaches to media as a means of defining and distributing social power in everyday life.

name: Global Media Industries
description: Provides the foundation for the study of globalized film and media industries.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in FAMS 240 or FAMS 300.
name: Special Topics In Popular Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in popular film and media. May be repeated up to three times for a total of nine credit hours as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in FAMS 240 or FAMS 300.
name: Classical Hollywood Cinema
description: Survey of Classical Hollywood Cinema in aesthetic, cultural, political, and economic contexts.

name: Music and the Hollywood Film
description: Examination of how music guides audience interpretation and shapes Hollywood film style.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in FAMS 240 or FAMS 350, or ENGL 350.
name: Superheroes across Media
description: Examination of the superhero within and across media, industries, and eras addressing topics such as genre, style, seriality, remediation, franchising, and fandom.

name: The Blockbuster
description: Examination of the post-1975 blockbuster film phenomenon with an emphasis on marketing, finance, and reception.

name: Special Topics in Non-Film Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic concerning a medium or mediums other than film. May be repeated up to three times for a total of nine credit hours as content varies by title.

name: American Television
description: Examination of American television as an industry, art form, medium of social representation, and set of viewer practices.

name: Contemporary British Television Industry
description: Examination of industrial structures, network histories, production cultures, and regulation contexts of contemporary British television.

name: Introduction to Comics Studies
description: Scholarly study of the formal and aesthetic evolutions of graphic novels, comic books, and other related forms.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in FAMS 240 or FAMS 300.
name: Special Topics in Global Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in film and media centered outside the U.S. May be repeated up to three times for a total of nine credit hours as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in FAMS 240 or FAMS 300.
name: Middle East on Screen
description: Examines representations of the Middle East on screen within multiple media-making traditions and considers their aesthetic, political, and ethical dimensions.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in FAMS 240 or FAMS 300.
name: Hong Kong Action Cinema
description: Survey of the transnational history of Hong Kong action cinema and introduction to critical approaches through which it has been studied.

name: Screening China
description: Survey of Chinese language cinema. Chinese film history and vocabulary with which to discuss film texts. Covers classic leftwing cinema, Hong Kong martial arts films, as well as the Hong Kong, Taiwan, and PRC New Waves. Taught in English. Films subtitled.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in FAMS 240 or FAMS 300.
name: Special Topics in Alternative Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic concerning film and media forms and/or practices outside the commercial mainstream. May be repeated as many as three times for a total of nine credit hours as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in FAMS 240 or FAMS 300.
name: History of Experimental Film
description: Survey of key examples and tendencies in the history of experimental film.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in FAMS 240 or FAMS 300.
name: Documentary Studies
description: History, theory, and practices of documentary film and media.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and program director is required.

name: Genre Studies Film & Media
description: Critical study of a popular genre (e.g., horror, science fiction, melodrama), or set of genres, in film and media. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of courses by title. May be repeated as topics vary.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in FAMS 308.
name: Internship in Film and Media Studies
description: Internship in Film and Media Studies. (Variable) Supervised professional experience working with media production, distribution, exhibition, archiving, and/or education.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in FAMS 300.
name: Special Topics in Film and Media Histories
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in film and media history. May be repeated as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FAMS 240.
name: Special Topics in Film and Media Studies
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in film and media studies. May be repeated as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FAMS 240.
name: Special Topics in U.S. Film and Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in U.S. film and media studies. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Critical Interactives
description: Foundational techniques in multidisciplinary software development, specifically of applications designed to present sensitive, sometimes controversial, materials in ways to engender empathic awareness of the interactor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FAMS 240.
name: Special Topics in Global Film and Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic concerning films produced in a country other than the United States. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Introduction to Personal Finance
description: Course will provide a basic framework for student personal financial management while in college. Topics include money management skills, banking, credit cards, creditworthiness, credit reports, students loans, identity theft, and basic taxes.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 224.
name: Money and Banking
description: The role of money in the market economy. Commercial banks, the Federal Reserve System, and monetary policy.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 224 or ECON 221 and ECON 222, ACCT 222.
name: Finance and Markets
description: In-depth introduction to the world of finance. Interaction of individuals and companies with financial markets.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: FINA 363.
name: Management of Risk and Insurance
description: Introduction to decision making under uncertainty and overview of how carious markets allow individuals and organizations to diversify risk. Includes measurement of risk, behavioral bias in decision making under uncertainty, diversification of risk, the role of capital in ensuring performance, moral hazard, adverse selection, insurance pricing, and applications to public policy issues such as health care, catastrophe risk, and safety regulation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ECON 221 and ACCT 225; C or better in STAT 206, STAT 509, STAT 511, STAT 515, or MATH 511.
name: Introduction to Finance
description: Basic concepts of finance related to decision making.

name: Financial Institutions
description: A study of the functions and operations of financial institutions and their relationships to the commercial banking system and the general economy. Attention is devoted to savings institutions, insurance companies, rural and urban real estate credit, consumer credit, and associated topics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in FINA 363.
name: Corporate Financial Analysis
description: Analysis of business investment and financing decisions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in FINA 363.
name: Introduction to Real Estate and Urban Development
description: Real estate analysis and administration; basic principles, concepts, terminology, and institutional factors related to real estate decisions in the urban environment. This course fulfills a pre-examination requirement of the South Carolina Real Estate licensing law (30-hour approved course).

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FINA 366.
name: Real Estate Market Analysis
description: Concepts, methodologies, and analytical tools used in urban real estate analysis.

name: Personal Finance
description: Life insurance, health insurance, wills, trusts, Social Security, stocks, bonds, real estate, mutual funds, and other uses of funds.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in FINA 341 and FINA 363.
name: Life and Health Insurance
description: Individual financial management of economic losses caused by premature death, disability, and old age; functional aspects of life-health insurer management.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in FINA 341 and FINA 363.
name: Property and Liability Insurance
description: Functional aspects of property-liability insurer management and operations including detailed treatment of pricing, risk assessment, marketing, investment, contract design, financial statement analysis, and regulation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in FINA 341, FINA 363, and MGSC 291.
name: Corporate Risk Management
description: Tools and concepts used by corporations in managing all types of risk with a focus on the use of derivatives and insurance. Analysis of when risk reduction is beneficial.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FINA 341.
name: Employee Benefits
description: Management of employer-sponsored benefits, especially group life, health, and retirement plans; emphasis on plan design and administration, cost, funding, regulation, and tax considerations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in FINA 341 and FINA 363.
name: Insurance Operations
description: Innovative insurance operations to compete in the modern world.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FINA 365.
name: Case Studies in Corporate Finance
description: Application of financial concepts and tools to corporate decisions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in FINA 365 or FINA 465 or FINA 469.
name: Financial Innovation
description: Explores the history, current environment, and near term outlook of financial innovation (FinTech), focusing on applications of Blockchain technology and Machine Learning tools. The course is designed to provide hands on experience in writing a �€�smart contract�€? using a blockchain and in applying machine learning tools.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FINA 363.
name: Commercial Bank Practice and Policy
description: Fundamental principles underlying the employment of bank funds. Allocation of funds among the various classes of loans and investments to bank operating costs and to changing bank practices.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FINA 366 or FINA 469.
name: Real Estate Investment Fundamentals
description: Analysis and decision-making; return and risk; financing; tax implications; pricing and investment strategies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FINA 366 or FINA 469.
name: Real Estate Finance
description: The nature and importance of credit in real estate development and operations; legal framework, sources of mortgage funds, role of public and private financial institutions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FINA 366.
name: Real Estate Appraisal
description: Traditional appraisal concepts and methodologies; appraisal process, real property analysis.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in FINA 363 and MGSC 291.
name: Investment Analysis and Portfolio Management
description: Conceptual and analytical framework for formulating investment policies, analyzing securities, and constructing portfolios.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ACCT 225 and ACCT 226 and FINA 363.
name: Financial Statement Analysis
description: This course focuses on the analysis of financial statements for profitability and risk assessment and for firm and segment valuation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FINA 469.
name: Derivative Securities
description: Options, forward and futures contracts, and swap contracts are analyzed, along with their uses in risk management, portfolio management, and corporate financing. Markets where these contracts trade will be examined.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in MGSC 291.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in FINA 469.
name: Student-Managed Investments
description: Hands-on experience in investment analysis; managing a real portfolio, decision-making in the design of a portfolio management process, asset allocation, security selection, and risk management. Enrollment in this course requires a special permission from the instructor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FINA 469.
name: Fixed Income Securities
description: Examine fundamental principles of fixed-income securities and fixed-income valuation models.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221 and ECON 222.
name: Foundations of Capitalism
description: Examines the foundations of capitalism and why it has prevailed over alternative systems. Topics include the justification of private property, distribution of wealth, profit motive, source of wealth creation, and others.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FINA 366.
name: Global Real Estate Capital Markets
description: Global institutional investment in real estate; international capital markets viewed from the perspective of real estate investment and finance professionals.

name: Special Topics in Finance
description: 1-3 credit hours for up to 9 credit hours total.

name: Real Estate and Urban Development
description: An overview of real estate in both the public and private sectors that serves as the basis for advanced study in the various disciplines of real estate and urban development. No prior knowledge of the field is assumed.

name: Selected Topics
description: Studies in language not otherwise taught. May include a cultural and/or linguistic component.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: admission to the professional program of education.
name: Teaching Internship in Foreign Languages
description: Application of effective teaching techniques and organization of instructional settings in foreign languages for K-12.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Introduction to Technology in Language Education
description: Acquaints students with principles and practices concerning the use of technology in foreign language teaching. Explores connections between second language acquisition and the implementation of Internet and multimedia technologies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: admission to the professional program in education.
name: Directed Teaching in Foreign Languages
description: Students apply methods of curriculum and assessment, professionalism, effective teaching, and organization of instructional settings during internship in foreign language classroom.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 2 semesters of college-level Spanish or equivalent.
name: Spanish for Medical Personnel
description: Basic course in health professions. Functional language and lexicon as well as cultural practices for interaction with Hispanic clients.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 210 level of a foreign language or its equivalent.
name: Teaching Second Languages to Young Children
description: To assist prospective teachers of young children in the development of a second language and multicultural learning activities. Practicum sessions are an integral part.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 210 level of a foreign language or its equivalent.
name: Teaching Foreign Languages in Secondary Schools
description: Current methods, techniques, and materials of instruction appropriate for secondary schools.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FAMS 240.
name: Special Topics in Global Film and Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic concerning films produced in a country other than the United States. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Beginning French I
description: Introduction to grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Admission to FREN 109 restricted to those who have never studied French, who have not studied French in the previous five years, or who have a score of F-1 on the placement test.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FREN 109.
name: Beginning French II
description: Introduction to grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Admission to 110 restricted to those who have completed FREN 109. Credit may be received only for one of the following: FREN 109/FREN 110 or FREN 121.

name: Elementary French
description: Grammar and vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Assumes prior experience in French. Admission to FREN 121 restricted to those who have a score of F-2 on the placement test. Credit may be received for only one of the following: FREN 109/FREN 100 or FREN 121.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FREN 110, FREN 121 or placement score of F-3.
name: Basic Proficiency in French
description: Practice and further development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FREN 122 or score of F-5 on placement exam.
name: Reading and Written Expression
description: Readings in French; grammar, basic writing, and composition.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FREN 122 or score of F-5 on placement exam.
name: Oral Communication
description: Practice in conversation involving authentic listening materials; vocabulary building.

name: French Literature in Translation
description: Readings and discussion in English, with consideration of the cultural context.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FREN 110, FREN 121, or equivalent.
name: Topics in French Culture
description: Intensive one-term study of a particular topic identified by title. Taught in English.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 209 and FREN 210, or equivalents, or a score of F-6 on the French language placement exam.
name: French Phonetics
description: Analysis of and practice in pronunciation and listening comprehension.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 209 and FREN 210, or equivalents, or a score of F-6 on the French language placement exam.
name: Advanced Oral Practice
description: Development and maintenance of speaking and listening skills at the advanced level. Offered Pass-Fail only. May be repeated.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 209 and FREN 210, or equivalents, or a score of F-6 on the French language placement exam. Not open to students with a score of F-7.
name: Reading French Texts
description: Reading, discussion, and written analysis of French texts, both literary and nonliterary.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 209 and FREN 210, or equivalents, or a score of F-6 on the French language placement exam. Not open to students with score of F-7.
name: Advanced Oral Communication
description: Current issues and events presented in French-language media. Discussion and presentations in French provide practice with advanced structures and idiomatic speech.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Grades of C or better in both FREN 209 and FREN 210, or equivalents, or a score of F-6 on the French language placement exam. FREN 309 strongly recommended. Not open to students with score of F-7.
name: French Composition
description: Practice in French composition; intensive review of French grammar.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 309 and FREN 310, or equivalents.
name: Introduction to Business French
description: Practical oral and written communication in a commercial context; introduction to business terminology and correspondence.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 309 and FREN 310, or equivalents.
name: The French Theatre Experience
description: Project work in the production of plays in French. Includes readings in and public performance of French theatre and related materials.

name: French Language Study Abroad
description: Intensive language practice with special attention to oral skills. Classroom instruction by native speakers.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FREN 209 or 210.
name: Service Learning in the French-Speaking World
description: Cultural and linguistic service-learning experience in a French-speaking environment. Course may be repeated once in a different location.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 209 and FREN 210 are required, and FREN 309 is strongly recommended.
name: World Cinemas in French
description: An introduction to the history of the French film, with special emphasis on the aesthetic appreciation of the films in their artistic and cultural context. Films in French, with English subtitles. Taught in English. To be counted towards FREN major or minor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 209 and FREN 210 are required, and FREN 309 is strongly recommended.
name: Selected Topics in French & Francophone Culture
description: Intensive study of selected topics of the French-speaking world. May be repeated for credit under a different title. May not be counted for major or minor credit. Note: Taught in English. To be counted towards FREN major or minor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 309 and FREN 310, or equivalents, or a score of F-6 on the French language placement exam.
name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 309 and FREN 310, or equivalents, or a score of F-7 on the French language placement exam. FREN 311 strongly recommended.
name: French Cultural History
description: French history and the arts from early times through the Napoleonic era.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FREN 316.
name: Advanced Business French
description: Commercial organizations and businesses in France. Practical business correspondence. Terminology and techniques in commercial transactions with the Certificat Pratique of the Paris Chamber of Commerce in view. Taught in French.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 309 and FREN 310, or equivalents, or a score of F-7 on the French language placement exam. FREN 311 strongly recommended.
name: Topics in Literature
description: May be repeated for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 309 and FREN 310, or equivalents, or a score of F-7 on the French language placement exam. FREN 311 strongly recommended.
name: French Literature and Culture Before 1800
description: Study and discussion of French works written before 1800 within their cultural and historical contexts.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 309 and FREN 310, or equivalents, or a score of F-7 on the French language placement exam. FREN 311 strongly recommended.
name: French Literature and Culture After 1800
description: Study and discussion of French works written after 1800 within their cultural and historical contexts.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 309 and FREN 310, or equivalents, or a score of F-7 on the French language placement exam. FREN 311 strongly recommended.
name: Francophone Literatures and Cultures
description: Study and discussion of works from French-speaking societies outside France, with attention to their cultural contexts and historical contexts.

name: Senior Thesis
description: Graduation with Leadership Distinction: GLD: Research

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 309 and FREN 310, or equivalents, or a score of F-7 on the French language placement exam. FREN 311 strongly recommended.
name: Contemporary France
description: Readings in and discussion of the culture of contemporary France.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 309 and FREN 310, or equivalents, or a score of F-7 on the French language placement exam. FREN 311 strongly recommended.
name: Current Events in the France and the Francophone World
description: Development of advanced oral skills in French. Study of linguistic and cultural aspects of French language media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in each of FREN 309, FREN 310, and FREN 311, or equivalents, or a score of F-7 on the French language placement exam.
name: Techniques of Literary Analysis
description: Texts from standard authors, with emphasis on explication de texte.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in each of FREN 309, FREN 310, and FREN 311, or equivalents, or a score of F-7 on the French language placement exam.
name: Advanced French Stylistics
description: Practice in descriptive and narrative composition with special attention to contrastive stylistics; thÃ¨me et version.

name: French Phonology
description: The sound system and its functioning in the morphological system of French from the point of view of current phonological theory.

name: French Linguistics
description: The structure, morphology, and syntax of modern French.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both FREN 309 and FREN 310, or equivalents, or a score of F-7 on the French language placement exam. FREN 311 strongly recommended.
name: Special Topics in French
description: Poetry, prose, theatre, cinema, civilization, language, linguistics. Unique opportunities will be announced by title. May be repeated.

name: Intensive Readings in French
description: Graduate students fulfill their foreign-language reading requirement with successful completion of the course. Undergraduates may take the course as an elective only. Grades S/U for graduates and undergraduates.

name: Genetic Counseling: Career for the Future
description: Introduction to the genetic counseling profession including professional literature and online resources. Preparation for graduation education in genetic counseling.

name: Foundations of Geography
description: A survey of the principles and methods of geographic inquiry. Not required for the geography major.

name: Introduction to Physical Geography
description: Basic concepts of landform geography, climatology and meteorology, and biogeography.

name: The Digital Earth
description: Introduction to geographic data; use of digital maps and aerial/satellite images as means of Earth observation; basics of spatial data analysis; location-based Web APPs; digital map services.

name: Geographies of Global Change
description: Introduction to processes of political, economic, social, and environmental change around the world; topics include geopolitical transitions, nationalism, trade, uneven development, conflict, environmental geopolitics, and demographic change, with an emphasis on non-U.S. contexts.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Landform Geography
description: Hydrology, soil science, and interpretation of physical features formed by water, wind, and ice, with emphasis on environmental change. Three hours of lecture and one two-hour laboratory per week.

name: Weather and Climate
description: Processes that influence weather and climate patterns on the earth. Three lectures and one two-hour laboratory per week.

name: Peoples, Places, and Environments
description: Basic principles of human geography.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Geography of South Carolina
description: An intensive regional analysis of South Carolina. Selected phenomena such as urbanization, industrialization, land use, the physical environment, and their interrelationships.

name: Geography of Latin America
description: Physical and human geography of Latin America.

name: Geography of North America
description: Physical and human geography of North America with emphasis on the United States.

name: Geography of Europe
description: Physical and human geography of Europe.

name: Geography of the Middle East
description: A regional geographic approach to the environmental, social, economic, and political aspects of the Middle East (Southwest Asia and north Africa) with emphasis on contemporary problems.

name: Geography of Sub-Saharan Africa
description: A regional approach to the physical, social, economic, and political aspects of Sub-Saharan Africa with emphasis on contemporary problems.

name: Introduction to Drones for Airborne Spatial Data
description: This course is an introduction to the use of small unmanned aerial systems (UAS) in collecting/processing imagery for mapping/information analysis. Course content includes UAS characteristics, small camera considerations, project planning and processing, and legal requirements in the United States and selected European countries.

name: Topics in Geography
description: Selected topics of special interest in geography. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Landscape and Cultural Geography
description: The temporal-spatial relationship between humans and the natural environment with emphasis on the role through time of human activity in changing the face of the earth.

name: Geography and Global Geopolitics
description: Geographic perspectives on problems in international relations. Political geographic analysis of contemporary world problems.

name: Economic Geography
description: Spatial interrelation and linking of economic activities and how location affects the nature of economic systems.

name: Sustainable Cities
description: Overview of the relationships between urbanization and environmental processes and an exploration of pathways to greater sustainability.

name: Landscapes of the United States
description: Geographic change through time in the United States, with emphasis on evolution of the American landscape. Physical environment as modified by human intervention over time within a regional framework.

name: The Geography of Disasters
description: The study of disasters, their triggering mechanisms (natural, human, technological), their spatial distributions from local to global scales, and associated human responses.

name: Cartography
description: Introduction to the theory and principles of map construction including discussions of equipment and materials, lettering and symbolization, scale and generalization, data manipulation and representation. Presentation of geographic information on maps.

name: Environment and Society
description: A geographic consideration of the interactions between environment and society. The ways in which social, economic, and cultural processes interact across local to global scales and influence environmental practices, policies, and patterns of change will be emphasized.

name: Geographies of American Cities
description: Overview of the development of American cities from industrial period to the present. Special attention given to the political, economic, social processes that shape urban space and urban ways of life.

name: Introduction to Remote Sensing
description: Basics of remote sensing and image interpretation in aerial photography, drone technology and satellite imagery for earth observations. Emphasis on competent use of remote sensing data for a variety of geographic and multidisciplinary applications.

name: Climate and Society
description: Major theories and methodologies for studying the relationship between climate and society.

name: Water as a Resource
description: Introduction to spatial and institutional aspects of water availability, demand, and quality. Water storage/conveyance strategies and facilities. Real and perceived flood, drought hazards.

name: Biogeography
description: Spatial distributions of plants and animals as they relate to historical biogeographic patterns and human impact on the biosphere.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOG 341 or GEOG 363.
name: Cartographic Animation
description: Introduction to theories and principles of cartographic animation.

name: Geography of Wind
description: Fundamental principles of wind formation, measurement, and its impacts on the natural and human environment �€“ landscape, human settlement and health, transportation, and energy.

name: Hurricanes and Tropical Climatology
description: Atmospheric circulation, structure, and processes of tropical climates and hurricanes. Forecasting and model simulations of hurricanes. Temporal variations of tropical climate change and hurricanes.

name: America�€�s National Parks
description: Resource, managerial, and recreational-use components of the national park system; contemporary issues, problems, and managerial alternatives.

name: Air Pollution Fundamentals
description: Fundamentals, processes, and issues that relate to air pollution. Emphasis is on the role of the atmosphere. Additional topics include pollution sources, environmental and health effects of air pollution, air quality measurements, urban smog, and ozone depletion, regulations, and societal impacts.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Seminar in Geography
description: Research methods and projects; restricted to students with at least 15 hours of credit in geography. Restricted to students with at least 15 hours of credit in geography.

requisiteText: Corequisite: Must be taken simultaneously with designated Geography courses, levels 200 and above.
name: Special Topics: Service Learning in Geography
description: Service learning experience in conjunction with designated Geography courses. Direct, hands-on service experience with an agency, voluntary organization, or community-based project. May be repeated, as content varies by title. Students enrolled in designated Geography courses by Instructor permission.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Research on a significant geography problem in the local environment. Emphasis will be on the development of relatively individualized experiences in scientific investigation.

name: Senior Thesis
description: Senior research thesis on a problem of fundamental geographic significance, supervised by faculty member; must include a written final project report.

name: Special Topics in Geographic Research
description: Selected topics of special interest in geography. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Planning and Locational Analysis
description: Scientific approaches to locational problems in urban and regional planning, including regional growth and decline, land use control, public facility location and provision, and locational efficiency.

name: Migration and Globalization
description: A survey of the political, economic, and social causes and consequences of migration. Topics include immigration policy, border control, settlement patterns, transnationalism, multiculturalism, and integration. Selected contemporary and historical cases.

name: Political Geography
description: Concepts of space and power and their relationship to polities, elections, geopolitics, identities, law, economics, populations, and civil society.

name: Coastal Zone Management
description: Analysis of the competing demands for limited resources in the coastal zone with emphasis on the role of management in the resolution of conflicts over resource use.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Landscapes of South Carolina
description: An examination of the factors responsible for creating the contemporary South Carolina cultural landscape.

name: Geographical Analysis of Transportation
description: Analysis of transportation systems and the application of geographic tools to transportation planning.

name: Environmental Hazards
description: Human and environmental contributions to the generation and management of hazards originating from extreme natural events to technological failures. Contemporary public policy issues at the national and international level.

name: Quantitative Methods in Geographic Research
description: A survey of basic quantitative approaches for handling and interpreting geographically related data; univariate and bivariate procedures applicable to a variety of problems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOG 363 and GEOG 530, or equivalents.
name: Hazards Analysis and Planning
description: Examination of the geo-spatial aspects of hazards analysis and planning with specific reference to disaster preparedness, recover, mitigation, and resilience.

name: Global Food Politics
description: Political, social, and cultural landscapes of food and farming around the world; issues of agricultural production, trade, consumption, and food security.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOG 341.
name: Advanced Cartography
description: Planning, compiling, constructing, and evaluating thematic maps. Theory and practice in scribing, separation and screening, color proofing, and map reproduction. Discussions of the process of map communication and the ways the cartographer can improve that communication.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOG 341.
name: Dynamic Cartography
description: Theories and principles of interactive and animated cartographic design.

name: Geography of the City
description: The influence of political boundaries, historical forces, settlement patterns, and transportation processes on urban life.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in GEOG 202.
name: Weather Analysis and Forecasting
description: Principles and controls of weather and climate as they occur at the regional/synoptic scale. Background on the critical tools and concepts used for daily weather forecasting by the National Weather Service and prominent government agencies, and used by broadcast meteorologists.

name: Applied Climatology
description: Analysis of climate applications in natural and human-modified environments. Content may include water resources, solar energy, urban planning, air quality, agriculture, and tourism. Course work includes lab and field experimentation.

name: Fluvial Geomorphology
description: Introduction to landforms and processes associated with flowing water at the earth�€�s surface. Hydrology, sedimentology, and theories of channel formation and drainage basin evolution.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOG 347, GEOL 371, or ECIV 360.
name: Water and Watersheds
description: Spatial variation of hydrology, water quality, and water-related hazards, including runoff generation, soil erosion, sedimentation, and flood hazards. Emphasizes a watershed perspective using geographic data and methods.

name: Remote Sensing of the Environment
description: Computer-assisted digital image analysis; Image correction; Spatial/spectral transformation; image classification and change detection; Use of remote sensing for solving real-world environmental problems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOG 363 or GEOG 341 or GEOG 345 or GEOG 551 or GEOG 563.
name: LiDARgrammetric and Photogrammetric Digital Surface Mapping
description: Introduction to fundamental concepts used to map topographic and planimetric Earth surface features using digital LiDAR (LiDARgrammetric) and digital soft-copy photogrammetry (Photogrammetric).

name: Spatial Programming
description: Computer programming of spatial problems; spatial statistical analysis, interactive graphics, and computer maps.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOG 363.
name: WebGIS
description: Web-based Geographic Information Systems (WebGIS), including concepts and principles of WebGIS, web programming fundamentals, web-based mapping techniques, and developing WebGIS applications.

name: Contemporary Issues in Geography Education
description: Key concepts of geography and current approaches to teaching geography with specific attention to classroom materials, curriculum reform, cross-curricular integration, learning theory, and the use of geospatial/instructional technology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOG 345 or GEOG 363 or GEOG 551.
name: Satellite Mapping and the Global Positioning System
description: Technology and use of Global Positioning Systems (GPS). GPS space segment, receiver technologies, range observables, and positioning accuracy. Applications to large/medium scale mapping, remote sensing, and aerial photography.

name: Advanced Geographic Information Systems
description: Theory and application of geographic information systems including discussions of automated input, storage, analysis, integration, and display of spatial data. Use of an operational geographic information system.

name: GIS-Based Modeling
description: Geographical information systems for modeling physical/human processes in space and time using raster and vector data. Cartographic modeling concepts, embedded models, and GIS-model coupling.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOG 363 or GEOG 341 or GEOG 551 or GEOG 563.
name: Geographic Information System (GIS) Databases and Their Use
description: Representation, construction, maintenance, and analysis of spatial data in a geographic information system (GIS) database.

name: Climate Adaptation and Community Resilience Planning
description: The processes of climate adaptation planning and management from central concepts in adaptation to issues such as projecting impacts, vulnerability assessment, coping with uncertainty, and decision making.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: A 200-level course in physical geography or geology or equivalent.
name: Long-Term Environmental Change
description: Climatic changes of the past and their impact on the physical landscape, with an emphasis on the Quaternary period.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOG 343.
name: Human Dimensions of Global Environmental Change
description: Consequences of increasing anthropogenic changes on environmental systems including the sources of change, regional impacts, and social and policy responses.

name: International Development and the Environment
description: Intersections of international development and environmental change; study of general theoretical perspectives balanced with case studies from the Global South.

name: Geography of Public Land and Water Policy
description: Geography of public land, water, and related public trust resources (wildlife, timber, minerals, fuels, recreation, wetlands, coastal zones, wilderness); historical geography of policy; spatial aspects of current research and management.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOG 202.
name: Microclimatology
description: Field techniques and processes in the atmospheric boundary layer including radiation, soil heat fluxes, turbulence, momentum, latent and sensible heat fluxes, moisture, and evaporation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOG 202 or equivalent.
name: Climatic Change and Variability
description: Observations and theories of climatic change and variability as they occur at different space and time scales. Projections of future climates. Techniques used in climatic change research and impact analysis.

name: Globalization and Cultural Questions
description: This course examines cultural understandings of and responses to globalization, examining topics such as its history and theories, migration, economic integration and inequality, identity, social movements, and the environment.

name: Beach-Dune Interactions
description: Influence of wind on coastal systems, with emphasis on nearshore currents, sediment transport and bedforms, aeolian transport, and dunes. Minimum Junior standing required.

name: Internship in Geography
description: Internship in government agencies, private-sector businesses, and non-profit organizations under the joint supervision of sponsor and departmental. A maximum of three credits may be applied to undergraduate Geography major or to Geography master's degree. May be repeated to a maximum of six credits.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Introduction to the Earth
description: Origin and nature of the earth with emphasis on internal processes and phenomena such as earthquakes, volcanoes, and mountain building; surface processes, including landform evolution. Three lectures and three laboratory hours each week.

name: Fossils and the Evolution of Life on Earth
description: Basic overview of fossils, including dinosaurs, and their importance for understanding earth history and the evolution of life. Three lectures and three laboratory hours each week.

name: Environment of the Earth
description: Analysis of basic energy cycles of the earth. Interaction of human activity with earth processes to affect the environment. Three lectures and three laboratory hours each week. Field trips required.

name: Cultural Geology
description: The growth of geological concepts, scientific and non-scientific. The impact of geological factors on human affairs. The role of time and evolution (biological and physical). Restricted to non-science majors.

name: Observing the Earth
description: An introduction to study of the earth through observation of ancient and modern earth systems in a field setting. Field trips required.

name: Earth Resources
description: Mineral, energy, and water resources with emphasis on geological processes governing their distribution. Intended for non-science majors. Three lecture hours each week with occasional field trips.

name: Coastal Environments of the Southeastern U.S.
description: Coastal zones of South Carolina and neighboring states, including geologic history, geomorphology, stratigraphy, hydrogeology, shoreline processes, environmental issues, and effects of man. Not available for geological science or marine science major credit. Three lecture hours each week plus optional field trips.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in GEOL 215 or MSCI 215.
name: Coastal Environments of the Southeastern U.S. (Laboratory)
description: Exercises examining coastal ecology, geomorphology, hydrogeology, shoreline processes, environmental issues, and human impact. Not available for marine science major credit. Two laboratory hours per week. Scheduled field trips required.

name: Geology of the National Parks
description: Examination of the geologic setting and scientific significance of selected National Parks. Three lecture hours.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in GEOL 101, GEOL 103, or GEOL 201; CHEM 111 recommended.
name: Rocks and Minerals
description: Chemical and physical processes of mineral formation in earth systems including an overview of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rock-forming processes. Includes laboratory. Field trips required.

name: Earth Systems through Time
description: Survey of earth history, the evolution of continents and oceans, the history of life, and geological dating methods. Includes laboratory and recitation. Required field trips. Taught alternate years.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in PHYS 201 or PHYS 211.
name: Surface and Near Surface Processes
description: Overview of groundwater, surface water hydrology, sediment transport, river systems, and coastal processes. Includes laboratory and recitation. Required field trips.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in GEOL 101, GEOL 103, or GEOL 201 and consent of instructor.
name: Field Studies in Geology
description: Directed field studies of extraordinary geological locations in North America. Requires a seven- to nine-day field trip during spring break.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOL 302.
name: Stratigraphy and Sedimentary Basins
description: Overview of sedimentary basins, sediment transport, sedimentation, depositional environments, stratigraphy, seismic stratigraphy, eustacy, and sedimentary petrology. Includes laboratory and recitation. Required field trips.

name: Processes of Global Environmental Change
description: The science of global change, its relation to the hydrosphere, atmosphere, lithosphere, and biosphere. Global system science, biogeochemical cycles, paleoclimatology, glaciation, and eustacy.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOL 302; MATH 122 or MATH 141.
name: Igneous and Metamorphic Processes
description: Origin and significance of igneous and metamorphic rocks, and relation to tectonic processes. Mineralogy, geochemistry, volcanism, plate tectonics, isostasy, heat flow. Includes laboratory and recitation. Required field trips.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOL 302; PHYS 201 or PHYS 211.
name: Structural Geology and Tectonics
description: Geologic structures and deformation of Earth materials. Stress and strain, deformation mechanisms, P-T-t paths, geologic maps, and structural regimes in plate tectonics. Includes laboratory and recitation. Required field trips.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOL 101 or GEOL 103 or GEOL 201.
name: A View of the River
description: Introduction to terrestrial and tidal river morphology and processes, with case studies of South Carolina. Field trips required.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Student research on problems of regional and fundamental significance, supervised by a faculty member of the student�€�s choice. Emphasis is on the development of critical thinking and lucid scientific report writing.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Student research on problems of regional and fundamental significance, supervised by a faculty member of the student�€�s choice. Emphasis is on the development of critical thinking and lucid scientific report writing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOL 325 and GEOL 355.
name: Field Geology
description: Geological field techniques including the use of field instruments and the preparation of geologic maps. Written and oral reports required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in GEOL 101.
name: Principles of Geomorphology
description: The process of earth denudation with emphasis on chemistry of weathering, stream and erosion hydraulics, quantitative analysis of land form evolution.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: MATH 122 or MATH 141.
name: Principles of Coastal Geomorphology
description: Geological and physical controls on the morphology, development, and stability of coastlines. Analysis of waves and erosional processes, and coastal zone morphodynamics. Several required field trips.

name: Regional Stratigraphy and Biostratigraphy of North America
description: Sedimentologic, biostratigraphic, and tectonic history of North America, approached from paleogeographic considerations with emphasis on the Atlantic Coastal Plain and Continental Margin. Three hours lecture and three hours recitation per week. Required field trips.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in GEOL 305.
name: Advanced Paleontology
description: Systematic, ecologic, biogeographic, and evolutionary aspects of paleontology; lectures, practical exercises, field trips.

name: Marine Micropaleontology
description: Marine microfossils; distribution, ecology, paleoecology, and biostratigraphy; use of microfossils in marine sediments to study oceanographic history. Three lectures and two laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOL 325.
name: Sedimentology
description: Modern concepts of sediment composition, sedimentary facies, depositional environments, and stratigraphy. Includes laboratory.

name: Surface to Subsurface Stratigraphy
description: Surface to subsurface stratigraphic interpretation and techniques; litho- and biostratigraphy; geophysical log interpretation and subsurface presentation.

name: Isotope Geology and Geochronology
description: Dating techniques for Pleistocene deposits, sediments, archaeological materials, igneous and metamorphic rocks.

name: Introduction to Geochemistry
description: Investigation of low temperature chemical reactions controlling the geochemistry of the earth�€�s surface. Emphasis on CO2, carbonates, oxidation-reduction, thermodynamics, isotopes, biogeochemistry.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CHEM 111, CHEM 112 and MATH 141.
name: Environmental Radioisotope Geochemistry
description: Introduction to radioactivity and the use of radionuclides to study environmental processes, including age-dating and biogeochemical cycling in aquatic systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOL 202.
name: Igneous Petrology
description: Petrography and petrogenesis of igneous rocks; evolution of contrasting petrotectonic terranes. Three lectures and three laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOL 202.
name: Metamorphic Petrology
description: Petrography and petrogenesis of metamorphic rocks in orogenic belts. Three lectures and three laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Must have passed two GEOL courses numbered 300 or above, or consent of instructor.
name: Plate Tectonics
description: Geological and geophysical evidence for plate tectonics, detailed development of the plate tectonics model, and present areas of research, including measurements of plate motion using satellite geodesy.

name: Field Methods in Geophysics
description: Application of two or more geophysical field methods to a current geological problem. Independent study contract required.

name: Earth Science for Teachers I
description: Origin, internal structure and internal processes of the earth, including plate tectonics, earthquakes, volcanoes, and mountain building. Required field trips, two lectures, and three lab hours per week. Cannot be used in MS or PhD programs in geology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDSE 548/GEOL 540.
name: Earth Science for Teachers II
description: Surface processes acting on the earth; introduction to weather and climate, weathering, erosion, and sedimentary processes; land form evolution; ocean currents and tides, near-shore geologic processes. Required field trips, two lecture, and three lab hours per week. Cannot be used in MS or PhD programs in geology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in least one course in GEOL, ENVR, MSCI or GEOG.
name: Methods in Geoscience Education Research
description: Introduction to methods used in discipline-based education research and their application to research questions in the geosciences.

name: Geological Oceanography
description: A comprehensive study of the origin and development of the major structural features of the ocean basins and the continental margins. Discussion of the techniques used in obtaining geologic data and the interpretation of sedimentary processes, vulcanism, and the stratigraphy of the ocean basins.

name: Marine Geophysics
description: Introduction to the nature and structure of the ocean floor as revealed by geophysical techniques. Two hours lecture and three hours laboratory.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 141 and PHYS 201 or PHYS 211.
name: Environmental Geophysics
description: Practical geophysical techniques for exploring the shallow subsurface. Seismic, resistivity, well log, gravity, magnetic method. Includes lectures and field exercises to collect and analyze data.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOL 325.
name: Sedimentary Simulations and Sequence Stratigraphy
description: Problems of sequence stratigraphy resolved with graphic computer simulations. Sedimentary fill of basins by carbonates and/or clastics tracked as a function of rate of sediment accumulation, tectonic behavior, and sea level. Includes laboratory.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOL 516.
name: Marine Sediments
description: Marine sedimentary environments; physical/biological factors which control the formation and distribution of modern marine sediments.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 141; PHYS 201 or PHYS 211.
name: Applied Seismology
description: Theory of seismic wave propagation. Seismic reflection data acquisition, processing, and interpretation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 241.
name: Elementary Seismology
description: Basic elements of seismology. Mathematical development of seismic wave equations; measurement, description, and interpretation of seismic data.

name: Seismic Reflection Interpretation
description: The interpretation of geologic structure using seismic sections. Recognition of apparent structure caused by velocity anomalies, multiples, and complex reflector geometry. Application to hydrocarbon exploration.

name: Coastal Processes
description: Physical and geological processes controlling the formation and evolution of beach, barrier, and nearshore environments, including discussion of coastal management issues.

name: Earth Resource Management
description: An approach to problems of resource management by lecture and seminar using case studies in mineral, energy, hydrogeological, and environmental science.

name: Environmental Field Geology
description: An introduction to field methods in sedimentology, structural geology, hydrogeology and geophysics with special reference to geological hazards and environmental problems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: A 200-level course in physical geography or geology or equivalent.
name: Long-Term Environmental Change
description: Climatic changes of the past and their impact on the physical landscape, with an emphasis on the Quaternary period.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 201 and MATH 141.
name: Introduction to Micrometeorology
description: Small-scale processes in the atmospheric boundary layers, including energy budget, radiation, soil heat transfer, humidity, viscous flows, turbulence, momentum and heat exchanges, evaporation, and marine atmospheric boundary layer.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOL 101 and CHEM 111 or their equivalents.
name: Environmental Hydrogeology
description: Environmental considerations of the hydrologic cycle, occurrence and movement of ground water, aquifer analysis, and water well emplacement and construction. Water quality, pollution parameters, and the geochemistry of selected natural systems. The effects of environmental problems, waste disposal, and urban development upon the aqueous geochemical regime.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PHYS 202 and MATH 142.
name: Soil Hydrology
description: Saturated and unsaturated water flow through soils, pore pressure development, runoff generation, and watershed response to rainfall. Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 142; MATH 241 is recommended.
name: Numerical Modeling for Earth Science Applications
description: Finite difference and finite element methods for solving the diffusion equation and advection-dispersion equation, with applications in hydrogeology, geophysics, geology, and marine science.

name: Air-Sea Interaction
description: The physical mechanism responsible for interaction between the ocean and the atmosphere and the influence of air-sea interaction on atmospheric and oceanic dynamics and thermodynamics on a wide variety of spatial/temporal scales.

name: Satellite Oceanography
description: This course provides knowledge of various techniques used in satellite remote sensing of the oceans. Key skills will be developed in satellite data processing, image analysis, and hands-on research.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MSCI 314.
name: Estuarine Oceanography
description: Estuarine kinematics and dynamics; classification of estuaries; estuarine circulation and mixing. Scheduled field trips are required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 241 and C or better in either PHYS 201 or PHYS 211.
name: Marine Hydrodynamics
description: Basic principles of fluid statics and dynamics. Conservation of mass, momentum, and energy; viscosity, vorticity, and boundary layers with examples from the marine environment. Applications to and analysis of ocean currents and waves.

name: Geology and Geochemistry of Salt Marshes
description: Geological and geochemical processes in salt marshes. Methods of geological research in marshes including instrumental techniques, sampling design, and data analysis. Two lectures per week plus four weekends of project oriented fieldwork and/or equivalent lab work. Scheduled field trips are required.

name: Senior Seminar in Geology and Geophysics
description: Advanced research topics in geology and geophysics; critical reading of literature, technical presentations, and written reports. Senior standing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CHEM 111 or equivalent.
name: Electron Microscopy and Microanalysis
description: SEM, ESEM, TEM, and EMPA, WDS quantitative analysis, EDS semi-quantitative analysis, EBSD, methods of sample preparation, and applications in varieties of disciplines. Two lecture and three laboratory hours per week.

name: Senior Thesis
description: Senior capstone experience, research on a problem on fundamental significance, supervised by faculty member; must include field study component, written final project report, and oral presentation at departmental seminar.

name: Beginning German I
description: Introduction to grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Restricted to those who have never studied German or who have placed by examination into GERM 109. Credit may be received only for one of the following GERM 109; GERM110; GERM 111; GERM 121.

name: Beginning German II
description: Introduction to grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Credit may be received only for one of the following: GERM 109; GERM 110; GERM 111; GERM 121.

name: Intensive Beginning German
description: Intensive introduction to grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Admission only to highly motivated beginning students who obtain permission of the department. Credit may be received only for one of the following: GERM 109 and GERM 110; GERM 111; GERM 121.

name: Elementary German
description: Grammar and vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Assumes prior experience in German. Admission only by proficiency examination. Credit may be received for only one of the following: GERM 109; GERM 110; GERM 111; GERM 121.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Admission either by placement examination or successful completion of GERM 110, GERM 111, or GERM 121.
name: Basic Proficiency in German
description: Practice and further development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GERM 122, or satisfactory score on Basic Proficiency Phase II placement test.
name: Intermediate German
description: Further development of listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills; discussion of selected literary texts, and current issues; intensive review of basic grammar structures.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: GERM 122, or satisfactory score on Basic Proficiency Phase II placement test.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: GERM 210.
name: Intermediate German
description: Reading strategies, a review, and expansion of grammar structures, supplemented with materials concerning current issues.

name: The Idea of Nature in Germany
description: The idea of nature in Germany from the 18th century to today. Focus on scientific, philosophical, social and political entanglements that prompt radical shifts in how German thinkers view nature.

name: Knights and Ladies
description: Survey of medieval romances and love lyrics of Germany. History and culture of the High Middle Ages in Germany, especially courtly society. The function of chivalry and courtly literature in society.

name: German Culture and Civilization
description: Survey of German cultural history from the Middle Ages to the present. Taught in English.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Viking Mythology
description: Survey of Germanic mythological and heroic texts of the Viking Age. History and culture of Germanic tribes, especially the Vikings. The function of myth in society.

name: Green Technology in Germany
description: Examination of roots and culture of environmentalism and related technological innovation in Germany. Comparison of green practices around the world to practices within Europe and U.S.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GERM 210 and GERM 211.
name: German Conversation
description: Continued practice in the four skills with focus on a selected aspect of German culture and society.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GERM 210 and GERM 211.
name: German Conversation and Composition
description: Continued practice in the four skills with emphasis on developing writing skills and with focus on a specific aspect of German culture.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in GERM 210 and GERM 211.
name: Advanced German for Business and Other Professions I
description: Development of advanced language and cultural skills necessary for functioning in the professional world of German-speaking countries.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GERM 310.
name: German Kabarett Production
description: Literary-historical analysis and discussion of texts from German Kabarett, including comedic skits, political and social satire, parody, humorous poetry. Semester ends with a public performance in German.

name: Study of German Abroad
description: Intensive language practice and cultural studies. May be repeated for credit by permission.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GERM 310 and GERM 311.
name: Readings in German Literature
description: An introduction to the literary genres illustrated by masterpieces in German poetry, drama, and prose.

name: Selected Topics
description: Taught in English. Intensive study of cultural and/or literary movements in German-speaking countries. Course content varies by title.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Corequisite: GERM 210 or higher.
name: Practicum in Teaching German to Young Children
description: Introduction to principles of foreign language instruction and field experience planning instruction and teaching German to children in local elementary schools.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GERM 310 and GERM 311.
name: Advanced German Grammar
description: Emphasis on advanced grammar structures, with continued development of all four skills (reading, writing, listening, speaking).

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GERM 310 and GERM 311.
name: Advanced German Conversation
description: Advanced practice in correct spoken idiomatic German with special focus on issues of the 20th century and contemporary culture.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in GERM 310 and GERM 311.
name: Advanced German for Business and Other Professions II
description: Development of advanced language and cultural skills necessary for functioning in the professional world of German-speaking countries. Preparation for standardized exams.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GERM 340.
name: Medieval German Literature and Culture
description: Survey of German literature and culture from the beginnings to 1350, including Germanic mythology and heroic poetry, conversion to Christianity, courtly romance and love lyric, mystical writings, art and architecture.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GERM 340.
name: The German Enlightenment and its Countercurrents
description: German literature and culture of the 18th century with emphasis on the period between 1750 and Weimar Classicism. May include major works by Lessing, Goethe, and Schiller.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GERM 340.
name: German Literature and Culture from 1800-1871
description: German literary, cultural, and intellectual developments from Unification to the end of WWII, including Naturalism, Expressionism, the Weimar Republic, the Third Reich, and the exile period.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GERM 340.
name: German Literature from 1890-1945
description: German literary, cultural, and intellectual developments from 1890 to 1945, including Expressionism, Weimar Republic, the Third Reich, and exile period.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GERM 340.
name: Post-War and Contemporary German Literature
description: German literary, cultural and political developments from Post-War destruction and reconstruction, through the Cold War period of division, with examination of the reunification process.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: advanced reading ability in German.
name: Survey of German Culture
description: Historical survey of the German contribution to the intellectual and cultural life of Europe. Texts and films in German.

name: Introduction to German Linguistics
description: Structural and descriptive linguistics applied to the German language.

name: History of the German Language
description: Development of German in the Germanic, Old High German, Middle High German, and New High German periods. Phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and the relationship between dialects and the standard language.

name: Introduction to the Germanic Languages
description: Introduction to historical Germanic linguistics including a survey of the Old Germanic languages (Old English, Old Frisian, Old Saxon, Old High German, Old Norse, Gothic); comparative phonology, morphology, and syntax, typology of modern Germanic languages and dialects; and common Germanic in its Indo-European context.

name: German Sociolinguistics
description: Introduction to the study of variation in Modern German. Traditional German dialectology and dialect geography, language and society, multilingualism in the German-speaking countries, German in contact with other languages.

name: Topics in German Film
description: Examination of recurring themes and issues or of significant periods and influential styles in German film. Course content varies and individual topics will be announced with course title.

name: Intensive Readings in German
description: Intensive reading for non-majors. Graduate students fulfill their foreign-language requirement with successful completion of the course. Undergraduates may take the course as an elective only by permission of instructor. Grades S/U for graduates and undergraduates.

name: Introduction to Global Studies Through Literature
description: Given that literature represents real policies and practices in the contemporary world and our ethical responsibility as global citizens, the course will focus on literature from different periods, nations, and regions across the world in order to better understand the way human experiences and different cultures relate. All literature will be read and taught in English.

name: Introduction to International Development
description: Critical, historical, and theoretical introduction to modern development practice. Includes extended discussions of contemporary best practices in the field.

name: Global Media Industries
description: Provides the foundation for the study of globalized film and media industries.

name: History of Capitalism 1: Ancient and Medieval World
description: History of "capitalist" economic behavior and culture in various premodern societies: the Ancient Middle East, Classical Greece, the Roman Empire, early Islamic society, medieval Christian and Islamic states, the Mongol period and the era of global expansionism; evaluation of competing theories about premodern economic life and the meaning of "capitalism"

name: History of Capitalism From the Industrial Revolution to the Global Economy
