description: A history of capitalism and its evolving definitions in Europe from the Middle Ages to the 20th Century, including its role in agriculture, mechanical industry, international trade, and colonialism and domination.

name: Topics in Global Studies
description: Selected topics in Global Studies. May be repeated with a change in topic. May be taken three times for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Two courses from the following: ANTH 102; GEOG 121; GEOG 210; LING 101; POLI 101; RELG 101.
name: Global Studies Internship
description: Academic counterpart to a professional work experience in which global or international affairs play a central role. Provides an introduction to foreign affairs and intercultural interactions in a working environment. Introduction to career possibilities for a student trained in global studies. Global Studies major with 3.0 or better GPA and completion of at least 45 credits.

name: Elementary Ancient Greek I
description: Basic grammar and vocabulary necessary for reading Classical and Koine Greek. Assumes no prior experience in the language.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GREK 121.
name: Elementary Ancient Greek II
description: Additional grammar and vocabulary necessary for reading Classical and Koine Greek.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GREK 121 and GREK 122.
name: The Greek New Testament
description: Readings in the Gospels and Epistles.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GREK 121 and GREK 122.
name: Plato
description: The life of Socrates based on the reading of Plato�€�s Apology and Crito in Greek. Supplementary reading in English from Xenophon�€�s Memorabilia and Aristophanes�€� Clouds.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GREK 121 and GREK 122.
name: Homer
description: Readings from the Iliad and the Odyssey in Greek. Discussion of the language, background, and composition of the poems.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Herodotus
description: Readings from the Histories.

name: Thucydides
description: Readings from the History of the Peloponnesian War.

name: Sophocles
description: Selected plays.

name: Euripides
description: Selected plays.

name: Hesiod and the Homeric Hymns
description: Readings from the Works and Days, the Theogony, and the Homeric Hymns.

name: Greek Seminar
description: Authors and topics not covered in other Greek language courses, chosen to meet the needs of individual students. May be repeated with the approval of the department.

name: Independent Study
description: Special projects for independent study and research.

name: Independent Study
description: Special projects for independent study and research.

name: Intensive Grammar Review of Ancient Attic Greek
description: Intensive review for nonmajors designed to prepare them for GREK 615.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GREK 614.
name: Intensive Readings in Ancient Attic Greek
description: Intensive reading for nonmajors. A review of grammar and syntax with reading of passages from Plato�€�s Apology. Primarily for graduate students to fulfill the foreign-language reading requirement.

name: Elementary Hebrew
description: Grammar and practical vocabulary for fundamental communication skills. Assumes no prior experience in the language. Offered only in fall.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: HEBR 121.
name: Basic Proficiency in Hebrew
description: Practice and further development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills. Offered only in spring.

name: Intermediate Hebrew
description: Review of the basic principles of grammar, with emphasis on reading, oral skills, and writing.

name: Intermediate Hebrew
description: Review of the basic principles of grammar, with emphasis on reading, oral skills, and writing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: HEBR 202 or equivalent.
name: Conversation and Composition
description: Practical training in the spoken and written language.

name: Selected Topics
description: Intensive study in selected and cultural topics related to Judaism. May be repeated for credit under different titles. Taught in English.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Special Problems in Higher Education and Student Affairs
description: The course is designed to provide opportunities for the study of special topics in higher education and student affairs administration.

name: European Civilization from Ancient Times to the Mid-17th Century
description: The rise and development of European civilization from its Mediterranean origins through the Renaissance and Reformation.

name: European Civilization from the Mid-17th Century
description: European development and expansion from the mid-17th century to the present.

name: Introduction to South Asian History
description: Political, cultural, and economic forces that have conditioned the development of institutions and ideas in South Asia.

name: Introduction to the Civilization of the Islamic Middle East
description: An analysis which treats the major cultural elements of traditional Islamic civilization and then concentrates upon the reactions of the Arabs, Turks, and Iranians to the problems of adjusting to the modern world.

name: Introduction to East Asian Civilization
description: The evolution of social, political, and cultural patterns in East Asia, with emphasis on the development of philosophical, religious, and political institutions and their relationship to literary and artistic forms in China and Japan.

name: Introduction to African History
description: An examination of several traditional sub-Saharan African societies and of their political and economic transformation in the modern, colonial, and post-independence periods.

name: Introduction to Ancient Near Eastern Civilization
description: The political, social, religious, economic, military, and intellectual development of Ancient Egypt, Mesopotamia, and adjoining areas from the origins of civilization until the seventh century A.D.

name: Science and Technology in World History
description: The development of science and technology and their roles in world civilizations from antiquity to the present.

name: Introduction to Latin American Civilization
description: A discussion of the political, cultural, and economic forces which have conditioned the development of institutions and ideas in Spanish and Portuguese America.

name: United States History to 1865
description: A general survey of the United States from the era of discovery to 1865, emphasizing major political, economic, social, and intellectual developments.

name: United States History since 1865
description: A general survey of the United States from 1865 to the present, emphasizing major political, economic, social, and intellectual developments.  Honors sections are available for students in the honors program.

name: American Founding Documents
description: Introduction to Declaration of independence, Constitution, Federalist Papers, Bill of Rights, landmark Supreme Court cases and constitutional amendments; exploration of these texts�€� historical context and debates about their meaning.

name: History of the American West
description: The history and development of an American region, �€�the West,�€? through the narratives of its diverse people and the effects of its complex geography.

name: The Practice of Public History
description: Introduction to the field of public history. Explores the challenges of portraying history in museums, parks, and other public history venues.

name: History of the Devil
description: A survey of the beliefs and practices associated with the demonic and the Devil from c 500 B.C.E. to the 20th century.

name: Introduction to the History Major: The Historian�€�s Craft
description: The nature of historical evidence, the formulation of historical questions, the process of historical research, and the construction of historical arguments using primary sources and secondary materials.

name: The Ancient Near East to 323 B.C.
description: The formation of ancient Near Eastern cultures, the ultimate synthesis of these cultures and the resulting establishment of the Near East as an historical entity.

name: Greek History and Civilization to 146 B.C.
description: The origins and development of Greek civilization in its political, economic, social, and cultural aspects with special attention being given to the early and late classical periods and the Hellenistic Age.

name: Roman Republic and Early Empire
description: The origins of Rome and shaping of its republican government, the spread of Roman rule in Italy and across the Mediterranean, the establishment of the principate and formation of one diverse imperial society and culture.

name: Late Antiquity: Imperial Rome to Islam
description: Political, social and religious transformation of the Mediterranean world, 2nd to the 8th century., including the rise of Christianity, the decline of Roman power, and the rise of Islam.

name: Greece and Rome in Film and Popular Culture
description: Representations of antiquity in cinema, television, and other contemporary media, with emphasis on Hollywood�€�s reception of Greek and Roman history.

name: Medieval Europe, ca. 300-1492
description: Topics include the formation of monarchies, the rise of Christianity, learning and universities, knighthood and social orders, and heresy and crusades.

name: Family and Society in Europe, c. 1200-1700
description: Explores the concerns and importance of families in pre-modern Europe. Topics include household furnishings and management, social classes, gender roles, family law, marriages, business, children, feuds, and sexuality.

name: Magic and Witchcraft in Europe, c. 1200-1700
description: Practices of, reactions against, and ideas surrounding magic and witchcraft during the late Middle Ages and the time of Europe's "Great Witch Craze".

name: Age of Renaissance
description: Social, cultural, and artistic movements in Italy and northern Europe from the Black Death (c. 1350) to religious reforms and revolutions (c. 1520).

name: Age of the Reformation
description: Religious, social, and political reforms from the rise of local religious protests (c. 1450) to the crisis of the 17th century. The rise of Protestantism and reactions in Catholicism.

name: The Age of Absolutism, 1648-1789
description: A survey of European political, economic, and intellectual development from the age of Louis XIV to the eve of the French Revolution.

name: French Revolution and Napoleon
description: The changes in France and Europe during the revolutionary decade, the rise of Napoleon, and the establishment of French hegemony over the Continent.

name: The Enlightenment
description: Intellectual and cultural history of the Enlightenment with particular attention to its relationship with the colonial world and its challenges to eighteenth-century states. Readings focused on primary sources.

name: Video Games and History
description: History in video games; comparison of selected games with historical scholarship, to assess the validity of the games�€� presentations of historical developments and the value of games to the understanding of history.

name: Nineteenth-Century Europe
description: Political, social, economic, and intellectual developments from 1815-1900, which brought European culture to its zenith and contributed to Europe's global domination.

name: Contemporary Europe from World War I to World War II
description: The Great War, revolution, and reconstruction; the rise of authoritarian and totalitarian regimes and the coming of World War II.

name: Europe from World War II to the Present
description: The Second World War and its origins; the Cold War; European recovery; a divided continent and Europe in the Global Era.

name: The History of Great Britain I
description: A survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural development of the British Isles from pre-history to the Restoration of 1660.

name: The History of Great Britain II
description: A survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural development of the British Isles since 1660.

name: The British Empire
description: Examination of the British Empire, tracing various historical themes as regions of world fell under British control, with particular attention to Ireland, India, and sub-Saharan Africa (especially South Africa) in the 17th Century-20th Century.

name: Slavery and Freedom in the Ancient and Medieval World
description: Exploration of varied forms of servitude in the ancient and medieval Mediterranean; examination of human bondage in the Hebrew Bible, ancient Greece, Roman society, late antique religious teachings, and medieval Christian and Islamic societies; study of ancient slavery in modern political debates, historians�€� writings, and television and film.

name: Byzantine History: 4th to 11th Centuries
description: The political, religious, and military developments within the Eastern Empire including its influence on Western and Slavonic Europe and Islam.

name: Byzantine History: 11th to 15th Centuries
description: The political and military developments within the Eastern Empire from the invasion of the Seljuk Turks to its final destruction by the Ottoman Turks.

name: The Crusades
description: Holy war and realpolitik in Mediterranean East-West relations from the 10th through the 15th centuries with emphasis on the role of the crusades in the cultural formation, development, and international relations of East and West.

name: Nineteenth-Century Britain
description: The political, economic, and social developments in Great Britain and Ireland during the Victorian Age.

name: Modern and Contemporary Britain
description: The political, economic, and social developments in Great Britain and Ireland during the 20th century.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: France Since 1815
description: A political and social history from the Bourbon Restoration to the present.

name: The History of Russia from the Earliest Times to the Mid-19th Century
description: The earliest life on the steppe, the Kievan State, the foundations of Moscow, and the Russian empire to the reign of Nicholas I.

name: The History of Modern Russia and the Soviet Union
description: The decline of Imperial Russia, the Revolution of 1917, Lenin, Stalin, and the Soviet Union since Stalin.

name: Russian and Soviet Diplomatic History
description: Imperial and Soviet foreign and military policies in the 19th and 20th centuries.

name: Modern Germany
description: A survey of German history including political, cultural, social, and economic developments from unification in 1871 to the present.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: The Slavs in History
description: An introductory survey of the civilization of the Slavic peoples. The historical traditions and culture of the peoples that occupy much of the Eurasian continent.

name: The Fall of the Eastern European Empires
description: Nineteenth-century eastern European states and peoples; the political and social forces leading to World War I.

name: Eastern Europe Since WWI
description: Survey of states in East-central and Southeastern Europe. Problems of national identity, modernization, and small state politics. Impact of WWII, the Cold war, the fall of communism, and the return to pluralism.

name: The Middle East in Modern Times
description: The impact of modern civilization upon the Middle East, including the history of the Arab, Turkish, Iranian, and Israeli segments of the Middle East during the 19th and 20th centuries.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: North Africa from Colonialism to Revolution: 1830-1962
description: A survey of French North Africa (Morocco, Algeria, and Tunisia) and Libya under colonial rule. The creation, development, and triumph of the nationalist movements, with particular attention to Algeria and its revolution.

name: The Contemporary Middle East and North Africa
description: Political, social, and economic history of the Middle East and North Africa in the years since World War II.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Saving Africa: Development and Humanitarianism in Historical Perspective
description: Exploration of how and why Africa is often represented as helpless, the colonial origins of common patterns of development and humanitarianism, and other possible models for these processes.

name: Africa to 1800
description: Social, cultural, economic, and political developments, focusing on internally and externally generated changes.

name: Africa since 1800
description: Commercial and religious revolutions of the 19th century, imposition and ending of formal colonial rule, and post-colonial issues.

name: Problems in the History of Africa South of the Sahara
description: Independent readings and written papers on appropriate topics.

name: Modern East Asia
description: Surveys modern development of East Asia from 1800 to the present.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Late Imperial China
description: Political, economic, social, and intellectual transformations of late imperial China from the Ming dynasty (1368-1644) through the last empire of China, the Qing dynasty (1644-1911).

name: China Since 1949
description: Introduction to the major social, economic, and political changes in China from the Communist Revolution in 1949 to the present.

name: Japan to 1800: Aristocrats and Warriors
description: The growth of the ancient state and the evolution of the samurai class and its political authority.

name: Japan since 1800
description: The development of modern Japan: political evolution, industrial growth, social change, war, defeat, and occupation.

name: Into the Wild: Global Conservation since 1800
description: Global and comparative environmental-historical investigation of the ecological, socioeconomic, and cultural significance of wilderness protection, nature conservation, national parks, and nature tourism; field excursions required.

name: East Africa and the Indian Ocean World
description: East Africans�€� contributions to an Indian ocean World that transcends single nation-states (stretching from Mozambique and Somalia to the Middle east, India and China) from the deep past to the present, including sections on �€�piracy,�€? Islam, slavery, race, and gender.

name: 1947 Partition of India and Pakistan
description: Causes, consequences, and legacies of the largest mass displacement in modern history: the division of British India into independent states of India and Pakistan. Focuses upon British imperialism, South Asian nationalisms, religious identity, mass violence between Hindus, Muslims, and Sikhs, and how these events are remembered.

name: History of Capitalism 1: Ancient and Medieval World
description: History of "capitalist" economic behavior and culture in various premodern societies: the Ancient Middle East, Classical Greece, the Roman Empire, early Islamic society, medieval Christian and Islamic states, the Mongol period and the era of global expansionism; evaluation of competing theories about premodern economic life and the meaning of "capitalism"

name: History of Capitalism 2: From the Industrial Revolution to the Global Economy
description: A history of capitalism and its evolving definitions in Europe from the Middle Ages to the 20th Century, including its role in agriculture, mechanical industry, international trade, and colonialism and domination.

name: History of Airpower
description: The evolution of airpower from the early 20th Century through the early 21st Century. The emphasis is on the development of various theories about the application of aerial force, and how operations in time of war have confirmed or challenged these theories from a multinational perspective.

name: History of Modern Sea Power
description: The evolution of sea power through the development of steam navies around the globe, 1860 CE - 2020 CE.

name: Nationalism: Myth and Reality
description: A comparative examination of the origins and development of nationalism and its impact on the modern world.

name: Nazis and Fascists in European History, 1919-1945
description: German and Italian political movements; emphasis on the role of leadership, propaganda, and ideology. Fascist movements in France, Rumania, Hungary, and Great Britain.

name: War and European Society, 1914-1945
description: Thematic examination of the nature and impact of total war on European society; emphasis on socio-economic, cultural, and military aspects.

name: Business in Historical Perspective
description: Capitalism in the Western world; the rise of modern corporate enterprise in Europe and America since 1850.

name: Urban Experience in Modern Europe
description: Social and cultural impact of urbanization in Europe since 1789 through a comparison of major cities such as London, Paris, Vienna, and Berlin.

name: Women in Modern Europe
description: Survey of women in European history from the eighteenth to the twenty-first century. Focus on women�€�s citizenship beginning with Enlightenment idea of rights through developments in modern feminism.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: History of the Holocaust
description: Introduction to Nazi Germany�€�s systematic mass-murder of Europe�€�s Jews and other minorities during World War II. Examination of forces that led to the Holocaust, including scientific racism, Nazi policy implementation, and dynamics of annihilation during war.

name: The Nobel Peace Prize: Peace, War, and Politics
description: Modern history through the lens of the Nobel Peace Prize. Limitations of the Nobel as encouragement to peace.

name: History of Medicine: Antiquity to the Scientific Revolution
description: A survey of the history of premodern medicine. How Western cultures of the past approached health and illness; anatomy; nutrition; sexuality; disease and plague; mental and emotional health; and more. From ancient Greece, through medieval and early modern Islamic, Jewish, and Christian approaches to medicine and the body.

name: Jewish History I: Late Antiquity to 1500
description: The religious, cultural, social, and political conditions that shaped the Jewish experience in the Near East and Europe from Late Antiquity to 1500.

name: Jewish History II: 1500 to the Present
description: Case studies of Jewish history in Europe, America, and the land of Israel, 1500 to the present.

name: The Expansion of Christianity
description: Critical epochs in the spread of Christianity. Consideration of the great crises that shaped the structure and form of Christianity during the last 20 centuries: the Hellenistic world; the medieval syntheses; the breakup of Western Christian unity; the transition to worldwide mission activity in the industrial age.

name: Islamic Institutions and Traditions
description: The religious, political, social and economic institutions and intellectual and scholarly traditions developed by Muslim societies throughout Afro-Eurasia from late antiquity to the present.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Messiahs, Mystics and Rebels in the Islamic World
description: Representative messianic movements, millenarian visionaries and apocalyptic imaginings in the Islamic world from the 7th century to the present, with attention to related developments in the Jewish and Christian traditions over the last two millennia.

name: Science, Magic and Religion
description: Occultism as a link between science and religion and its central role in Western intellectual and cultural history; the historical development of the science-magic-religion continuum in the Islamo-Christian world from late antiquity to present.

name: Engineering in History
description: History of engineering practices, professions, and sciences, as well as development of engineered artifacts from the Middle Ages to the present.

name: Information Technology: Past and Present
description: The history of the computer; how it acquired various forms through the 20th century; how information, as defined by computers, had shaped the world over the past century.

name: Making Modern Science: The Physical Sciences
description: The history of physics, chemistry, geology, and related sciences since the Scientific Revolution.

name: Making Modern Science: The Life Sciences
description: The study of the life from antiquity to the present. Investigates the origins of modern biology and medicine and how life has shaped scientific, political, and economic thought.

name: History of the Automobile
description: Evolution of the automobile from a conceptual idea through the present-day. Emphasis on analysis of the automobile's impact on culture, economics, the environment, politics, science and technology, and society.

name: Plagues and Societies in World History
description: A survey of biopolitical, social, economic, and cultural aspects of epidemic diseases throughout world history.

name: Evolution of Warfare I
description: A history of tactics, strategy, weapons, and logistics from 500 B.C. to A.D. 1400.

name: Evolution of Warfare II
description: A history of tactics, strategy, weapons, and logistics from A.D. 1400 to the present.

name: Sustainability in World History from Early Times to the Anthropocene
description: An interdisciplinary examination of sustainability around the world from social, environmental, technological, and economic perspectives from early times to the present.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Urban America in the Modern Age, 19th Century-present
description: Survey of the urban history of the United States from the 19th Century through today.

name: The Development of the American People to 1789
description: The founding of the English colonies, their developing maturity, the events leading to the Revolution, and the creation of a new nation.

name: The New Nation, 1789-1828
description: The new republic and the developing democratic spirit in politics and culture.

name: The Sections and the Nation, 1828-1860
description: The three cultures of East, South, and West; their interactions and the events leading to the Civil War.

name: Civil War and Reconstruction, 1860-1877
description: The political, military, and social history of the War and the reorganization which followed.

name: The Rise of Industrial America, 1877-1917
description: A survey of recent United States history with emphasis on the economic, social, and literary developments from 1877 to 1917.

name: The United States and a World at War, 1917-1945
description: The United States and a World at War, 1917-1945.

name: United States History Since 1945
description: A survey of the political, economic, social, and cultural developments in the period after World War II.

name: The History of South Carolina, 1670-1865
description: A study of South Carolina origins and developments.

name: History of South Carolina Since 1865
description: A survey of recent South Carolina history with emphasis on social and institutional development.

name: History of Canada
description: A survey of Canadian development from colony to modern nation.

name: Voices of America: U.S. History Through Biography
description: Historical exploration of the daily lives and personal stories of Americans through biographies and ethnographies.

name: Histories of Native America
description: Experiences of Native people in North America from the period before European colonization through the 21st Century.

name: Colonial Latin America
description: The establishment and consolidation of the Spanish and Portuguese empires in the Western hemisphere; interaction of Indians, Africans, and Iberians, and the formation of social, economic, and political traditions in Latin America; political independence.

name: Modern Latin America
description: Traditional society in the area and problems arising from social, economic, and political changes since independence; comparative studies of national responses to these problems.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Social and Economic History of Latin America
description: The evolution of social groups and changes in economic patterns in Latin America from pre-Columbian times to the present.

name: History of Mexico
description: Mexico from the pre-conquest period to the present, with an emphasis on modern Mexico.

name: Caribbean Race and Slavery, 1500-1900
description: The roles race and slavery played in shaping Colonial Caribbean History from the pre-Columbian Civilizations to the end of the 19th century.

name: Everyday Life in Colonial America
description: The customs, mores, attitudes, and living conditions of men and women of the 17th and 18th centuries. Emphasis on the common people of the American colonies.

name: The American Revolution
description: The causes of the Revolution; the events of the period and their implications.

name: The Old South
description: Development of Southern society and of the forces that made the South a distinctive section of the United States.

name: The New South
description: Reconstruction, the Bourbon era, agrarian revolt, industrial revolution, racial problems, and the changes resulting from the impact of two world wars and the New Deal (1865-1946).

name: The Civil War in American History
description: The causes, events, and results of the Civil War.

name: The Reconstruction of the Nation
description: The events and results of the attempt to reorder the American nation after the Civil War.

name: Immigration and Ethnicity in America
description: Issues of immigration, assimilation and nativism in the United States, 1840 to 1930.

name: American Empire: Policy, Society, and Culture
description: Examines the full sweep of American history through the lens of empire, covering especially the linkages between U.S. foreign policy and American domestic culture.

name: American Environmental History
description: Interaction of cultural values, economic interests, public policy, and technology with the physical environment over time.

name: American Popular Culture Since 1890
description: A history of the contributions of the popular aspects of American culture and their interactions with American institutions.

name: The History of American Medicine
description: The development of the art and science of medicine as practiced in the United States from colonial times to Medicare. Emphasis on the social history of American medicine.

name: The History of Science in America
description: The development of science in America from colonial times to the present. Special attention will be given to defining those factors, scientific, economic, and social, which have raised American science to its commanding position in the 20th century.

name: Technology and American Society
description: The historical development of technologies and technological systems in the American context.

name: The American Civil Rights Movement
description: Examination of the origins of Jim Crow and the multi-faceted struggle against it, and other forms of racial inequality, in the American South and the rest of the US since the early 20th century.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: American Thought to 1865
description: The transfer and adaptation of European ideas to a new environment and the development of new patterns.

name: American Thought since 1865
description: The maturation and extension of a national culture.

name: Southern Intellectual and Cultural History
description: Intellectual and cultural developments characteristic of the Southern region from colonial times to the recent past.

name: Jim Crow: Histories & Revivals
description: This course critically examines the continuities and discontinuities between Jim Crow and our current historical and political moment.

name: History of American Women
description: The social, political, and economic roles and changing status of women in America.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: American Diplomatic History
description: A historical survey of American foreign policy and foreign relations. First semester: to World War I. Second semester: World War I to the present.

name: American Diplomatic History
description: A historical survey of American foreign policy and foreign relations. First semester: to World War I. Second semester: World War I to the present.

name: American Military Experience
description: Transformation of war and of the institutions for waging war from the American Revolution to the present.

name: Constitutional History of the United States
description: A study of the constitutional development of the United States from the creation of the Articles of Confederation to the Civil War. It deals primarily with problems of governmental organization, judicial interpretation, and sectional politics.

name: Constitutional History of the United States
description: An analysis of the growth of constitutional power from 1860 to the present, giving special attention to the constitutional problems of the Civil War period, the increasing role of the judiciary in national affairs, and the general extension of constitutional authority in the 20th century.

name: American Jewish History
description: Examination of experiences of Jews in the United States from Colonial Period to late 20th century, especially Jewish immigration, political behavior, social mobility, religious affiliation, group identity formation, and meaning of Anti-Semitism in American and global contexts.

name: Historic Preservation
description: Overview of historic preservation as the practice of protecting and conserving places that tell stories about the past.

name: Digital History
description: Introduction to Digital History that examines ways to engage and adapt the discipline of history to technological trends and explores new approaches and interpretive techniques.

name: Material Culture in the Digital Age
description: Examination of material culture (objects and artifacts a society produces) as primary sources for historical research; how these sources are transformed when digitized; and the nature of born-digital resources.

name: Oral History
description: Methodology, application and usage, historic and current literature, identification and examination of available resources.

name: Internship in Public History
description: Professional practice in museums, archives, preservation organizations, and other agencies involved in historical research, advocacy, and preservation of historical resources and history programming for public audiences.

name: Topics in History
description: Reading and research on selected historical subjects. Open only to juniors and seniors with permission of the instructor.

name: Topics in History
description: Reading and research on selected historical subjects. Open only to juniors and seniors with permission of the instructor.

name: Topics in History
description: Reading and research on selected historical subjects. Open only to juniors and seniors with permission of the instructor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: HIST 300.
name: Senior Seminar
description: Principles of historical research and writing as applied to the seminar topic. Open to history majors or by special permission of instructor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: HIST 300.
name: Senior Seminar
description: Principles of historical research and writing as applied to the seminar topic. Open to history majors or by special permission of instructor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: HIST 300.
name: Senior Thesis
description: Principles of historical research and writing. A senior year thesis related to one of the advanced courses in the major program.

name: The Middle East and the United States: 1800 to the Present
description: Political, cultural, and economic ties which have linked the Middle East to the United States. Middle Eastern views of these relationships and their impact on modern Middle Eastern history.

name: Topics in History
description: Reading and research on selected historical topics. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

name: South Carolina History
description: South Carolina since colonization.

name: The American South Comes of Age
description: Changes in the Southern region since 1940.

name: Historic Preservation Field Experience--Charleston, S.C.
description: On-site introduction to historic preservation including research, interpretation, management, and economics of preservation. Offered only in Charleston during summer term.

name: Introduction to Health Promotion, Education, and Behavior
description: The historical and philosophical basis, current problems, career opportunities, and literature in the health promotion, education, and behavior change professions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: HPEB 300.
name: Practicum in Health Promotion
description: Practical experience in applying health promotion principles in the community or organization.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Personal and Community Health
description: Psychosocial health, stress management, leading infectious and noninfectious diseases, nutrition, physical fitness, sexuality, consumer health and health care access, environmental health, aging, and death.

name: Health Education for the Elementary School
description: Methods and materials for elementary schools. Integration and correlation of materials with school subjects. Sample content developed for primary, intermediate, and upper grades.

name: First Aid and Emergency Preparedness
description: Emphasis upon preparing school personnel to act responsibly in emergency situations. Includes the American National Red Cross standard and advanced first aid instruction.

name: Independent Study
description: Enrollment and topic to be approved in advance by advisor and instructor. Open to sophomores and above.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: HPEB 221, HPEB 223, and HPEB 224.
name: Health Education
description: Methods of teaching health in school and community settings; techniques and strategies.

name: Safety and Safety Education
description: Place of safety in modern life. Contributing factors to accidents, developing an awareness of the potential accident situation with special emphasis upon school setting, planning for and conduct of a safety education program.

name: Principles of Global Health
description: Examination of major global health topics and approaches used by governmental, non-governmental, international institutions and donor agencies to improve health in low and middle income countries. Critical analysis and generation of intervention strategies to combat health issues in various country settings.

name: Social Determinants of Health
description: The social, cultural, economic, and political factors that influence health and its distribution within and between populations. How society helps shape our health beliefs, behaviors, and status.

name: Food Systems
description: Multiple dimensions of food systems along multiple dimensions of theory and practice. Restricted to Junior or Senior level standing.

name: Food Systems Capstone Seminar
description: Synthesis and application of content and competencies of the minor in nutrition and food systems in a practical setting with emphasis on student identified areas for professional growth. Restricted to Senior level standing.

name: Special Topics in Health Promotion, Education, and Behavior
description: A study of special topics in health promotion, education, and behavior. Individual topics to be announced in master schedule by title.

name: Human Sexuality Education
description: Planning, implementation and evaluation of effective sexuality education programs. Includes strategies for educating about a variety of sexuality topics (e.g., reproductive biology, relationships, HIV/AIDS, sexual orientation, pregnancy, childbirth, and parenting).

name: Applied Aspects of Human Nutrition
description: Application of nutrition principles including functions of food and nutrients in health and disease prevention throughout the life cycle. Applied topics include weight management, food safety, and other contemporary issues.

name: Health Promotion in a Changing Society
description: Promoting individual and community health in an ever-changing society with a focus on prevention.

name: Southern Discomfort: Public Health in the American South
description: Investigation of the unique health and disease profile of the American South, including regional disparities that remain unresolved despite a public health revolution. Topics range from endemic diseases of the antebellum period to the current HIV/AIDS crisis, and ethics of research.

name: Race, Ethnicity, and Health: Examining Health Inequalities
description: A comprehensive overview of race/ethnicity and health. Class discussions will focus on comparing health status and health outcomes of different racial/ethnic groups in the U.S. and discussing possible explanations for inequalities from a behavioral science perspective.

name: The Total School Health Program
description: A course designed to acquaint the student with the various facets of the modern school health program. Includes school responsibilities for health and safety instruction, school health services, school environmental health problems, school and community relationships, resources for health, and evaluation of programs.

name: Drug Prevention
description: Nature of drug actions, motivational factors that influence the use and abuse of drugs, and examination and evaluation of procedures to provide effective drug prevention efforts.

name: Tobacco Prevention and Control in Public Health
description: Examines policies and practices for tobacco prevention and control in public health.

name: Consumer Health in Contemporary Society
description: An analysis and appraisal of issues related to the production and distribution of products and services as these activities affect consumer health.

name: Behavioral Concepts and Processes for the Health Professional
description: The development of interpersonal skills in dealing with health clients in various settings.

name: Medical Anthropology: Field Work
description: Application of observation techniques, field notes, informant interviewing, and secondary data analysis to interpreting differential perceptions of health problem solving in the community and clinic.

name: Medical Anthropology
description: Socio-cultural factors in health, illness, healing, and in medical systems. Cross-cultural and ethnographic evidence for public health research and program applications.

name: Community Health
description: Identification and analysis of major community health problems, their causes, the roles of individuals, community agencies, and government in affecting their solutions. Emphasis upon personal involvement and the responsibility for community health.

name: Managing Stress
description: Conceptualizing the nature of the stress; psychological, emotional, and spiritual aspects of stress; competency in the active management of stress and mobilizing support.

name: Cooking Up a Storm: Food, Globalization, Localization, and Health in the South
description: The role of food in defining our relationships to our family, community, nation, and world. How food underlies much of the political, economic, and social struggles throughout the world.

name: Nutrition Through the Life Cycle
description: Examination of nutritional concerns, requirements, and metabolism from pre-conception through the aging process; analysis of cultural, environmental, psychosocial, physical, and economic factors affecting nutritional status through the life cycle; and methods for assuring adequate nutrition through dietary selection, promotion of healthy eating throughout the life cycle and nutritional assessment for each state of the life cycle.

name: Maternal and Child Health
description: Public health issues, social and behavioral science, policies, programs, and services related to maternal and child health in the United States and other countries.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender (LGBT) Health
description: Health status and concerns of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender communities. Includes an examination of measurement issues and methodological considerations in research, as well as intervention efforts targeting LGBT populations.

name: Health Promotion for Elementary and Middle School Teachers
description: A multimedia course emphasizing health education strategies for major S.C. health problems, risk factors, and concepts of positive health behavior.

name: Behavioral Economics in Public Health
description: The ways behavioral economics can help achieve goals in public health and health care. How behavioral insights can be applied to reach promotion aims ranging from achieving weight loss to medication adherence to appointment attendance.

name: Nutrition Assessment and Counseling
description: Assessment of nutritional outcomes and work with research participants/patients. Methods for collection of dietary data, anthropometry, and body composition, including the use of new technologies. Nutrition counseling and interviewing techniques useful in gathering nutrition information.

name: Maternal and Child Nutrition
description: A survey of current concepts in clinical and public health nutrition which are unique to infants, children, and pregnant and lactating women.

name: Social Networks, Social Capital, and Health
description: Examination of health sciences and sociological research on social networks, social capital, and health. Theoretical and methodological foundations for network analysis of social relationships and health, design of public health interventions, and use of online social networks to promote health. Key constructs include social support, social capital, and social diffusion.

name: Addressing Childhood Obesity through Community Approaches
description: Approaches for prevention of childhood obesity, using perspectives from public health, social work, exercise science, pharmacy, medicine, and behavioral nutrition. Training to teach diet/physical activity lessons in elementary school settings.

name: Laboratory Techniques in Physiological Measurement
description: Practical laboratory skills and theoretical bases of measurements in human physiology; bioelectrical potentials, respiratory physiology, energy expenditure, body composition, temperature regulation, and biochemical assays.

name: Contemporary Topics in Sexual Health
description: Comprehensive overview of contemporary topics in sexual health.

name: HIV/STI Prevention
description: The role of effective behavioral interventions in preventing the spread of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and other sexually transmitted infections (STI) among diverse populations.

name: Independent Study
description: Topics to be assigned and approved by advisor and department head.

name: Independent Study
description: Enrollment and topic to be approved in advance by advisor and instructor.

name: Health Economics
description: Designed to serve as an introduction to economic principles and applications used in the health sector. The role economics plays in various aspects of health care, demand-side and supply-side factors and issues, how various health care systems are impacted.

name: Special Topics in Health Services Policy and Management
description: Emerging issues in Health Services Policy and Management. May be repeated for a total of 6 credit hours as content varies by title.

name: Introduction to Health Care Management and Organization
description: Provide students with overview of health services management, management techniques and the different roles and functions of the different health care services. Use of field trips and guest speakers from different health care providers.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Fundamentals of Rural Health
description: Overview of the delivery and financing of health care in the rural U.S., with emphasis on vulnerable rural populations and access to care.

name: Comparative Health Systems and Health System Efficiency, Effectiveness, Sustainability and Equity
description: Comparative health systems of the world including health system organization, management, financing, resource use and health outcomes.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: HSPM 500.
name: Issues in Health Care Information Management
description: An introduction to data management in healthcare institutions for undergraduate students and non-HSPM major graduate students. Topics include the nature of medical data, legal protections surrounding such information, and basis strategies for managing information technology resources.

name: Introduction to Health Services Delivery and Policy
description: Overview of health services delivery in the United States, including organization and financing of health care, health insurance practices, primary and long-term care among other topics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BADM 225.
name: Finance in Health Administration
description: Introduction to health care finance. Course will teach reimbursement structures, regulatory mechanisms, cost control, and related factors unique to healthcare organizations.

name: HRSM Professional Development Seminar
description: Strategies, tactics, and requisite skills for career success in the hospitality, retail, sport, entertainment, and technology industries. Course must be taken prior to HRSM internship.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in HRTM 364, and SPTE 203, and RETL 362.
name: Event Production, Evaluation, and Analysis
description: This course examines and analyzes the effectiveness and efficiency of events in Hospitality, Tourism, Sport, Entertainment and Fashion and Retail Management industries. Event production, evaluation, and analysis will be conducted. Detailed activities involved in event production, evaluation, and analysis will be discussed and implemented.

name: Internship
description: The internship is a supervised work experience in the student�€�s major area of study.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Senior status, and HRSM student (SPTE, HRTM, RETL, or BAIS).
name: Senior Seminar
description: Integration of prior academic work through the examination of problem inquiry, conduct of research, application of a solution development and the completion of a research paper.

name: Introduction to Careers in Education
description: A survey of professional issues and concerns in education.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: EDTE 101.
name: Practicum in Careers in Education
description: Seminars and visits to schools and classrooms.

name: Issues and Trends in Teaching and Learning
description: Introduces and examines current issues and trends in teaching and learning.

name: Global Citizenship and Social Responsibility through Education
description: Examining the continuing evolution of education and the direct impact on the development of social responsibility, values, and our place as global citizens.

name: Convergence and Divergence in African American and Jewish Relations: Historical and Contemporary
description: An examination of African American and Jewish American inter-ethnic, historical and contemporary connections and disconnections. Implications for educational, social, and social settings are considered.

requisiteText: Corequisite: EDFN 300 and enrollment in an approved community experience.
name: Learning Through Community Service
description: Documentation and synthesis of community service activities designed to prepare professional educators.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: admission to the professional program of education.
name: Teaching Internship in Foreign Languages
description: Application of effective teaching techniques and organization of instructional settings in foreign languages for K-12.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: admission to the professional program in education.
name: Directed Teaching in Foreign Languages
description: Students apply methods of curriculum and assessment, professionalism, effective teaching, and organization of instructional settings during internship in foreign language classroom.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Integrated Curriculum at the Middle Level
description: Constructing, teaching, and assessing an integrated curriculum for students in middle schools. Upper level undergraduate students exploring middle level education.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: admission to internship II in early childhood or elementary education.
Corequisite: EDTE 590B and EDTE 590C.
name: Internship in Curriculum and Assessment
description: Internship for practice in classrooms appropriate to the level of certification sought (early childhood or elementary) related to curriculum design and assessment.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: admission to internship II in early childhood or elementary education.
Corequisite: EDTE 590A and EDTE 590C.
name: Internship in Teaching
description: Internship for practice in classrooms appropriate to the level of certification sought (early childhood or elementary) related to interactive teaching.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: admission to internship II in early childhood or elementary education.
Corequisite: EDTE 590A and EDTE 590B.
name: Internship in Professional Roles
description: Internship for practice in classrooms appropriate to the level of certification sought (early childhood or elementary) related to professional roles.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Systematic Effective Teaching
description: Application of research-supported effective teaching techniques to the teaching-learning process, including demonstration lessons, observations, and supervisory conferences.

name: Cooperative/Team Learning in Education
description: Instructional approaches, materials, and procedures for utilizing cooperative/team learning in education.

name: Integrated Reading and Writing Instruction
description: Theoretical bases and techniques for teaching reading and writing in the elementary school, using multiple subject areas.

name: Whole Language: Concepts and Practices
description: Development of concepts, materials, and practices to implement a whole language philosophy.

name: Restructuring Schools: Teachers and Classrooms
description: Examination of issues related to restructuring schools based on different assumptions about teaching, learning, and assessment.

name: Middle Level School Today
description: National trends in the middle level school; emphasis on the relationship of early adolescent developmental characteristics to organization, curriculum, instruction, and teaching.

name: Integrating Character Education into Instructional Programs
description: Rationale, processes, and methodologies for integrating character education into school or school district instructional programs.

name: Service Learning for Schools, Community, and Workplace Responsibility
description: Assist school personnel in designing academic, personal, civic, and workplace responsibility.

name: Technology to Support Instruction
description: Introduction to computers, educational technology, and selected applications for instructional management.

name: Computers in Science Education
description: Use of computer technology in teaching and managing science classes and problems in grades K-12.

name: Thriving in the Tech Age
description: Pervasive impact of computers on today's global society; skills and strategies for using technology. How information technologies impact daily life and drive change.

name: Advanced Business Document Preparation
description: Emphasis on production and versatility in preparing business documents. Not for TSTM majors. For business teacher certification.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Introduction to Computer Hardware and Software
description: Understanding of current computer hardware and software through computer building, repairing, and troubleshooting.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Business Communications
description: Theory and processes in written business communications; composing effective business letters and reports.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: keyboarding.
name: Word Processing Concepts and Technology
description: Introduction to word processing concepts and applications.

name: Introduction to Networking
description: Understanding the essential concepts of computer networks, including standards, topologies, security, media, switching, routing, and more.

name: Computer Applications in Business I
description: Survey of core skills and techniques for spreadsheet design and analysis of business problems.

name: Introduction to Databases
description: Fundamentals of modern database design and applications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ITEC 264.
name: Records Control
description: Analysis and control of office records including creation, processing, maintenance, protection, and disposition.

name: Cybersecurity Operations
description: Operations in Security Operations Centers (SOC). Securing information systems by monitoring, analyzing, detecting, and responding to security events.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITEC 242, ENGL 462, ENGL 463, or MGMT 250; C or better in ITEC 370.
name: Professional Internship Seminar
description: Preparation for professional internship.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CSCE 204 or ITEC 204.
name: Software Design
description: Survey of core software development principles, application development from pseudocode and flow charting through coding process.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in either ITEC 101, CSCE 101, or CSCE 102.
name: Introduction to Web Systems
description: Introduction to web based systems, including HTML, CSS, and JavaScript; working with Content Management systems (Wordpress, Joomla); Accessibility, SEO, and web development best practices.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITEC 265.
name: Database Systems in Information Technology
description: Survey of techniques for working with enterprise-level database systems.

name: Special Topics in Information Technology
description: Advanced concepts, issues, and trends in information technology. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be taken twice for credit.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department head for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CSCE 204, ITEC 204, or CSCE 145; C or better in ITEC 362.
name: Introduction to Human Computer Interaction
description: Human computer interaction: human factors of interactive software, methods to develop and assess interfaces, interaction styles, and design considerations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITEC 245.
name: Advanced Networking and Security
description: Advanced administration of client/server networks with major emphasis on network operating system software.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITEC 101 and ITEC 245.
name: Management of Information Technology
description: Overview of current practices and trends in end-user technology and information system management.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITEC 352, or C or better in CSCE 146.
name: Mainframe Systems
description: Introduction to the large scale computer systems used by businesses to support thousands of simultaneous users and process millions of transactions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITEC 352, or C or better in CSCE 146.
name: Job Control Language
description: Programming in job control language used to process batch jobs on mainframe computers. Use of standard system utility programs.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITEC 445.
name: Information Technology Security for Managers
description: Information technology security from a managerial perspective, including security awareness, risk assessment, and security policy development.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITEC 301.
name: Professional Internship
description: Internship coordinated by a faculty member and supervised by an approved business supervisor. Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department head is required for undergraduate students.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITEC 444.
name: Training Systems
description: Theory, design, and implementation of technology-based training systems, including hardware and software solutions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITEC 245.
name: Telecommunications
description: Telecommunications systems, applications, and equipment allowing for the global dissemination of information.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CSCE 204, ITEC 204, or CSCE 145.
name: Linux Programming and Administration
description: Shell scripting and administration in the Linux operating system.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITEC 264 or MGSC 290.
name: Project Management Methods
description: Project management principles and standard practices, including software applications for project management.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITEC 362.
name: Advanced Web Support Systems
description: The development of advanced, dynamic, Web-based information systems, including the integration of back-end database-records management systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both ITEC 362 and ITEC 560.
name: Capstone Project for Information Technology
description: Application of project management software, technologies, and practices to the design and implementation of real-world capstone projects.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITEC 370.
name: Database Management and Administration
description: Introduction to database administration and implementation using an enterprise-level Relational Database Management System (RDBMS).

name: Special Topics in Integrated Information Technology
description: Advanced concepts, issues, and trends in technology support and training management. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated twice for credit.

name: Introduction to Interdisciplinary Inquiry
description: A study of the history, philosophy, and theory of and modes of inquiry in interdisciplinary studies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MKTG 350, FINA 363.
name: Introduction to International Business
description: Provides an introduction to frameworks, tools, and factual knowledge useful for understanding the institutional and competitive environment and managerial challenges of firms engaged in international business. Restricted to business administration majors. International business majors excluded.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ACCT 226, MGSC, 291, ECON 221 and ECON 222.
name: Globalization and Business
description: The business opportunities and threats for individuals, companies, and countries created by the growth of globalization, and how companies must operate in diverse foreign environments and engage in specialized transactions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 222 and FINA 363.
name: International Financial Management
description: The financial management of a multinational business enterprise.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MKTG 350.
name: International Marketing
description: Cultural, legal, political, and economic factors affecting international marketing of products and services. Emphasis on differences in life styles, beliefs, attitudes, etc., and their influences upon marketing decisions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: International Entrepreneurship
description: Develop a business plan for a global startup, integrate international strategy into the business model and financing strategy, analyze the costs of internationalization.

name: International Information Systems
description: An examination of the challenges and opportunities associated with the development, management, and use of global information systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGMT 374.
name: International Human Resource Management
description: This course examines how human resources are managed within a global context. It examines how human resources are managed within global firms as well as across different cultural settings.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Business Anthropology
description: Analyze the relevance of anthropological theory for business, diverse business cultures, and their impact on global business practices.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Foreign Market Entry and Growth
description: International market selection, global market entry, and growth and regional expansion strategies. Topics covered through readings, case studies, and an international marketing simulation game.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Cross-Cultural Behavior and Negotiations
description: Understanding of cross-cultural differences and their effects on individual behavior and business practices in organizations.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Exporting and Importing
description: The conduct of international trade, including terms of sale (INCOTERMS), financing arrangements, means of payment, credit insurance, shipping and insurance issues, support services, and trade facilitation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Competitive Strategies in Developing Countries
description: Strategies multinational companies use to compete in developing countries. Topics include management of political risk, impact of culture, and corporate responsibility and ethics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Global Competitive Analysis
description: The course examines how to leverage the competitive advantage of the firm to another country, access comparative advantages of another location, and link these two to create cross-country advantages.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Global Stakeholder Management
description: Survey of the managerial, political, economic, sociological and psychological foundations of global stakeholder management and engagement through extant theory and case study examples of successful and failed stakeholder management strategies in various industries and multiple countries.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Islamic Economics and Finance
description: Introduction to Islamic economics and financial systems and their relationship to multinational corporations and international business.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Comparative Innovation Systems
description: To analyze how innovation is approached by firms in different institutional climates around the world.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both IBUS 310, and MGSC 291.
name: Research in International Business
description: This seminar introduces students to research issues related to conducting studies in a cross-cultural setting. Students also develop an awareness of current international research programs.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Intercultural Competencies for Working in International Teams
description: How to recruit, lead, and collaborate more effectively in international teams by examining differences related to culture, work-values, economic climate, and career progression.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: The Business Case for Services Offshoring
description: How to formulate and present a professional judgment on a corporate initiative (like services offshoring) with a sound business case based on the elements of cost, benefit, risk, and strategic flexibility.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Economic Globalization: Leadership and the Transnational Mindset
description: Explore evolving and emerging issues facing international business leaders in the 21st century to develop a greater understanding of economic globalization and the intersection of the public, private, and non-profit sectors and their interrelationship with particular emphasis on security.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Social Networks and Global Leadership
description: Survey of social network theories and evidence, such that you are able to better identify, build, and navigate the social settings in which your career unfolds. Concepts are applied to several case studies of multinational enterprises to illustrate the network coordination challenges of global business.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in IBUS 310.
name: Market Development and Global Strategy
description: Theoretical and comparative empirical perspectives on the roles of state and business in the development of emerging markets, sociopolitical frameworks of economic reform, and the impact of business strategies on development.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in FINA 341 for Risk and Insurance Majors.
name: Risk Management and Security Strategies in International Business
description: An interdisciplinary understanding of how multinational enterprises interact with political, sociocultural and economic environments worldwide and the ability of leaders to develop effective strategies in navigating complex security risks.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Business in Latin America
description: Discussion of the contemporary business environment of and business practices in the countries of Latin America.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Business in Asia
description: Discussion of business environments and business practices in countries in Asia.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Business in Europe
description: Discussion of business environments and business practices in the countries from Western, Central, and Eastern Europe and Russia.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Business in Africa
description: Discussion of business environments and business practices in the countries of Africa.

name: Specialized Study in International Business
description: Topics in international business. Reading and research on selected topics in the practices in the international business environment. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of courses by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in IBUS 310.
name: Social Networks and Global Leadership
description: A survey of social network theories and evidence that provide theoretical, empirical and practical examples of how different social network configurations achieve different function goals. Concepts are applied to case studies of multinational enterprises to illustrate the network coordination challenges of global business.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in IBUS 310 for undergraduates, no prerequisite for graduate students.
name: Ethnographic Methods in International Marketing
description: Analyze the relevance of anthropological theory for business, diverse business cultures, and their impact on global business practices.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: IBUS 310 for Undergraduates.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: DMSB 714 or IBUS 705 or IBUS 707 for Graduate Level.
name: Business in Latin America
description: Discussion and analysis of business environments and business practices in the countries of Latin America.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: IBUS 310 for Undergraduates.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: DMSB 714 or IBUS 705 or IBUS 707 for Graduate Level.
name: Business in Asia
description: Discussion and analysis of business environments and business practices in the countries of Asia.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: IBUS 310 for Undergraduates.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: DMSB 714 or IBUS 705 or IBUS 707 for Graduate Level.
name: Business in Europe
description: Discussion and analysis of business environments and business practices in the countries of Europe.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: IBUS 310 for Undergraduates.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: DMSB 714 or IBUS 705 or IBUS 707 for Graduate Level.
name: Business in Africa
description: Discussion and analysis of business environments and business practices in the countries of Africa.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in IBUS 310.
name: Specialized Study in International Business
description: Topics in international business. Reading and research on selected topics in the practices in the international business environment.

name: Elementary Italian
description: Grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ITAL 121.
name: Basic Proficiency in Italian
description: Practice and further development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills.

name: Accelerated Basic Proficiency in Italian
description: Accelerated development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills to obtain the Basic Proficiency Level in Italian. Credit may be received only for one of the following: ITAL 121 and ITAL 122, or ITAL 130.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ITAL 122.
name: Intermediate Proficiency in Italian I
description: Practice and rapid development of accurate skills in speaking, listening, reading and writing. Features BBC television course.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ITAL 221.
name: Intermediate Proficiency in Italian II
description: Practice and further rapid development of accurate skills in speaking, listening, reading and writing. Features BBC television course.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITAL 122 or ITAL 130.
name: Accelerated Intermediate Italian
description: Accelerated development of intermediate level listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills in Italian. Credit may be received only for one of the following: ITAL 221 and ITAL 222, or ITAL 230.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITAL 222 or ITAL 230 or by placement.
name: Italian Conversation
description: Oral practice with advanced protocols of Italian conversation, focusing on perfecting rhythms and tonalities, and on a clear presentation of meaning.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ITAL 222 or ITAL 230
name: Writing in Italian
description: Introduction to letter, short essay, and creative writing, and to newspaper reports and selected essays as models of self-expression.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ITAL 122.
name: Advanced Italian Study Abroad
description: Intensive language practice, emphasizing oral proficiency skills and advanced conversational protocols. Classroom instruction by native speakers, extensive contact with native environment, field trips. May be repeated for credit by permission.

name: Selected Topics
description: Intensive study of selected literary and cinematic topics of the Italian world. May be repeated for credit as topic varies by title. Taught in English.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ITAL 310 and ITAL 311, or ITAL 350.
name: Contemporary Italian Civilization
description: Significant values in the Italian cultural heritage, as presented in native print and visual media.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ITAL 310 and ITAL 311, or ITAL 350.
name: Twentieth Century Italian Literature
description: Selected plays, short stories, novels and poems which characterize quality achievements by Italians, and which promote a better understanding of Italian life.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ITAL 310 and ITAL 311, or ITAL 350.
name: The Italian Love Lyric
description: Italian love poetry, beginning with the "Dolce Stil Nuovo" of the late Middle Ages and ending with post-WWII avant-garde poetry.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ITAL 310, ITAL 311 and ITAL 312, or ITAL 350.
name: Business Readings in Italian
description: Selected literature from the Italian business world, such as correspondence, brochures, specialized newspapers and magazines, biographies of businessmen, prospectuses, and annual reports.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ITAL 310 and ITAL 311, or ITAL 350.
name: Advanced Conversation and Composition
description: Prepares students for making lengthy formal reports in Italian, both written and oral, on topics of importance for success within an Italian environment.

name: Italian Literature in Translation
description: Italian writers, focusing on the works of Dante, Petrarch, and Boccaccio, with additional selections from later authors.

name: Post-World War II Italian Cinema
description: Italian films of high esthetic value that present major cultural concerns of post-WWII Italians. Skills in film criticism and analysis. Films are subtitled. Taught in English.

name: Senior Project
description: Directed independent research project, with a formal presentation and public discussion.

name: Independent Studies in Italian Literature
description: Special topics in Italian literature.

name: Independent Studies in Italian Literature
description: Special topics in Italian literature.

name: Intensive Readings in Italian
description: Graduate students fulfill their foreign language reading requirement with successful completion of the course. Undergraduates may take the course as an elective only.

name: Elementary Japanese
description: Grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Assumes no prior experience in the language.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JAPA 121.
name: Basic Proficiency in Japanese
description: Practice and further development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills. Admission only by successful completion of Japanese 121.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in JAPA 122 or by placement.
name: Intermediate Japanese I
description: Review and continuation of fundamentals of the language; development of oral and reading skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JAPA 221.
name: Intermediate Japanese II
description: Review and continuation of fundamentals of the language; development of written and oral expression.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JAPA 121 and JAPA 122.
name: Reading and Writing Japanese
description: Acquisition and advancement of kanji literacy and writing skills. Development of foundational skills to review basic kanji and to aid in inferring the meaning of higher level kanji.
