Covers 250 kanji characters with complementary instruction through many mediums (brush writing, postcards, meishi).

name: Introduction to Japanese Culture
description: Introduction to Japanese culture through an examination of cultural elements such as traditions, arts, history, geography, people, society, and religion. Taught in English.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in JAPA 222.
name: Advanced Japanese I
description: Improvement of skills in conversation and composition; advanced reading in modern Japanese materials.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JAPA 321.
name: Advanced Japanese II
description: Continuation of JAPA 321, with emphasis on strengthening proficiency in the use of Kanji.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JAPA 222 or JAPA 223.
name: Japanese for Business I
description: Development of language skills specific to the Japanese business world and its practices.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JAPA 331.
name: Japanese for Business II
description: This is a continuation of JAPA 331.

name: Introduction to Japanese Culture and Literature
description: Introduction to Japanese literature and its cultural background. Conducted in English, but some background of Japanese is recommended.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JAPA 340.
name: Modern Japanese Literature
description: Survey of modern Japanese literature and its cultural background up to the present. Conducted in English, but some knowledge of Japanese is required.

name: Japanese Culture and Society through Film
description: Examination of Japanese culture and contemporary society using selected films. Taught in English.

name: Japanese Culture and Society through Theatre
description: Introduction to Japanese traditional theater and its influences on Japanese culture and society. Taught in English.

name: Japanese Culture and Society through Animation
description: Examination of Japanese culture and contemporary society through studying of popular animations. Taught in English.

name: Selected Topics
description: Intensive study of selected topics in Japanese literature and culture. May be repeated for credit as topic varies by title. Taught in English.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JAPA 322, JAPA 323.
name: Advanced Japanese III
description: Development of proficiency in speaking, reading, and writing through advanced studies of authentic Japanese materials.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JAPA 421.
name: Advanced Japanese IV
description: Strengthening proficiency in writing and reading.

name: Japanese Language in Society
description: Japanese language and communication in its socio-cultural context; emphasis on comparison with American English. Taught in English.

name: Convergence and Divergence in African American and Jewish Relations: Historical and Contemporary
description: An examination of African American and Jewish American inter-ethnic, historical and contemporary connections and disconnections. Implications for educational, social, and social settings are considered.

name: Introduction to Judaism
description: Overview of Jewish experiences, beliefs, practices from a contextual point of view.

name: Hebrew Bible (Old Testament)
description: Modern study of the Hebrew Bible from historical, literary, and archeological points of view. Reading and analysis of texts in translation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Literature and Film of the Holocaust
description: Film, poetry and literature created in response to the Holocaust as the means for a decades long cultural discussion, in European and American societies, of the moral and religious implications of the Holocaust on our self-understandings as religious and moral beings.

name: Jewish History I: Late Antiquity to 1500
description: The religious, cultural, social, and political conditions that shaped the Jewish experience in the Near East and Europe from Late Antiquity to 1500.

name: Jewish History II: 1500 to the Present
description: Case studies of Jewish history in Europe, America, and the land of Israel, 1500 to the present.

name: Jews and Muslims
description: Jewish-Muslim relations in the Near East and the US; an exploration of Jewish-Muslim encounters, issues of religious law, politics, radical religious ideologies, and their repercussions for today.

name: American Jewish History
description: Examination of experiences of Jews in the United States from Colonial Period to late 20th century, especially Jewish immigration, political behavior, social mobility, religious affiliation, group identity formation, and meaning of Anti-Semitism in American and global contexts.

name: Visions of Apocalypse
description: Symbolic visions, tours of heaven and hell, cosmic battles, divine judgment, messianic figures, prophecy, or other forms of revelation as found in literature, art, or social movements from diverse geographical and historical locations.

name: Special Topics in Jewish Studies
description: Intensive study of special topics in Jewish Studies; may emphasize interdisciplinary themes. Maybe be repeated as content varies by title.

name: History of the Holocaust
description: Introduction to Nazi Germany�€�s systematic mass-murder of Europe�€�s Jews and other minorities during war. Examination of forces that led to the Holocaust, including scientific racism, Nazi policy implementation, and dynamics of annihilation during war.

name: Media and Society
description: Principles, history, philosophies, theories of the mass media and allied professions and their societal role and impact.

name: Principles of Public Relations
description: Methods used by business, government, consumer groups, minorities, environmentalists, and others to influence public attitudes toward their activities.

name: Principles of Advertising and Brand Communications
description: An introduction to the advertising and strategic communications industries. Discussion of the structure and history of the business, social impacts and regulation, research, planning, creative, media planning, sales promotion, event promotion and the integrated nature of all promotional communication.

name: Principles of Visual Communications
description: Theory and history of visual communication in the mass media emphasizing informational and persuasive messages created by graphic, photographic, and multimedia processes.

name: Principles of Journalism
description: Principles and foundations of journalism to reflect both how journalism serves communities and how its techniques are developed to effectively communicate to audiences.

name: History and Philosophy of the Mass Media
description: Development of the mass media in the United States from colonial times to the present. The effects of American social, cultural, political, and economic theory on the media.

name: Special Topics in Mass Communications
description: Readings, critical review, discussion and analysis addressing significant issues in mass communications. Topics may change from term to term. May be repeated for credit with different course topics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 101 and STAT 201 or equivalent.
name: Account Planning: Mining Insights
description: Topics include data mining from secondary sources, and use of primary research tools such as surveys, focus groups, ethnography and projective techniques.

name: Special Topics in Sports Media
description: Topics addressing issues in the world of the sports media. Topics may change from term to term. May be repeated for credit with different topics.

name: Journalism Trends
description: Study and analysis of current and emerging issues in journalism philosophy and practice and how audiences perceive it. Emphases may change as practices evolve and issues emerge.

name: Writing for Mass Communications
description: Basic writing skills for all areas of the mass media. Lecture-laboratory.

name: Law and Ethics of Mass Communications
description: Examination of First Amendment free speech and press guarantees and limitations, including commercial speech regulation, libel, privacy, copyright, trademark and open records and meetings, and related ethical principles for mass communications professionals.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Internet and Social Media Law
description: Examination of the origins and history of First Amendment and related law and ethics, with an emphasis on how they apply to the Internet and social media.

name: Theories of Mass Communications
description: Survey of predominant theories in mass communications including mass media uses, functions, and effects.

name: Media and Youth
description: An introduction to media uses and effects research, considering cognitive, affective, and social development as a framework for analyzing media effects on youth.

name: Minorities, Women, and the Mass Media
description: The study of the relationship among persons of color, women, and the mass media in the United States.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 202 and JOUR 291.
name: Toolkit for Concept Development
description: Students will learn the theories and methods of applying consumer and brand insights to creative briefs and concepts.

name: A Focused Look at Brand Communications
description: Topics in advertising and strategic communications. Individual topics and prerequisites to be announced with title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 101.
name: Advertising and Brand Communications Speakers Series
description: Advertising and brand communications industry experts share insights about industry trends, innovative campaigns and careers.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in all of the following JOUR 291; JOUR 201 or JOUR 202.
name: Social Media Marketing Strategy
description: Instruction on how to align social media with business objectives and overall communication strategies; and exploration of how organizations have incorporated social media into various departmental functions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 201 and a course in basic statistics.
name: Mass Communications Research
description: Fundamentals of mass communications research methods and applications. Survey, observational and experimental research; primary research data-gathering techniques; secondary research sources; data analysis; message, market, competitive and audience research measures.

name: Public Relations for Nonprofit Organizations
description: Theory and practice of developing public relations strategies and messaging for nonprofit organizations with a focus on audience research, donor relations, membership recruitment and fund raising.

name: Special Topics in Public Relations
description: Special topics course addressing current issues, problems, and/or trends in public relations. Topics may change from term to term. May be repeated for credit with different course topics.

name: Social Media for Sports Media
description: Effective social media use in the world of the sports media. Topics relating to advertising, journalism, public relations, visual communications, and mass communications will be discussed. Provides contextual background on various social media and uses exercises to develop best practices.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in JOUR 203 or ARTS 102.
name: Graphics for Visual Communications
description: The personal computer and software related to the design and production of graphic and photographic images for print and onscreen media.

name: Photography for Visual Communications
description: Introductory photography that includes digital SLR camera use, multiple lenses, lighting, editing and distribution for web and display. Emphasis is on storytelling images for publication in editorial and persuasive media.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 291.
Corequisite: JOUR 361L.
name: Introductory Reporting and Writing
description: Basics of news reporting: Story generation, critical thinking, story development, writing, shooting and editing broadcast stories, writing Web stories, using visual components of still pictures, graphics and video.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: JOUR 291.
Corequisite: JOUR 361.
name: Introductory Reporting and Writing Lab
description: Basics of news reporting: Story generation, critical thinking, story development, writing, shooting and editing broadcast stories, writing Web stories, using visual components of still pictures, graphics and video.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 291.
name: Editing
description: Skills and techniques required in preparing stories for publication. Laboratory work includes editing various kinds of copy and writing headlines.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 204 and JOUR 291.
name: Social Media and Mobile Journalism
description: This course provides an introduction on how to use online social platforms and mobile tools following journalistic editorial guidelines. Students will get an overview of the digital-first mindset that informs and enriches their professional preparation.

name: Business Basics for Communications
description: Students will gain a fundamental understanding of business and how write about it. Students will learn how various aspects of business, finance and the economy relate to individuals, communities, companies, governments and world events and how to communicate that impact.

name: Sports Media and Society
description: History of sports media and an analysis of current relationships between the sports industry, athletes, media, social media and the audience.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 291.
name: Podcasting and Audio Production
description: This course is designed to teach you the fundamentals of audio storytelling, from conception and field gathering skills to writing for the ear and basic non-linear audio production. You will learn to distinguish the ways audio stories differ from those in print, and produce different types of media projects.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 291.
name: Digital Signage
description: This class is introduces you to what is rapidly becoming the "fifth screen" digital signage, its place in modern communications, some of the issues surrounding it and how to create and evaluate content for it. Students will evaluate the SJMC digital sign system and may create content for it.

name: Diversity Topics in Mass Media
description: Topics addressing the intersection of race, gender, sexual orientation, or other forms of diversity or marginality and mass media. Topics may change from term to term. May be repeated for credit with different topics.

name: Special Topics
description: Topics in journalism and mass communications. Individual topics and prerequisites to be announced. Some topics may have prerequisites; check with student services or the syllabus for the section you are interested in.

name: Digital Media and Big Data Analysis
description: Understanding digital media concepts including AI, blockchain, net neutrality, big data, privacy, and network analysis.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 220, JOUR 316 and JOUR 317.
name: Creative: Strategy to Execution
description: Principles and practices of developing creative and effective brand communications and to acquire proficiency in execution of brand communications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 202.
name: Media Analysis
description: Research and development of a media plan using integrated communications approach and simulation models.

name: Super Bowl Commercials
description: An exploration of how Super Bowl commercials reflect and influence our society. Topics include the way different groups are portrayed, the strategy behind the commercials, and how creative tactics have evolved.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 201 and JOUR 291.
name: Public Relations Writing
description: Special areas of writing for public relations.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 101, JOUR 201, JOUR 291 and JOUR 436.
name: Advanced Public Relations Writing
description: An applied writing skills laboratory that will review and create advanced types of public relations writing and study applicable theory, models and research methods.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 436.
name: Media Relations
description: Planning and writing skills to effectively execute media relations, including how to research reporters and outlets, build a media relations plan, create messaging platforms, identify and prepare spokespeople, manage crisis communications and employ social media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 201.
name: Leadership and Internal Relations Management
description: Leadership and communication inside an organization as a component of public relations management; strategy, change management, ethics, employees from executive to labor, and organizational theory applied to engage internal stakeholders.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 291.
name: Sports Announcing
description: This course is designed to introduce students to various aspects of live sports broadcasting. Students will learn skills and techniques that will prepare them to perform live on-air duties including game play-by-play and color analyst.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 203, JOUR 346 and STAT 110.
name: Informational Graphics
description: Visual presentation of quantitative and spatial information. Examines the planning, design, and preparation of statistical graphs, charts, timelines, diagrams, and maps.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 347.
name: Video for Visual Communications
description: Theory, skills, and techniques to create high-quality videos and multimedia for use in a variety of media applications, including editorial assignments, informational messages and persuasive communications. Emphasis on one-person producer with minimal equipment telling stories for non-traditional media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 347 and JOUR 447.
name: Multimedia for Visual Communications
description: Team-based multimedia storytelling with an emphasis on studio and location lighting to produce professional-level photography projects and short videos for use in a variety of applications, including editorial assignments and persuasive communications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 346.
name: Design of Online Content
description: Introduction to the skills and processes involved in the design and display of online content such as interactive graphics, animation, and video. Considerations for designing and delivering content on a variety of platforms from personal computers to mobile devices.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 347, ARTS 261, ARTS 361, or ARTS 260.
name: Studio and Location Lighting for Still Photography
description: Still photography lighting techniques for mass media applications. Emphasis on studio and on-location lighting of portraits, fashion, illustrations, food and product photography.

name: Freelancing for Creative Professionals
description: The theory and practice of entrepreneurship as they apply to creative professionals interested in starting their own freelance business.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 347, ARTS 261, or ARTS 361, or by instructor permission.
name: Photojournalism
description: Immersive course in long-form photojournalism storytelling. Students will spend the semester documenting a topic, with emphasis on gathering images with high technical level and compelling content. Class will edit content and create a presentation for the public compelling content.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 291.
name: Sports Journalism
description: This course introduces students to the core principles, values, and best practices that guide the work of professional sports journalists. Students will develop skills that are necessary to function as sports journalists in today�€�s media environment.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 204, JOUR 303, JOUR 361.
name: Intermediate Reporting and Production
description: Continuing development of students�€� ability to identify, gather, write, edit and present news, responsibly and ethically, across a range of formats, alone and in teams.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 361.
name: Power Producing
description: Examines the art and skill of television news producing, providing students the opportunity to learn about the production process in a real-world, hands-on environment.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 361 or JOUR 447.
name: Special Topics in Nonfiction Storytelling with Emerging Technologies
description: Students produce in-depth journalism projects using a range of storytelling tools and technologies, such as: websites, interactive graphics/maps, HD- and 360-video, drones, AR/VR technology, and podcasting. May be repeated for credit with different topics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 101 or SLIS 201.
name: Communication and Information Transfer
description: An overview of the communication models, major concepts, trends, and other related issues of information transfer with a focus on information seeking and use in digital age.

name: Special Topics
description: Topics in journalism and mass communications. Individual topics will vary by title. Prerequisites to be announced in class schedule.

name: Freedom, Responsibility, and Ethics of the Mass Media
description: Historical development of freedom, responsibility, and ethics in the mass media, including communication theories, pressures, ownership.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: International Mass Communications
description: A comparative study of world mass communications media, with particular attention to press systems, the sources and flow of international news, and the problems and implications of world communications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 101.
name: Mass Media Criticism
description: Development of critical thinking skills for analyzing mass media.

name: Health Communication: The Science and Practice
description: Explores the role of journalism in shaping perceptions of scientific issues and task. Emphasis on methods of effectively communicating about science, health, and the environment.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 291 and junior or senior standing or consent of instructor
name: Faith, Values, and the Mass Media
description: Faith and values influence the media. An examination of the influence, why it happens, and of religious diversity and the increased public presence of religions, including Hinduism and Islam.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 501, JOUR 506, or JOUR 542.
name: Mass Communications Capstone Portfolio
description: Development of Mass Communications E-portfolio showcasing and reflecting on coursework and experiential learning, with a focus on leadership, as preparation for matriculation in higher education or careers in mass media.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 416.
name: Advanced Creative Advertising
description: Development of writing styles for print and broadcast advertising.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 416 and JOUR 421.
name: Integrated Campaigns
description: The development of a complete, well coordinated integrated communications plan that incorporates research and analysis techniques, critical thinking, team work, creative and tactical skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 332, JOUR 416, JOUR 421.
name: Brand Communications Practicum/Competitions
description: Application of advertising techniques and skills in preparation of full scale campaign.

name: Interactive Communication Strategies
description: The development of a complete, well-coordinated integrated communications plan that incorporates research and analysis techniques, critical thinking, team work, creative and tactical skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 202.
name: Advertising Management
description: The dynamics of leadership and management in the creative industries.

name: Creative Leadership
description: Theories of leadership as applied to creative industries. Students will engage and interact with community-based organizations to assess needs, plan communications strategies, lead student teams in developing those ideas, and present to clients. Junior standing or permission of instructor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 201, JOUR 332, JOUR 436.
name: Public Relations Campaigns
description: Development of public relations campaigns for business and social institutions. Case studies of public relations campaigns and programs.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 201, JOUR 436.
name: Public Relations Management
description: Researching, programming, staff, budgeting, and planning public-relations programs by business, government, or consulting firms.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 291.
name: Publication Writing and Design
description: Publication writing and design as well as internal or constituent communications, specifically focused on an internal audience. Production of InterCom, the College of Mass Communications and Information Studies�€� alumni magazine.

name: Crisis Communications
description: Introduction to crisis communications and management from a strategic, theory-based approach using research from historical and current case studies.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 101; JOUR 201; JOUR 203 or JOUR 202; and JOUR 291.
name: The Carolina Agency
description: Participation in a functioning communications agency working for actual clients in a student-directed environment. Opportunity to both lead and be a part of a team servicing the communication needs of various clients.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 332 and JOUR 436.
name: The Bateman Team
description: Self-directed development and implementation of a public relations campaign as part of a national competition: PRSSA�€�s Bateman Competition.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 101.
name: Ethics in Public Relations and Public Policy
description: Review of the analytical process of resolving complex ethical issues and cases in public relations; study of the philosophical approaches to communication ethics.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Public Opinion and Persuasion
description: Theory and practice of persuasive communication and the role of persuasion in shaping public opinion.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 391.
name: Sports Media Capstone
description: A focus on career goal setting, personal branding and leadership in sports media; students will develop a comprehensive ePortfolio showcasing their knowledge, skills and ability to excel in a sports media position.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 566.
name: Advanced Magazine Article Writing
description: Writing techniques used in the preparation and marketing of major nonfiction articles for national, regional, and local publications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 446, JOUR 447, JOUR 449.
name: Capstone Portfolio Development
description: Advanced techniques of graphic and multimedia design and their application to problem-solving situations in the mass media. Emphasis on portfolio development.

name: Public/Civic Journalism
description: To gain an understanding of theory and practice of public/civic journalism, seen by its advocates as socially responsible journalism that attempts to build civic participation and empower communities.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 361 or JOUR 436.
name: Magazine Article Writing
description: Researching, organizing, writing, and marketing articles for publication in general and specialized publications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 291.
name: Editorial and Opinion Writing
description: Content and style; writing of editorials, analyses, and commentaries.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in JOUR 291.
name: Data Journalism
description: Acquiring, analyzing and presenting data using spreadsheets and other tools to uncover stories and provide depth and context to journalism.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: JOUR 326, JOUR 333, and JOUR 434.
Corequisite: JOUR 502, JOUR 503, and JOUR 526.
name: Broadcast Journalism Practicum
description: Production of public affairs programs.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 361.
name: Reporting Public Affairs
description: Concentrated analyses of reporting in special fields, particularly in the South, including coverage of government, business, labor, the arts and sciences.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: JOUR 325.
name: Broadcast Announcing
description: Theory and practice of professional broadcast announcing. Lecture-demonstration-laboratory course in principles underlying professional performance before microphones and cameras and the various broadcast performance functions.

requisiteText: Corequisite: JOUR 587, JOUR 589, and JOUR 590 or JOUR 586, JOUR 588 and JOUR 590.
name: Advanced Reporting Topics
description: Study and application of highly specialized reporting on topics related to current public discourse. May be repeated as content varies by title.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: JOUR 471.
Corequisite: JOUR 588 and JOUR 590.
name: Capstone I - Advanced Reporting - Broadcast and Online Journalism
description: Professional practice in meeting daily newscast deadlines through work on the Carolina News television newscast. Focus on polished reporting, performance and production techniques and demonstration of advanced television reporting skills under deadline pressure.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: JOUR 471.
Corequisite: JOUR 589 and JOUR 590.
name: Capstone I - Advanced Reporting - Multimedia Journalism
description: Professional practice in shaping journalistic reporting to the multimedia environment. Application of news gathering, synthesizing and reporting across platforms �€“ print and online, textual and graphic �€“ in timely fashion.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: JOUR 471.
Corequisite: JOUR 586 and JOUR 590.
name: Capstone II - Advanced Broadcast and Online Journalism Production
description: Advanced newscast production skills developed in the context of producing daily Carolina News broadcast. Shape and coordinate reporting and production team under deadline pressure in newsroom setting.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: JOUR 471.
Corequisite: JOUR 587 and JOUR 590.
name: Capstone II - Advanced Multimedia Journalism Production
description: Editing and design employed to maximize effectiveness in the multimedia environment. Creating accurate and engaging content to reach consumers in varied ways reflecting contemporary consumer use of media.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: JOUR 471.
Corequisite: JOUR 586 and JOUR 588 or both JOUR 587 and JOUR 589.
name: Capstone III - Digital Journalism
description: Exposure to the evolving variety of journalism techniques, software programs and equipment to effectively tell compelling stories and convey information in multiple visual and interactive forms. Emphasis on extending professional skills while reinforcing current best practices.

name: Domestic Study Away in Journalism and Mass Communications
description: Domestic study away course will focus on topics in journalism and mass communications and will be taught away from the University of South Carolina Columbia campus. Individual topics will vary by title. Prerequisites to be announced in class schedule.

name: Study Abroad in Journalism and Mass Communications
description: Study abroad course will focus on topics in journalism and mass communications and will be taught as a study abroad experience. Individual topics will vary by title. Prerequisites to be announced in class schedule.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: consent of Sequence Chair and Dean�€�s Office prior to registration.
name: Internship in Mass Communications
description: Supervised professional experience. Maximum of three hours credit. Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department head is required.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Directed Independent Studies
description: Individual mass media projects. Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department head is required for undergraduate students.

name: Advanced Special Topics
description: Advanced topics in journalism and mass communications. Individual topics and prerequisites to be announced by title in class schedule.

name: Elementary Korean
description: Grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Assumes no prior experience in the language.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: KORE 121.
name: Basic Proficiency in Korean
description: Practice and development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: KORE 122.
name: Intermediate Korean I
description: Review and continuation of fundamentals of the language; development of oral and reading skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: KORE 221.
name: Intermediate Korean II
description: Increased emphasis on written and oral expression in Korean.

name: Beginning Latin I
description: Introduction to grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental reading skills. Admission to 109 restricted to those who have never studied Latin, who have not studied Latin in the previous five years, or who have a score of L-1 on the placement test.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: LATN 109.
name: Beginning Latin II
description: Introduction to grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental reading skills. Credit may not be received for both LATN 109/LATN 110 and LATN 121.

name: Elementary Latin
description: Grammar and vocabulary necessary for fundamental reading skills. Assumes prior experience in Latin. Admission only by proficiency examination. Credit may be received for only one of the following: LATN 109/LATN 110 or LATN 121.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: LATN 110 or LATN 121.
name: Basic Proficiency in Latin
description: Practice and further development of essential reading skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: LATN 122.
name: Advanced Readings in Latin Literature
description: A survey of Latin literature designed for the student who wishes to develop a major or cognate in Latin.

name: Virgil
description: Readings from the Aeneid.

name: Latin Literature of the Golden Age
description: Selected readings in prose and poetry of representative authors.

name: Latin Composition
description: A study of Latin syntax in order to translate English prose into Latin. Instruction is individualized.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Latin Drama
description: Selected plays of Plautus and Terence.

name: Cicero
description: Readings from a variety of Cicero�€�s works to gain a concept of the man as a humanist.

name: Horace
description: Readings from the Odes.

name: Ovid
description: Selected readings from the Metamorphoses.

name: Tacitus
description: Agricola or selections from the Annales.

name: Livy
description: Readings from Ab Urbe Condita.

name: Roman Satire
description: Readings in Horace, Juvenal, and Petronius.

name: Latin Erotic Poetry
description: Readings from the elegies of Catullus, Tibullus, Propertius, and Ovid.

name: Lucretius
description: Readings from the De Rerum Natura.

name: Renaissance Latin
description: An examination of several genres of Latin writing from Europe during the period 1400-1600, emphasizing, but not limited to, Italian writers.

name: History of Latin Literature from the Origins to the Golden Age
description: Readings from the Twelve Tables to Virgil, supplemented by readings in history and scholarship. Designed to prepare majors and honors students for further study.

name: History of Latin Literature in the Silver Age
description: Readings from Ovid to Ammianus, supplemented by readings in history and scholarship. Designed to prepare majors and honors students for further study.

name: Independent Study
description: Special projects for independent study and research.

name: Independent Study
description: Special projects for independent study and research.

name: Teaching Advanced Latin in Secondary School
description: Methods and materials for teaching the Latin Advanced Placement courses in secondary school.

name: Intensive Grammar Review in Latin
description: Intensive grammar review for non-majors; designed as preparation for LATN 615.

name: Intensive Readings in Latin
description: Intensive reading for non-majors. Graduate students fulfill their foreign-language reading requirement with successful completion of the course. Undergraduates may take the course as an elective only.

name: Latin American, Caribbean, and Latino/a Cultures through Film
description: Interdisciplinary introduction to the diversity of landscapes and political and social issues in Latin America�€�s history. Films, lectures, and readings provide an overall comprehensive perspective. Lectures by faculty in Spanish, Portuguese, anthropology, and history.

name: Interdisciplinary Study of Latin America
description: Anthropology, geography, history, politics, language, and culture of Latin America.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: B or better in SPAN 210 or SPAN 211; placement at 300 level on Phase II placement exam.
name: Working with Hispanic Clients
description: Crosscultural approaches to interactions with persons of Hispanic origin in a variety of professional settings. Readings, speakers, media. Taught in Spanish. Departmental permission required for transfer students.

name: Latin American Cultures
description: Comparative study of selected Latin American cultures with emphasis on their significance for a broader anthropological theory.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: South American Indian Cultures
description: An examination of ethnographic data on South American Indians, emphasizing methods used to acquire those data and their applications to theoretical considerations.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Mesoamerican Prehistory
description: Cultural development and variation in Mesoamerica from the first arrival of man to the arrival of Europeans. Particular attention to cultural continuities from prehistoric times.

name: Prehistoric Civilizations of the New World
description: Study of Mesoamerican and South American civilizations, particularly the Mayan, Aztec, and Inca states. Processes of state formation as reflected in archaeological data.

name: Geography of Latin America
description: Physical and human geography of Latin America.

name: Colonial Latin America
description: The establishment and consolidation of the Spanish and Portuguese empires in the Western hemisphere; interaction of Indians, Africans, and Iberians, and the formation of social, economic, and political traditions in Latin America; political independence.

name: Modern Latin America
description: Traditional society in the area and problems arising from social, economic, and political changes since independence; comparative studies of national responses to these problems.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Politics and Governments of Latin America
description: The development, principles, political thought, and politics of the several Latin American states.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Spanish American Civilization
description: Lectures, readings, and visuals on selected topics of Spanish American civilization and its cultural heritage.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPAN 312.
name: Literary Tendencies and Masterpieces of Spanish America
description: A survey of the masterworks and literary tendencies of Spanish America.

name: Special Topics in Latin American Studies
description: Selected Topics on Latin America. May be repeated for credit as content varies by title.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Prehistoric Archaeology of South America
description: Prehistoric archaeology of the South American continent.

name: Social and Economic History of Latin America
description: The evolution of social groups and changes in economic patterns in Latin America from pre-Columbian times to the present.

name: History of Mexico
description: Mexico from the pre-conquest period to the present, with an emphasis on modern Mexico.

name: International Relations of Latin America
description: Contemporary international relations among Latin American states, including economic and political security and relations with the United States.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Contemporary Spanish-American Literature
description: Survey of the most significant work from 1960 to the present.

name: Senior Seminar
description: Study in depth of a topic on Latin America.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Placement at 300-level on Phase II placement exam or C or better in SPAN 303. Department permission required for transfer students.
name: Contemporary Latin America
description: Analysis and discussion of contemporary Latin American history and the sociocultural forces that have contributed to define this area's national identities. Taught in Spanish.

name: Colonial Spanish-American Literature to Neoclassicism
description: Survey or pre-Columbian poetry and of texts dating from the time of Columbus to the end of the Colonial period.

name: Information Literacy
description: Introduction to methods and ethics of information research, with emphasis on analyzing and defining information needs and resources, creating and refining search strategies, evaluating resources, and synthesizing and citing information. Admission restricted to undergraduates.

name: Linguistics 1: Introduction to Language
description: Introduction to the human capacity for language and to how it is acquired. Investigation of language varieties, dialects, and styles. Examination of the social and geographical factors that contribute to language variation and change.

requisiteText: Corequisite: LING 103.
name: Integrated Linguistic Skills for Non-Native Speakers 1
description: Linguistic skills for low-advanced non-native speakers of English related to writing, grammar, reading, listening and speaking for academic purposes. Students enrolled in the International Accelerator Program.

requisiteText: Corequisite: LING 102.
name: Integrated Linguistic Skills for Non-Native Speakers 2
description: Linguistic skills for low-advanced non-native speakers of English related to writing, grammar, reading, listening and speaking for academic purposes with a focus on research skills. Students enrolled in the International Accelerator Program.

name: Integrated Linguistic Skills for Non-Native Speakers 3
description: Linguistic skills for advanced non-native speakers English related to writing, grammar, reading, listening and speaking for academic purposes with a focus on productive skills. Students enrolled in the International Accelerator Program.

name: Special Topics in Linguistics I
description: Topics of a broad nature that require no previous study in linguistics. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Linguistic Diversity Awareness
description: A course designed to cultivate awareness of phonological and grammatical differences among dialects of English and ability to switch comfortably between one�€�s dialect and standard usage. Two-hour lecture and laboratory.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Special Topics in Linguistics II
description: Topics of a more focused nature that require no previous study in linguistics. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Language Conflict and Language Rights
description: Examination of linguistic conflict and rights, as well as centrality of language rights to human rights and personal/cultural identity. Basic facts about language related to identity, culture, attitudes, dialects, bilingualism. Case studies (local, national, international) with particular attention to nationalism, language revitalization, language planning.

name: Language and Popular Culture
description: Linguistic anthropological study of forms of language through the lens of popular culture. Explore the ethnography of communication through play and performance, discursive and semiotic practices, and varieties of language invoked in popular cultural forms that provide resources for cultural reproduction and contestation.

name: Language and Humor at the Intersections of Religion, Race, Ethnicity, and Gender
description: Explores language and humor, looking at (i) the linguistic structure and psychology of humor, (ii) changing societal standards for humor, (iii) racial, ethnic, religious, and gender-based humor, and (iv) socio-political questions surrounding the use of these.

name: Korean Popular Culture and Language
description: Introduction to linguistic and anthropological concepts through the lens of South Korean popular culture.

name: Cross-Cultural Communication
description: This course introduces students to the fields of interactional sociolinguistics and linguistic anthropology. Students will learn how they approach the study of cross-cultural and intercultural forms of (mis)communication within the context of globally interconnected people, places, and systems of communication.

name: Introduction to Language Sciences
description: Introduction to the linguistic component of human cognition. Properties of speech, the organization of language in the mind/brain, cross-linguistic universals, child language acquisition, and aspects of adult language processing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: The English Language
description: Introduction to the field of linguistics with an emphasis on English. Covers the English sound system, word structure, and grammar. Explores history of English, American dialects, social registers, and style.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CHIN 121.
name: Chinese Language and Society
description: A comprehensive and up-to-date survey of Chinese language in a social context, teaching students not only the linguistic structure of modern standard Chinese but also how language and society mutually influence each other in history and today�€�s digital age. Hands-on instruction to carry out linguistic research.

name: Special Topics in Linguistics III
description: Reading and research on selected topics in linguistics that may require previous study in linguistics or a related field. Prerequisites listed for each course offering. May be repeated as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C+ or better in SPAN 302; placement at 300 level of Phase II placement exam.
name: Spanish Phonetics and Pronunciation
description: Analysis of and practice in pronunciation, listening comprehension, and dialect recognition based on study of the speech sounds, combinations, patterns, and processes of Spanish phonetics and phonology. Department permission required for transfer students.

name: Language, Culture, and Society
description: Language in its social setting. The relationship between linguistic categories and culture categories. Language and cognition.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101; ENGL 102.
name: Language in the USA
description: Linguistic examination of the structure, history, and use of language varieties in the U.S., with a particular focus on regional and sociocultural variation and relevant sociolinguistic issues.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Teaching English Abroad
description: An intensive, hands-on introduction to principles and techniques of teaching English language learners, exposing students to norms of the field of Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages (TESOL), working with non-native English speakers, and discovering TESOL opportunities worldwide.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and program director is required for undergraduate students.

name: Topics in Linguistics
description: Intensive study of selected topics; may emphasize interdisciplinary themes.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: English Grammar
description: Major structures of English morphology and syntax; role of language history and social and regional variation in understanding contemporary English.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Development of the English Language
description: History of English from the earliest Old English texts through Middle English to Contemporary English. No previous knowledge of Old or Middle English is required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Language in Society
description: Patterns in language use as a reflection of social group memberships or the negotiation of interpersonal relationships; special attention to social dialects and stylistic difference in American English.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102, and one course between ENGL 270-ENGL 292.
name: African-American English
description: Linguistic examination of the structure, history, and use of African-American English, as well as literary presentations, language attitudes, and issues relating to education and the acquisition of Standard English.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Introduction to Technology in Language Education
description: Acquaints students with principles and practices concerning the use of technology in foreign language teaching. Explores connections between second language acquisition and the implementation of Internet and multimedia technologies.

name: Cognitive and Social Aspects of Bilingualism
description: Bilingual language development, social and cultural aspects of bilingualism, the bilingual brain, bilingualism throughout the lifespan.

name: French Linguistics
description: The structure, morphology, and syntax of modern French.

name: Introduction to German Linguistics
description: Structural and descriptive linguistics applied to the German language.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SPAN 303.
name: Introduction to Spanish Linguistics
description: Phonology, morphology, and syntax of modern Spanish.

name: Interdisciplinary Topics in Linguistics
description: Topics selected by the instructor for specialized study. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes title. May be repeated with different title.

name: French Phonology
description: The sound system and its functioning in the morphological system of French from the point of view of current phonological theory.

name: Contrastive English-Spanish Phonetics and Phonology
description: Introduction to the study of phonetics and phonology and their application to the sounds and sound systems of English and Spanish. Includes transcription practice and discussion of relevance to teaching.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 450, LING 421, ENGL 680, or LING 600.
name: Advanced English Grammar
description: Practical survey of the syntactic structures of English; usage, social and regional variation emphasis on data.

name: Introduction to Mathematical Methods in Linguistics
description: Introduction to mathematical mechanisms that play a prominent role in the formalization of syntactic and semantic theories, showing how they are applied to an understanding of the working parts of human language. The topics covered include: set theory, logic, English as a formal language, and languages & grammars.

name: Language Change
description: Major ways in which phonetics, phonology, syntax, morphology, and semantics change through language history; social factors which promote innovation.

name: Introduction to the Germanic Languages
description: Introduction to historical Germanic linguistics including a survey of the Old Germanic languages (Old English, Old Frisian, Old Saxon, Old High German, Old Norse, Gothic); comparative phonology, morphology, and syntax, typology of modern Germanic languages and dialects; and common Germanic in its Indo-European context.

name: Topics in Language and Culture
description: Introduction to sociolinguistic issues, focusing on a single language. Course content varies and will be announced by title. May be repeated twice as topics vary.

name: Language and Gender
description: Approaches to gender and language emphasizing the social grounding of both; how language reflects sociocultural values and is a tool for constructing different types of social organization.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Research in Language Conflict and Language Rights
description: Research into the parameters governing linguistic conflicts and language rights issues, involving a close examination of the nexes of language and: individual and ethnic identity, culture, dialects, bilingualism. Examination of regional, national, and international case studies, with particular attention to nationalism, language revitalization, and language planning.

name: Discourse, Gender, and Politics of Emotion
description: Anthropological approach to issues of discourse, gender, and emotion. Issues under consideration include the social control, force, and forms of emotional discourse and the relationship between emotion and culture from gender-oriented perspectives.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Anthropological Approaches to Narrative and Performance
description: The ways people from various cultures reflect on, reinforce, and construct their social realities through narrating, which will be considered as both artistic expression and social action.

name: Japanese Language in Society
description: Japanese language and communication in its socio-cultural context; emphasis on comparison with American English. Taught in English.

name: German Sociolinguistics
description: Introduction to the study of variation in Modern German. Traditional German dialectology and dialect geography, language and society, multilingualism in the German-speaking countries, German in contact with other languages.

name: The Structure of Modern Spanish
description: Description of the grammatical structures of Modern Spanish. Intensive study of the theory and practice of word formation and sentence structure of Spanish.

name: Language and Globalization
description: Anthropological approach to issues of language and globalization. Linguistic consequences of globalization under consideration include communicative patterns, linguistic change, and language and political economy.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in PHIL 114 or PHIL 511.
name: Philosophy of Language
description: An examination of concepts and problems such as meaning, reference, analyticity, definition, and the relation between logic and philosophy.

name: Psychology of Language
description: Theories of speech perception, linguistic theories of syntax and semantics, the brain mechanisms underlying language, the development of language in children, and the role of language in thought.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: COMD 501 and COMD 507.
name: Introduction to Language Development
description: The language acquisition process in normal children, including the development of semantics, morphology, syntax, phonology, and pragmatics; American dialects and bilingualism.

name: Survey of Linguistics
description: Survey of core areas of linguistics and extensions to closely related disciplines. Introduction to the linguistic component of human cognition. Formal description and analysis of the general properties of speech and language, the organization of language in the mind/brain, and cross-linguistic typology and universals.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in any of LING 300, LING 301, LING 600, PHIL 114, PHIL 511.
name: Introduction to Semantics and Pragmatics
description: Introduction to the study of linguistic meaning, including the following topics: meaning, reference, and truth; the connections among language, thought, and reality; word meaning and sentence meaning; possible worlds and modality; thematic roles; meaning and context; presupposition and implicature; speech acts; formal semantics; and cognitive semantics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: LING 300, LING 301, or LING 600.
name: Introduction to Morphology
description: Foundations of generative morphology, focusing on morphological data collection and analysis; the structure of the lexicon; and the interfaces between morphology and phonology, semantics, and syntax.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101, ENGL 102.
name: Professional Communication
description: Theory and practice of oral and written communication skills required in the contemporary business environment.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Principles of Management
description: A comprehensive survey of the basic principles of management applicable to all forms of business. The course provides the student with a basis for thinking about complex business situations in the framework of analysis of the management process.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGMT 371.
name: Strategic Human Resource Management
description: A survey of the major approaches used in managing human resources. Covers selection, compensation, legal compliance, discipline, organizational restructuring, TQM, motivation, labor relations, and performance management.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGMT 371.
name: Employee Engagement
description: Introduction to human behavior in organizations. Emphasis on factors that contribute to the effectiveness of individuals and groups in organizations.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGMT 371.
name: Negotiation and Conflict in the Workplace
description: This course is designed to improve students' knowledge and skills in the areas of workplace conflict resolution and negotiations.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGMT 371.
name: Managing Teams in the Workplace
description: Team dynamics in organizational settings; basic concepts of interpersonal behavior, how to facilitate effective teamwork and create, motivate, and participate in effective teams based on concepts in team design and team process.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGMT 371.
name: Leadership in Organizations
description: Reviews research and practice in organizational leadership; provides students with self-assessment, developmental exercises, and case studies to prepare students for leadership roles.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGMT 374.
name: Compensation and Retention
description: An examination of how organizations use pay and other types of rewards (both intrinsic and extrinsic) to affect employee motivation and behavior.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGMT 374.
name: Talent Management
description: An examination of how organizations can improve workforce quality by making effective use of recruiting and selection processes. Attention is also given to the training and development of new hires and to legal issues that surround the staffing process.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGMT 374.
name: International Human Resource Management
description: This course examines how human resources are managed within a global context. It examines how human resources are managed within global firms as well as across different cultural settings.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGMT 371.
name: Corporate Social Responsibility and Stakeholder Management
description: This course examines the role of corporate social responsibility in managing organizations. Attention is given to the role of stakeholder management and ethics in organizational decision-making.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGMT 371.
name: Diversity and Inclusion
description: An introduction to diversity and inclusion in the workplace. Topics include the nature of workforce diversity and inclusion, practices that enhance diversity, inclusion, and effectiveness, and approaches for building inclusion.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both MGMT 371 and MGSC 291.
name: Analytics for the Human Resources Professional
description: Metrics and measurements of HR concepts; processes through which knowledge is gained; tools and techniques for gathering and analyzing data; and critical thinking centered on whether findings are likely to be reproducible and trustworthy.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: IBUS 310.
name: Intercultural Competencies for Working in International Teams
description: How to recruit, lead, and collaborate more effectively in international teams by examining differences related to culture, work-values, economic climate, and career progression.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MGMT 373.
name: Developing and Launching New Ventures
description: Explore business models and paths to commercialization for new ventures and concepts through experimentation; investigate strategies to develop and validate the business model; identify the resources needed to launch the venture and methods for acquiring those resources.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MGMT 473.
name: Executing Strategy in New Ventures
description: Influencing the performance of new ventures through the strategies, metrics, and resources needed for their development, monitoring, and funding.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGMT 371 and junior standing.
name: Collective Bargaining
description: Practice and structure of collective bargaining, and administration of collective agreements, law of union-management relations, labor history, and bargaining theory and practice.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MKTG 350, FINA 363, MGMT 371.
name: Strategic Management
description: A study of the formulation and application of functionally integrated business policy by top management. Emphasis is on decision making in the face of changing conditions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MGMT 473.
name: Applications in Entrepreneurship and New Ventures
description: Through immersive projects, students apply entrepreneurial concepts, tools, and frameworks to advance a new or established venture.

name: Special Topics in Management
description: Current topics, issues and practices in various areas of Management. Course may be repeated up to three (3) times as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Completion of DMSB core curriculum except MGMT 478, plus at least one additional course in the student�€�s major field of study. Cumulative GPA of 2.75 or consent of instructor.
name: Business Internship in Management
description: Supervised work experience as approved by department. Generally three hours of academic credit, but upon special request of supervising professor and approval of appropriate area director, an internship may carry a maximum of six hours credit, however, only three hours may apply towards major credit. Pass-Fail only. Internship contract required.

name: Special Topics in Management
description: Current topics, issues and practices in various areas of Management. Course may be repeated up to four (4) times as content varies by title.

name: Computer Information Systems in Business
description: An introduction to the effective use of information systems tools in day-to-day business communications, analysis, and decision making.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: STAT 206.
name: Applied Statistics for Business
description: Descriptive statistics, topics in probability, statistical inference and modeling. Emphasis on the collection, summarization, analysis, and reporting of numerical findings relevant to business decisions and economic analysis.

name: Program Design and Development
description: Fundamental algorithms and processes used in business information systems. Development and representation of programming logic. Introduction to implementation using a high-level programming language.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGSC 290 or equivalent.
name: Business Information Systems
description: Introduction to the planning, development, and management of Business Information Systems (BIS) and related information technologies in organizations. Topics include hardware, software, database, telecommunications, and the Internet.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MGSC 291.
name: Applied Statistical Modeling
description: Multiple regression, ANOVA, forecasting, quality control, and nonparametric techniques. Emphasis is on the application of these statistical models in business decision making.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGSC 291.
name: Quantitative Analysis for Business Decision Making
description: Quantitative approaches for managerial problem solving and decision making. Formulation, solution, analysis, and interpretation of spreadsheet-based models for common business decision-making situations. Optimization, simulation, decision analysis.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGSC 392.
name: Advanced Management Science
description: Advanced topics in management science; stochastic models, nonlinear programming, dynamic programming, Markov processes, and multiple criteria decision models.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MGSC 290 and MGSC 291.
name: Data Analytics for Business
description: Extracting, transforming, visualizing, and analyzing data to support business intelligence and decision making. Business analytics, relational database management, principles and applications of data visualization.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in STAT 206.
name: Operations Management
description: Management of activities/resources that result in the production of competitive goods and services in the global market place. Integrates cross-functional concepts from marketing, finance, and management.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 204 or MGSC 298.
name: Applied Problem Solving and Programming
description: Systematic problem definition, solution formulation, and computer implementation for business and related areas. Internet and database applications. Programming exercises in a high-level programming language.

name: International Information Systems
description: An examination of the challenges and opportunities associated with the development, management, and use of global information systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MGSC 395.
name: Special Topics in Management Science
description: Current topics, issues and practices in various areas of Management Science. Course may be repeated up to three (3) times as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGSC 395.
name: Business Process Management
description: Course entails learning and applying cutting-edge concepts and techniques of business process analyses to process improvement initiatives such as reengineering, lean, and six-sigma.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MGSC 291 and MGSC 395.
name: Service Operations Management
description: Course focuses on the management of service operations, with considerable attention paid to cutting-edge quantitative techniques. Topics covered include facility location, waiting line management, and revenue management, among others.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGSC 395.
name: Global Sourcing Strategies and Application
description: Course covers skills necessary to pursue sourcing-related careers in manufacturing, services, retailing, and government agencies, including discussion of cutting-edge negotiation and global sourcing strategies pursued in exemplar firms.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MGSC 395.
name: Innovation and Design
description: Creation and launch of viable businesses using innovation tournaments. Development of problem solving and design skills. Application to real innovation and entrepreneurial hurdles.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGSC 394 or CSCE 145, and MGSC 390.
name: Information Systems Analysis and Design
description: Analysis and design of business information systems using modern tools, techniques, and methodologies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MGSC 395.
name: Supply Chain Management
description: This course examines principles governing an integrated supply chain that includes the cross-functional processes of sourcing, inventory management, and logistics. Key tools for managing supply chains will also be discussed.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MGSC 395.
name: Logistics, Transportation and Distribution
description: This course is designed to provide a body of knowledge, technical know-how, and standards for those in the logistics, transportation and distribution industries.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGSC 390.
name: Business Telecommunications
description: Identifies and explains the principal technologies, concepts, and techniques currently applied in the business data communications field. Current and future hardware and software technologies, networking, protocols, and the OSI Model are covered.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGSC 395.
name: Supply Chain Planning and Execution
description: Managing the flow of materials from suppliers to customers; supply chain concepts, terminology, and relationships; processes used to develop operations plans.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MGSC 485 and permission of instructor based on competitive application.
name: OSC Capstone Project
description: Course entails executing projects that apply OSC concepts to solve significant operational or supply-chain problems at simulated or actual firms. Teams write recommendation reports and oversee sourcing strategies pursued in exemplar firms.

name: Project Management for Business
description: An introduction to the qualitative and quantitative approaches to the management of projects as well as a review MS Project software.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in STAT 516 or MGSC 391.
name: Forecasting and Time Series
description: Time series analysis and forecasting using the multiple regression and Box-Jenkins approaches.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGSC 291 or STAT 509 or STAT 515.
name: Statistical Quality Control
description: Statistical procedures for process control including CUSUM and Shewhart Control Charts, and lot acceptance sampling.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGSC 390.
name: E-Commerce Concepts and Research Topics
description: Social, technological, commercial, marketing, and political implications of current and impending tends in E-Commerce.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGSC 291.
name: Simulation of Business Systems
description: Theory and design of business simulation experiments, development and use of computer simulation models, and analysis of data generated by computer simulation experiments.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGSC 291.
name: Analysis of Decisions Under Uncertainty
description: Theory and practice of making decisions in an environment of uncertainty; development of skill in the assessment of preferences and probability distributions.

name: Strategic Management of Information Systems
description: Strategic management and use of information systems in organizations.

name: Database Management for Business
description: Technology overview and principles of database design for business applications. Enterprise database administration and planning. Design exercises and projects using the latest database management systems software.

name: Quantitative Foundations for Business and Economics I
description: Calculus and classical optimization methods applied to problems in business and economic analysis; matrices, derivatives, and integrals in the analysis of both univariate and multivariate business and economic models.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGSC 690 or ECON 690.
name: Quantitative Foundations for Business and Economics II
description: Statistics and probability theory applied to problems of business and economic analysis.

name: Quantitative Methods I
description: Probability and statistics necessary for graduate study in economics and business administration; estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, analysis of variance, and nonparametric methods.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MGSC 692 or equivalent.
name: Quantitative Methods II
description: Decision models useful in business and economics; linear programming, sensitivity analysis and duality, network models, integer programming, dynamic programming, inventory and queuing, and simulation.

name: The Ocean Environment
description: Origin and evolution of the oceans, plate tectonics, ocean circulation, waves and tides, seawater and sediment composition, and influences on biology. Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week. Scheduled field trips required.

name: The Living Ocean
description: Origin, evolution, and diversity of marine life, biological production, trophic dynamics, nutrient cycles, marine resources, and environmental concerns. Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week. Scheduled field trips required.

name: Oceans and Society
description: A nontechnical introduction to human interactions with the marine environment: marine organisms, marine systems, and the physical and chemical characteristics of oceans and estuaries. Not available for marine science major credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: MSCI 210.
name: Oceans and Society Laboratory
description: Experiments and exercises which illustrate how specific components of marine environments are structured, function, and can be measured. Two laboratory hours per week. Not available for marine science major credit. Attendance on designated field trips may be required.

name: Coastal Environments of the Southeastern U.S.
description: Coastal zones of South Carolina and neighboring states, including geologic history, geomorphology, stratigraphy, hydrogeology, shoreline processes, environmental issues, and effects of man. Not available for geological science or marine science major credit. Three lecture hours each week plus optional field trips.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in GEOL 215 or MSCI 215.
name: Coastal Environments of the Southeastern U.S. (Laboratory)
description: Exercises examining coastal ecology, geomorphology, hydrogeology, shoreline processes, environmental issues, and human impact. Not available for marine science major credit. Two laboratory hours per week. Scheduled field trips required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MSCI 101 and MATH 141.
name: Ocean Data Analysis
description: Instrumentation, oceanographic time series, spatial and directional data sets, and basic parametric modeling.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MSCI 102 or BIOL 101.
name: Biology of Marine Organisms
description: Biological concepts emphasizing adaptation to marine environments. Laboratory experiments emphasize principles and techniques of marine biological study. Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week. Scheduled field trips are required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MSCI 101, CHEM 111, CHEM 112, and MATH 141.
name: The Chemistry of the Sea
description: Biogeochemical cycling, carbonate chemistry, climate change, hydrothermal vents, stable isotopes, trace metals, radioactive tracers, mass balance, and properties of sea water. Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MSCI 101 and MATH 141; C or better in PHYS 201 or PHYS 211.
name: Physical Oceanography
description: Properties of seawater, mass and momentum balances, circulation, mixing, waves and other processes in the marine environment.

name: Processes of Global Environmental Change
description: The science of global change, its relation to the hydrosphere, atmosphere, lithosphere, and biosphere. Global system science, biogeochemical cycles, paleoclimatology, glaciation, and eustacy.

name: The Deep Sea
description: The Deep Sea is an interdisciplinary, scientific survey of the geology, biology, chemistry, and physical setting of the deep-sea (more than 1000 m depth).

name: Policy and Marine Science
description: Analysis of past and current issues in global and national marine policy. Relationship between science and policymakers.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MSCI 311, BIOL 301.
name: Principles of Biological Oceanography
description: Principles and methods of measuring production in the sea. Emphasis on the ocean�€�s role in the global carbon budget. Three lecture hours per week. Scheduled field trips are required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MSCI 101 and MSCI 102 or C or better in BIOL 101 and 102.
name: Field and Laboratory Investigations in Marine Science
description: Intensive inquiry-based investigations combining oceanographic field sampling with laboratory measurements of collected samples using modern analytical instrumentation, and with analysis and integration of data into a final research report. Most of the course is conducted in residence at a marine field site.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MSCI 311, MSCI 313 and MSCI 314.
name: Internship in Marine Science
description: Internship experience that offers practical field or laboratory experience in oceanography and/or related marine sciences. Course content varies and will be announced by title in schedule of courses. Usually conducted off campus and student must be able to access internship on their own.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Student research on problems of fundamental significance in collaboration with faculty mentors. Emphasis on critical thinking, problem solving, proposal development, scientific writing, and professional presentation. Nine hours of laboratory, field, or library work per week.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Student research on problems of fundamental significance in collaboration with faculty mentors. Emphasis on critical thinking, problem solving, proposal development, scientific writing, and professional presentation. Nine hours of laboratory, field, or library work per week.

name: Undergraduate Research
