description: Student research on problems of fundamental significance in collaboration with faculty mentors. Emphasis on critical thinking, problem solving, proposal development, scientific writing, and professional presentation. Nine hours of laboratory, field, or library work per week.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Student research on problems of fundamental significance in collaboration with faculty mentors. Emphasis on critical thinking, problem solving, proposal development, scientific writing, and professional presentation. Nine hours of laboratory, field, or library work per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in GEOL 101.
name: Principles of Geomorphology
description: The process of earth denudation with emphasis on chemistry of weathering, stream and erosion hydraulics, quantitative analysis of land form evolution.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: MATH 122 or MATH 141.
name: Principles of Coastal Geomorphology
description: Geological and physical controls on the morphology, development, and stability of coastlines. Analysis of waves and erosional processes, and coastal zone morphodynamics. Several required field trips.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MSCI 102 or BIOL 102, CHEM 112.
name: Environmental Microbiology
description: An overview of the microbial world including a survey of the distribution, functioning, and diversity of microorganisms in natural systems. Discusses the crucial roles that microorganisms play in ecosystem function, biogeochemical cycles, and environmental quality.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 141.
name: MATLAB-Based Data Analysis in Ocean Sciences
description: MATLAB-based course in processing, analysis, and visualization of large oceanographic data sets. Includes scalar and vector time series measured at fixed locations as well as shipboard surveys of oceanographic characteristics varying both in 3-D and in time. Methods and techniques are relevant to other geoscience disciplines.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Invertebrate Zoology
description: Phylogenetic and comparative aspects of anatomy, physiology, reproduction, and embryology of the invertebrates. Three lecture and one three-hour laboratory period per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in GEOL 305.
name: Advanced Paleontology
description: Systematic, ecologic, biogeographic, and evolutionary aspects of paleontology; lectures, practical exercises, field trips.

name: Marine Micropaleontology
description: Marine microfossils; distribution, ecology, paleoecology, and biostratigraphy; use of microfossils in marine sediments to study oceanographic history. Three lectures and two laboratory hours per week.

name: Introduction to Geochemistry
description: Investigation of low temperature chemical reactions controlling the geochemistry of the earth�€�s surface. Emphasis on CO2, carbonates, oxidation-reduction, thermodynamics, isotopes, biogeochemistry.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CHEM 111, CHEM 112 and MATH 141.
name: Environmental Radioisotope Geochemistry
description: Introduction to radioactivity and the use of radionuclides to study environmental processes, including age-dating and biogeochemical cycling in aquatic systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Marine Plants
description: Diversity, distribution, physiology, ecology, evolution, and economic importance of marine algal, seagrass, and mangrove communities. Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week. Scheduled field trips are required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: Fishery Management
description: Management and conservation of aquatic and marine resources, with emphasis on fisheries. Data procurement and analysis; commercial and recreational fisheries; sociological, political, legal, and environmental factors that affect fishery management; and fish biodiversity.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Ichthyology
description: Phylogeny, morphology, behavior, and ecology of fishes. Three lecture and 3 laboratory hours plus three field trips to be arranged.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Aquaculture
description: Introduction to the practical and scientific aspects of the commercial culture of freshwater and marine organisms. Three lecture hours per week. One all-day field trip required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 101 and BIOL 102 or MSCI 311.
name: Behavior of Marine Organisms
description: The identification of behavioral adaptations of estuarine and marine organisms: their ecology, physiology, development, and evolutionary history; field observations.

name: Geological Oceanography
description: A comprehensive study of the origin and development of the major structural features of the ocean basins and the continental margins. Discussion of the techniques used in obtaining geologic data and the interpretation of sedimentary processes, vulcanism, and the stratigraphy of the ocean basins.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOL 325.
name: Sedimentary Simulations and Sequence Stratigraphy
description: Problems of sequence stratigraphy resolved with graphic computer simulations. Sedimentary fill of basins by carbonates and/or clastics tracked as a function of rate of sediment accumulation, tectonic behavior, and sea level. Includes laboratory.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Population Genetics
description: An introduction to the principles of population genetics, with emphasis on the origin, maintenance, and significance of genetic variation in natural populations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GEOL 516.
name: Marine Sediments
description: Marine sedimentary environments; physical/biological factors which control the formation and distribution of modern marine sediments.

name: Conservation and Health in Marine Systems
description: Introduces the field of conservation and explores the intersection between conservation and environmental health with a particular focus on coastal and marine case studies.

name: Coastal Processes
description: Physical and geological processes controlling the formation and evolution of beach, barrier, and nearshore environments, including discussion of coastal management issues.

name: Ecosystem Analysis
description: The formulation and simulation of compartment models of marine and terrestrial ecosystems with complex nutrient cycling, food chains, and energy flow. Analog and digital simulation techniques. Ecosystem stability and sensitivity. Organization, structure, and diversity of an ecosystem.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 201 and MATH 141.
name: Introduction to Micrometeorology
description: Small-scale processes in the atmospheric boundary layers, including energy budget, radiation, soil heat transfer, humidity, viscous flows, turbulence, momentum and heat exchanges, evaporation, and marine atmospheric boundary layer.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: Marine Conservation Biology
description: Exploration of how human activities affect marine natural populations, species, communities and ecosystems, including threats to biodiversity; approaches to marine conservation; and ecological and evolutionary responses to anthropogenic disturbance.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CHEM 111 and BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Marine Ecology
description: Structure, dynamics, and interactions between populations and communities in marine ecosystems. Attendance at designated departmental seminars is required. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: MSCI 575 or BIOL 575.
name: Marine Ecology Laboratory
description: Laboratory and field exercises in coastal environments. Three hours per week plus field trips.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301.
name: Marine Fisheries Ecology
description: Interdisciplinary examination of the distribution, reproduction, survival, and historical variation of the principal commercial marine fisheries.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: BIOL 301 or MSCI 311.
name: Ecology of Coral Reefs
description: Structure, productivity, and biodiversity of coral reefs, emphasizing their sensitivity, stability, and sustainability. Taught as an extended field experience with daily lectures and guided research activities.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MSCI 311 or equivalent.
name: Physiological and Pollution Ecology of Marine Organisms
description: Functional adaptation of marine plants and animals to ecological stresses including pollution. Three lecture hours per week.

name: Air-Sea Interaction
description: The physical mechanism responsible for interaction between the ocean and the atmosphere and the influence of air-sea interaction on atmospheric and oceanic dynamics and thermodynamics on a wide variety of spatial/temporal scales.

name: Satellite Oceanography
description: This course provides knowledge of various techniques used in satellite remote sensing of the oceans. Key skills will be developed in satellite data processing, image analysis, and hands-on research.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MSCI 314.
name: Estuarine Oceanography
description: Estuarine kinematics and dynamics; classification of estuaries; estuarine circulation and mixing. Scheduled field trips are required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 241 and C or better in either PHYS 201 or PHYS 211.
name: Marine Hydrodynamics
description: Basic principles of fluid statics and dynamics. Conservation of mass, momentum, and energy; viscosity, vorticity, and boundary layers with examples from the marine environment. Applications to and analysis of ocean currents and waves.

name: Geology and Geochemistry of Salt Marshes
description: Geological and geochemical processes in salt marshes. Methods of geological research in marshes including instrumental techniques, sampling design, and data analysis. Two lectures per week plus four weekends of project oriented fieldwork and/or equivalent lab work. Scheduled field trips are required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MSCI 312.
name: Coastal Tropical Oceanography
description: Descriptive oceanography of mangrove and coral reef coasts with emphasis on physical processes. Taught as an extended field experience with daily lectures and guided research activities.

name: Beach-Dune Interactions
description: Influence of wind on coastal systems, with emphasis on nearshore currents, sediment transport and bedforms, aeolian transport, and dunes. Minimum Junior standing required.

name: Topics in Marine Science
description: Current developments in marine science selected to meet faculty and student interests. Course content varies and will be announced by title in schedule of courses.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: CHEM 321, MATH 142.
name: Aquatic Chemistry
description: Study of the chemical reactions and processes affecting the distribution of chemical species in natural systems. Three lecture hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MSCI 102 or MSCI 450 or BIOL 450.
name: Marine Phytoplankton
description: Examines the physiology and ecology of phytoplankton, including environmental controls on community composition, primary productivity, and detection and characterization of water quality (eutrophication) and harmful algal blooms.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ECON 221, ECON 222, ACCT 225, and ACCT 226 for Business Administration majors; ECON 224 and ACCT 222 for non-Business Administration majors.
name: Principles of Marketing
description: Principles and concepts underlying marketing functions, including the conception, pricing, promotion, and distribution of products and services and the role of marketing in society.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MKTG 350.
name: Consumer Behavior
description: The consumer decision process, with emphasis on consumer decision making, satisfaction/dissatisfaction factors, perception, learning, group influences, and marketing strategy implications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MKTG 350, MGSC 291.
name: Principles of Marketing Research
description: Investigates the theory and practice of marketing research with emphasis on the problem-oriented nature of marketing research and how research activities are implemented by marketing researchers and used by managers.

name: Sales Strategy
description: Understand the fundamentals of the sales process and how to ensure client engagement. Learn follow-up skills that will help you in every walk of life. Learn the fundamentals of effective business communication (voicemail, email, and hand-written).

name: Sales Automation and Customer Management
description: The context, tools and conceptual understanding of the technology-related and managerial expectations of an entry level sales representative.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MKTG 350.
name: Pricing Strategy and Analytics
description: An in-depth understanding of the fundamentals of pricing strategy formulation and implementation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: B+ or better in MGSC 291.
name: Data Science for Business Decision-Making
description: The conceptual, applied, and managerial elements of advanced data science methods for business decision-making.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MKTG 350.
name: Topics in Marketing
description: Reading and research on selected topics in marketing. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MKTG 350, MKTG 351, MKTG 352.
name: Marketing Practicum
description: Students form a working marketing agency and complete a real-world marketing campaign for a client. Working as a team, they apply marketing theory and concepts to a substantively important marketing problem.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MKTG 350.
name: Business-to-Business Marketing
description: Marketing strategy in marketing to other business and nonprofit organizations, emphasizing relationship building, alliances and partnerships, data interchange, power shifts in the channel and the impact of changing technology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MKTG 350.
name: Marketing Communications and Strategy
description: Integration of advertising, sales promotion, point-of-purchase communications toward the goal of enhancing brand equity.

name: Introduction To Sales
description: Examines fundamentals of personal selling and sales management and the development of communication and selling skills that yield desired sales results.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MKTG 350.
name: Marketing Channels and Distribution
description: Marketing functions and channel flows used to develop distribution strategies that provide effective, efficient, and reliable delivery of products and services to end-user markets.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MKTG 350.
name: Product and Brand Management
description: The primary tasks involved in developing marketing strategies from a product and/or brand management perspective, including product policy, competitive analysis, pricing, brand equity management, marketing information systems management, sales forecasting and monitoring customer satisfaction.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MKTG 350.
name: Retailing Management
description: Studies retail institutions, relationships with other channel members, factors influencing patronage patterns, adapting to change in dynamic environments with emphasis on strategy implications for managers in retail organizations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MKTG 350, MKTG 352.
name: Marketing Strategy and Planning
description: Management of marketing organizations and integration of functions, with emphasis on planning and designing strategies and applying tools and techniques for problem solving and decision making. For marketing majors only.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: placement through the Math Assessment of Prerequisites (MAP).
name: Basic College Mathematics
description: Basic college algebra; linear and quadratic equations, inequalities, functions and graphs of functions, exponential and logarithm functions, systems of equations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: placement through the Math Assessment of Prerequisites (MAP).
name: Intensive Basic College Mathematics
description: An intensive treatment of the topics covered in MATH 111.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 111 or MATH 111I, or placement through the Math Assessment of Prerequisites (MAP).
name: Trigonometry
description: Topics in trigonometry specifically needed for MATH 141, MATH 142, MATH 241. Circular functions, analytic trigonometry, applications of trigonometry. Credit may not be received for both MATH 112 and MATH 115.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 111or MATH 111I, or placement through the Math Assessment of Prerequisites (MAP).
name: Precalculus Mathematics
description: Topics in algebra and trigonometry specifically needed for MATH 141, MATH 142, MATH 241. Subsets of the real line, absolute value; polynomial, rational, inverse, logarithmic, exponential functions; circular functions; analytic trigonometry.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 112 or MATH 115, or placement through the Math Assessment of Prerequisites (MAP).
name: Brief Precalculus Mathematics
description: Essential algebra and trigonometry topics for Calculus, including working with equations that involve polynomials, rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, and trigonometric and inverse trigonometric functions. Intended for students with prior experience in Precalculus, but not ready for MATH 141.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 111, MATH 111I or MATH 115 or placement through the Math Assessment of Prerequisites (MAP).
name: Calculus for Business Administration and Social Sciences
description: Derivatives and integrals of elementary algebraic, exponential, and logarithmic functions. Maxima, minima, rate of change, motion, work, area under a curve, and volume.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 112, MATH 115, or MATH 116, or placement through the Math Assessment of Prerequisites (MAP).
name: Calculus I
description: Functions, limits, derivatives, introduction to integrals, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, applications of derivatives and integrals. Four classroom hours and one laboratory hour per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 141.
name: Calculus II
description: Methods of integration, sequences and series, approximations. Four classroom hours and one laboratory hour per week.

requisiteText: Corequisite: MATH 141.
name: Calculus Workshop I
description: Small study group practice in applications of calculus. For elective credit only.

requisiteText: Corequisite: MATH 142
name: Calculus Workshop II
description: Part of a pilot program at UofSC to help at-risk students in Calculus I & II. It is for elective credit only. The class will consist of small study group practice in applications of calculus.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 111 or MATH 111I or MATH 122, or placement through the Math Assessment of Prerequisites (MAP).
name: Finite Mathematics
description: Elementary matrix theory; systems of linear equations; permutations and combinations; probability and Markov chains; linear programming and game theory.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 122 or MATH 141.
name: Mathematical Modeling for the Life Sciences
description: Biological modeling with differential and difference equations; techniques of model modifications; analytic, numerical, and graphical solution methods; equilibria, stability, and long-term system behavior; geometric series; vectors, matrices, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors. Applications principally to population dynamics and compartment models.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 112 or above, or placement through the Math Assessment of Prerequisites (MAP).
name: Discrete Mathematics for Computer Science
description: Logic, number theory, sequences, series, recursion, mathematical induction, set theory, enumeration, functions, relations, graphs and trees. Connections to computers and to programming are emphasized when possible.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 141.
name: Introduction to Careers and Research in the Mathematical Sciences
description: An overview of different areas of mathematical research and career opportunities for mathematics majors. Pass/fail only.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 111 or MATH 111I or placement through the Math Assessment of Prerequisites (MAP).
name: Basic Concepts of Elementary Mathematics I
description: The meaning of number, fundamental operations of arithmetic, the structure of the real number system and its subsystems, elementary number theory. Open only to students in elementary or early childhood teacher certification.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 221.
name: Basic Concepts of Elementary Mathematics II
description: Informal geometry and basic concepts of algebra. Open only to students in elementary or early childhood teacher certification.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 142.
name: Vector Calculus
description: Vector algebra, geometry of three-dimensional space; lines, planes, and curves in space; polar, cylindrical, and spherical coordinate systems; partial differentiation, max-min theory; multiple and iterated integration, line integrals, and Green�€�s theorem in the plane.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 142.
name: Elementary Differential Equations
description: Ordinary differential equations of first order, higher order linear equations, Laplace transform methods, series methods; numerical solution of differential equations. Applications to physical sciences and engineering.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 142.
name: Transition to Advanced Mathematics
description: Rigor of mathematical thinking and proof writing via logic, sets, and functions. Intended to bridge the gap between lower-level (computational-based) and upper-level (proof-based) mathematics courses.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 142.
name: Applied Linear Algebra
description: General solutions of systems of linear equations, vector spaces and subspaces, linear transformations, determinants, orthogonality, characteristic polynomials, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, singular value decomposition, and generalized inverse. MATH 344L is an optional laboratory course where additional applications will be discussed.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better or concurrent enrollment in MATH 344 or MATH 544.
name: Applied Linear Algebra Lab
description: Computer based applications of linear algebra for science and engineering students. Topics include numerical analysis of matrices, direct and indirect methods for solving linear systems, and least squares method (regression). Typical applications include practical issues related to discrete Markov processes, image compression, and linear programming.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both MATH 142 and either CSCE 106 or CSCE 146 .
name: Discrete Structures
description: Propositional and predicate logic; proof techniques; recursion and recurrence relations; sets, combinatorics, and probability; functions, relations, and matrices; algebraic structures.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 122, or MATH 141.
name: Conceptual History of Mathematics
description: Topics from the history of mathematics emphasizing the 17th century to the present. Various mathematical concepts are discussed and their development traced. For elective or Group II credit only.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 241, MATH 300 and at least one 500 level MATH course; CSCE 145 or CSCE 206 and one of the following STAT courses STAT 509, STAT 512, STAT 515.
name: Mathematics Internship
description: Academic counterpart to a professional work experience in which mathematics plays a central role. Introduction to the uses of problem formulation and problem solving in a working environment. Introduction to career possibilities for a student trained in mathematics. Restricted to MATH major with 3.0 or better GPA and completion of at least 60 credits.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Research on a specific mathematical subject area. The specific content of the research project must be outlined in a proposal that must be approved by the instructor and the Undergraduate Director. Intended for students pursuing the B.S. in Mathematics with Distinction. Pass-Fail grading only.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in MATH 241.
name: Probability
description: Probability and independence; discrete and continuous random variables; joint, marginal, and conditional densities, moment generating functions; laws of large numbers; binomial, Poisson, gamma, univariate, and bivariate normal distributions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 241.
name: Financial Mathematics I
description: Probability spaces. Random variables. Mean and variance. Geometric Brownian Motion and stock price dynamics. Interest rates and present value analysis. Pricing via arbitrage arguments. Options pricing and the Black-Scholes formula.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 514 or STAT 522.
name: Financial Mathematics II
description: Convex sets. Separating Hyperplane Theorem. Fundamental Theorem of Asset Pricing. Risk and expected return. Minimum variance portfolios. Capital Asset Pricing Model. Martingales and options pricing. Optimization models and dynamic programming.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 344 or MATH 544.
name: Ordinary Differential Equations
description: Differential equations of the first order, linear systems of ordinary differential equations, elementary qualitative properties of nonlinear systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 520 or in both MATH 241 and MATH 242.
name: Boundary Value Problems and Partial Differential Equations
description: Laplace transforms, two-point boundary value problems and Green�€�s functions, boundary value problems in partial differential equations, eigenfunction expansions and separation of variables, transform methods for solving PDE�€�s, Green�€�s functions for PDE�€�s, and the method of characteristics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 344 or MATH 544.
name: Wavelets
description: Basic principles and methods of Fourier transforms, wavelets, and multiresolution analysis; applications to differential equations, data compression, and signal and image processing; development of numerical algorithms. Computer implementation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 142, BIOL 301, or MSCI 311 recommended.
name: Mathematical Modeling of Population Biology
description: Applications of differential and difference equations and linear algebra modeling the dynamics of populations, with emphasis on stability and oscillation. Critical analysis of current publications with computer simulation of models.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 241 and one of MATH 344 or MATH 544.
name: Nonlinear Optimization
description: Descent methods, conjugate direction methods, and Quasi-Newton algorithms for unconstrained optimization; globally convergent hybrid algorithm; primal, penalty, and barrier methods for constrained optimization. Computer implementation of algorithms.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 300 and in either MATH 344 or MATH 544.
name: Mathematical Game Theory
description: Two-person zero-sum games, minimax theorem, utility theory, n-person games, market games, stability.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 142.
name: Numerical Linear Algebra
description: Matrix algebra, Gauss elimination, iterative methods; overdetermined systems and least squares; eigenvalues, eigenvectors; numerical software. Computer implementation. Credit may not be received for both MATH 526 and MATH 544. Three lectures and one laboratory hour per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 520 or in both MATH 242 and MATH 344.
name: Numerical Analysis
description: Interpolation and approximation of functions; solution of algebraic equations; numerical differentiation and integration; numerical solutions of ordinary differential equations and boundary value problems; computer implementation of algorithms.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 344 or MATH 544.
name: Mathematical Foundation of Data Science and Machine Learning
description: Unconstrained and constrained optimization, gradient descent methods for numerical optimization, supervised and unsupervised learning, various reduced order methods, sampling and inference, Monte Carlo methods, deep neural networks.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 300.
name: Foundations of Geometry
description: The study of geometry as a logical system based upon postulates and undefined terms. The fundamental concepts and relations of Euclidean geometry developed rigorously on the basis of a set of postulates. Some topics from non-Euclidean geometry.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 300.
name: Modern Geometry
description: Projective geometry, theorem of Desargues, conics, transformation theory, affine geometry, Euclidean geometry, non-Euclidean geometries, and topology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 241 and MATH 300.
name: Elementary Geometric Topology
description: Topology of the line, plane, and space, Jordan curve theorem, Brouwer fixed point theorem, Euler characteristic of polyhedra, orientable and non-orientable surfaces, classification of surfaces, network topology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 241 and MATH 300.
name: Elements of General Topology
description: Elementary properties of sets, functions, spaces, maps, separation axioms, compactness, completeness, convergence, connectedness, path connectedness, embedding and extension theorems, metric spaces, and compactification.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 300.
name: Modern Applied Algebra
description: Finite structures useful in applied areas. Binary relations, Boolean algebras, applications to optimization, and realization of finite state machines.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 300 and in either of MATH 344 or MATH 544.
name: Algebraic Coding Theory
description: Error-correcting codes, polynomial rings, cyclic codes, finite fields, BCH codes.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 241 and MATH 300.
name: Linear Algebra
description: Vectors, vector spaces, and subspaces; geometry of finite dimensional Euclidean space; linear transformations; eigenvalues and eigenvectors; diagonalization. Throughout there will be an emphasis on theoretical concepts, logic, and methods. MATH 544L is an optional laboratory course where additional applications will be discussed.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 300 and 544.
name: Algebraic Structures I
description: Permutation groups; abstract groups; introduction to algebraic structures through study of subgroups, quotient groups, homomorphisms, isomorphisms, direct product; decompositions; introduction to rings and fields.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 546.
name: Algebraic Structures II
description: Rings, ideals, polynomial rings, unique factorization domains; structure of finite groups; topics from: fields, field extensions, Euclidean constructions, modules over principal ideal domains (canonical forms).

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 300 and in one of MATH 344 or MATH 544.
name: Geometry, Algebra, and Algorithms
description: Polynomials and affine space, Grobner bases, elimination theory, varieties, and computer algebra systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 241.
name: Vector Analysis
description: Vector fields, line and path integrals, orientation and parametrization of lines and surfaces, change of variables and Jacobians, oriented surface integrals, theorems of Green, Gauss, and Stokes; introduction to tensor analysis.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 241 and MATH 300.
name: Introduction to Differential Geometry
description: Parametrized curves, regular curves and surfaces, change of parameters, tangent planes, the differential of a map, the Gauss map, first and second fundamental forms, vector fields, geodesics, and the exponential map.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 241.
name: Applied Complex Variables
description: Complex integration, calculus of residues, conformal mapping, Taylor and Laurent Series expansions, applications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 241 and two 500-level classes requiring MATH 300: MATH 525, MATH 531, MATH 532, MATH 533, MATH 534, MATH 540, MATH 541, MATH 544, MATH 546, MATH 548, MATH 551, MATH 561, MATH 570, MATH 574, MATH 575, or MATH 580.
name: Analysis I
description: Least upper bound axiom, the real numbers, compactness, sequences, continuity, uniform continuity, differentiation, Riemann integral and fundamental theorem of calculus.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 554.
name: Analysis II
description: Riemann-Stieltjes integral, infinite series, sequences and series of functions, uniform convergence, Weierstrass approximation theorem, selected topics from Fourier series or Lebesgue integration.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 300.
name: Introduction to Mathematical Logic
description: Syntax and semantics of formal languages; sentential logic, proofs in first order logic; Godel�€�s completeness theorem; compactness theorem and applications; cardinals and ordinals; the Lowenheim-Skolem-Tarski theorem; Beth�€�s definability theorem; effectively computable functions; Godel�€�s incompleteness theorem; undecidable theories.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CSCE 350 or MATH 300.
name: Theory of Computation
description: Basic theoretical principles of computing as modeled by formal languages and automata; computability and computational complexity.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 300 and in one of MATH 544 or MATH 344.
name: Discrete Optimization
description: Discrete mathematical models. Applications to such problems as resource allocation and transportation. Topics include linear programming, integer programming, network analysis, and dynamic programming.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 374 or MATH 574; C or better in MATH 344 or MATH 544.
name: Mathematical Foundation of Network Science
description: Graphs and probability, Web graphs, random graphs, models for complex graphs, graph searching algorithms, eigenvalues, PageRank.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 300.
name: Discrete Mathematics I
description: Mathematical models; mathematical reasoning; enumeration; induction and recursion; tree structures; networks and graphs; analysis of algorithms.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 574.
name: Discrete Mathematics II
description: A continuation of MATH 574. Inversion formulas; Polya counting; combinatorial designs; minimax theorems; probabilistic methods; Ramsey theory; other topics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 300 or MATH 374.
name: Combinatorial Game Theory
description: Winning in certain combinatorial games such as Nim, Hackenbush, and Domineering. Equalities and inequalities among games, Sprague-Grundy theory of impartial games, games which are numbers.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 300.
name: Elementary Number Theory
description: Divisibility, primes, congruences, quadratic residues, numerical functions. Diophantine equations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CSCE 145 or MATH 241, and at least one of CSCE 355, MATH 300, or MATH 374.
name: Introduction to Cryptography
description: Design of secret codes for secure communication, including encryption and integrity verification: ciphers, cryptographic hashing, and public key cryptosystems such as RSA. Mathematical principles underlying encryption. Code-breaking techniques. Cryptographic protocols.

name: Undergraduate Seminar
description: A review of literature in specific subject areas involving student presentations. Content varies and will be announced in the Master Schedule of Classes by title. For undergraduate credit only.

name: Topics in Mathematics
description: Recent developments in pure and applied mathematics selected to meet current faculty and student interest.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 122 or MATH 141 or equivalent.
name: An Inductive Approach to Geometry
description: This course is designed for middle-level pre-service mathematics teachers. This course covers geometric reasoning, Euclidean geometry, congruence, area, volume, similarity, symmetry, vectors, and transformations. Dynamic software will be utilized to explore geometry concepts. This course cannot be used for credit toward a major in mathematics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in MATH 122 or MATH 141 or equivalent.
name: Inquiry Approach to Algebra
description: This course introduces basic concepts in number theory and modern algebra that provide the foundation for middle level arithmetic and algebra. Topics include: algebraic reasoning, patterns, inductive reasoning, deductive reasoning, arithmetic and algebra of integers, algebraic systems, algebraic modeling, and axiomatic mathematics. This course cannot be used for credit towards a major in mathematics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: current secondary high school teacher certification in mathematics and a C or better in at least 6 hours of calculus.
name: AP Calculus for Teachers
description: A thorough study of the topics to be presented in AP calculus, including limits of functions, differentiation, integration, infinite series, and applications. Not intended for degree programs in mathematics.

name: Introduction to Mechanical Engineering
description: Introduction to Mechanical Engineering; Engineering thinking; Problem-solving skills; University life and academic expectations.

name: Introduction to Computer-Aided Design
description: Principles and practice of visualization and graphical representation using modern computer-aided design tools.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 141.
name: Statics
description: Principles of mechanics; Equilibrium of particles and rigid bodies; Distributed forces, centroids, and centers of gravity; Moments of inertia of areas; Analysis of simple structures and machines; Friction.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in MATH 141.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in MATH 142.
name: Introduction to Applied Numerical Methods
description: Introduction and application of linear algebra and numerical methods to the solution of physical and engineering problems. Techniques include iterative solution techniques, methods of solving systems of equations, and numerical integration and differentiation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 142, PHYS 211.
name: Mechanical Engineering Fundamentals for Non-Majors
description: Introduction to the fundamentals of mechanical engineering for other engineering disciplines. Excluded: Mechanical Engineering Majors.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 241; C or better in EMCH 200 or ENCP 200.
name: Solid Mechanics
description: Study of forces and deformation in solids; Basic concepts of stress and strain; Elastic relations between stress and strain; Stress and strain transformations; Applications to mechanical components under axial, torsional, bending and pressure loads.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 211; C or better in MATH 142.
name: Thermodynamics
description: Definitions, work, heat, and energy; First law of analyses of systems and control volumes; Second law analysis.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 260 or ENCP 260.
name: Introduction to Finite Element Stress Analysis
description: Introduction to stress analysis for beams, plates, shells, and solids using finite element based computer tools.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 242; C or better in EMCH 200 or ENCP 200.
name: Dynamics
description: Kinematics of particles and rigid bodies; Kinetics of particles, emphasis on Newton's second law: energy and momentum methods for the solution of problems; Applications of plane motion of rigid bodies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EMCH 260 or ENCP 260.
name: Machine Design
description: Design against static failure and fatigue failure of structural members and machine parts; Design and selection of components including: fasteners, welds, shafts, springs, gears, bearings, and chain drives.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 242 and either EMCH 310 or ENCP 210.
name: Mechanical Vibrations
description: Analysis of forced and damped one-degree-of-freedom systems. Rotating unbalance and vibration isolation. Introduction to two-degrees-of-freedom systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 310 or ENCP 210.
name: Kinematics
description: The application of vector and graphical analysis for the determination of positions, velocities and accelerations of planar linkages used in modern machinery.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 360 or AESP 265 or ENCP 360.
name: Heat Transfer
description: One- and two-dimensional steady and transient heat conduction; Free and forced convection; Boiling and condensation; Radiation; Heat exchangers.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in EMCH 200 or ENCP 200 or BMEN 212; D or better in EMCH 290 or ENCP 290 or BMEN 290; C or better in MATH 242.
name: Fluid Mechanics
description: Applications of fluid statics and dynamics; Conservation of mass, momentum, and energy; Similitude and dimensional analysis; Open channel flow, lift and drag; Introduction to turbulent flow

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 290, ENCP 290, or BMEN 290; D or better in EMCH 260 or ENCP 260; D or better in EMCH 201 or ENCP 201; D or better in ELCT 220 or ELCT 221.
name: Laboratory I
description: Basic concepts of instruments, measurements, and experimental data analysis; Statistical analysis of experimental data and uncertainty analysis; LabView control, sensors, and measurement of parameters in mechanical engineering systems; Technical writing and presentation.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 361.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in EMCH 360 or AESP 265 or ENCP 360; D or better in EMCH 310 or ENCP 210.
name: Laboratory II
description: Basic concepts of hypothesis, simple design of experiments to demonstrate principles and applications of fluid dynamics, manufacturing, mechanical properties, heat transfer, and vibration analysis through a series of lab experiments.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: EMCH 362.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: EMCH 332, EMCH 354, EMCH 371.
name: Mechanical Engineering Laboratory III
description: Experiments directly related to advanced mechanical engineering courses. Physical and statistical design of experiments. Written and oral reports.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 310 or ENCP 210; D or better in EMCH 368.
name: Controls
description: Introduction to closed-loop control systems in Mechanical Engineering; Development of concepts, including transfer function, feedback, frequency response, and system stability; Programmable logic controllers (PLC); Control system design methods.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in CSCE 206; D or better in ELCT 220 or ELCT 221; D or better in EMCH 260 or ENCP 260.
name: Mechatronics
description: Introduction to the principles of integrating mechanical, electrical and computer engineering disciplines within a unified framework towards designing mechatronic systems; Fundamental overview of mechatronics (sensors, signals, actuators, microprocessors and models of mechatronic systems); Experimental exercises using microcontrollers.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 260 or ENCP 260.
name: Materials
description: An introduction to the relationships between chemical bonding, crystal structure, phase equilibria, microstructure, and properties of engineering materials.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 371.
name: Manufacturing
description: Basics of: Deformative Manufacturing, Subtractive Manufacturing, Additive Manufacturing, Assembly Processes; Introduction to: Polymers Manufacturing, Composites Manufacturing, Computer-Aided Manufacturing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 241.
name: Project Management
description: Introduction to decision making for engineering projects; Planning methods; Forecasting; Exploratory charts; Team building and leadership; Project scheduling; Project economics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 201 or ENCP 201 and EMCH 290 or ENCP 290.
name: Applied Thermodynamics
description: Basics of: Fundamentals of thermodynamics, Thermodynamic properties, Energy and Mass Conservation, Entropy and the Second Law Analysis; Introduction to: Power, Refrigeration, and Heat Pump Cycle Systems for vapor cycles and gas cycles; Application of Thermodynamic concepts to determine changes of enthalpy, entropy, and internal energy related with cycle systems, psychometrics, and combustion process.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 380.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: D or better in EMCH 332, EMCH 354, EMCH 362, EMCH 371, and EMCH 368.
name: Design I
description: Open-ended design project initiation including: identifying and ranking customer and project needs, benchmarking appropriate design specifications, planning and project management, functional analysis, innovation and concept generation, learning through mockups, concept ranking and concept selection.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 427.
name: Design II
description: Open-ended design project continuation including: identifying and performing relevant engineering analyses, parametric design refinement, project life cycle economic analysis, product/prototype construction, testing, and evaluation of the design; Consideration of safety, reliability, sustainability, and social impact.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 260 or ENCP 260, EMCH 394.
name: Automotive System Fundamentals
description: Automotive engineering systems, descriptions, and associated operating and design principles. Past, present, and future automotive systems and components.

name: Special Problems
description: Individual investigation or studies of special topics. A maximum of three credits may be applied toward a degree. Advance approval of project proposal by advisor and instructor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EMCH 354, EMCH 394.
name: Design of Thermal Systems
description: Methodology of design, mathematical modeling of thermal equipment, system simulation, system optimization using digital computer, and investment economics. Requires a semester-long design project. Two lectures and one problem session per week.

name: Fundamentals of Engineering Preparation
description: Preparation for the Fundamentals of Engineering Exam. Review general engineering and mechanical engineering-specific areas. Restricted to seniors. May not be used to satisfy program requirements.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 242.
name: Engineering Analysis I
description: Engineering applications of solution techniques for ordinary and partial differential equations, including Sturm-Liouville theory, special functions, transform techniques, and numerical methods.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 242.
name: Engineering Analysis II
description: Engineering applications of optimization methods, calculus of variations including approximate methods, and probability concepts.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 201 or ENCP 201; D or better in EMCH 327.
name: Computer-Aided Design
description: Solid modeling using commercial computer-aided design (CAD) applications package to reverse engineer-manufactured parts. Analytical curves and surfaces, transformation matrices, assembly modeling, and computer tools for analyzing parts and mechanisms.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 201 or ENCP 201; D or better in EMCH 327.
name: Finite Element Analysis in Mechanical Engineering
description: Development of the fundamental concepts of finite element modeling. Matrix equation assembly and reduction. Mechanical engineering applications in structures, stress analysis, ideal flow, and heat transfer problems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in MATH 241.
name: Computer-Aided Manufacturing
description: Optimizing computer-controlled machining processes, programmable logic controllers (PLCs), motion control of servomechanisms, CNC machining practices and programming, and robotics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in MATH 242; D or better in EMCH 330 or ENCP 330.
name: Control Theory in Mechanical Engineering
description: An introduction to closed-loop control systems; development of concepts, including transfer function, feedback, frequency response, and system stability by examples taken from mechanical engineering practice; control system design methods.

name: Technology Planning
description: Assessment of technological needs in the organization; coupling research and development to production; selection and evaluation of the technical project/program; technical planning, resource allocation, direction, and control; effective use and development of the engineering staff; the process of and barriers to technological change; technology, values, and policy. Senior or graduate standing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EMCH 327.
name: Concurrent Engineering
description: A systematic approach to the mechanical design of products, requiring the concurrent design of all related processes.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EMCH 327 and EMCH 377.
name: Design for Manufacture and Assembly
description: Product design principles for early consideration of issues to shorten product development time and to ensure smooth transition to manufacturing, thus accelerating time-to-market.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EMCH 327.
name: Design of Mechanical Systems
description: Summary of mechanical design, project management, product liability and the law, intellectual property ethics and professionalism.

name: Product Safety Engineering
description: Design considerations and methodologies for products to ensure adequate safeguards for the prevention of accidents, failures, and injuries. Senior standing.

name: Sustainable Design and Development
description: System design and development accomplished with consideration of environmental/ecological, economic, and social constraints. Students will be introduced to sustainable design and accomplish a design project. Senior standing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 142, Graduate standing.
name: Introduction to Engineering Optimization
description: Mathematical formulation of an optimum design problem, introduction to optimum design concepts and multidisciplinary design optimization. Use of mathematical programming methods for unconstrained and constrained minimization for engineering design optimization.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EMCH 332.
name: Intermediate Dynamics
description: Kinematics and dynamics of particles and rigid bodies using Newtonian mechanics. Work/energy, impulse/momentum, 3-D motion.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EMCH 332.
name: Robotics in Mechanical Engineering
description: Overview of robotics in practice and research: forward and inverse kinematics, statics and dynamics, trajectory generation, control, vision, and motion planning.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EMCH 354.
name: Compressible Fluid Flow
description: Application of the conservation laws of a compressible fluid to isentropic flows, flow with friction, and flows with heating or cooling. Shock and expansion waves. Nozzle and diffuser design.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CHEM 111, PHYS 211, MATH 241, MATH 242.
name: Introduction to Nuclear Safeguards
description: International nuclear non-proliferation programs and activities, proliferation risk assessment, and nuclear materials management and safeguards, including physical protection systems, material accounting and control, monitoring, and regulatory issues.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CHEM 111, PHYS 211, MATH 241, MATH 242.
name: Introduction to Nuclear Engineering
description: Radioactivity and nuclear reactions; steady state and transient nuclear reactor theory.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CHEM 111, PHYS 211, MATH 241, MATH 242.
name: Nuclear Fuel Cycles
description: Processing of nuclear fuel including fabrication, irradiation, and waste disposal or storage. In-core and out-of-core fuel management. Fuel cycle economics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EMCH 354.
name: Intermediate Heat Transfer
description: Radiant heat exchange, combined modes of heat transfer, computer techniques in heat transfer analysis and design, environmental heat transfer.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CHEM 111, PHYS 211, MATH 241, MATH 242.
name: Instrumentation for Nuclear Engineering
description: Basic operational principles of radiation detection and nuclear instrumentation systems. Selection of the proper detector to measure radiation. Statistical analysis of results.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in CHEM 111, PHYS 211, MATH 241, MATH 242.
Corequisite: EMCH 555.
name: Nuclear Instrumentation Laboratory
description: Use of nuclear radiation detection and instrumentation systems and computers. Data acquisition and analysis.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CHEM 111, PHYS 211, MATH 241, MATH 242.
name: Introduction to Risk Analysis and Reactor Safety
description: An introduction to probabilistic risk assessment (PRA) methods as applied to nuclear power plants but also examples from the chemical industry, aerospace, transportation, and other sectors. Addresses failure and reliability analysis, fault trees, event trees, reactor safety, regulatory practice.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CHEM 111, PHYS 211, MATH 241, MATH 242.
name: Introduction to Radiation Shielding and Sources
description: Radiation interactions and transport, design of radiation shields, point kernel, and Monte Carlo methods. Dosimetry, buildup factors, radiation sources, and shield materials.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in CHEM 111, PHYS 211, MATH 241, MATH 242.
name: Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Systems
description: PWR and BWR reactors, reactor system designs for accident prevention and mitigation, protection systems, containment design, emergency cooling requirements, code of federal regulations, and design criteria.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 310 or ENCP 210; D or better in EMCH 360 or ENCP 360.
name: Intermediate Fluid Mechanics
description: Integral and differential analysis of fluids. Potential flow. Boundary layer analysis. Flow in closed and open channels. Flow dynamics of turbomachinery. Steady and unsteady flows.

name: Current Topics in Mechanical Engineering
description: Special topics related to current issues in mechanical engineering. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in CHEM 112 and CHEM112L or CHEM 142.
name: Micro/nanofluidics and Lab-on-a-Chip
description: Basic fluid mechanics, capillary, drop and micro/nanoparticle, electrokinetics; micropump, mixer, preconcentrator, electrophoresis, microactuator and particle manipulator; sensors for pressure, velocity, concentration, temperature in environmental monitoring/biodefence, clinical diagnostics, drug discovery/delivery.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in CHEM 112 and CHEM 112L or CHEM 142.
name: Bio Nano/Micro Electro-Mechanical Systems
description: Fundamentals of nano- and microfabrication, metrology and their applications in biomedical engineering and science. The fabrication covers photolithography, nano/microfabrication for nano/microstructures, etching and additive techniques, MEMS integration and packaging, etc. Metrology focuses on characterization of nanostructures with imaging technologies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 260 or ENCP 260; D or better in EMCH 371.
name: Mechanical Behavior of Materials
description: Micromechanisms of the deformation and fracture of structural materials; brittle versus ductile behavior; fatigue and creep; strengthening mechanisms; mechanical testing techniques; methods in analysis of mechanical failures.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EMCH 371.
name: Physical Metallurgy
description: Equilibrium and phase relations in metallic systems; kinetics of phase transformations; annealing and precipitation phenomena.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in EMCH 371, CHEM 111, PHYS 211, MATH 241, MATH 242.
name: Introduction to Nuclear Materials
description: Materials for nuclear applications; materials degredation processes occuring in the nuclear reactor environment. Restricted to Engineering Upper Division and Graduate Students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 260 or ENCP 260; D or better in EMCH 310 or ENCP 210.
name: Adaptive Materials and Smart Structures
description: A multidisciplinary introductory course addressing the engineering field of adaptive materials and smart structures.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EMCH 290 or ECHE 310 or ENCP 290.
name: Fundamentals and Applications of Fuel Cells
description: Study of fuel cell principles, fuel cell characterization, characteristics of the major types of fuel cells, fuel cell and stack components, fuel cell stack and system design, fuel cell applications in portable, transportation, and stationary areas, as well as the current status and future research focus of fuel cells. Restricted to: Upper division.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 260 or ENCP 260; D or better in EMCH 310 or ENCP 210.
name: Aerospace Structures I
description: Static analysis of aerospace structural elements such as bars, beams, columns, plates, and shells. Topics include, but not limited to elasticity theory, simple beam theory, boundary value problems, and structural stability. Upper division or graduate status.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in AESP 265; D or better in ENCP 360 or EMCH 360.
name: Introduction to Aerodynamics
description: Fundamentals of aerodynamics, elements of compressible flow, thin airfoil therory, finite wing theory, flow through nozzles diffusers and wind tunnels, normal and oblique shock waves, elements of the methods of characteristics of finite difference solutions for compressible flows, aspects of hypersonic flow.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 242.
name: Mechanics of Solid Biomaterials
description: Introduction to the mechanical behavior of solid biomaterials. Structure and mechanical properties of tissue including skin, myocardium, and tendon. Mathematical treatment of anisotropic elasticity, nonlinear elasticity, linear and quasi-linear viscoelasticity, muscle activity.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 260 or ENCP 260.
name: Advanced Mechanics of Materials
description: Topics in stress analysis, including unsymmetrical bending, three-dimensional stress-strain; torsion; rotational stress; thick-walled pressure vessels; beams on elastic foundations; and stress concentration.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EMCH 327, EMCH 371, MATH 242.
name: Introduction to Composite Materials
description: Introduction to fiber reinforced polymer (FRP) composite materials, manufacturing methods and processes. Micro-Mechanics and properties of orthotropic laminated and woven composites. Analysis of composite structures (Mechanics and Synergistic environmental effects). Structure/property relationships. Characterization of modern composite materials. Design considerations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 260 or ENCP 260.
name: Experimental Stress Analysis
description: Stress analysis utilizing experimental techniques including transmission and scattered light photoelasticity, strain gauges, and brittle coatings. Introduction to modern concepts of coherent optics in stress analysis with emphasis on engineering applications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EMCH 354, EMCH 394.
name: Introduction to Combustion
description: Chemical thermodynamics, reaction kinetics, and combustion phenomena in energy production. Application to the modeling of coal combustion, incineration, and combustion engines.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in EMCH 290, ENCP 290, EMCH 354, or ECHE 321.
name: Solar Heating
description: Solar radiation; review of heat transfer and radiation characteristics of relevant materials; flat plate and focusing collectors; energy storage models for design of solar heating systems; system design by computer simulation; direct conversion by solar cells.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EMCH 354, EMCH 394.
name: Thermal Environmental Engineering
description: Vapor compression and absorption refrigeration systems. Heat pumps. Properties of refrigerants. Cryogenic refrigeration. Heating and cooling of buildings. Solar heating and cooling systems.

name: Making Media That Matters
description: Introductory media arts creation and study for non-majors, with emphasis on developing an individual aesthetic for screen and related media.

name: Media Culture
description: Introduction to the critical study of film,video, photography, audio, and new media.

name: Foundations of Media Arts Production
description: Fundamental conceptual and technical aspects of media.

name: Digital Media Arts Fundamentals
description: Introduction to theory and practice of origination, sequencing, and processing of screen-based and related media art.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MART 210.
name: Digital Compositing
description: Introduction to time-based digital media, concept development, and foundational techniques for video compositing and visual effects.

name: Media Writing
description: Storytelling forms and formats for screen-based and related media arts.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 210.
name: Sound Design
description: Aesthetic and communicative elements of audio design for screen-based and related media arts.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 201 and MART 210.
name: The Moving Image
description: Introduction to the theory and practice of motion picture production.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 210 or ARTS 102.
name: New Media Art
description: Introduction to the design and development of new media art, including internet-based art, media performance, installation, and interactivity.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department head is required for undergraduate students.

name: Special Topics in Media Arts
description: May be repeated once for credit as topic varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: junior status
name: Research Seminar
description: Research in a selected area of media arts.

name: Internship in Media Arts
description: Supervised experience in media productions and media production facilities. Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department head is required for undergraduate students.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 321.
name: Media Writing Advanced: Screenwriting
description: Advanced study of screenwriting.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 321.
name: Media Writing Advanced: Feature Film
description: Advanced study of feature film writing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 321.
name: Media Writing Advanced: Manga and Anime
description: Advanced study of Manga and Anime.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 321.
name: Media Writing Advanced: Television Writing
description: Advanced study of television writing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 371.
name: Moving Image Advanced: Narrative
description: Narrative for motion picture.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 371.
name: Moving Image Advanced: Documentary
description: Documentary production.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MART 262.
name: Moving Image Advanced: Animation
description: Animation production.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 371.
name: Moving Image Advanced: Experimental
description: Experimental motion picture production.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 371.
name: Moving Image Advanced: Cinematography
description: Motion picture cinematography.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 380.
name: New Media Advanced: Site-based and Installation Art
description: Art and practice of site-based and installation art.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 380.
name: New Media Advanced: Mobile Platforms
description: Art and practice of mobile platforms.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 380.
name: New Media Advanced: Media Performance
description: Art and practice of media performance.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 380.
name: New Media Advanced: Video Game Design
description: Art and practice of video game design.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 380.
name: New Media Advanced: Sound Art
description: Art and practice of sound art.

name: Special Topics in Media Arts
description: Selected topics in media arts. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FAMS 240.
name: Special Topics in Film and Media Studies
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in film and media studies. May be repeated as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in FAMS 300.
name: Special Topics in Film and Media Histories
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in film and media history. May be repeated as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FAMS 240.
name: Special Topics in U.S. Film and Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in U.S. film and media studies. May be repeated as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FAMS 240.
name: Special Topics in Global Film and Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic concerning films produced in a country other than the United States. May be repeated as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MART 110 and MART 210.
name: Media Management and Distribution
description: Research in media management and distribution.

name: Middle Level Teaching and Management
description: Overview of national trends in the middle school with an analysis of the relationship of early adolescent developmental characteristics to organization, curriculum, instruction, and teaching in the middle school level.

name: Foundations in Reading
description: Reading foundations, curriculum, and assessments for teaching young adolescents across academic disciplines.

name: Middle Level Content Area Reading and Writing
description: Examination of planning, implementation, and assessment of reading strategy instruction across disciplines and content areas in middle level classrooms. Restricted to: teacher candidates enrolled in the middle level degree program.

name: Methods and Materials for Teaching Science in the Middle Grades
description: A study of methods, techniques, and materials of instruction appropriate to science teaching in the middle school.

name: Methods and Materials for Teaching Social Studies in the Middle School
description: A study of goals, content, methods, and materials of instruction in middle school social studies.

name: Middle Level Literacy Assessment
description: Introduces literacy assessment for individual and small groups or middle level students.

name: Methods and Materials for Teaching English/Language Arts in the Middle Grades
description: Introduces goals, content, and methods of teaching language arts at the middle level.

name: Methods and Materials for Teaching Mathematics in the Middle Grades
description: A study of methods, techniques, and materials of instruction appropriate to mathematics teaching in the middle school.

requisiteText: Corequisite: EDML 599.
name: Middle School Internship Seminar
description: Inquiry into the issues that arise during internship B experiences including classroom management, adolescent development, legal/professional responsibilities, multicultural perspectives, and needs of exceptional children.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Corequisite: ARMY 101L.
name: Introduction to Army Fundamental Tactics
description: Introduces cadets to the Army and the Profession of Arms.

requisiteText: Corequisite: ARMY 101L.
name: Foundations of Agile and Adaptive Leadership
description: Continuation of ARMY 101. Builds on the introduction to the Army and the Profession of Arms.

requisiteText: Corequisite: ARMY 201L.
name: Leadership and Decision Making
description: Exploration of tactical leadership strategies, team dynamics, historical leadership theories and developing leadership attributes.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Corequisite: ARMY 202L.
name: Army Doctrine and Team Development
description: Soldier skills, including map reading and land navigation. Introduces Army troop-leading procedures through practical exercises and principles of war using historical events. Note: Two lectures and leadership laboratory per week.

requisiteText: Corequisite: ARMY 301L.
name: Training Management and War Fighting Function
description: Classroom instruction on Army Publications and Doctrine, War Fighting Functions and the Branches of the Army, Oral Presentations, as well as dedicated leadership labs focusing on Field Craft, Marksmanship, and Individual, Team, and Squad Movement Techniques.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in ARMY 301.
Corequisite: ARMY 302L.
name: Adaptive Leadership and Tactical Operations
description: Continuation of ARMY 301. Classroom instruction on Army Publications and Doctrine, War Fighting Functions and the Branches of the Army, Oral Presentations, as well as dedicated leadership labs focusing on Field Craft, Marksmanship, and Individual, Team, and Squad Movement Techniques.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: completion of the Leadership Development Assessment Course [LDAC], NURS 412 or its equivalent, acceptance into any Army ROTC, and enrolled Army ROTC Nursing Cadets.
name: Nurses Summer Training Program Clinical Elective
description: A 3-week summer nursing experience conducted at an Army hospital in the United States, Europe, or Asia that orients the cadet nurse to the mission of the U.S. Army Medical Department and its health care delivery system. It provides a minimum of 120 hours of clinical experience to develop nursing, leadership, administrative, and interpersonal skills.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in ARMY 301 and ARMY 302.
Corequisite: ARMY 401L.
name: The Army Officer and the Profession of Arms I
description: Focuses on developing the knowledge, skills, and abilities to plan, resource, and assess training at the small unit level. Topics include Army programs that support counseling subordinates and evaluating performance, values and ethics, career planning, and legal responsibilities.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in ARMY 401.
Corequisite: ARMY 402L.
name: The Army Officer and the Profession of Arms II
description: Continuation of ARMY 401. Focuses on developing the knowledge, skills, and abilities to plan, resource, and assess training at the small unit level. Topics include Army programs that support counseling subordinates and evaluating performance, values and ethics, career planning, and legal responsibilities.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: American Military Experience
description: Transformation of war and of the institutions for waging war from the American Revolution to the present.

name: Music Convocation
description: Music Convocation gathers the School of Music community together for shared experiences regarding different aspects of Professional Skills and Entrepreneurship, Academic Integrity and Excellence, Wellness and Safety, Performance and Collaboration, and Global Engagement. Pass/Fail grading only.

name: Music Advocacy I: Understanding the Power of Your Music
description: An introduction to advocacy methods, techniques and experiences to understand the positive effects of music in American society. Pass/Fail Grading.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

description: An introduction to playing the guitar as both a solo and an accompanying instrument. One class meeting and one private lesson per week.

name: Introduction to Piano
description: An introductory course in the beginning techniques of making music at the piano. One group class and one private lesson each week. This class is designed for students with no prior formal training in piano.

name: Introduction to Singing
description: An introduction to singing, designed for students with no prior formal training in music.

name: Introduction to Music
description: Perceptive listening and appreciation of musical elements, forms and style periods, including composers' lives, individual styles and representative works. Emphasis on classical music; jazz and American popular music included.

name: Special Topics in Popular Music
description: An investigation into the function of popular music in contemporary society. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Introduction to Music Theory
description: Practice in basic written theory and aural skills. Concepts of rhythm, melody, harmony, form, and expression. Open to non-music majors. Not for credit toward major requirements in music degrees. Subdiscipline: Music (Theory and Composistion).

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 114 or passing score on the Undergraduate Theory Diagnostic Exam.
name: Music Theory I
description: A survey of the sound, harmony, melody, rhythm, and form of diatonic tonal music of a variety of styles.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 115.
name: Music Theory II
description: Continuation of MUSC 115.

name: Aural Skills I
description: Development of musical independence, including sightsinging, ear training, rhythmic reading, dictation, and partsinging.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 117.
name: Aural Skills II
description: Continuation of MUSC 117.

name: Ensemble - Accompanying
description: Chamber ensembles; special ensembles of instruments and voices. Not Auditable.

name: University Band
description: University Band is a University of South Carolina concert ensemble established as a performing opportunity for both music majors and non-majors. This course is open to all USC students, regardless of major and degree, and no audition is required.

name: The Marching Band
description: Provides opportunities to improve performance skills, improve individual and ensemble musicianship and supports the USC football program and the university in general. Music education majors have the opportunity for experience and skills necessary to direct marching band programs. Open to any academic major accepted through audition.

name: Symphonic Winds
description: Provides opportunities to improve performance skills, improve individual and ensemble musicianship and provides music education majors with experience and skills necessary to conduct instrumental wind and percussion ensembles. The ensemble rehearses and performs standard repertoire and 21st century works by contemporary composers. Performance opportunities include concerts each semester. Open to any academic major accepted through audition.

name: University Concert Choir
description: Not Auditable.

name: University Orchestra
description: Instruction in orchestral music through the study and performance of quality literature representing a variety of style periods and musical genres. Over the course of multiple semesters, students will develop increased ensemble skills, technical proficiency, and stylistic understanding.

name: University Chorus
description: Not Auditable.

name: Jazz Ensemble
description: Opportunities to learn classic big band arrangements in a big band setting, culminating in a public performance.

name: Wind Ensemble
description: The USC Wind Ensemble is a flexibly-instrumented performing ensemble comprised of undergraduate and graduate students selected by audition. The ensemble performs repertoire representing a variety of styles and time periods with concerts both on and off campus. Membership is open to any University of South Carolina student regardless of major.

name: Jazz and American Popular Music
description: Development of jazz and American popular music through the study of important soloists, ensembles, arrangers, and composers.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 110 for non music majors.
name: Introduction to Music Literature
description: Listening to examples of all style periods and genres of Western music. Analysis of form and other audible style characteristics. Study of major works of the concert repertory.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 103.
name: Basic Guitar II
description: A continuation of MUSC 103 in which students learn to play the guitar as both a solo and an accompanying instrument. One class meeting and one private lesson per week.

name: Understanding the Psychology of Music
description: Various psychological and psychosocial aspects of human musical behavior, including introductory musical acoustics, perception and cognition of music, music and the brain, music processing across world cultures, music and emotions, music and human health, music in social contexts, and principles of experimental design.

name: Beginning Piano Accompanying

name: Introduction to Singer's Diction
description: Techniques of pronunciation, phonetics, and international phonetic alphabet as applied to standard vocal repertory. Not auditable.

name: Introduction to Music Industry Studies
description: An overview of the music industry. Students will explore a variety of music industry career paths in areas such as arts management, music products and merchandizing, public relations, music production and recording, publishing, online music distribution, and live music event organization.
