requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 115 or equivalent experience.
name: Music Composition I
description: Introduction to music composition.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 215.
name: Jazz Theory I
description: Introduction to the language of jazz improvisation: rhythms, articulations, style, harmony and melody, forms, simple analysis, chord/scale relationships, ear training and keyboard harmony.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 215.
name: Jazz Theory II
description: Introduction to the language of jazz improvisation: rhythms, articulations, style, harmony and melody, forms, simple analysis, chord/scale relationships, ear training and keyboard harmony.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 220.
name: Jazz Improvisation III
description: Application of advanced aural and theoretical skills in selected jazz repertory. .

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 329.
name: Jazz Improvisation IV
description: Application of advanced aural and theoretical skills in selected jazz repertory.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 217.
name: Basic Choral and Instrumental Conducting
description: A course in organizing and conducting choral and instrumental ensembles in which basic conducting technique is acquired.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 333, MUSC 218.
name: Instrumental Conducting
description: Emphasis upon advanced baton technique and its application through practical experience with laboratory ensembles.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 333, MUSC 218, MUED 355.
name: Choral Conducting
description: Further study of the techniques of choral conducting, principles of group tone production, and interpretative factors.

name: Introduction to Computer Music
description: Techniques of computer-generated music production including aspects of MIDI, digital synthesis, and music programming. Open to students in any discipline. Not Auditable.

name: Jazz Literature
description: Study of significant jazz recordings structured to foster familiarity with important jazz stylists, improvisers, composers, and arrangers in the post-swing era of jazz history.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 100L, MUSC 115, MUSC 116.
name: History of Western Music I
description: Western music from ca. 1500 through 1750, considering musical styles, genres and forms, and the contributions of composers through historical, analytical and musical perspectives. Subdiscipline: Music - History and Literature.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 353.
name: History of Western Music II
description: Western music from ca. 1730 through ca. 1970, considering musical styles, genre and forms, and the contributions of composers through historical, analytical, and musical perspectives. Subdiscipline, Music - History and Literature.

name: An Introduction to Audio Recording Techniques
description: Basic acoustics; miking techniques; analog tape: recording, editing, mixing and duplication; signal processing.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor and department chair is required for undergraduate students. Not auditable.

name: Vocal Coaching
description: A study of stylistic, linguistic, and other performance issues in solo operatic, oratorio, and recital repertoire for singers. Not auditable.

description: Intermediate level composition class.

name: Musical Theatre Workshop
description: Intensive musical theatre training in areas of song interpretation, musical theatre, dance, voice and acting.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 354.
name: History of Western Music III
description: Western music from ca. 1860 until the present time, considering musical styles, genre and forms, and the contributions of composers through historical, analytical, and musical perspectives. Subdiscipline, Music - History and Literature.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 305; C or better in one of the following: MUSC 580, MUSC 582, or MUSC 593; successful review of a Music Industry Studies portfolio.
name: Music Industry Capstone
description: Culmination of Music Industry Studies with a focus on experiential learning or research, supervised by a faculty member. Studio Portfolio materials will be gathered to aid in matriculation to higher education or careers in the music industry. Can be taken twice for a credit for a maximum of six credit hours.

name: Topics in Performance and Literature
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of course title.

name: Secondary Applied Music
description: Courses consist of individual instruction including individualized assignments and regular private instruction and review. Instruments are designated by suffix: 501A-flute/piccolo; 501B-oboe/English horn; 501C-clarinet; 501D-bassoon; 501E-saxophone; 501F-French horn; 501G-trumpet; 501H-trombone; 501I-euphonium; 501J-tuba; 501K-percussion; 501L-harpsichord; 501N-classical guitar; 501O-organ; 501P-piano; 501R-violin; 501S-viola; 501T-violoncello; 501U-double bass; 501V-voice; 501W-service playing; 501Y-conducting; 501Z-jazz. Repeatable for credit. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Undergraduate Students: C or better in MUSC 215; Graduate Students: Passing score on the Music Theory portion of the Music Graduate Diagnostic Exam or a grade of C or better in MUSC 523.
name: Orchestration
description: Instrumentation and orchestration; possibilities and limitations idiomatic to specific orchestral instruments and ensemble combinations. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 417 or equivalent experience.
name: Composition
description: Private study in music composition; may be repeated. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Undergraduate Students: C or better in MUSC 215; Graduate Students: a passing score on the music theory portion of the Graduate Music Diagnostic Exam or a grade of C or better in MUSC 523.
name: Form and Analysis
description: Examination of fundamental principles of musical forms; analysis of representative tonal works. Not auditable.

name: Studio Arranging and Composition
description: Instruction and practice in arranging and composing in various jazz and commercial music styles and genres. May be repeated for credit. Not auditable.

name: Techniques and Materials of Tonal Music
description: Study of the techniques and materials of tonal harmony and voice leading with integrated ear-training component. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Undergraduate Students: C or better in MUSC 215; Graduate students: passing score on the Music Theory portion of the Music Graduate Diagnostic Exam or a grade of C or better in MUSC 523.
name: Post-Tonal Music Theory
description: Studies in post-tonal theoretical techniques and analysis. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Undergraduate Students: C or better in MUSC 215; Graduate Students: Passing score on the Music Theory portion of the Music Graduate Diagnostic Exam or a grade of C or better in MUSC 523.
name: Analytical Studies
description: Analytical techniques applied to music of a particular style, period, or genre. May be repeated for a total of 9 credits. Topic for any semester to be announced by title in the schedule of classes. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Undergraduate Students: C or better in MUSC 215; Graduate Students: Passing score on the Music Theory portion of the Music Graduate Diagnostic Exam or a grade of C or better in MUSC 523.
name: Seminar in Music Theory
description: Advanced studies in music theory. Individual projects. Three meetings per week. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Undergraduate Students: C or better in MUSC 215; Graduate Students: Passing score on the Music Theory portion of the Music Graduate Diagnostic Exam or a grade of C or better in MUSC 523 .
name: Eighteenth-Century Counterpoint
description: Analysis and writing in contrapuntal forms with emphasis on the style of Bach. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Undergraduate Students: C or better in MUSC 215; Graduate students: passing score on the Music Theory portion of the Music Graduate Diagnostic Exam or a grade of C or better in MUSC 523.
name: Sixteenth-Century Counterpoint
description: Analysis and writing in contrapuntal forms with emphasis on the style of Palestrina. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 336.
name: Projects in Computer Music
description: Directed study in computer-music composition or research. Not auditable.

name: Song Literature
description: A study of the development of the solo art song, illustrated by major works of the song writers of all major nationalities. Not auditable.

name: Topics in Music History
description: Topic for any semester to be announced by title in the schedule of classes. May be repeated for a total of nine credits. Not auditable.

name: Survey of the Opera
description: A survey of the literature of Classic, Romantic, and modern opera, with special attention given to the recognition of the best-known works in each school. Recordings. Open to all students as an elective. Not auditable.

name: Orchestra Literature
description: Symphony, concerto, tone poem, and other symphonic works from the Classic, Romantic, and modern repertory. Changing concepts of orchestration. Not auditable.

name: Survey of Chamber Music
description: The literature for small instrumental ensembles from the Baroque era to the present. The string quartet, divertimento, keyboard-accompanied sonata, etc. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 110 or equivalent.
name: World Music
description: Rhythms, scales, forms, and instrument types basic to all music. European and American folk song, African and Native American tribal music, Asian music. Not auditable.

name: American Music
description: Survey of the music composed in the United States from the colonial period to the present. The influences of European, African, Indian, and South American musical styles. Not auditable.

name: Piano Literature I
description: Standard piano literature including major masterpieces from 1700 to 1850. Emphasis on instrumental and stylistic developments, and historical and theoretical background for interpreting the literature of the piano. Not auditable.

name: Piano Literature II
description: Standard piano literature including major masterpieces from 1850 to present . Emphasis on instrumental and stylistic developments, and historical and theoretical background for interpreting the literature of the piano. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 365.
name: Advanced Audio Recording Techniques
description: Multi-microphone and ambisonic stereo recording techniques; multi-track recording, signal processing and audio production; digital audio. Studio and field experience. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 565.
name: Fundamentals of Sound Use for Media
description: Music for use in media; midi applications and synchronization methods using time code; direct-to-hard-disc tapeless audio recording software. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 565.
name: Recording Studio Techniques
description: Technology and techniques in the recording studio including use of equalizers, limiters, reverberators, compressors, the mixing console, multi-track recording, microphone techniques, and basic acoustics related to the instrumental and vocal recording process. Not auditable.

name: Intermediate Piano Accompanying
description: Approaches to specific problems in vocal and instrumental accompanying; supervised accompanying in class. Advanced work for experienced students. Not auditable.

name: Italian and Latin Diction
description: Techniques of pronunciation, phonetics, and international phonetic alphabet as applied to standard vocal repertory, with emphasis on Italian and Latin languages. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 365.
name: Digital Audio Technology
description: A study of the theory and practice of digital audio technology including analog to digital conversion, digital storage, error correction, transmission, basic digital signal processing, and synchronization.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 565.
name: Advanced Audio Topics
description: A study of the theory and practice of audio topics such as digital signal processing, psychoacoustics, data compression, sound reinforcement systems, wireless transmission, large scale system integration, and emerging technologies.

name: Performance Pedagogy I
description: Basic concepts, techniques and materials for teaching a specific instrument. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Corequisite: MUSC 573.
name: Pedagogy Laboratory
description: Directed teaching in laboratory and private settings. Not auditable.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 573.
Corequisite: MUSC 574L.
name: Performance Pedagogy II
description: Basic concepts, techniques and materials for teaching a specific instrument intermediate studies. Not auditable.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 573L.
Corequisite: MUSC 574.
name: Pedagogy Laboratory
description: Directed teaching in laboratory and private settings. Not auditable.

name: Directed Teaching in Pedagogy I
description: Supervised teaching in a performance area. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Corequisite: MUSC 575.
name: Pedagogy Laboratory
description: Directed teaching in laboratory and private settings. Not auditable.

name: Teaching in Pedagogy II
description: Supervised teaching in a performance area. Course may be repeated for credit (6 credits total). Not auditable.

name: Pedagogy Laboratory
description: Practical experience in preparing lesson plans and teaching theory-performance classes for precollege piano students on electronic and acoustical instruments. May be repeated for credit. Not auditable.

name: Vocal Pedagogy
description: Anatomy and function of the singing voice with practical application to teaching. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 570.
name: German and English Diction
description: Techniques of pronunciation for singing in German and English. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 570.
name: French Diction
description: Techniques of pronunciation for singing in French. Not auditable.

name: Music & Arts Entrepreneurship
description: Entrepreneurial skills and context for arts-based careers and business ventures. Students develop arts projects related to their interests.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: The Alexander Technique
description: Theoretical/experimental exploration of major body systems and developmental movements to bring more articulation to the body and more awareness and physical ease in performance. For music and education students. Not auditable.

name: Music and Money
description: A survey of the for-profit and non-profit music economies and the broader policy that drives these economies. Restricted to Music majors.

name: Music and Worship
description: The selection and leadership of music in the church service; music for the rural church; selecting and directing anthems and service music for the nonprofessional church choir; the transition from psalmody to hymnody in the 18th century; the Anglican Chant and the Lutheran Chorale. Not auditable.

name: Workshop in Music
description: Selected topics in music. May be repeated as topic varies. Not auditable.

name: Organ Literature I
description: Organ literature and registration from antiquity to 1750. Not auditable.

name: Organ Literature II
description: Organ literature and registration 1750 to the present. Not auditable.

name: Repertories of Lute, Vihuela, and Guitar
description: Solo literature for plucked, fretted instruments from the Renaissance into the 20th century. National styles, traits, and technical innovations included. Not auditable. Admission to upper division guitar study.

name: Business of Music
description: This course analyzes the forms and structures of both major and independent record labels. Course concepts will be reinforced with case studies, journal articles, and guest speakers. Not auditable.

name: Arts Management
description: Management techniques for organizations with a musical component such as: orchestra, opera, ballet, artist series. Not auditable.

name: Seminar in Music Industry
description: Survey of current events and topics within the music industry, and analyses of music businesses through the use of case studies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 580 and MUSC 582.
name: Music Leadership Practicum
description: A practicum to design and execute an entrepreneurial music leadership project in Columbia, South Carolina. Restricted to Music majors.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: 21st Century Performer
description: Issues confronting the professional performing musician. Topics will include performance-based income models and opportunities, program development, and promotional and supporting materials. Restricted to School of Music students.

name: Arts Marketing
description: Arts marketing program challenges, arts organizations, building the successful private studio, marketing plans, social media and guerilla marketing, and market research.

name: Independent Music Teaching Business
description: A study of all aspects of the creation and maintenance of a viable independent music teaching business. Restricted to School of Music students.

name: Community Engagement Through Music
description: Community engagement as it relates to music, with a focus on developing practical skills in creating engaging, interactive performances for various audiences.

name: Music Business Internship
description: Supervised work experience as approved by area program director. May be repeated up to 6 credits. Not auditable.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Secondary Strings-Violin
description: Secondary Strings-Violin. Fundamentals of playing and teaching string instruments in a homogeneous class. Special study of problems unique to the instrument relating to care and repair, tone production, bowing, articulation, fingering, intonation, and teaching materials. One class meeting per week. May be repeated for credit.

description: Secondary Strings-Viola. Fundamentals of playing and teaching string instruments in a homogeneous class. Special study of problems unique to the instrument relating to care and repair, tone production, bowing, articulation, fingering, intonation, and teaching materials. One class meeting per week. Special study of problems unique to the instrument relating to care and repair, embouchure, tone production, articulation, fingering, intonation, and teaching materials. One class meeting per week. May be repeated for credit.

name: Secondary Brass-Trumpet
description: Secondary Brass - Trumpet. Fundamentals of playing and teaching brass instruments in a homogeneous class. Special study of problems unique to the instrument relating to care and repair, embouchure, tone production, articulation, fingering, intonation, and teaching materials. One class meeting per week. May be repeated for credit.

name: Secondary Brass-French Horn
description: Secondary Brass - French Horn. Fundamentals of playing and teaching brass instruments in a homogeneous class. Special study of problems unique to the instrument relating to care and repair, embouchure, tone production, articulation, fingering, intonation, and teaching materials. One class meeting per week. May be repeated for credit.

name: Secondary Brass-Trombone
description: Secondary Brass - Trombone. Fundamentals of playing and teaching brass instruments in a homogeneous class. Special study of problems unique to the instrument relating to care and repair, embouchure, tone production, articulation, fingering, intonation, and teaching materials. One class meeting per week. May be repeated for credit.

name: Secondary Brass-Tuba Euphonium
description: Secondary Brass - Tuba Euphonium. Fundamentals of playing and teaching brass instruments in a homogeneous class. Special study of problems unique to the instrument relating to care and repair, embouchure, tone production, articulation, fingering, intonation, and teaching materials. One class meeting per week. May be repeated for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in both MUED 200 and MUED 356.
name: Classroom Instruments
description: Class instruction in guitar, recorder, non-pitched and pitched percussion, with emphasis on the development of performance skills, the understanding of pedagogical techniques and materials, and the ability to play and teach these instruments in a group setting.

name: Group Piano
description: A course for beginning piano students meeting in groups. Emphasis on music reading and elementary techniques. Two meetings and two laboratory periods a week. Repeatable once for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUED 155 or advanced placement via exam.
name: Group Piano
description: A course for beginning piano students meeting in groups. Emphasis on music reading and elementary techniques. Two meetings and two laboratory periods a week. Repeatable once for credit.

name: Class Voice (Basic)
description: Elementary courses in singing in which both group and individual techniques are employed. Study of voice production and principles of singing.

name: Class Voice (Basic)
description: Elementary courses in singing in which both group and individual techniques are employed. Study of voice production and principles of singing.

name: Music Education Practicum
description: Practicum experiences in various types of public school music settings. Seminars and group discussions included. Pass-Fail credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUED 165, MUED 166, or preparation satisfactory to the instructor.
name: Class Voice (Intermediate)
description: Continued study of the principles of singing and song repertoire.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUED 165, MUED 166, or preparation satisfactory to the instructor.
name: Class Voice (Intermediate)
description: Continued study of the principles of singing and song repertoire.

requisiteText: Corequisite: MUSC 333.
name: Choral Literature Lab I
description: Practical application of choral conducting skills and rehearsal techniques with choral literature.

requisiteText: Corequisite: MUSC 335.
name: Choral Literature Lab II
description: Continued application of choral conducting skills and rehearsal techniques with choral literature.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUED 156 or advanced placement via exam.
name: Advanced Group Piano
description: Group piano for music education students emphasizing choral music. Opportunities for accompanying instrumentalists, vocalists, and choral groups. Repeatable once for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUED 355 or advanced placement via exam.
name: Advanced Group Piano
description: Group piano for music education students emphasizing choral music. Opportunities for accompanying instrumentalists, vocalists, and choral groups. Repeatable once for credit.

name: Wind Pedagogy I
description: Fundamentals of playing and teaching wind instruments in a heterogeneous class. Study of basic principles regarding embouchure, tone production, articulation, fingering, and teaching materials.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Passing grade in MUED 200.
name: Strings
description: Fundamentals of playing and teaching string instruments in a heterogeneous class. Problems unique to each instrument relating to care and repair, tone production, bowing, fingering, and teaching materials.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Passing grade in MUED 200.
name: Instrumental Techniques for Choral Majors
description: Techniques for leading an instrumental or mixed choral/instrumental ensemble. Instrumental tone, maintenance, score-reading skills, transposition, and rehearsal methods. Not auditable.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Satisfactory in MUED 200.
name: Percussion Techniques
description: Fundamentals of playing and teaching percussion instruments. Special study of problems unique to each percussion instrument and related teaching materials.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Satisfactory in MUED 200.
name: Percussion Practicum
description: Practicum experiences teaching percussion in various types of school and community music settings.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 215 and MUSC 218.
name: Music for Young Children
description: Examination and practical application of methods, techniques, and materials for teaching music, Pre-K to Grade 5.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Band Literature and Materials
description: A study of teaching materials, solo- and small-ensemble literature, and full band ensemble literature appropriate for grades 5-12.

name: Jazz/Pop Styles and Improvisation
description: A study of the essential elements in jazz and popular music. Familiarization and practice with materials and methods of teaching improvisation and jazz performance.

name: Technology for Music Teachers
description: Familiarization with computer software and hardware for the teaching of music and administration of music programs.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Satisfactory in MUED 200.
name: General Music in Elementary Schools
description: Discussion of sequential music development; implementation of methods, techniques, and materials for teaching music in grades K-5.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Corequisite: MUED 465.
name: Practicum in Elementary Music
description: Practical application of elementary methods and techniques studied in school settings.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in EDUC 300.
name: General Music in Secondary Schools
description: Middle-school and high-school general music education philosophy, teaching techniques, music objectives, curriculum development, administration, facilities, and equipment.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in MUSC 218 and MUED 356; a passing grade in MUED 200.
Corequisite: MUED 467P.
name: Choral Methods and Materials
description: Procedures and materials for choral instruction applicable to elementary, middle-school, and high-school choruses; basic concepts of choral tone and vocal development.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Corequisite: MUED 467.
name: Practicum in Choral Music
description: Practical application of choral methods and techniques in school settings. Not auditable.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Marching Band Techniques
description: Fundamentals of marching, maneuvering, and formations; special features such as drum majoring and auxiliary units; discussion and planning of halftime shows.

name: Directed Teaching (Music)
description: A clinical field experience in the public school setting. Note: Prior to enrolling in MUED 477, students must complete the following: 1) Admission to the Professional Program, and 2) All MUED courses, and conducting courses are required for the student�€�s specific degree track. Courses must be passed with Grade of �€�C�€? or better. Students are strongly encouraged to complete all MUSC courses prior to the student teaching semester for optimum preparation for the pre-service internship. No additional course work may be taken during the Directed Teaching semester without permission of the School of Music Undergraduate Director. Restricted to seniors. Special Permissions: Department
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: Passing grade in MUED 200 and C or better in three semesters selected from MUED 104A - MUED 104D.
Corequisite: MUED 533P.
name: Orchestra Methods I
description: Fundamentals of teaching orchestral stringed instruments in school string and orchestra classes. Emphasis on sequential instruction, materials, and classroom management.

requisiteText: Corequisite: MUED 533.
name: Practicum in Orchestra Methods I
description: Practical application of string methods and materials in public and community school settings. Not auditable.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in MUED 533 and MUSC 101.
Corequisite: MUED 534P.
name: Orchestra Methods II
description: Continued study of methods, materials, and concepts of teaching orchestral stringed instruments in school string and orchestra classes. Emphasis on rehearsal techniques and curricula.

requisiteText: Corequisite: MUED 534.
name: Practicum in Orchestra Methods II
description: Practical application of string methods and materials in public and community school settings. Not auditable
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Passing grade in MUED 200 and C or better in four semesters selected from MUED 105A-MUED 105P and MUED 106A-MUED 106P.
name: The Middle School Band
description: Study of teaching materials, methods, literature, and educational practices used in middle school band settings.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUED 551.
name: The High School Band
description: Study of teaching materials, methods, literature, and educational practices used in high school band settings.

name: Workshop in Music Education
description: Selected topics in music education. May be repeated as the topic varies. Credits 1-3 per registration; 12 maximum.

name: Integrating Music into PreK & Elementary Classrooms
description: Develop activities and learning plans that integrate music into language arts, math, science, social studies, ELA, and learning for students with special needs. Apply those lessons in practicums with children.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUED 357 or admission to MAT (music) program.
name: Wind Pedagogy II
description: Continued study of the issues in playing and teaching wind instruments in a heterogeneous class. Special study of problems unique to each woodwind and brass instrument regarding fingering and intonation.

name: Arraning for the Marching Band
description: Instruction and practice in arranging music for the marching band.

name: String Instrument Pedagogy
description: Principles and practices in teaching string instruments, including Suzuki and Rolland. Emphasis on teaching in the private studio.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUED 465.
name: Specialized Elementary Music Methods
description: Advanced study of Orff, Kodaly, Dalcroze, and Gordon music learning theories as applied in elementary schools.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MUED 200.
name: Organization and Administration of Music Programs
description: Topics include materials and techniques of class teaching, equipment purchase, budgeting, recruiting, public relations, and the music library.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Corequisite: MUED 568.
name: Practicum in Instrumental Music
description: Practical application of instrumental methods and techniques in school settings. Not auditable.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Fundamentals of Naval Science
description: The Naval Service with emphasis on the mission, organization, regulation, and components of the Navy and Marine Corps.

name: U.S. Military History
description: A historical survey on the importance of military doctrine and the many roles of the United States Military covering from the American Revolution to present day. HIST 468 or ARMY 406 may be taken in lieu of this course to meet the Naval ROTC History requirement.

name: Naval Military Laboratory
description: Military drill, cruise preparation, customs, traditions, and special areas of knowledge required of commissioned officers in the Navy and Marine Corps. Pass/Fail grading.

name: Naval Ships Systems I
description: Types, structure, and purpose of naval ships. Hydrodynamic forces, stability, compartmentation, electrical, and auxiliary systems. Theory of design and operation of steam, gas turbine, and nuclear propulsion. Shipboard safety and firefighting.

name: Naval Ships Systems II
description: Fire control systems, weapons types, capabilities, and limitations. Physical aspects of radar and underwater sound for target acquisition, threat analysis, tracking, weapons selection, delivery, and guidance. Explosives, fusing, and naval ordnance.

name: Navigation/Naval Operations I
description: Piloting and celestial navigation theory, principles, and procedures. Tides, current, weather, use of navigational instruments and equipments, and practicum. Laboratory required.

name: Navigation/Naval Operations Lab I
description: Laboratory work in piloting and celestial navigation to complement Naval Science 301. One hour per week.

name: Navigation/Naval Operations II
description: International and Inland Rules of the Road; relative motion-vector analysis; ship handling, employment, tactics, and afloat communications; and operations analysis. Laboratory required.

name: Navigation/Naval Operations II Lab
description: Laboratory work in maneuvering board (vector analysis) and Rules of the Road to complement Naval Science 302. One hour per week.

name: Evolution of the Art of War
description: A survey of military history emphasizing principles of warfare, strategy and tactics, and significant military leaders and organizations.

name: Naval Leadership and Management I
description: Theory and principles of management, focusing on the officer-manager as an organizational decision maker. Includes interpersonal skills; behavior factors; group dynamics.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Naval Leadership and Ethics
description: Integration of professional military competencies and qualities of effective leadership with emphasis on moral and ethical responsibilities, accountability, communications, and military law for the junior officer.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Fundamentals of Maneuver Warfare
description: The history of Maneuver Warfare emphasizing doctrine and techniques while enabling students to become critical thinkers and better prepare them for future service.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: Admission to the nursing program
Corequisite: BIOL 243, BIOL 243L; ENGL 101; LANU 206, LANU 106
name: Nursing Care Management I
description: This course focuses on the knowledge, skills, and abilities that are fundamental to nursing practice with application in acute or extended care settings.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: Admission to the nursing program; LANU 159, LANU 211
Corequisite: BIOL 243, BIOL 243L; ENGL 101, ENGL 102; LANU 104, LANU 206
name: Pharmacologic Basics
description: This introductory course outlines the basic concepts of pharmaceutics, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and pharmacotherapeutics. The process of clinical calculations is introduced, as well as the major drug classifications.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: LANU 104, LANU 106, LANU 206
Corequisite: BIOL 244, BIOL 244L; PSYC 101; LANU 211
name: Nurse Care Management II
description: Focuses on the delivery of nursing care to an increasing number of individuals experiencing health problems emphasizing selected physiological systems.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: Admission to the nursing program
Corequisite: BIOL 243, BIOL 243L; ENGL 101; LANU 104, LANU 106
name: Clinical Skills Application
description: Involves the application of knowledge, skills, and abilities in a clinical setting.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: LANU 159, LANU 211
Corequisite: ENGL 102
name: Nursing Management III
description: Focuses on the delivery of nursing care to an increasing number of individuals experiencing health problems emphasizing selected physiological systems.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: LANU 104, LANU 106, LANU 206
Corequisite: LANU 159; PSYC 101; BIOL 244, BIOL 244L
name: Care of the Childbearing Family
description: This course facilitates the application of the nursing process to assist in meeting the needs of the childbearing and child-rearing family. Focus is on both normal and abnormal aspects.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: LANU 229
Corequisite: LANU 219, humanities/fine arts elective, elective
name: Mental Health Nursing
description: This course facilitates the utilization of the nursing process to assist in meeting the needs of patients with common mental health problems. Focus is on the dynamics of human behavior, ranging from normal to extreme.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: LANU 214
name: Nursing Management and Leadership
description: This course prepares the student for the professional nursing role through the introduction of management skills required to care for small groups of individuals and to function as a leader of a nursing team.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: LANU 209
Corequisite: BIOL 330, BIOL 330L; MATH 111
name: Nursing Care Management IV
description: This course focuses on the delivery of nursing care to clients throughout the lifespan who are experiencing complex, multi-system health problems.

name: Introduction to Nursing as a Profession
description: Introduction to the profession of nursing. Provides the framework for the development and evolution of nursing practice.

name: Introduction to Human Genetics for Health Care Professionals
description: A comprehensive introduction to the field of human genetics designed to raise nursing students�€� awareness of the role of genetics in all areas of medical care. A clinical approach and emphasis.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101.
name: Facilitative Communication
description: Examination of communication theory and development of communication skills. Focuses on non-directive and directive interviewing techniques with dyads, small groups, and families.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CHEM 102; BIOL 243 and BIOL 244 or EXSC 224 and accompanying labs.
name: Biophysical Pathology
description: Pathology associated with biophysical alterations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: NURS 216.
name: Clinical Nutrition
description: Principles of normal and therapeutic nutrition, and the role of the nurse in nutritional care.

name: Socio-Cultural Variations in Health and Illness
description: Diverse health care belief systems and how they influence human responses to health and illness. Focus on African-American and other cultural groups.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Nursing Science in Professional Practice
description: Nursing as a science; selected concepts of self-care and communication within the context of nursing science. Transition course for registered nurse students only. Credit received for NURS 110 and NURS 210 upon completion.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: NURS 250.
name: Nursing Health Assessment
description: Cognitive skills, psychomotor skills and technologies necessary to perform health assessment.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in NURS 216 and NURS 220.
Corequisite: NURS 312, NURS 313, NURS 314, and NURS 324.
name: Introduction to Health Assessment
description: Cognitive skills, psychomotor skills, and technologies necessary to perform health assessment. Laboratory required.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in NURS 216 and NURS 220.
Corequisite: NURS 311, NURS 313, NURS 314, and NURS 324.
name: Foundations of Nursing Practice
description: Cognitive, affective, and psychomotor skills and technologies necessary to nursing intervention. Practicum required.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: Generic BSN Students: C or better in NURS 216 and NURS 220; RN-BSN Students: C or better in NURS 250.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: Generic BSN Students: C or better in NURS 311, NURS 312, NURS 314, and NURS 324.
name: Nursing Care of the Older Adult
description: Nursing care focusing on health promotion, restoration, and support of older adults. Restricted to upper division nursing students.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in NURS 216 and NURS 220.
Corequisite: NURS 311, NURS 312, NURS 313, and NURS 324.
name: Clinical Reasoning in Nursing Practice
description: The process of making clinical judgments.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in NURS 250.
name: Application of Pathophysiology and Pharmacology in Nursing
description: Concepts of disease processes in the human body and related pharmacologic interventions. Focus on nursing assessments and interventions.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in NURS 216 and NURS 220.
Corequisite: NURS 311, NURS 312, NURS 313, and NURS 314.
name: Chemical Therapeutics
description: Pharmacology with an emphasis on clinical applications within the context of the nursing process and prioritization of needs.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: NURS 322, NURS 323.
name: Perioperative Nursing
description: Perioperative care of clients with common, recurring nursing problems requiring surgical intervention. Perioperative practicum required.

name: Selected Topics
description: Topics of special interest in nursing. Individual topics to be announced in schedule by title.

name: Independent Study
description: Number of credits to be contracted with instructor at the beginning of the course. Contract approved by instructor, advisor and department head is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in NURS 314 for Generic BSN students; C or better in NURS 250 for RN-BSN students.
name: Evidence-based Nursing Practice
description: Introduction to the language and process of research and the use of best practices to guide nursing practice.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: NURS 323 or equivalent.
name: Critical Care Nursing of Adults
description: Introduction to nursing of the critically ill adult. Application in selected clinical settings.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in NURS 311, NURS 312, NURS 313, NURS 314, NURS 324, NURS 412, NURS 424, and NURS 425.
Corequisite: NURS 422 and NURS 431.
name: Psychiatric/Mental Health Nursing
description: Nursing care of clients experiencing psychiatric/mental health problems, with focus on promotion, restoration, and support. Practicum required.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in NURS 311, NURS 312, NURS 313, NURS 314, and NURS 324.
Corequisite: NURS 400, NURS 424, and NURS 425.
name: Acute Care Nursing of Adults I
description: Nursing care of acutely ill adults in a variety of settings. Practicum required.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: NURS 250.
name: Emerging Issues in Health Care
description: Examination of emerging health-related issues and their relevance to professional nursing practice.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in NURS 311, NURS 312, NURS 313, NURS 314, NURS 324, NURS 412, NURS 424, and NURS 425 .
Corequisite: NURS 411 and NURS 431.
name: Acute Care Nursing of Adults II
description: Nursing care of acutely ill adults in a variety of settings. Practicum required.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in NURS 311, NURS 312, NURS 313, NURS 314, and NURS 324.
Corequisite: NURS 400, NURS 412, NURS 425.
name: Maternal/Newborn Nursing
description: Nursing care of childbearing women and their neonates and families. Focus on uncomplicated pregnancy and birthing processes. Practicum required.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in NURS 311, NURS 312, NURS 313, NURS 314, and NURS 324.
Corequisite: NURS 400, NURS 412, NURS 424.
name: Nursing of Children and Families
description: Nursing care of families throughout their childrearing years, focusing on health promotion, restoration, and support of their children. Practicum required.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in NURS 250 for RN-BSN students; C or better in NURS 400, NURS 412, NURS 424, NURS 425, NURS 411, NURS 422, and NURS 431 for Generic BSN students .
Corequisite: NURS 435 for Generic BSN students only.
name: Nursing Leadership and Management
description: Concepts and principles of leadership, management, policy, and politics in delivering patient care within health care systems and the implications related to nursing practice. Relationships between policies and politics in the health field and the impact on patient care and access to healthcare.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: Generic BSN Students: C or better for NURS 313, NURS 412, NURS 424, and NURS 425; RN-BSN Students: C or better in NURS 250.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: Generic BSN Students: C or better in NURS 411 and NURS 422.
name: Population Health Nursing
description: Concepts and principles of aggregate and community health.

name: Community-Based Clinical Practicum for RNs
description: Community-based application and synthesis of professional nursing roles and responsibilities with selected populations determined to be at risk for a variety of health-related problems.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in NURS 400, NURS 412, NURS 424, NURS 425, NURS 411, NURS 422, and NURS 431 for Generic BSN students.
Corequisite: NURS 428.
name: Senior Nursing Capstone Practicum
description: Clinical experiences in managing patient care and leading the healthcare team in a variety of agencies. Practicum required.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Corequisite: NURS 708.
name: Community and Environmental Assessment
description: Comprehensive assessment and analysis of a community and its environment within the framework of community health nursing. Practicum only.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Emergency Preparedness: Implications for Health Care Professionals
description: Principles of emergency preparedness with implications for health care at the local, regional, national, and global levels.

name: Caring for Limited English Proficient Patients
description: Principles and policies for clinical practice with Limited English Proficient patients.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: NURS 312.
name: Special Topics in International Nursing
description: Experiential field study to examine international nursing in another country. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of courses by title. May be repeated for credit.

name: The Rural Interdisciplinary Practicum
description: Students live and practice in a rural, interdisciplinary environment and participate in an organized community-based health care activity. Contract approved by instructor and department chair is required for undergraduate students.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Issues in Women's Health
description: An exploration of women�€�s health and health care concerns from multiple perspectives.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: In-Service Education
description: Organizing, developing, implementing, and evaluating the in-service education program.

name: Special Topics
description: Topics vary by title, consent of instructor.

name: Nursing Concepts, Communication, and Calculations
description: This course introduces concepts essential to basic nursing practice. Nursing's historical evolution as a profession through theory, concept and role development will be presented. An overview of medical terminology and medical calculations is provided as skills that promote patient safety within the health disciplines. Written communication skills for the professional nurse will be presented. Students will be introduced to the difference between scholarly and non-scholarly sources.

name: Foundations of Composition
description: A course in writing skills with practice in composing essays, including intensive review of grammar, punctuation, and mechanics.

name: Contemporary College Mathematics
description: Linear and quadratic equations and models, functions, exponential models, logarithms, systems of equations, fundamentals of probability and statistics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PCAM 106 students must pass the math placement test (MPT) with a minimum score of MB1 or MA2.
name: Foundations of College Algebra
description: Operations on real numbers, linear equations and inequalities, quadratic equations, factoring, absolute value equations, exponential and radical expressions, graphs, and functions. Additional topics may include math study skills, logarithms, exponential functions, probability, statistics, systems of equations, polynomial division, and mathematical modeling.

name: Introduction to Computer Keyboarding
description: Keyboarding using the touch method, inputting, editing, and printing. Designed for students without keyboarding skills. Elective credit only. This course might not apply toward associate�€�s degrees or Columbia baccalaureate degrees.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: CSCE 101.
name: Introduction to Internet Research
description: Developing the means by which students may learn to access the Internet through mainframe and PC connections to accomplish specific research needs. This course might not apply toward associate degrees or Columbia baccalaureate degrees.

name: Foundations of Leadership
description: This course combines leadership theory with practical application, equipping students with the knowledge and skills needed to work more effectively with people, become better leaders, and reach their professional goals.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and academic dean is required for undergraduate studies. May be taken for elective credit only. May be repeated for up to 6 credits hours.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PALM 493 and PALM 494 or PALM 495.
name: Palmetto Senior Capstone Experience
description: Integration of interdisciplinary program of study and general education; intensive writing and research project.

name: South Carolina Studies
description: Reading and writing about South Carolina from the perspective of multiple disciplines, incorporating elements of the student�€�s major and cognate.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PALM 493.
name: Internship
description: Supervised immersion and exploration in a field related to the major, with a career, cultural, or community focus.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PALM 493.
name: Service-Learning
description: An exploration of theories of service-learning with application of practical solutions to meet community needs.

name: Introduction to Pharmacy in the United States
description: This course will provide students with a comprehensive introduction to the profession of pharmacy. It will explore the history of pharmacy and its evolving scope of practice; examine educational and career pathways; and allow students to gain insights into the regulatory and ethical considerations of pharmacy practice and more.

name: Problems in Pharmacy I
description: Conferences, assignments, and laboratory. Elective course. Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department head is required for undergraduate students.

name: Special Topics in Philosophy
description: Topics selected by the instructor for specialized study. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

name: Introduction to Philosophy
description: An introduction to the main problems of philosophy and its methods of inquiry, analysis, and criticism. Works of important philosophers will be read. Honors section offered.

name: Special Topics in Ethics and Values
description: A study of the moral principles of conduct and the basic concepts underlying these principles, such as good, evil, right, wrong, justice, value, duty, and obligation, as they relate to specific issues or areas of life. May be repeated as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: At least one of the following: PSYC 227; SOCY 220; STAT 110, STAT 112, STAT 201, STAT 205, or STAT 206; MGSC 291.
name: Introduction to Logic II
description: Philosophical foundations of inductive inference, including probability, statistics, and decision theory; application of the methods and results of inductive inference to philosophical problems such as the problem of rationality, epistemology, theory confirmation, social and political philosophy.

name: Introduction to Formal Logic I
description: Formal logic, including foundational logical concepts, syntax and semantics of first-order logic; derivations; applications.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in PHIL 114 or PHIL 110, or a department-approved equivalent.
name: Introduction to Formal Logic II
description: Intermediate topics in predicate logic, including second-order predicate logic; meta-theory, including soundness and completeness; introduction to non-classical logic

name: Philosophical Themes in Literature
description: Selected philosophical problems as they are presented in imaginative and theoretical literature. Works of fiction and philosophical treatments of issues involved in them will be read and discussed.

name: Contemporary Moral Issues
description: Moral issues confronting men and women in contemporary society. Topics will vary but may include discussion of problems related to abortion, drugs, euthanasia, war, social engineering, and punishment of criminals.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Images of the Human Person
description: Images of the human person in contemporary philosophy, literature, psychology, and religion, and an evaluation of these images as norms for human conduct and social policy. Particular attention may be given to images found in specific philosophical traditions, including existentialism, Marxism, behaviorism, and mysticism.

name: Communicating Moral Issues
description: Moral issues confronting men and women in contemporary society and the challenges of communicating effectively about them. Topics will vary but may include access to health care, euthanasia, abortion, same sex marriage and the moral and environmental consequences of eating animals.

name: Science and Pseudo-Science
description: Attempts to distinguish science from pseudo-science; inquiry into such cases as astrology, psychoanalysis, and parapsychology.

name: Ancient Philosophy
description: An introduction to the work of ancient philosophers, with special emphasis on Plato and Aristotle.

name: Greek and Roman Philosophy after Aristotle
description: Problems such as hedonism, providence, belief and evidence, and mysticism, as they appear in the writings of Epicureans, Stoics, Skeptics, and Plotinus.

name: History of Medieval Philosophy
description: Major philosophical traditions in the Middle Ages.

name: Seventeenth and Eighteenth-Century Philosophy
description: An introduction to Continental and British philosophy running roughly from Descartes through Kant.

name: Nineteenth and Twentieth-Century Philosophy
description: An introduction to Continental and British philosophy since Kant through study of the works of representative philosophers. Particular emphasis is placed on the development of Idealism, Marxism, Existentialism and Phenomenology, and analytic philosophy.

name: American Philosophy
description: The principal movements of philosophical thought from Colonial times to the present, with special emphasis on the 19th and 20th centuries.

name: Existentialism
description: An introduction to existentialist themes in contemporary philosophy, literature, psychology, and religion. The writings of existentialists such as Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Camus, Sartre, Buber, May, and Binswanger will be read and discussed.

name: Classical Origins of Western Medical Ethics
description: Examination of ancient Greek and Roman philosophical, medical, and literary works (in English) as sources for the origins of medical ethics. Priority enrollment for Medical Humanities students.

name: Between Magic and Method: Ancient Medicine
description: Introduction to ancient medicine: science and art, theory and practice, healing and predicting. Topics include Medicine before Hippocrates, Hippocratic medicine, holism, naturalism, medicine, religion and magic, medicine and scientific explanation, Hellenistic medicine and methodology, Galenic medicine.

name: Asian Religious Philosophy
description: A historical overview and critical introduction to the philosophical practices of Asian religions; an examination of the basic worldviews, thought frameworks, and foundational questions of the main schools of premodern Asian religious philosophy.

name: Ethics
description: A study of the moral principles of conduct and the basic concepts underlying these principles, such as good, evil, right, wrong, justice, value, duty, and obligation. The ethical works of influential philosophers are analyzed in terms of these concepts.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Medical Ethics
description: The concepts of Person and Justice as they relate to biomedical sciences and technologies.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Environmental Ethics
description: Examination of principles and arguments surrounding moral issues involving the environment.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Ethics of Science and Technology
description: Role of ethical judgments in directing or curtailing scientific research; case studies from natural and social sciences.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Business Ethics
description: Ethical problems in business; application to business situations of philosophical theories of individual, corporate, and governmental rights and responsibilities.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Engineering Ethics
description: An investigation of ethical issues in engineering and engineering-related technology. Topics include whistleblowing, employee/employer relations, environmental issues, issues related to advances in information technology, and privacy.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Law and Religion
description: An examination and critical assessment of the philosophical concepts, issues, and questions surrounding the relationship of church and state.

name: Social and Political Philosophy
description: An overview of major themes in political philosophy such as the nature of politics, obligation, community, representation, freedom, equality, and justice.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Crime and Justice
description: The fundamental concepts of a criminal justice system and their philosophical bases. Rights, privacy, responsibility, and the problem of justification of state control of private behavior through punishment and therapy.

name: Philosophy of Education
description: A critical examination of the theories of education of such philosophers as Plato, Rousseau, Dewey, Newman, and Whitehead. Emphasis is on the development of a philosophy of higher education.

name: Contemporary Marxism and Society
description: Recent Marxist-inspired critics of politics, science, technology, art, advertising, and other aspects of cultural life, with comparison both to Marx�€�s philosophical and economic writings and to other types of contemporary criticisms.

name: Feminist Philosophy
description: Introduces feminist philosophy and applications to philosophical problems.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Philosophy of Art
description: Philosophical problems relating to the arts, the nature of artworks, artistic meaning, aesthetic experience, and artistic values.

name: Philosophy and Film
description: Selected philosophical problems as they are presented in feature and documentary films.

name: Knowledge and Reality
description: Examination of skeptical attacks, critical defenses, and philosophical theories of what we know and what is to be taken as ultimate reality.

name: Mind and Nature
description: Philosophical theories about the nature of consciousness, the problem of qualia, phenomenal concepts, the explanatory gap hypothesis, higher-order consciousness, prospects for naturalistic accounts of consciousness.

name: Feedom and Human Action
description: The principal movements of philosophical thought from Colonial times to the present, with special emphasis on the 19th and 20th centuries.

name: History and Philosophy of Science
description: Philosophy and history of science and their interaction from ancient Greece to the present. Emphasis on physics, astronomy, and chemistry.

name: Philosophy of Research Design in Science and Medicine
description: A philosophical investigation of research methods used in science and medicine from systematic reviewing and randomized controlled trials to theories of sampling and causal inference.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in any course that satisfies the ARP Carolina Core requirement.
name: Formal Theories of Rationality and Their Philosophical Implications
description: Formal theories of rationality in the context of decision-making and games; uses of these formal theories to address traditional philosophical issues such as rationality, knowledge, choice, social welfare, cooperation, and communication.

name: Special Topics in Philosophy
description: Topics selected by the instructor for specialized study. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

name: Junior Seminar in Philosophy
description: Overview of philosophical theories and debates with attention to skills in discussion and presentation and in preparing and writing a research paper in philosophy. Topics selected by the instructor.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Senior Seminar in Philosophy
description: Review of central topics in philosophy serving as a capstone course for senior majors in philosophy.

name: Senior Thesis
description: Directed research resulting in a written thesis. Senior philosophy major or double major, GPA of 3.30, permission of faculty member.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 304.
name: British Empiricism
description: A historical and critical survey of the British philosophers of experience. Principal concentration is on Locke, Berkeley, and Hume.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 304.
name: Continental Rationalism
description: A critical and historical study of the 17th-century European philosophers. The works of Descartes, Spinoza, and Leibniz are emphasized.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better on 3 hours in philosophy beyond the 100 level.
name: Analytic Philosophy
description: A critical study of recent and contemporary works in philosophical analysis, and an evaluation of the purposes, methods, and results of this movement.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 304 or PHIL 305.
name: Phenomenology and Existentialism
description: A critical study of some fundamental themes in phenomenology and the philosophy of existence. Emphasis is placed on an intensive study of selected works of such writers as Kierkegaard, Jaspers, Husserl, and Heidegger.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 301.
name: Plato
description: An intensive study of selected Dialogues by Plato.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 301.
name: Aristotle
description: An intensive study of some of the more important of Aristotle's works.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 303.
name: Medieval Philosophy
description: A historical and critical study of the works of the leading medieval philosophers.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 304.
name: Hume
description: An intensive study of the philosophical writings of Hume, especially A Treatise of Human Nature.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 304.
name: Kant
description: An intensive study of the work of Kant, especially the Critique of Pure Reason.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in 3 hours in philosophy beyond the 100 level.
name: Theory of Knowledge
description: An examination of some representative theories of truth, meaning, probability, and perception.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 115.
name: Symbolic Logic
description: A presentation and philosophical examination of the fundamentals of modern symbolic logic.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in 3 hours in philosophy beyond the 100 level.
name: Philosophy of Science
description: A critical examination of methods and concepts of the sciences. Topics include scientific revolutions, the unity of science, experimentation, explanation, and evidence.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in 3 hours in philosophy beyond the 100 level.
name: Philosophy of History
description: A philosophical examination of historical inquiry. Theories of historical development. The logical problems of historical explanation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 320.
name: Ethical Theory
description: Survey of recent and historical developments in ethical theory with special emphasis on the meaning of ethical language and the forms of reasoning employed in discussing moral values.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in 3 hours in philosophy beyond the 100 level.
name: Philosophy of Religion
description: A critical study of selected problems in the philosophy of religion. Emphasis is placed on problems relating to the existence of God, religious knowledge, and the language of religion.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in 3 hours in philosophy beyond the 100 level.
name: Advanced Aesthetics
description: Detailed examination of the literature on aesthetics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in PHIL 114 or PHIL 511.
name: Philosophy of Language
description: An examination of concepts and problems such as meaning, reference, analyticity, definition, and the relation between logic and philosophy.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in 3 hours in philosophy beyond the 100 level.
name: Philosophy of the Social Sciences
description: The goals of inquiry and problems such as objectivity, reduction, value freedom, and ideology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 350 or PHIL 351 or PHIL 360.
name: Metaphysics
description: Major issues in classical and modern metaphysics. Topics include the idea of first philosophy, being, substance, the problem of universals, essentialism, causation, time and space, and metaphysical method.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 350 or PHIL 351 or PHIL 360.
name: Philosophy of Mind
description: The concept of mind, the mind-body problem, emotions and cognition, the possibility of artificial minds, theories of embodied cognition.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 511.
name: Mathematical Logic
description: Axiomatic development of logic and the set-theoretic foundations of mathematics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in any of LING 300, LING 301, LING 600, PHIL 114, PHIL 511.
name: Introduction to Semantics and Pragmatics
description: Introduction to the study of linguistic meaning, including the following topics: meaning, reference, and truth; the connections among language, thought, and reality; word meaning and sentence meaning; possible worlds and modality; thematic roles; meaning and context; presupposition and implicature; speech acts; formal semantics; and cognitive semantics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 511.
name: Advanced Topics in Logic
description: Philosophical problems about logic, the development of philosophical logics, and the problems surrounding them.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in 3 hours of Philosophy beyond the 100 level.
name: Philosophy of Biology
description: Examination of major conceptual, theoretical, and methodological issues in biological science. Topics include reductionism, units of selection, adaptationism, relations between evolutionary and developmental biology and between biology and society.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 301 or PHIL 302.
name: Hellenistic Philosophy
description: Survey of the major schools and trends in Hellenistic philosophy: Epicureans, Stoics, Academic Skeptics. Topics include eudaimonism, hedonism, monism, teleology, and the criterion of truth.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 320.
name: Virtues, Acts, and Consequences
description: Recent contributions to three central strands of ethical theory: virtue theory, deontology, and utilitarianism; historical roots and recent developments.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 350 or PHIL 351 or PHIL 360.
name: Concepts of Evidence
description: Systematic approaches to data analysis--Bayesian, Fisherian and decision theoretic--will be critically appraised. Applications of these theories to some problems of inductive logic: the paradoxes of confirmation, the role of simplicity, and the probability of inductive generalizations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 320 or PHIL 321 or PHIL 322 or PHIL 330 or PHIL 331.
name: Social Justice
description: Recent theories of distributive justice and their application to such issues as redistribution of wealth, reverse discrimination, and the conflict between liberty and equality. Authors include Rawls, Nozick, Hayek, and Popper.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in 3 hours in philosophy beyond the 100 level.
name: Contemporary European Social Philosophy
description: An examination of European social philosophy associated with either the Frankfurt School of Social Research or contemporary French Poststructuralism.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 3 hours in philosophy beyond the 100 level.
name: Ecofeminism
description: An exploration of the connections between oppression of women and oppression of nature.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 114.
name: Language and Interpretation in Contemporary European Philosophy
description: Selected contemporary European philosophical movements, their views on language, and their approach to interpretation: hermeneutics, structuralism, poststructuralism.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 301 or PHIL 302 or PHIL 303.
name: Renaissance Philosophy
description: Humanism (e.g., Petrarca), Platonism (e.g., Pico and Ficino), Aristotelianism (e.g., Pomponazzi), philosophies of nature (e.g., Telesio, Campanella, and Bruno), and Nicholas of Cusa, Erasmus, Montaigne, and Suarez.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHIL 320 or PHIL 321 or PHIL 322 or PHIL 330 or PHIL 331.
name: Health Care Ethics
description: An exploration of the ethical dimensions of patient care in the clinical setting.

name: Readings in Philosophy
description: Prerequisite: 6 hours in philosophy beyond the 100 level.

name: Contemporary Physical Activity
description: Development of skills in an identified area. Course content will vary and be announced by title. May be repeated as topics vary.

name: Self-Defense For Women
description: Basic knowledge and understanding of the culture and context in which interpersonal violence occurs, the root causes and patterns of behavior within violent relationships, self defense against forcible attacks, making immediate decisions when confronted with an assault, and the procedures necessary after an assault has occurred.

name: Contemporary Physical Activity
description: Course contact will vary and be announced by title. May be repeated as topics vary.

name: Jogging
description: Exercise, lectures, and self-evaluation for weight control and fitness improvement.

name: Personal Fitness and Weight Control
description: Advanced techniques for controlling weight and improving fitness through exercise, lectures, and self-evaluation.

name: Weight Training
description: Fundamentals of progressive resistance exercise training.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PEDU 105.
name: Advanced Weight Training
description: Advanced techniques.

name: Group Exercise
description: Cardio-respiratory fitness, flexibility, muscular strength and endurance, and agility through various group exercise formats while utilizing a variety of equipment.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PEDU 140.
name: Fitness Swimming
description: Individualized physical conditioning through lap swimming and aquatic calisthenics, games, and activities.

name: ROTC Conditioning
description: Exercise testing, technique, and leadership, program design and implementation, nutrition, individual and team competitions, and other forms of training.

name: Orientation to Physical Education
description: Experiences in a variety of physical-activity areas.

name: Badminton
description: Basic strokes and introduction to the history, rules, and strategy of the game.

name: Basketball
description: Fundamental skills of game performance. Strategy, rules, and basic offenses and defenses.

name: Bowling
description: Fundamental skills and techniques of bowling.

name: Golf
description: Basic strokes, rules, and strategy of golf.

name: Gymnastics
description: Fundamentals of gymnastics on the trampoline and balance beam; tumbling, parallel bars, rings, and the horse.

name: Handball
description: Fundamentals, strategy, and rules of handball.

name: Karate
description: Fundamentals.

name: Rugby
description: Fundamental skills for game performance.

name: Soccer
description: Fundamental skills for game performance; history, rules, and game strategy.

name: Softball
description: Fundamental skills for game performance; history, rules, and game strategy.

name: Beginning Tennis
description: Basic strokes, history, rules, and strategy of the game.

name: Volleyball
description: Recreational and competitive volleyball skills.

name: Pilates
description: Focus is placed on mind-body exercises which help strengthen and condition the muscles. Each exercise will focus on building core strength, lengthening muscles, and improving flexibility. Proper breathing will also be demonstrated for each exercise in order to achieve the maximum benefits.

name: Fencing
description: Basic foil-fencing techniques, rules, terminology, history, and etiquette.

name: Intermediate Karate
description: Prerequisites: PEDU 117.

name: Badminton/Golf
description: Students will learn to perform basic skills as well as to implement game strategies. Major consideration will be given on how to teach each sport.

name: Field Hockey
description: Fundamental skills, rules, and terminology of field hockey.

name: Football
description: Fundamental skills, rules, and terminology.

name: Racquetball
description: Fundamental skills, rules, and terminology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PEDU 114.
name: Intermediate Golf
description: Intermediate strokes and strategies; heavier emphasis on the total golf swing.

name: Basketball/Soccer
description: Students will learn to perform basic skills as well as to implement game strategies. Major consideration will be given on how to teach each sport.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PEDU 121.
name: Intermediate Tennis
description: Intermediate skills and strategies.

name: Track and Field
description: Fundamental skills, rules, and terminology.

name: Flying Disc Sports
description: Fundamentals and strategies of disc golf, ultimate and various physical activities using flying discs in recreational and competitive situations.

name: Tai-Chi-Chuan
description: Students will learn to perform basic Tai-Chi-Chuan skills. Major consideration will be given to breathing skills and meditation to relieve stress.

name: Yoga
description: Fundamental skills and terminology.

name: Tae Kwon Do
description: Fundamental skills of Tae Kwon Do.

name: Softball/Volleyball
description: Students will learn to perform basic skills as well as to implement game strategies. Major consideration will be given on how to teach each sport.

name: Tennis/Track
description: Students will learn to perform basic skills as well as to implement game strategies. Major consideration will be given on how to teach each sport.

name: Beginning Swimming
description: Skills for safety and recreation.

name: Intermediate Swimming
description: Prerequisites: PEDU 140.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: swim 500 yards, tread water for one minute, and swim 20 feet underwater.
name: Lifeguard Training
description: Skills of lifesaving.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 17 years of age; sound physical condition; possession of the Red Cross Advanced Lifesaving Certificate, a Red Cross Swimmer Certificate, or the ability to perform the Swimmer Course.
name: Water Safety Instructor Certification
description: Skills, methods, and techniques to teach Red Cross Swimming and Life Saving.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: tread water and swim 20 feet underwater.
name: Beginning Springboard Diving
description: Basic dives and aesthetics of springboard diving.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ability to swim at the intermediate level.
name: Skin and Scuba Diving
description: Safe and effective use of equipment with emphasis on principles and physical laws of diving.

name: Scuba (Open Water)
description: Certification program in open water scuba instruction: safety, emergency procedures, equipment handling, navigation, and air consumption. Includes five open water dives.

name: Beginning Stand-Up Paddleboarding
description: History and development of stand-up paddleboarding as a sport, safety protocol, paddleboard construction and design, terminology, fitness attributes and paddling techniques.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: intermediate swimming skills.
name: Team Water Sports
description: Fundamental skills, rules, and strategies for participation in team water sports.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: swim 100 yards, tread water for one minute, and swim 20 feet underwater.
name: Survival Swimming
description: Skills and techniques for survival under adverse conditions.

name: Basic Keelboat Sailing
description: The course is designed to teach students to safely skipper and crew on a 20 to 27 foot sailboat with a tiller and outboard engine on lakes, bays, and sheltered waters in moderate weather conditions. Theory, history, safety, and teamwork will be emphasized.

name: Beginning Skateboarding
description: History, rules, etiquette and techniques of skateboarding.

name: Power Yoga
description: Vigorous yoga utilizing breath and movement to improve strength and flexibility.
