name: Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation
description: Knowledge and skills in providing artificial respiration, first aid for foreign body obstruction, one and two rescuer CPR for adults, infants, and children.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PEDU 146.
name: Advanced Open Water Scuba
description: Development skills beyond open water diving: underwater navigation, night diving, and deep diving.

name: Personal Training Preparation
description: Safe and effective methods of exercise by the application of theories and principles of exercise science. Discussion of facility organization, legal liability, and injury prevention and treatment within the score of becoming a fitness professional.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PEDU 136.
name: Intermediate Yoga
description: This course is designed to provide the historical and philosophical context of Mindfulness and how it relates to classical yoga of Pantanjali. Students will be guided in deepening their mindfulness meditation practice that includes analysis of the Four Establishments of Mindfulness and will develop an advanced asana sequence as part of their practice.

name: Intermediate Fencing
description: Basic footwork and bladework for foil and épée along with more complex skills, concepts, terminology, strategy, and understanding of the rules.

name: Zumba Fitness
description: Principles of fitness interval training and resistance training applied to maximize caloric output, fat burning and total body toning with a fusion of Latin and International music-dance themes.

name: Geocaching
description: History, rules, terminology, and strategy of geocaching. Strategies for seeking as well as creating geocaches.

name: Beginning Latin Dance
description: Introductory course to multiple styles of social Latin dancing including Salsa, Merengue and Bachatta. Designed to develop the skills and techniques necessary for social level Latin dancing. Emphasis will be placed on basic social elements of dance, patterns, music, and leading and following.

name: Swing Dance
description: Introduction to swing dances originating from the first half of the 20th century such as the Charleston, East Coast Swing, Lindy Hop, Jitterbug, Jive, and The Big Apple.

name: Rock Climbing and Bouldering
description: Safe climbing and bouldering techniques. Movement on rock, rope systems, anchors, rappelling, belaying, risk management, spotting and lead climbing philosophy. Save use of equipment required for sport climbing and bouldering.

name: Folk and Square Dance
description: Fundamental skills and terminology.

name: Social Dance
description: Fundamental skills and terminology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PEDU 174.
name: Intermediate Social Dance
description: Development of skills to an intermediate level in six dances: fox trot, waltz, tango, swing, cha cha, rumba.

name: Clogging
description: History, folklore, and skills; individual steps and team routines.

name: Beginning Shag
description: Techniques and history of the Shag, South Carolina's state dance. Chronicled development, style variations, and cultural contributions are emphasized.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PEDU 177.
name: Intermediate Shag Dance
description: Introduction to more challenging shag moves for couples, based on steps, turns, spins, and passes. Emphasis on good shag form and rhythm, male lead, female follow, and tight couple positions going through step variations. Steps include Sugarfoot, Boogie Walk, Stagger, Walkup and others.

name: Beginning Belly Dance
description: Techniques, history, terminology, and dance combinations/choreography associated with Belly Dance at the fundamental level.

name: Archery
description: Fundamentals of target and field archery shooting, history, scoring, and rules.

name: Equestrian
description: Fundamentals of riding, grooming and tacking.

name: Backpacking
description: Living in the out-of-doors; gear selection, map and compass reading, backpacking, hiking, and camping.

name: Canoeing
description: Fundamentals of lake, river, and whitewater canoeing.

name: Snow Skiing
description: Fundamental skills and techniques.

name: Beginning Kayaking
description: Fundamentals of whitewater kayaking including equipment selection and use, safety techniques, strokes, Eskimo roll, river strategies, rescue procedures, and trip planning.

name: Bicycle Touring
description: Fundamental skills and techniques.

name: Rock Climbing
description: Fundamentals of rock and mountain climbing including gear selection and use, knots and rope management, anchoring systems, belaying, rappelling, climbing techniques, and safety considerations.

name: Triathlon Training
description: Intensive conditioning and cross training to achieve a high level cardiovascular fitness. Biking, running, and swimming in preparation for triathlon event.

name: Spinning
description: Spinning to obtain physiological and psychological benefits.

name: Introduction to the Description and Analysis of Human Movement
description: Analysis and performance of fundamental motor skills.

name: Educational Gymnastics
description: Development of knowledge and skill in educational gymnastics. Designed to establish a content base for elementary and middle school physical education programs.

name: Educational Games
description: Development of knowledge and skill in game activities appropriate for the elementary and middle school physical education game setting.

name: Educational Dance
description: Development of personal skills in the use of movement for expressive purposes. Designed to establish a content base for elementary school physical education programs.

name: Fit Carolina
description: Basic concepts associated with physical activity and the opportunities in community environments to engage in health-promoting and wellness activities.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PEDU 190.
name: Physical Education for Primary Grades
description: Selection and development of appropriate content for elementary school physical education experiences.

name: Philosophy and Principles of Physical Education
description: Historical background, current problems, and publications.

name: Athletic Training Lab
description: Techniques and skills used in the prevention or protection of injury.

name: Functional Musculoskeletal Anatomy
description: Knowledge and skill of orthopedic anatomy relative to muscle, ligament, and tendon origin, insertion, innervation, and action.

name: First Aid and CPR
description: Knowledge and skills necessary to meet the guidelines for professional certification. Skills include AED, adult, child, and infant CPR, breathing emergencies, and first aid.

name: Practicum in Physical Education Field Experiences
description: Supervised field experiences for physical educators. Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department head is required for undergraduate students.

name: Foundations of Coaching
description: The philosophical bases, leadership theory, administrative practice, and organizational problems of competitive athletics.

name: Scientific Bases of Coaching I
description: Anatomical, kinesiological, and biomechanical principles affecting performance in competitive athletics; use of biomechanical analysis techniques. Primarily for non-physical education majors who wish to coach.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PEDU 303.
name: Scientific Bases of Coaching II
description: Physiological, psychological, ethical, and sport medicine principles affecting performance in competitive athletics; application of scientific principles. Primarily for non-physical education majors who desire to coach.

name: Emergency Medical Responder
description: Knowledge and skills necessary to work as an emergency medical responder (EMR) to help sustain life, reduce pain and minimize the consequences of injury or sudden illness until more advanced medical help takes over. Appropriate decision making about the care to provide in a medical emergency; skills an EMR needs to act as a crucial link in the emergency medical services (EMS) system.

name: Coaching Gymnastics, Volleyball, and Softball
description: Prerequisites: PEDU 302 and PEDU 303.

name: Coaching Basketball, Track and Field, and Soccer
description: Prerequisite: PEDU 302 and PEDU 303.

name: Coaching Football, Baseball, and Wrestling
description: Prerequisites: PEDU 302 and PEDU 303.

name: Practicum in Coaching
description: Supervised practical experience in interscholastic coaching settings; concurrent seminar.

requisiteText: Corequisite: PEDU 360.
name: Practicum in the Instructional Aspects of Physical Education
description: Application of instructional principles to small peer group settings using open and closed gross motor skills.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: PEDU 340 and PEDU 360, cumulative GPA of 2.75, have met the state basic skills testing requirement for educator preparation program admission.
Corequisite: PEDU 361.
name: Practicum in Instruction of Young Learners in Movement Settings
description: Application of curriculum and instructional principles to small group instruction with young learners.

name: Recreational Sports Programming
description: Current program elements and techniques in recreational sports.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: PEDU 190, cumulative GPA of 2.50.
Corequisite: PEDU 340.
name: Instructional Aspects of Physical Education
description: Instruction in physical education settings, including environmental arrangements, task presentation, content development, and feedback.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: PEDU 340 and PEDU 360, cumulative GPA of 2.75, have met the state basic skills testing requirement for educator preparation program admission.
Corequisite: PEDU 341.
name: Instruction of Young Learners in Movement Settings
description: Development of knowledge and skills to teach physical education to young learners.

name: Seminar in Physical Education
description: Various topics related to current events in physical education.

name: Independent Study
description: Open to sophomores and above. Enrollment and topic to be approved in advance by advisor and instructor. Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department head is required.

name: Motor Learning in Physical Education
description: Application of cognitive, sensory, and motor processes related to learning motor skills in physical education and sport settings.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: PEDU 341.
Corequisite: PEDU 462.
name: Practicum in Secondary School Physical Education
description: The application of curriculum and instructional principles to large group instruction in the secondary school.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 15 credits in professional physical education, including PEDU 232 and 6 semester hours of professional skill courses.
name: Measurement & Evaluation in Physical Education
description: The historic background of measurement in physical education; statistical techniques to be used in scoring and interpreting tests; evaluation of measures now available in the field; and the administration of a testing program. Available for undergraduate credit only.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Cumulative GPA of 2.75, Admission to Directed Teaching Semester.
name: Physical Education Curriculum
description: The study of K-12 physical education school curriculum theory, issues, and design.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: PEDU 462, PEDU 440.
name: Teaching Physical Education
description: Analysis of teaching and learning in physical education.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: PEDU 341 and PEDU 361, cumulative GPA of 2.75, have met the state basic skills testing requirement for educator preparation program admission.
Corequisite: PEDU 440.
name: Instruction in Secondary School Physical Education
description: Physical education content and processes for the secondary school.

name: Directed Teaching in Physical Education
description: Prerequisites: Cumulative GPA of 2.75, Admission to Directed Teaching Semester.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 90 hrs. and permission of instructor.
name: Advanced Seminar in Physical Education
description: Advanced learning opportunities in professional physical education.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EXSC 223/EXSC 224 or BIOL 243/BIOL 244.
name: Teaching Health Related Physical Fitness
description: Knowledge and application of processes and principles of health related physical fitness in physical education and sport settings.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PEDU 340, PEDU 360.
name: Physical Education for Inclusion
description: Designing physical education programs for special populations and for students with special needs.

name: Observational Analysis of Sports Techniques and Tactics
description: Qualitative and quantitative techniques to observe, describe, analyze, and evaluate human movement in physical education and sports settings.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 18 credits in physical education, including six semester hours of professional skill courses.
name: The Organization and Administration of Physical Education
description: Organization of instructional, intramural, interscholastic, and recreational programs, with emphasis on criteria for the evaluation and selection of activities.

name: Human Child/Adolescent Growth
description: Human physical growth and development of children with emphasis on years 4 to 18.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDTE 201.
name: Physical Education for the Classroom Teacher
description: Appropriate movement experiences for children. Not available for physical education majors.

name: Dance Performance
description: Rehearsal, choreographic analysis, and dance performance. All components of dance production--including music, costume, lighting, and scenery--will be considered.

name: South Carolina Physical Education Curriculum
description: Development of physical education programs using the South Carolina Physical Education Curriculum Materials.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: current responsibilities or previous experience in college or high school coaching.
name: Advanced Theory and Techniques of Coaching Football
description: An intensive investigation of current theories of offensive and defensive football. Generalship, strategy, conditioning, staff utilization, film analysis, and practice organization are covered in depth.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: current responsibilities or previous experience in college or high school coaching.
name: Advanced Theory and Techniques of Coaching Basketball
description: An intensive investigation of the latest techniques and theories of coaching basketball. Systems of offense and defense, generalship, conditioning, staff utilization, film analysis, and practice organization are covered in depth.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: current responsibilities or previous experience in college or high-school coaching.
name: Advanced Theory and Techniques of Coaching Track and Field Events
description: A thorough study of the latest techniques of coaching track and field events. Isometric, isotonic, and interval conditioning theories involving the cardiovascular and muscular systems are examined to acquaint the student with varying physiological approaches to conditioning.

name: Advanced Theory and Techniques of Teaching and Officiating Girls' Gymnastics
description: A thorough study of the latest techniques of teaching and officiating girls' gymnastics. Balance beam, vaulting, uneven bars, tumbling, dance skills and routines, and officiating methods.

name: Theoretical Foundations of Athletic and Mental Performance Coaching
description: Theoretical foundations of athletic and mental performance across a variety of contexts and developmental levels.

name: Counseling Student Athletes
description: Issues facing student athletes regarding their personal and career development beyond athletics.

name: The Physics of How Things Work I
description: A practical introduction to physics and science in everyday life-from concrete examples to basic physical principles.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: PHYS 101.
name: The Physics of How Things Work I Lab
description: Experiments, exercises, and demonstrations to accompany PHYS 101.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 101.
name: The Physics of How Things Work II
description: A continuation of PHYS 101 with emphasis on electricity, magnetism, optics, and atomic physics.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: PHYS 102.
name: The Physics of How Things Work II Lab
description: Experiments, exercises, and demonstrations to accompany PHYS 102.

name: Physics in the Arts
description: The physics of sound, color, illumination; musical instruments and photographic processes. Credit may not be received for both PHYS 151 and PHYS 153 or both PHYS 151 and PHYS 155.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: PHYS 151.
name: Physics in the Arts Laboratory
description: Laboratory work on wave motion, including acoustic, optical, photographic, and electronic measurements. Credit may not be received for both PHYS 151L and PHYS 153L or both PHYS 151L and PHYS 155L.

name: Physics in the Visual Arts
description: Principals of optics: video, and photography, eye and vision, color, polarization, lasers, and holography. Credit may not be received for both PHYS 153 and PHYS 151.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: PHYS 153.
name: Physics in the Visual Arts Laboratory
description: Laboratory work in geometrical and wave optics. Credit may not be received for both PHYS 153L and PHYS 151L.

name: Musical Acoustics
description: The principles of musical and architectural acoustics, waves and vibrations, digital techniques for generating and recording sound, perception and measure of sound (psychoacoustics). Credit may not be received for both PHYS 155 and PHYS 151.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: PHYS 155.
name: Acoustics Laboratory
description: Laboratory work in musical and architectural acoustics. Credit may not be received for both PHYS 155L and PHYS 151L.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 115 or equivalent or higher.
name: Measurement and Analysis in Physics
description: Measurements in classical and modern physics are performed, and the analyzed results are compared with basic principles. Four hours of mixed lecture and laboratory per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 111, MATH 111I, MATH 112, MATH 115, MATH 116, MATH 122, MATH 141, or by placement score into MATH 122, MATH 141, or higher.
name: General Physics I
description: First part of an introductory course sequence. Topics include mechanics, and selections from wave motion, sound, fluids, and heat. No previous background in physics is assumed.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in PHYS 201.
name: General Physics Laboratory I
description: Experiments, exercises, and demonstrations to accompany PHYS 201.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 201.
name: General Physics II
description: Continuation of PHYS 201; includes electromagnetism, and selected topics from optics, relativity, quantum physics, atomic and nuclear physics.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in PHYS 202.
name: General Physics Laboratory II
description: Experiments, exercises, and demonstrations to accompany PHYS 202.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 141.
Corequisite: PHYS 211L.
name: Essentials of Physics I
description: Classical mechanics and wave motion. Calculus-level course for students of science and engineering.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in PHYS 211.
name: Essentials of Physics I Lab
description: Experiments, exercises, and demonstrations to accompany PHYS 211.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 211 and MATH 142.
Corequisite: PHYS 212L.
name: Essentials of Physics II
description: Classical electromagnetism and optics.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in PHYS 212.
name: Essentials of Physics II Lab
description: Experiments, exercises, and demonstrations to accompany PHYS 212.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: B or better in MATH 115 or equivalent.
name: Einstein�€�s Relativity: Understanding by Example
description: Special theory of relativity. Algebra-based course for students of all majors.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 212 and MATH 142.
Corequisite: MATH 241.
name: Principles of Physics III
description: Wave motion, optics, and thermodynamics. Calculus-level treatment; a continuation of PHYS 212.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 212 and MATH 241.
name: Introduction to Modern Physics
description: Experimental foundations and general concepts of quantum theory and special relativity; with selected applications from atomic, condensed matter, and nuclear physics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 212 and STAT 509 or STAT 515.
name: Intermediate Experimental Physics
description: Descriptive statistics, scientific ethics, and design, construction, and reporting the results of experiments.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: MATH 141.
Corequisite: MATH 142.
name: Introduction to Applied Numerical Methods
description: Introduction and application of linear algebra and numerical methods to the solution of physical and engineering problems. Techniques include iterative solution techniques, methods of solving systems of equations, and numerical integration and differentiation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ASTR 211 and MATH 115 and PHYS 202 or PHYS 212.
name: Introduction to Relativistic Astrophysics
description: Final states of stellar evolution; white dwarfs, neutron stars, black holes. Cosmology.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Senior Thesis
description: An individual investigation in the library or laboratory or both under supervision of the major professor. The preparation of a scientific report is an integral part of the work.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 310.
name: Undergraduate Research
description: Introduction to and application of the methods of research. A written report on work accomplished is required at the end of each semester.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 307 and MATH 242 or MATH 520.
name: Quantum Physics I
description: A self-contained treatment of quantum theory and its applications, beginning with the Schrodinger equation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 501.
name: Quantum Physics II
description: Advanced topics in quantum physics, plus topics in special relativity, high-energy physics, and cosmology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 306 or PHYS 307 and MATH 242 or MATH 520.
name: Mechanics
description: Classical mechanics of particles, systems, and rigid bodies; discussion and application of Lagrange's equations, introduction to Hamiltonian formulation of mechanics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 503.
name: Electromagnetic Theory
description: Field theory of electric and magnetic phenomena; Maxwell's equations applied to problems in electromagnetism and radiation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 306, PHYS 307, MATH 241 and MATH 242 or MATH 520.
name: Thermal Physics and Statistical Mechanics
description: Principles of equilibrium thermodynamics, kinetic theory, and introductory statistical mechanics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 501.
name: Nuclear Physics
description: An elementary treatment of nuclear structure, radioactivity, and nuclear reactions. Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 242 or MATH 520.
name: Mathematical Physics I
description: Analytical function theory including complex analysis, theory of residues, and saddlepoint method; Hilbert space, Fourier series; elements of distribution theory; vector and tensor analysis with tensor notation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 515.
name: Mathematical Physics II
description: Group theory, linear second-order differential equations and the properties of the transcendental functions; orthogonal expansions; integral equations; Fourier transformations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 212 and MATH 142.
name: Computational Physics
description: Application of numerical methods to a wide variety of problems in modern physics including classical mechanics and chaos theory, Monte Carlo simulation of random processes, quantum mechanics and electrodynamics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 310.
name: Advanced Experimental Physics I
description: Continuation of PHYS 310. Optical apparatus (telescope, microscope, interferometer) and advanced project planning including equipment design and budgeting.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 541.
name: Advanced Experimental Physics II
description: Continuation of PHYS 541. Study of topics from advanced optics, astronomy, biophysics, digital electronics, nuclear/particle physics, or solid state physics, plus conduction of a physics experiment, including a written paper and an oral presentation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PHYS 307.
name: Introduction to Astrophysics
description: An astrophysics course for physics students. Covers the basics of observational techniques, structure and evolution of stars, interstellar medium and star formation, structure and properties of the Milky Way and nearby galaxies, and generation and transfer of radiation in astrophysical environments.

name: Topics in Physics
description: Readings and research on selected topics in physics. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

name: Introduction to Global Politics
description: Introduction to theories about global politics. Issues and controversies central to global politics.

name: Controversies in the Politics of Global Regions: Africa
description: Social, cultural, and historical forces underlying contemporary political controversies in Africa POLI 103A, Asia POLI 103B, Europe POLI 103C, Latin America POLI 103D, and the Middle East POLI 103E; region will be identified by title.

name: Controversies in the Politics of Global Regions: Asia
description: Social, cultural, and historical forces underlying contemporary political controversies in Africa POLI 103A, Asia POLI 103B, Europe POLI 103C, Latin America POLI 103D, and the Middle East POLI 103E; region will be identified by title.

name: Controversies in the Politics of Global Regions: Europe
description: Social, cultural, and historical forces underlying contemporary political controversies in Africa POLI 103A, Asia POLI 103B, Europe POLI 103C, Latin America POLI 103D, and the Middle East POLI 103E; region will be identified by title.

name: Controversies in the Politics of Global Regions: Latin America
description: Social, cultural, and historical forces underlying contemporary political controversies in Africa POLI 103A, Asia POLI 103B, Europe POLI 103C, Latin America POLI 103D, and the Middle East POLI 103E; region will be identified by title.

name: Controversies in the Politics of Global Regions: Middle East
description: Social, cultural, and historical forces underlying contemporary political controversies in Africa POLI 103A, Asia POLI 103B, Europe POLI 103C, Latin America POLI 103D, and the Middle East POLI 103E; region will be identified by title.

name: Introduction to Politics
description: Concepts and problems involved in human relationship with governments, the nation-state, and political change.

name: Controversies in Political Theory
description: An introduction to the analysis of disputes about the nature of politics and of political ideas such as freedom, equality, and justice.

name: Controversies in Public Policy
description: An introduction to the analysis of contentious public policy questions in contemporary American society, such as welfare, gun control, health care financing, immigration, affirmative action, and/or abortion.

name: Controversies in American Politics
description: An introduction to the analysis of key issues in contemporary American politics focusing on the arguments, the groups involved, and the political factors that influence the outcome of the debate.

name: Green Explorations
description: Interdisciplinary seminar combining the intellectual exploration of ecological perspectives with the physical exploration of the local environment. First-year students only.

name: Green Engagements
description: Interdisciplinary seminar on designing, researching, and implementing collaborative projects to promote ecological sustainability. First-year students only.

name: American National Government
description: The formation and development of the national government, its organization and powers. Overlay Course.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: POLI 201.
name: Policies and Functions of American Government
description: The policies and functions of the American national government directed to the public issues and problems of contemporary America.

name: Introduction to Leadership Studies
description: Conceptions and models, values and pitfalls, strategies and skills of leadership and of leaders in diverse contexts
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Language Conflict and Language Rights
description: Examination of linguistic conflict and rights, as well as centrality of language rights to human rights and personal/cultural identity. Basic facts about language related to identity, culture, attitudes, dialects, bilingualism. Case studies (local, national, international) with particular attention to nationalism, language revitalization, language planning.

name: Social and Political Philosophy
description: An overview of major themes in political philosophy such as the nature of politics, obligation, community, representation, freedom, equality, and justice.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: The Political Science Discipline
description: The history and development of approaches, methods, and fields of study in political science.

name: Classical and Medieval Political Theory
description: Political theories from the Greeks to the Renaissance.

name: Modern Political Theory
description: Political theories from the Renaissance to the 19th century.

name: Contemporary Political Theory
description: Nineteenth and 20th century political theories.

name: Race, Class, Gender, and Sexuality
description: Historical and contemporary power relationships in race, social class, gender, and sexual orientation.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Feminist Theory
description: Historical development of feminist theory and contemporary debates within feminism.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: International Relations
description: International political behavior and institutions.

name: Comparative Politics
description: Comparative approaches to political systems, behavior, and institutions.

name: International Organization
description: An introduction to the structure and functions of international political and economic organizations. Particular attention to the United Nations and its specialized agencies, and to emerging regional communities.

name: The Conduct and Formulation of United States Foreign Policy
description: An analysis of how contemporary United States foreign policy is made and conducted.

name: Contemporary United States Foreign Policy
description: A critical analysis of selected problems of United States foreign policy.

name: National Security Policies of the United States
description: Formulation and implementation of contemporary United States defense and security policies.

name: Public Opinion and Politics
description: A broad survey of the role and development of public attitudes toward political problems in a democracy. Emphasis on the origins, manifestations, and consequences of public opinion in American politics.

name: Gender and Politics
description: Impact of gender on the distribution of power in society; foundations for intersections of gender, race, social class, and sexuality and their economic, social, and political concomitants.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Introduction to U.S. Racial and Ethnic Politics
description: Survey of theories of the impact of race, ethnicity, and racism on American politics, and analysis of major policies and racial group experience regarding American citizenship.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Film, Politics, and Social Change
description: Critical analysis of film as expression and agent of political cultural, ideology, and change.

name: American Political Parties
description: A broad survey of the role of political parties in the American political system. Following an examination of the historical evolution of party systems in the United States, primary attention is given to three aspects of contemporary political parties: the party as an organization, the party as an electorate, and the party as a governing elite.

name: Elections and Voting Behavior
description: An analysis of elections and the voting process. Topics include candidate selection, campaigning, and the conduct of elections as well as public opinion, voting behavior, and the role of elections in the democratic political system.

name: Politics and the Mass Media
description: Survey of the role in American politics of mass communications media, including the press and electronic news reporting; influence of mass media on the conduct of political campaigns, political leadership style, and public opinion.

name: Southern Politics
description: Selected political patterns and trends within the 11 states of the American South. Historical developments with the central focus on Southern politics since 1950.

name: African-American Politics
description: African-American politics from the colonial period to the present. Emphasis on voting rights and strategies to advance black representation.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: State Government
description: A study of state-federal relations, relations among states, state constitutions, and the structure and functions of the three branches of government. Emphasis is given to South Carolina.

name: Interest Groups and Social Movements
description: The mobilization, organization, tactics, and results of group-based politics, including latent interests and the suppression of interests.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Introduction to Public Administration
description: A study of the basic principles and theory of administrative structure, responsibility, and control in relation to policy making in the modern state.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Politics of Taxing and Spending
description: Principles and practices of financial administration, including organization, budgeting, assessment, treasury management, and debt.

name: Regulatory Policies
description: Types and limits of powers exercised by regulatory agencies; procedural law and remedies against administrative action.

name: Public Policy
description: Process of and major approaches to making public policy particularly, in the United States. Case study materials will focus on such major policies as welfare, health care, national security, and resource management.

name: Public Affairs Internship
description: A course designed to complement internship work in state/local government by introducing students to key concepts in state and local governance and politics to best facilitate the internship experience.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Comparative Politics of Developing Countries
description: A comparative analysis of the political problems confronting new nations, the political consequences of the breakdown of traditional society and the problems of developing new institutional forms and procedures.

name: Comparative Politics of Industrialized Countries
description: Introduction to the development, structure, and functioning of government and politics in Western Europe, the former Soviet states, and other selected industrialized countries.

name: Genocide: A Comparative Perspective
description: An analysis of the causes of genocide and the application of those insights to explain how genocide has occurred repeatedly at various times and places across the globe.

name: Topics in Political Science
description: May be repeated once as topics change.

name: Race and Science Fiction
description: Draws on science fiction to understand the contemporary history of American racial and ethnic politics and to speculate about the significance of race in America�€�s political future.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Independent Study/Poli Sci
description: Note: Prior approval of an individualized contract by the director of undergraduate studies in political science and the instructor who will supervise the project required.

name: Independent Study in Political Science
description: Prior approval of and individualized contract by the director of undergraduate studies in political science and the instructor who will supervise the project required.

name: Independent Study in International Studies
description: Prior approval of an individualized contract by the director of undergraduate studies in international studies and the instructor who will supervise the project required.

name: Selected Topics in Political Theory
description: Intensive analysis of a particular topic or topics. To be identified by title each semester.

name: Selected Thinkers in Political Theory
description: Intensive analysis of particular theorist or theorists. To be identified by title each semester.

name: African American Political Thought
description: Survey of many of the major schools of historic and contemporary African American political thought.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Democratic Theory
description: An introduction to contemporary theories and practices with focus on Western, especially American, experience.

name: The State of American Politics
description: Major factors that affect the state of contemporary American politics, including the Constitution, the Congress, the courts, the presidency, the states, federalism, political parties, special-interest groups, and the electoral process.

name: Revolution and Political Violence
description: Forms, causes, and consequences of domestic political violence with special attention to revolution.

name: Theories of War in International Relations
description: The contributions of the social sciences and social theorists to an understanding of the causes of war.

name: International Law
description: The origin, development, and principles of the international law of peace and the enforcement of these principles, the law of war and pacific settlement of disputes.

name: Law and Contemporary International Problems
description: The growth of law in several areas of increasing international concern: environmental protection, expropriation, outer space, individual rights and obligations, conservation of resources, state responsibility, and terrorism.

name: Ideology and World Politics
description: An introduction to the ideological context of world affairs, with attention to traditional democratic, totalitarian, and Third World "developmental ideologies".

name: Science, Technology, and Public Policy
description: Interaction between science and politics, the making of the national science and technology policy, and the role of public policy in promoting and managing scientific change.

name: Nationalism and Ethnicity in World Politics
description: Nationalism and ethnicity as factors in world politics, including the sources, nature, and analysis of conflicts associated with them.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Economic Aspects of International Politics
description: Economic problems and policies in international politics including theory of comparative advantage; international economic aid, trade and monetary issues; the United States' role in the international economy; and the functions of international economic institutions.

name: International Relations of Latin America
description: Contemporary international relations among Latin American states, including economic and political security and relations with the United States.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Russian Foreign Policy
description: Analysis of the development of foreign policies in Russia and other states of the former USSR with special attention to relations with Europe and the United States.

name: Globalization and Security
description: Exploration of the ways in which globalization may impact national and international security.

name: International Relations of East Asia and the Pacific
description: Political patterns and forces in the Asia/Pacific region in recent times including the process of decolonization, regional conflicts, great power relations, and economic interdependencies.

name: International Relations in Japan
description: The institutions, actors, and processes of Japan's contemporary political and economic foreign affairs.

name: Political Economy of Africa's Regions
description: The historic and contemporary political and economic processes and structures of one or more regions in Africa, such as North Africa, West Africa, East Africa, Central Africa, or Southern Africa.

name: International Relations of Africa
description: Contemporary international relations among African nations including decolonization, pan-Africanism, and movements of national liberation; Africa's role in the United Nations, relations between African states and the former colonial powers, the United States, and communist countries.

name: Foreign Policies of Selected Powers
description: Foreign policy-making institutions, processes, and policies of selected powers with special attention to the domestic determinants of foreign policy.

name: Politics and Government of China
description: Political institutions and processes of the People's Republic of China with secondary emphasis on the government and politics of the Republic of China on Taiwan.

name: International Relations of the Middle East
description: Examination of super- and great-power policies toward the Middle East; inter-regional relations and Middle East foreign relations.

name: Constitutional Law I: Institutional Powers
description: Nature and functions of the national government and its relations with the states.

name: Constitutional Law II: Civil Liberties
description: Due process and civil liberties.

name: The Judicial Process
description: A study of the growth of law, the law-making function of the courts, the structure and organization of federal and state courts, the procedures involved in civil and criminal cases, and the problems and proposals for reform in the administration of justice.

name: Moot Court and Legal Research
description: Introduction to fundamental legal research techniques and strategies applied to controversial court cases in both oral and written forms.

name: Women and the Law
description: Constitutional and statutory case law dealing with gender equality issues. Topics include abortion, affirmative action, pornography, sexual harassment, fetal protection policies, employment discrimination, and women in the military.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Congress and the Presidency
description: Analysis of the interaction between the legislative and executive branches within a separation-of-power system.

name: The Legislative Process
description: A study of the structure, organization, powers, functions, and problems of legislative bodies.

name: The American Chief Executive
description: Constitutional, statutory and political powers and roles of the American chief executive.

name: Roosevelt Institution Seminar
description: Analysis and discussion of contemporary public policy problems through exposure to campus experts and intensive writing and peer review.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101.
name: Psychology and Politics
description: The role of psychology in political attitudes and behavior. Examination of individual psycho-political relationships and aggregate typologies. Particular emphasis on the psychological roots of the need for or the rejection of political authority.

name: Federalism and Intergovernmental Relations
description: The origins and evolution of the American federal system, focusing on the constitutional, regulatory, and financial entanglements among federal, state and local governments.

name: Survey Research
description: Principles and practice of survey research/public opinion polling including sampling, questionnaire design, data collection, coding processing and analysis.

name: Black Activism
description: Critical review of theories of community organizing, grassroots activism, and social movements, and examination of contemporary forms of black activism.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Green Politics
description: An analysis of green political thought and environmental movements at the local, state, national, and global levels.

name: Environmental Policy
description: Themes in environmental policy in industrialized nations. Analysis of issue framing, the role of the public and private tools, and conflicting perspectives. Incorporates analysis of policy process and public management.

name: Politics and Government of Russia
description: Political processes and institutions of Russia and other independent states of the former USSR.

name: Politics and Governments of Europe
description: Political processes and institutions of European nations.

name: Middle East Politics
description: Focuses on the internal politics of Middle East states; historical and cultural setting of Middle East politics, social institutions, and dynamics of the political process.

name: Politics and Governments of Africa
description: Political developments, processes, and institutions of the African nations.

name: Politics and Governments of Latin America
description: The development, principles, political thought, and politics of the several Latin American states.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Politics and Government of Japan
description: Political institutions and processes of Japan.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: minimum GPA of 3.60 in major courses, 3.30 overall.
name: Research Experience
description: Working with a faculty mentor, students develop a research project and related search skills.

name: Senior Thesis
description: For intensive majors. Individual instruction in research techniques and supervised thesis preparation.

name: Selected Topics in Civilization and Culture
Methods of Political Analysis
description: Quantitative techniques in political science; levels of measurement; problems of description, causation, and inference.

name: American Political Thought
description: Themes and thinkers in American political history.

name: Politics and Ethics
description: The nature of, and relationship between, politics and ethics.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Utopian Political Thought
description: A critical examination of utopian and dystopian political ideas.

name: Research in Language Conflict and Language Rights
description: Research into the parameters governing linguistic conflicts and language rights issues, involving a close examination of the nexes of language and: individual and ethnic identity, culture, dialects, bilingualism. Examination of regional, national, and international case studies, with particular attention to nationalism, language revitalization, and language planning.

name: Economic Development Policy
description: The role government policies have in local and regional differences in economic performance; strategies governments and non-profits use to evaluate economic development policies; topical focus on a range of economic development policies, including land use, infrastructure, workforce development, and education.

name: Law and Society
description: The American judicial system, including the decision to resolve disputes by legal means, political influence on the legal system, the social impact of legal rulings, the relationship of the courts to other branches of government, and the applicability of higher law concepts in judicial decision making.

name: American Local Government
description: An introduction to the institutions, functions, policy-making processes, and politics of American local government.

name: State and Local Government
description: This course will examine the purpose, structure, and functions of state governments and their local subdivisions. Requires special permission of department. Restricted to social studies teachers.

name: South Carolina Government and Politics
description: South Carolina state and local government in the context of South Carolina history and U.S. state and local government.

name: Special Topics in Political Science
description: Intensive study of special topics in Political Science. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Elementary Portuguese
description: Grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Assumes no prior experience in the language.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PORT 121.
name: Basic Proficiency in Portuguese
description: Practice and further development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PORT 122, PORT 130.
name: Intermediate Portuguese I
description: Review of the basic principles of grammar with additional emphasis on reading and oral skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PORT 201.
name: Intermediate Portuguese II
description: Continued review of the basic principiles of grammar with additional emphasis on reading, writing, and oral skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPAN 302, advanced proficiency or equivalent in Spanish.
name: Accelerated Portuguese for Speakers of Spanish
description: Accelerated Portuguese for speakers of Spanish, taught through a communicative approach. Students will develop intermediate-level oral and written communication skills in Portuguese and increase knowledge about multiple aspects of Luso-Brazilian cultures.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Any 200-level PORT course.
name: Advanced Conversation and Composition I
description: Development of advanced conversational and compositional skills through systematic grammar study and review, reading, oral activities, and film discussion.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Any 200-level PORT course.
name: Advanced Conversation and Composition II
description: Development of advanced conversational and compositional skills through systematic grammar study and review, reading, and the analysis of texts through both writing and oral discussion.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PORT 309 and PORT 310.
name: Introduction to Luso-Brazilian Literature
description: Introduction to reading literary texts in Portuguese through carefully selected readings from different genres/periods.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PORT 309 and PORT 310.
name: The Brazilian Modern Short Story
description: Examination of Brazilian short fiction and cronicas (literary journalistic pieces).

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PORT 309 and PORT 310.
name: Special Topics in Luso-Brazilian Cultural Production
description: Intensive study of special topics in Luso-Brazilian cultural production. May be repeated once as content varies by title. Taught in Portuguese.

name: Selected Portuguese Topics
description: Intensive study of selected topics. May be repeated for credit under different title. Taught in English. Individual topics to be announced by title.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Intensive Readings in Portuguese
description: Intensive reading for non-majors. Graduate students fulfill their foreign-language reading requirements with successful completion of the course. Undergraduates may take the course as an elective only.

name: Introduction to Psychology
description: An introduction to and survey of the basic concepts and findings within the field of psychology.

name: Psychology of Adjustment
description: Introduction to theories and processes underlying and facilitating human adjustment in the community, family, and workplace.

name: Human Sexual Behavior
description: Psychological, physiological, and sociological factors of human sexual behavior and attitudes.

name: Psychology of Marriage
description: The psychological, physiological, and social characteristics of marriage.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Psychology of Women
description: Women�€�s experiences: childhood and adolescence, work, family, cultural images, adjustment, and social change.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Psychology of Religion
description: The development of the religious consciousness and its various expressions, the psychological dynamics of growth and conversion, response to crisis, and the relation of spiritual practice to health and wholeness.

name: Psychology and the African-American Experience
description: Psychological theory and research as it applies to African Americans. Explores Africentric and other perspectives and roles of culture, racism, and historical phenomena.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Industrial Psychology
description: Psychological techniques applied to various industrial problem areas, such as management and supervision, morale, efficiency, training, personnel selection and placement, and relations among personnel.

name: Applied Psychology
description: Uses of psychological knowledge and techniques in practical contexts; clinical, school, industrial, consumer, and environmental psychology.

name: Psychology of Consciousness
description: Theories, controversies, and research findings on the nature of various states of consciousness; topics such as sleep/dreams, hypnosis, drug-induced states, and psychic phenomena.

name: Sport Psychology
description: The role of sports in socialization, personality development and competence, including: spectator-performer interactions, motivation, competition effects; and the application of psychological techniques to performance enhancement.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101.
name: Independent Study
description: Closely supervised project or research experience in psychology. Approved contract required. May be repeated for up to six credits. Not for psychology major credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101 or SCHC 130.
name: Survey of Learning and Memory
description: Research and applications concerning the acquisition of new behavior and knowledge, including accounts based on classical and instrumental conditioning and on information-processing models.

name: Cognitive Psychology
description: Research and theories on sensory memory, attention, short-term and working memory, human learning and forgetting, imagery, long-term memory, speech perception, reading, language, thinking and problem solving, and decision making.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101 or SCHC 130.
name: Behavioral and Mental Disorders
description: Covers the classification, diagnosis, etiological theories, and treatments of the major mental and emotional disorders.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101 or EDPY 335 or SCHC 130.
name: Survey of Developmental Psychology
description: Psychological development from conception to late adulthood. Topics include physical, cognitive, and social processes associated with development at each stage of the life cycle.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101 or SCHC 130.
name: Survey of Social Psychology
description: Introduction to theory and research in social psychology from a psychological viewpoint. Topics include social perception, social cognition, attitudes, interpersonal relationships, aggression, prosocial behavior, and group processes.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Men and Masculinities
description: This course provides an overview of psychological, social, physical, and emotional issues related to men's lives. Major topics include: gender construction, men and work, men and health, men in relationships, male sexualities, men in families, and masculinities in the media and popular culture.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101 or SCHC 130.
name: Survey of Personality
description: Covers the major theories and research on personality and the dynamics of human motivation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101 or SCHC 130.
name: Sensation and Perception
description: Processing of information from the environment. Physiological, physical, psychological, and contextual determinants of perception.

name: Introduction to Neuroscience
description: Function of the brain including basic neuroanatomy, neurophysiology and neurochemistry, neural systems, and psychopharmacology as it relates to behavior.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101 or SCHC 130.
name: Brain and Behavior
description: How the brain mediates simple and complex behavior and how we can apply basic research about the brain to real world problems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101.
name: Health Psychology
description: Application of psychological theories and assessment and treatment methodologies for health maintenance and the diagnosis and treatment of illness.

name: Introduction to Language Sciences
description: Introduction to the linguistic component of human cognition. Properties of speech, the organization of language in the mind/brain, cross-linguistic universals, child language acquisition, and aspects of adult language processing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: B or better in PSYC 220 and PSYC 221.
name: Survey of Clinical Psychology
description: The scientific basis of clinical psychology. Topics include history, theory, research, ethics, and best practices. For students interested in graduate school in psychology or other mental health professions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101.
name: Multi-Cultural Psychology
description: This course provides an introduction to theories and research in the study of psychosocial issues of racial, ethnic and cultural groups.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101 or SCHC 130 and at least 3 hours in psychology at 400 level or above.
name: Community Psychology
description: Application of knowledge from other areas of psychology to the study of the role of the individual in the community.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 15 hours in psychology.
name: Community Psychology Practicum
description: Supervised, structured field experience in a community agency, applying psychological principles, theory, and research. May be repeated once for credit.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PSYC 226.
name: Internship in Psychology
description: A supervised experiential course in psychology. Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and Office of Academic Programs is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 9 hours of psychology.
name: Advanced Independent Study
description: Closely supervised project or research experience in psychology. Approved contract required. May be repeated for up to six credits.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101 and 9 hours of upper-level courses all in psychology, business, engineering, or nursing.
name: Human Factors Psychology
description: Application of research in experimental psychology to ergonomics, the design of human-environment systems, with emphasis on work settings.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 450 or PSYC 455 or PSYC 460.
name: Psychology of Drug Use and Effects
description: Research and theoretical considerations of substance abuse. Pharmacological, sociological, psychological, medical, economic, forensic, and other relevant research and treatment disciplines.

name: Psychology of Language
description: Theories of speech perception, linguistic theories of syntax and semantics, the brain mechanisms underlying language, the development of language in children, and the role of language in thought.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PSYC 405.
name: Cognitive Neuroscience
description: Research and theories on the role of the brain in facets of cognitive behavior, including attention, short-term and working memory, perception, language, executive function, thinking, and problem solving.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 420 or PSYC 410.
name: Child Behavioral and Mental Disorders
description: Theories, description, and assessment of child behavior problems and disorders; methods of intervention.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 420.
name: Psychology of Child Development
description: Examination of development from conception through older childhood. Specific cognitive and social processes will be given in-depth study.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 420.
name: Psychology of Adolescence
description: Theories and research examining social, emotional, and intellectual development in adolescence. Explores influence of family, peer, school, and cultural contexts.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 420.
name: Psychology of Early and Middle Adulthood
description: Developmental changes in abilities, personality, and behavior which occur between adolescence and old age.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 420.
name: Psychology of Aging
description: Psychological, social, and biological phenomena associated with maturity and aging.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 410 or PSYC 420 or equivalent.
name: Prevention of Psychological Problems in Children and Youth at Risk
description: Etiology, prevention of, and intervention in behavioral, social, emotional, educational, and psychological problems in children and youth at risk.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in PSYC 420 or PSYC 520.
name: Psychology of Neurodevelopmental Disorders
description: Characteristics, causes, needs, and intervention strategies for individuals with neurodevelopmental differences including a focus on biological, societal, cognitive, physical, and social/emotional strengths and challenges.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDEX 523 or PSYC 528.
name: Nature of Students with Specific Learning Disabilities
description: Children with average/above average intelligence and specific learning impairments; diagnostic and remedial techniques. Offered by both the College of Education and the Department of Psychology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 430.
name: Advanced Social Psychology
description: Intensive study of topics selected from the field of social psychology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 450.
name: Advanced Sensation and Perception
description: Intensive study of topics selected from the field of sensation and perception.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in NSCI 300, PSYC 455, or PSYC 460, for undergraduates.
name: Advanced Topics in Neuroscience
description: Intensive study of topics selected from the field of neuroscience. Course may be repeated for credit under different topics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in NSCI 300, PSYC 455, or PSYC 460.
name: Neuroscience Laboratory
description: Practice in the methods of scientific inquiry and the dissemination of research in neuroscience.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in PSYC 507 and either PSYC 455 or PSYC 460.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in one course from PSYC 400, PSYC 405, PSYC 450, PSYC 455, or PSYC 460.
name: Cognitive Neuroscience Laboratory
description: Methods of observation and experimentation in cognitive neuroscience. Two lectures and one three-hour laboratory per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: PSYC 405.
name: Cognitive Psychology Laboratory
description: Practice in the experimental techniques used in the study of cognitive psychology. Two lectures and one three-hour laboratory per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: PSYC 450.
name: Sensation and Perception Laboratory
description: Concepts and principles in the study of sensation and perception in the laboratory. Two lectures and one three-hour laboratory per week.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: B or better in PSYC 220 and PSYC 221.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in PSYC 420 or PSYC 520.
name: Developmental Psychology Laboratory
description: Methods of observation and experimentation on human psychological development. Two lectures and one three-hour laboratory per week.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: B or better in PSYC 220 and PSYC 221.
name: Intermediate Statistics for Psychologists
description: Advanced analysis of the uses and applications of statistics to research in psychology, and interpretation of statistics in the psychological literature.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: B or better in PSYC 227 and PSYC 228.
name: Psychological Tests and Measurement
description: Introduction to the theory and practice of measuring psychological attributes. Emphasis on test construction in a laboratory setting. Hands-on experience in designing, administering, and analyzing psychological tests and measures.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 9 hours in psychology at 400 level or above.
name: History and Systems of Psychology
description: Systematic approaches to psychology.

name: Selected Topics in Psychology
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 15 hours of psychology.
name: Individual Research
description: Planning and execution of supervised research in psychology. Approved contract required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 15 hours of psychology.
name: Individual Research
description: Planning and execution of supervised research in psychology. Approved contract required.

name: Introduction to Public Health
description: An introduction to the history, theory, and practice of public health. Emphasis will be on the population perspective and the ecological model including the population impacts of health care systems.

name: Independent Study in Public Health
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and dean of the Arnold School is required for undergraduate students. May be repeated for up to 6 credits.

name: Special Topics in Public Health
description: Issues and emerging themes in public health. May be repeated for a total of 9 credit hours as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PUBH 302.
name: Public Health Capstone Seminar
description: Synthesis and application of BS/BA public health program content and competencies in a practice setting with emphasis on student identified areas for professional growth.

name: Foundations of Public Health Leadership
description: An introduction to core principles in public health leadership. Areas included are ethics, public health issues, communication issues, leadership competencies, and leadership values.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Transforming Health Care for the Future
description: Foundation for beginning health professions students to gain an understanding of the complexities of the health care system through experiential activities conducted in interprofessional teams and the importance of interprofessional collaboration in order to improve the system.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Elementary Literacy Instruction I
description: Examination and implementation of the key concepts, content, goals, and strategies in teaching reading and the language arts in the elementary school. Students will work with elementary children in a school setting to learn literacy concepts and instructional strategies. Admission to the B.A. program in elementary education, children�€�s literature course. Designated for undergraduate students seeking initial certification.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: admission to the professional program.
name: Reading Assessment
description: Seminar and supervised one-on-one field experience focused on reading assessment of and instruction for individual children and groups of children. Restricted to: Undergraduate students pursuing teacher certification.

name: Content Area Literacy PK-12
description: A survey of research and practice which facilitates students' literacy skills in the content areas. For K-12 content area teachers of art, dance, physical education, foreign language, music and theatre.

name: Teaching Reading to Adults I
description: Diagnostic and prescriptive modes of teaching reading to adults, based on the physical, psychological, intellectual, and social characteristics of the adult learner.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDCO 511 or EDRD 511.
name: Teaching Reading to Adults II
description: Preparation of materials for teaching basic reading skills to adults and practicum experiences in teaching adults to read.

name: Teaching of Reading in the Elementary School
description: Study of the various phases of reading in their relation to a modern program of education and the place of reading in the curriculum. Emphasis on modern practices in the classroom teaching of reading.

name: Reading in the Secondary School
description: The place of reading instruction in high schools, the programming of special services in reading instruction, methods of teaching basic and developmental reading skills, and case studies of programs. Demonstrations of tests and devices.

name: Foundations of Reading Instruction
description: An overview of reading and its curriculum implications: grades K-12 and adults. Emphasis is placed on current trends and issues and related methodologies.

name: Teaching Reading Through A Literature Emphasis
description: Integrating appropriate literature into traditional and alternative reading programs. Identifying appropriate literature for classroom use and recreational reading. Use of literature as a means of developing and reinforcing reading skills.

name: Introduction to Teaching Media Literacy
description: A survey of analysis of electronic and non-print media themes and messages aimed at youth, with special emphasis on design and implementation of curricula for enhancing children�€�s media literacy.

name: Helping Relationships: Fundamentals of Counseling Practice
description: Development of communication skills necessary to foster and develop effective counseling relationships.

name: Culture and Disability
description: Concepts and procedures relating to disability and culture, covering relevant issues affecting racially and culturally diverse individuals with disabilities, as well as promoting sensitivity and competence. Includes implications for an array of helping professions.

name: Exploring Religion
description: Beliefs and practices of the world's religions and the methods scholars use to study them.

name: Comparative Religion
description: Issues, theories, and debates that shape global religious traditions, cultures, and communities; examination of historical contexts and development, applying social scientific inquiry and methods to analyze relevant current circumstances and concerns.

name: Religion and Culture
description: Exploration of the dynamic relationships between selected religions and cultures.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Introduction to Reason and Faith
description: Critical study of the intellectual strands leading to Western disconnections between reason and faith; the search for balance between belief and reason with emphasis on contemporary developments.

name: Introduction to Religions in America
description: The diversity of religious traditions in America.

name: Morality, Ethics, and Religion
description: Values and ethics as developed, contested, and transmitted through a variety of religious practices.

name: History of the Devil
description: A survey of the beliefs and practices associated with the demonic and the Devil from c 500 B.C.E. to the 20th century.

name: Introduction to African American Religions
description: The variety of religious traditions of African Americans, with emphasis on the contexts in which they developed.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Biblical Archaeology
description: The fundamental elements of human culture as it relates to biblical archaeology. The defining characteristics of different kinds of society through interdependency of language and culture. The affects of modern world interests in defining / redefining this area.

name: Introduction to Hinduism
description: An interdisciplinary examination of the complexity of the Hindu religious and philosophical traditions covering such topics as deity, self, cosmos, body ritual, karma, and yoga.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Ethics and the Good Life in Asian Religions
description: Fundamental questions of ethical and moral inquiry in the religious traditions of Asia.

name: Introduction to Buddhism
description: An introduction to Buddhism from a social historical perspective that examines Buddhist religious goals and practices in the local contexts of India, Sri Lanka, Tibet, China, and Japan.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Buddhist Meditation in Theory and Practice
description: Buddhist methods of meditation, asceticism, and similar disciplinary practices for personal and social transformation. Examination of classic Buddhist works from diverse cultures with attention to modern American practices.

name: Introduction to Judaism
description: Overview of Jewish experiences, beliefs, practices from a contextual point of view.

name: Introduction to Christianity
description: Introduction to the Christian religion, with emphasis on the history of the major traditions and movements that have shaped the multicultural practices and social impact of modern global Christianity.

name: Introduction to Islam
description: Interpretation of primary materials reflecting many dimensions of the Islamic religious tradition, such as the Qur'an, Hadith, legal, and theological and mystical writings, art, rituals, and contemporary Muslim voices.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Anthropology of Magic and Religion
description: A comparative examination of such topics as ritual, cosmology, revitalization movements, magic, witchcraft, myth, and possession.

name: Global Human Religiosity
description: The human experience and expression of what it means to be religious.

name: Religion and the Arts
description: Literary, visual, and/or performance art associated with religious discourse and practice.

name: Special Topics in Religious Studies
description: Special topics in Religious Studies. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Hebrew Bible (Old Testament)
description: Modern study of the Hebrew Bible from historical, literary, and archeological points of view. Reading and analysis of texts in translation.

name: New Testament
description: Historical and critical study of the New Testament writings, with emphasis on origins, production, and transmission.

name: Paul and the Philosophers
description: Paul�€�s teachings and practices, as shown in his letters and how these resemble those of various cultural formations of his time, with emphasis on moral teachings and schools of Hellenistic philosophy.

name: Gospel Literature and the Formation of Christianity
description: Gospels about Jesus from the 1st and 2nd centuries CE; analysis with attention to canonical texts as well as those not contained in today�€�s major canonical collections; assessment of gospel literature in competing configurations of Christianity during its formative years.

name: The Life and Letters of Paul
description: A critical study in the life and thought of Paul, his letters to the early Christian churches, his role in the expansion of the Christian movement, and his continuing influence today.

name: Religion and Culture
description: The impact of religion on modern Western culture and, in turn, of culture on religion. Selected topics: Holocaust, Puritanism, fundamentalism, Islam, Freud, "love" wisdom tradition, "civil religion."

name: Early Christianity
description: Christianity in the 1st through 5th centuries; its formation as seen through the literature of early Christians and their detractors.

name: Imagining Jesus: Antiquity to Present
description: Conceptions and representations of Jesus in antiquity up to the present; including the gospel traditions as well as literature, art, and film.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: GREK 121 and GREK 122.
name: The Greek New Testament
description: Readings in the Gospels and Epistles.

name: Old Testament Prophets
description: Old Testament prophets, the nature of their prophetic experience, their place in the life of ancient Israel, their message, and their continuing theological significance.

name: Christian Theology
description: Basic Christian teachings concerning God, creation, sin, the person and work of Christ, and life after death.

name: Sex, Gender, and Religion
description: Gender and sexuality in the shaping of social and individual identity in religious contexts.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Asian Religious Philosophy
description: A historical overview and critical introduction to the philosophical practices of Asian religions; an examination of the basic worldviews, thought frameworks, and foundational questions of the main schools of premodern Asian religious philosophy.

name: Christian Ethics
description: Basic Christian teachings concerning human nature and conduct; historical foundations and contemporary applications.

name: Social Justice & Religion
description: Historical, contextual, and developmental aspects of social justice as a significant function of religion.

name: Religion and Politics
description: Relationships between religion and the structure, institutions, and content of a nation�€�s political processes.

name: Sociology of Religion
description: Sociological perspectives related to selected aspects of religious behavior. Includes references to non-Western religions.

name: Law and Religious Traditions
description: The study of the role of law, legal argumentation, and legal contexts in one or more religious traditions.

name: God and the Gods
description: The worship of Yahweh and other deities in ancient Israel with special attention to the evolution of monotheism.

name: Religions of the African Diaspora
