description: Explore development/theologies of African/African Diaspora religions; examine misunderstandings; arrive at a more sophisticated and nuanced vision of these religions and the people who hold them.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: At least one 100- or 200-level Religious Studies course.
name: Hindu Devotional Traditions
description: One of the main paths to the divine in the Hindu tradition; deep devotion to a god or goddess, or bhakti, with expressions in art, poetry, mythology, theology, and ascetic fervor.

name: Tantra: Sex, Power, and Bliss in South Asian Religions
description: Investigation of the Buddhist and Hindu religious ideas and practices know as tantra. Topics include tantric views of the human body, freedom, and consciousnes; tantric use of sec, imagination, visualization, and manipulation of bodily energy; role of tantric traditions in south Asian religions and cultures.

name: Buddhist Stories, Poetry, and Films
description: Buddhist stories, poetry, novels, and films from various cultures and times examined for how they creatively convey their religious ideals. Study of great works of Buddhist writing, in English translation, analyzing their techniques and examining how Buddhists use film today for similar aims.

name: Yoga: The Art of Spiritual Transformation
description: Examination of major South Asian religions--Hinduism, Jainism, Buddhism, and Islam, emphasizing the historical context for changing religious ideals, and the commingling of traditions.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Religions of East Asia
description: Expansion of Buddhism beyond India, development of Confucianism, Taoism, Shinto, and other national religious expressions in China and Japan.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Islamic Institutions and Traditions
description: The religious, political, social and economic institutions and intellectual and scholarly traditions developed by Muslim societies throughout Afro-Eurasia from late antiquity to the present.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: The Qur'an and Hadith
description: Intensive study of the Qur'an and Hadith: its major themes and literary quality, with attention to a range of classical and contemporary discourses about the Qur'an, both Islamic and Western.

name: Islamic Theology and Philosophical Thought
description: Close reading and discussion of primary texts (the Qur'an, Hadith, creeds, classical theological arguments, and modern writings) on major theological problems such as salvation, God, revelation, and religious pluralism.

name: Psychology of Religion
description: The development of the religious consciousness and its various expressions, the psychological dynamics of growth and conversion, response to crisis, and the relation of spiritual practice to health and wholeness.

name: Science, Magic and Religion
description: Occultism as a link between science and religion and its central role in Western intellectual and cultural history; the historical development of the science-magic-religion continuum in the Islamo-Christian world from late antiquity to present.

name: Sufism
description: A survey of Islamic mysticism, its foundation in the Quranic revelation doctrines and practices, subsequent development, significance within Islamic civilization, and role in the contemporary world, both Islamic and non-Islamic.

name: Messiahs, Mystics and Rebels in the Islamic World
description: Representative messianic movements, millenarian visionaries and apocalyptic imaginings in the Islamic world from the 7th century to the present, with attention to related developments in the Jewish and Christian traditions over the last two millennia.

name: Islamic Law
description: Close reading and discussion of primary texts (scriptural, classical, and modern) and accounts of court cases, focuses on one aspect of Islamic law such as equity, violence, authority, or gender.

name: Religion and Existentialism
description: Existentialist thought as adapted by theologians to interpret religious experience and the biblical message. The movement from philosophical protest against essentialism into imaginative description of existence revealed under stress.

name: Literature and Film of the Holocaust
description: Film, poetry and literature created in response to the Holocaust as the means for a decades long cultural discussion, in European and American societies, of the moral and religious implications of the Holocaust on our self-understandings as religious and moral beings.

name: Religion in the South
description: Regional faith traditions in Southern historical-cultural context: evangelical piety, denominational tradition, revival, African-American church, Lost Cause idealism.

name: Religion and Literature
description: Classic literary works from one or more religious traditions which have shaped and/or expressed the core ethos of a religious tradition or of the more general human concern for the religious and spiritual; and/or general literature (fiction, poetry, plays, essays, non-fiction) which incorporates religious or spiritual references, ideas, symbolism, allusions.

name: Jewish History I: Late Antiquity to 1500
description: The religious, cultural, social, and political conditions that shaped the Jewish experience in the Near East and Europe from Late Antiquity to 1500.

name: Jewish History II: 1500 to the Present
description: Case studies of Jewish history in Europe, America, and the land of Israel, 1500 to the present.

name: Jews and Muslims
description: Jewish-Muslim relations in the Near East and the US; an exploration of Jewish-Muslim encounters, issues of religious law, politics, radical religious ideologies, and their repercussions for today.

name: Theories of Religion
description: A historical overview of major theories and approaches in the academic study of religion.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Origins of Western Morality
description: Greek and Roman ethical theory, its adaptation into Judean and Christian traditions and impact on Western models of morality.

name: Faith, Doubt, and God
description: Judeo-Christian views of God; modern criticism and contemporary responses.

name: Race and Religion
description: Conceptualization of race and its transformative impact on the study of religion; genealogical, historical, and theoretical parameters of the intersection between race and religion; recent scholarship that combines the categories of race and religion in the context of various religious communities.

name: Religion and Science: Human Questions
description: Relationships between religion and science, especially considering impacts of mutual responses and questions with respect to human life in the 21st century.

name: Religions, Medicines, and Healing
description: Inter-relationships between religion, medicines, and healing; examining perspectives and practices, interfaces and influences across cultures.

name: Spiritual Lives
description: Contemporary and historical life-stories about spiritual or religious figures as presented in various forms such as biography, autobiography, hagiography, art, and/or film; explores both the specific issues within unique accounts and idealized, general models for spiritual lives.

name: Visions of Apocalypse
description: Symbolic visions, tours of heaven and hell, cosmic battles, divine judgment, messianic figures, prophecy, or other forms of revelation as found in literature, art, or social movements from diverse geographical and historical locations.

name: Perspective in Religious Studies
description: Build an understanding of the contexts of religious studies; participate in ongoing scholarly discussions; and expand the serious student�€�s skills in critically analyzing religions.

name: Advanced Special Topics in Religious Studies
description: Advanced special topics in Religious Studies. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Special Topics in Research in Religious Studies
description: Focused research on special topics in Religious Studies. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Advanced Project
description: A supervised research project or other creative work, required of intensive majors, to be completed in the senior year.

name: Tradition and Transformations in Islamic Cultures
description: Islam as a dynamic cultural tradition: emphasis on the tension between Islamization and the larger Islamic tradition.

name: Introduction to Classroom Assessment
description: Development of assessments for different content areas and grade levels, and processes for making decisions based on assessment results.

name: Introduction to Testing and Evaluation
description: The construction and use of teacher-made tests; descriptive statistics, measurement error, norms, and interpretation of scores; types of standardized instruments for use in elementary and secondary schools.

name: Fashion History: A Global View
description: Examination of influences on fashion throughout history both domestically and globally.

name: Fashion Through the Ages: 1800 A.D. to Present
description: Introduction to the history of fashion from 1800 A.D. to the present.

name: Exploration of Retail Management and Fashion Merchandising Industries
description: Exploration of retail management and fashion merchandising curriculum and careers.

name: History of Designers
description: Survey of influential fashion designers since 1857, examining their design influences and their contributions to fashion.

name: The Changing Consumer Marketplace
description: The economic problems of everyday life presented within a business framework, promoting the student�€�s well-being as a consumer. Consideration is given to the economics of consumption, real income, consumer buying, consumer protection, operations leading to family prosperity, security, and estate planning.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: HRSM Professional Communications
description: Theory, processes, and applications of business communications.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Sustainability in Fashion and Retail
description: Examination of concepts, practices, and opportunities of fashion sustainability (such as social and environmental responsibility) available to designers, developers and consumers.

name: Principles of Accounting I
description: A study of the accounting cycle with emphasis on preparation and analysis of financial statements.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RETL 261.
name: Principles of Accounting II
description: A study of the preparation and interpretation of corporate financial statements with an emphasis on analysis and decision making techniques.

name: Principles of Retailing
description: Management methods, location analysis, store organization, personnel, planning, buying and pricing techniques, and customer service policies for retail firms.

name: Principles of Fashion Merchandising
description: The place of fashion in buying, selling, and promoting merchandise. Meets the needs of individuals in retail organizations from entry level to buyer.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in RETL 265.
name: Retailing Practicum
description: Supervised work experience in an area of the retail industry, selected by the student and approved by the instructor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RETL 265.
name: Digital Retailing
description: Development of a comprehensive plan for implementing a retailing business online via digital technology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RETL 265.
name: Asset Protection for Retailers
description: Examination of asset protection and risk management issues which affect the retailing industry, such as retail risk assessment and response, loss prevention, employee-related risks, facility security, crisis management, and intellectual property protection.

name: Personnel Organization and Supervision
description: Recruitment, selection, utilization, and development of human resources; role of supervisors in management and personnel administration.

name: Sales Strategies
description: Theories, principles, and techniques of personal selling with application to different buyer-seller situations.

name: Retail Entrepreneurship
description: Essentials of creating and operating a new retail venture in physical and virtual environments.

name: Principles of Customer Service
description: Essential skills necessary to manage successful service operations, including retail, e-commerce, hospitality/tourism, food/beverage, and sports/event organizations.

name: Visual Merchandising and Store Design
description: Displays and visual merchandising strategies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RETL 261.
name: Retail Buying
description: Planning, purchasing, and controlling inventories.

name: Fashion Product Analysis
description: Analysis of fashion products with emphasis on textile selection, product construction, life cycle, cost elements, and the changing demographics of the fashion consumer.

name: Retail Promotion
description: Planning and executing retail promotion strategies.

name: Advanced Retail Accounting
description: Accounting topics related to retail establishment with emphasis on managerial interpretation and use.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in RETL 261 and RETL 265.
name: Global Sourcing in Retail and Fashion
description: Exploration of theoretical, political, economic, social, and environmental implications of global sourcing decisions in retail and fashion.

name: Fashion Forecasting
description: Forecasting fashion trends to impact retail merchandising performance.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department head is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in RETL 265.
name: Customer Experience Management
description: Study of customer trends and experience management.

name: Retail Branding Strategies
description: Overview of retail branding strategies with emphasis on implications of the development of brand equity towards increasing customer loyalty.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RETL 366 and RETL 368.
name: Merchandise Management Strategies
description: The knowledge of the principles of merchandising as applied in manufacturing and retailing business organization and understanding of the retail buyer�€�s role in merchandise management including merchandise planning, negotiating, buying, pricing, assorting, and timing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in RETL 265.
name: Category Management
description: Application of category management principles and models to competitive behavior in retailing with a focus on product category issues. Case-based analysis and/or JDA computer software will be applied to industry-specific problems related to inventory management.

name: Multi-National Retailing
description: Retail operations within foreign environments.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RETL 366.
name: Retail Management Strategies
description: Application of strategic management principles and models to competitive behavior in retailing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RETL 295.
name: Retailing Internship
description: Supervised work experience within the retail industry that links classroom learning and student interest with the acquisition of knowledge in an applied work setting.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPTE 240 or equivalent.
name: Legal Aspects of Entrepreneurship and E-Commerce
description: Examination of domestic and international laws affecting retail entrepreneurship and online commerce, such as data privacy and breach response, intellectual property protection, sales tax, advertising and unfair trade practices, consumer protection laws, employment laws, and legal obligations involving physical locations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPTE 240 or equivalent.
name: Fashion and the Law
description: Examination of domestic and international laws which affect the fashion industry, such as intellectual property protection, licensing agreements, operational and marketing issues, and international trade.

name: Retail Logistics
description: Examination of the flow of retail inventory from initial production to final purchase. Meets the needs of individuals in retail organizations from entry-level sales floor personnel to buyers. Students must be qualified to enroll in a 500 level course at The University of South Carolina.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RETL 351.
name: Retail and Fashion Business Planning
description: Essential skills for building a new or expanding an existing retail or fashion business in both brick-and-mortar and online venues by developing a marketing plan and corresponding e-Commerce website for a business or fashion organization.

name: Advanced Merchandising Management Strategies
description: The analysis of assortment planning and inventory management of apparel products utilizing merchandising principles and industry software.

name: Advanced Retail Promotion and Social Media Analytics
description: Essential principles and analytical tools used in retail promotion; appraisal of methods and outcomes via field experiences, visuals, and simulations.

name: Special Topics in Retail Management
description: Course content varies. May be repeated once under a different title.

name: Retailing/Fashion Merchandising Field Study
description: Study of international/domestic fashion manufacturers, retailers, ancillary businesses, and selected resident buying offices. May be repeated once for credit. Must be in good standing with a 2.0 GPA or better; No pending or past judicial council infractions.

name: Fundamentals of Omni-Channel Retailing
description: Exploration of the fundamentals of Omni-Channel Retailing.

name: Personnel Development & Relations Management
description: Advanced examination of human resource management within retail organizations.

name: Customer Relationship Management for the Retail Industry
description: The analysis of customer relationship management for retailers utilizing merchandising principles and industry software.

name: Elementary Russian
description: Grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Assumes no prior experience in the language.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RUSS 121.
name: Basic Proficiency in Russian
description: Practice and further development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RUSS 122 or satisfactory score on language placement test.
name: Intermediate Russian I
description: Continued exposure to the fundamentals of Russian grammar, along with increased focus on reading and speaking skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RUSS 201 or satisfactory score on language placement test.
name: Intermediate Russian II
description: Completion of exposure to the fundamentals of Russian grammar, with emphasis on writing, reading, and conversation.

name: Introduction to Russian Civilization
description: A multimedia introduction to Russian culture from its beginnings to the present. No knowledge of Russian required.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Selected Topics
description: Introductory-level study of selected topics in Russian culture. Does not apply toward the Russian major. May be repeated for credit under a different title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RUSS 202 or satisfactory score on language placement test.
name: Russian Conversation and Composition I
description: Conversation, reading, composition, comprehensive review of grammar.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RUSS 301 or satisfactory score on language placement test.
name: Russian Conversation and Composition II
description: Emphasis on oral proficiency, using contemporary authentic materials from Russian newspapers, textbooks, and television newscasts.

name: Nineteenth-Century Russian Literature in Translation
description: Masterworks of Russian literature by Tolstoy, Dostoevsky, Turgenev, Pushkin, Chekov, and others.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RUSS 302.
name: Nineteenth-Century Russian Literature in Russian
description: A Russian-language course designed to supplement 319. Reading and discussion in Russian of 19th-century poetry and prose.

name: Twentieth-Century Russian Literature in Translation
description: Masterworks of Russian literature by Bely, Pasternak, Bulgakov, Nabokov, Solzhenitsyn, and others.

name: Twentieth-Century Russian Literature in Russian
description: A Russian-language course designed to supplement RUSS 320.

name: Selected Topics
description: Intensive study of selected topics in Russian cultural and/or literary movements. Taught in English. May be repeated for credit under a different title.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RUSS 302 or satisfactory score on language placement test.
name: Advanced Russian I
description: Acquisition of subtleties of Russian grammar. Increased focus on reading, writing, and discussion.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RUSS 401 or satisfactory score on language placement test.
name: Advanced Russian II
description: Exposure to prose and poetry from a wide variety of sources and periods. Focus on oral proficiency, reading, comprehension, and writing.

name: Selected Topics in Russian
description: Reading and research on selected topics in Russian. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of courses by title.

name: Intensive Readings in Russian
description: Intensive reading course for non-majors. Primarily for graduate students to fulfill the foreign- language reading requirement. It will not be applied toward the degree language requirements nor will it be accepted as a substitute in the course sequence leading to the various degree requirements.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: RUSS 615.
name: Intensive Readings in Russian
description: Intensive reading course for non-majors. Primarily for graduate students to fulfill the foreign-language reading requirement. It will not be applied toward the degree language requirements nor will it be accepted as a substitute in the course sequence leading to the various degree requirements.

name: HNRS: Undergraduate Research
description: Student research supervised by a faculty member. Emphasis is on the development of critical thinking, appropriate research skills, and writing.

name: HNRS: Honors Internship
description: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing or above; Honors College; approval of honors dean required.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: HNRS: Senior Thesis/Project
description: Required of all students graduating with honors from South Carolina Honors College.

name: The Teacher as Manager
description: To help teachers, principals, and other personnel solve school problems by identifying and applying selected management techniques.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Resources for Teaching and Learning
description: An introduction to educational technology, its increasing importance in the total school program, and its relationship to learning theories and communication.

name: The Effective Teacher
description: Use of theory and research to understand and improve classroom teaching. Emphasis on teacher reflection and decision-making. The administrative role in enhancing effectiveness is highlighted.

name: Concepts and Connections: An Introduction to Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics
description: This course introduces concepts, connections, and evolving relationships among the sciences engineering and mathematics to strengthen understanding of current ideas and applications of advancing technologies.

name: Life Science for Teachers I
description: Topics appropriate for elementary and middle-school curricula; phylogenetic organization of major kingdoms, characteristics of plants and animals, including humans; ecological principles; communities; energy needs, resources, flow and balance; heredity and adaptation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: introductory-level courses in life, earth, and physical sciences.
name: Energy, Motion, and Matter
description: Integrated study of the earth�€�s atmosphere for pre-service and in-service middle school teachers combining concepts from earth, life, and physical science leading to an understanding of the interaction of all systems.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: introductory-level courses in life, earth, and physical sciences.
name: Interdependence of Living Systems
description: Integrated study of the biotic and abiotic environments combining life, earth, and physical science concepts to understand relationships in living systems. For pre-service and in-service middle school teachers.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: introductory-level courses in life, earth, and physical sciences.
name: Origin and Evolution of Living and Non-Living Systems
description: Study of the earth system for pre-service and in-service middle school teachers, with emphasis on the origin, evolution, and interactions of the subsystems of the earth system.

name: Data Analysis for Teachers
description: Introduction to statistics for elementary, middle, and high school teachers. The fundamentals of data collection, descriptive statistics, probability, and inference with special focus on methods of teaching statistical reasoning. For M.A.T. (excluding mathematics) / M.Ed. / M.T. and nondegree credit only. For M.A.T. (excluding mathematics) / M.Ed. / M.T. and nondegree credit only.

name: Introduction to Careers in Education
description: An individualized survey of careers in education, utilizing practica, seminars, and input from various disciplines to focus on personal and professional development. Pass-fail credit.

name: Practicum in Education
description: A sequence of supervised practica in various educational settings. Seminars and group discussions included.

name: Practicum in Education
description: A sequence of supervised practica in various educational settings. Seminars and group discussions included.

name: Practicum in Education
description: A sequence of supervised practica in various educational settings. Seminars and group discussions included.

name: Practicum in Education
description: A sequence of supervised practica in various educational settings. Seminars and group discussions included.

name: Practicum in Education
description: A sequence of supervised practica in various educational settings. Seminars and group discussions included.

name: Practicum in Education
description: A sequence of supervised practica in various educational settings. Seminars and group discussions included.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Practicum in Education
description: A sequence of supervised practica in various educational settings. Seminars and group discussions included.

name: Secondary School Curriculum
description: The organization, historical context, foundations for curriculum development, process of curriculum planning, design of the curriculum, and strategy of curriculum change in the secondary school. A laboratory experience in teaching media is included. Open only to juniors and seniors or graduates completing certification requirements.

name: Directed Teaching in High School (Business Education)
Directed Teaching in High School (History and Social Studies)
Directed Teaching in High School (Distributive Education)
Directed Teaching in High School (Theatre and Speech)
Secondary Student Teaching Seminar
description: Classroom management, discipline, legal responsibilities, multicultural perspectives, and needs of exceptional children.

name: Equity and Community Engagement
description: Field-based inquiry into theories of critical multicultural education, culturally relevant and equity pedagogies with an emphasis on middle/high school students and engaging parents and the larger school community.

name: Teachers and Teaching
description: Teaching as reflective and ethical practice. Professional standards, teacher leadership and school change, and various roles of professional educators.

name: Teaching Middle and High School (Business Education)
description: A study of methods, techniques, and materials of instruction in middle and high school business education.

name: Study of the Teaching of Business Education in the Secondary School
description: Teaching techniques and methodology related to the business education curriculum, emerging technology and software.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Admission to MAT program for graduate students; EDSE 402 for undergraduate students.
name: Teaching Middle and High School (English)
description: A study of methods, techniques, and materials of instruction in middle and high school English.

name: Earth Science for Teachers I
description: Origin, internal structure and internal processes of the earth, including plate tectonics, earthquakes, volcanoes, and mountain building. Required field trips, two lectures, and three lab hours per week. Cannot be used in MS or PhD programs in geology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: EDSE 548/GEOL 540.
name: Earth Science for Teachers II
description: Surface processes acting on the earth; introduction to weather and climate, weathering, erosion, and sedimentary processes; land form evolution; ocean currents and tides, near-shore geologic processes. Required field trips, two lecture, and three lab hours per week. Cannot be used in MS or PhD programs in geology.

name: Teaching Middle and High School (Mathematics)
description: A study of methods, techniques, and materials of instruction in middle and high school mathematics.

name: Teaching Middle and High School (Health)
description: A study of methods, techniques, and materials of instruction in middle and high school health.

name: Teaching Middle and High School (Marketing Education)
description: A study of methods, techniques, and materials of instruction in middle and high school marketing education.

name: Teaching Middle and High School (Science)
description: A study of methods, techniques, and materials of instruction in middle and high school science.

name: Teaching Middle and High School (Theatre and Speech)
description: A study of methods, techniques, and materials of instruction in middle and high school theatre and speech.

name: Teaching Middle and High School (History and Social Studies)
description: A study of methods, techniques, and materials of instruction in middle and high school history and social studies.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 210 level of a foreign language or its equivalent.
name: Teaching Foreign Languages in Secondary Schools
description: Current methods, techniques, and materials of instruction appropriate for secondary schools.

requisiteText: Corequisite: LATN 580.
name: Teaching Advanced Latin in Secondary School
description: Methods and materials for teaching the Latin Advanced Placement courses in secondary school.

requisiteText: Corequisite: Internship II.
name: Middle and High School Internship Seminar
description: Classroom management, service learning, legal/professional responsibilities, multicultural perspectives and needs of exceptional children.

requisiteText: Corequisite: Students must be enrolled in the Internship I field experiences.
name: Secondary Internship Seminar I
description: Integration of content, pedagogy, and disposition knowledge learned during coursework with Internship I field experiences.

requisiteText: Corequisite: Students must be enrolled in the Internship II field experiences.
name: Secondary Internship Seminar II
description: Integration of content, pedagogy, and disposition knowledge learned during coursework with Internship II field experiences.

name: Teaching Mathematics with Manipulatives, Grades 7-12
description: Methods and materials for using manipulative devices to teach middle and high school level mathematics.

name: Graphics Calculators in High School Mathematics
description: Methods and materials for using graphics calculators to teach algebra, elementary functions, and analytic geometry.

name: Social Advocacy and Ethical Life
description: Introduction to nature and relationship of ethics and oral forms of advocacy. Includes foundational training in ethical theory and its relevance to socio-political expression and training in the principles and performance of ethical oral communication, with emphasis on argumentation and audience engagement.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Introduction to Social Work
description: This course introduces students to the history and contemporary context of the social work profession, including generalist practice and the role of advocacy. It emphasizes responses to current needs and changing contexts.

name: Social Welfare Policies and Programs
description: This course introduces students to the historical and current context of social welfare policies and programs in the United States, including examination of social inequalities and the processes of social policy development.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101, SOCY 101, or SOWK 201.
name: Social Work With Children, Youth, and Families
description: This course introduces the context for social work with children, youth, and families as well as specific theories, policies, programs, and services. Areas examined include antipoverty policies and programs, child welfare, education, behavioral health, healthcare, disabilities, and juvenile justice.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101, SOCY 101, or SOWK 201.
name: Social Work With Older Adults and Families
description: This course introduces students to the context for social work with older adults, as well as specific theories, policies, programs, and services. Areas examined include the aging process, health and wellness, behavioral health, sexuality, work and retirement, bereavement, living arrangements and housing options, and social programs and policies targeting older adults.

name: Gender, Race and Social Justice
description: This course introduces anti-oppressive theoretical and applied approaches to understand and address intersections of gender and racial inequality. Social welfare policies and services available to women in contexts such as criminal justice, behavioral health, child welfare, and the military are examined.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101, SOCY 101, or SOWK 201.
name: Global Inequalities and Social Justice
description: This course introduces students to global dimensions of social inequality, beginning with the historical roots of global social inequality and moving through contemporary themes relevant to international social work practice from an anti-colonial perspective. Topics examined include human rights, gender-based violence, global health, climate change, and immigration/displacement.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: PSYC 101, or SOCY 101, or SOWK 201.
name: Life Transitions: Loss and Grief
description: This course will examine the grief and loss process that is part of everyday life. This course surveys the knowledge and skills of human service practice with people as they cope with life transitions.

name: Foundations of Social Work Practice
description: This course introduces students to the context and mission of social work. It emphasizes the interactions between personal and professional values, ethical and professional behavior, and beginning engagement and interpersonal skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SOWK 311.
name: Social Work Practice with Individuals and Families
description: This course introduces students to engagement, assessment, intervention, and evaluation with individuals and families. It includes specific models and techniques of practice with an emphasis on managing barriers to change, client strengths, and understanding diversity and difference in practice.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SOWK 201, SOWK 222.
name: Social Policy Analysis
description: Knowledge, values, and skills for social work practitioners to analyze the political and ideological factors and outcomes of policy development, implementation, evaluation, and advocacy.

name: Diversity and Social Justice in Contemporary Society
description: Builds cultural competency through awareness, understanding, and skill necessary for proactive functioning in our diverse society with populations considered vulnerable and oppressed.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SOWK 201.
name: Theories for Understanding Individuals, Families, and Groups
description: This course focuses on theories for understanding individual, family, and group behavior to better serve clients across settings. It emphasizes diversity, difference, and the advancement of human rights and social, economic, and environmental justice.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SOWK 201, SOWK 222 and select one course from the following: STAT 201 or higher, PSYC 227 or SOCY 220.
name: Social Work and Scientific Inquiry
description: Foundational knowledge and skills for scientific inquiry and the use of quantitative and qualitative research to inform evidence-based practice.

name: Refuge and Refugees
description: This course provides students with foundational knowledge about forced migration and the institutions of humanitarian aid that address forced migration. Students will learn about global theories of forced migration, humanitarian aid policy, empirical studies of humanitarian aid, refugee resettlement, and displacement, and evaluate biographies and literature on forced migration.

name: Special Topics in Social Work
description: An in-depth study of selected issues and social concerns related to being a generalist social worker. Content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SOWK 311.
name: Introduction to Field Education
description: An initial application of generalist social work skills and theories taught in a controlled and planned classroom setting.

name: Independent Study
description: Requires permission of the department.

name: Current Issues in Social Welfare
description: A project-type study of selected issues, social concerns, and applications of behavioral implications for practice. May be repeated for credit when the topics covered or subject matter is different.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SOWK 312.
name: Social Work Practice with Groups
description: This course introduces students to engagement, assessment, intervention, and evaluation with treatment and task groups. It includes specific models and techniques of practice with an emphasis on group practice with diverse populations across practice settings.

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: C or better in SOWK 411.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: SOWK 441.
name: Social Work Practice with Organizations and Communities
description: This course introduces students to engagement, assessment, intervention, and evaluation with organizations and communities. It includes specific models and techniques of practice with an emphasis on diversity, difference, and the advancement of human rights and social, economic, and environmental justice.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SOWK 322.
name: Advocacy for Social and Economic Justice
description: Knowledge and skills embedded in values of social and economic justice for all people across systems of all sizes that are essential in generalist practice.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Theories for Understanding Organizations and Communities
description: This course focuses on theories for understanding large social systems to better serve clients across settings. It emphasizes diversity, difference, and the advancement of human rights and social, economic, and environmental justice.

requisiteText:
Corequisite: SOWK 483.
Prerequisite or Corequisite: SOWK 322.
name: Practicum I: Field Education
description: Application of skills and theories taught in the classroom in a controlled and planned setting.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: SOWK 412, SOWK 422, SOWK 484.
name: Practicum II: Field Education
description: Further application of the generalist social work skills and theories taught in the classroom in a controlled and planned setting.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText:
Prerequisites: SOWK 382.
Corequisite: SOWK 481.
name: Practicum Seminar
description: Taken with the field practicum, this seminar facilitates student's integration of generalist practice knowledge with practice in a field agency.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

requisiteText: Corequisite: SOWK 482.
name: Capstone
description: Competent generalist social work practice demands integration of a wide range of theories, knowledge, skills, and values. This course is designed to draw on all previous courses and to engage students in integrating and applying all that they have learned.

name: Special Topics in Social Work
description: Study of special populations, settings, and/or problems encountered by social workers and other human service professionals, and interventions and skills for dealing with them. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Transforming Health Care for the Future
description: Foundation for beginning health professions students to gain an understanding of the complexities of the health care system through experiential activities conducted in interprofessional teams and the importance of interprofessional collaboration in order to improve the system.

name: Addressing Childhood Obesity through Community Approaches
description: Approaches for prevention of childhood obesity, using perspectives from public health, social work, exercise science, pharmacy, medicine, and behavioral nutrition. Training to teach diet/physical activity lessons in elementary school settings.

name: Introductory Sociology
description: An introduction to sociological facts and principles: an analysis of group-making processes and products.

name: Social Structures
description: Selected theoretical orientations, methodological procedures, and illustrative substantive data pertaining to social structures.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SOCY 101.
name: Sex and Gender
description: Offers a sociological lens to develop critical ways of thinking about sex and gender as social processes in everyday lives. This course considers how sex and gender shape and affect the experiences of women, men, girls, boys, and individuals who live in the spaces in-between (those who are intersex or transgender) across a wide range of social institutions (family, work, education, politics, etc.).
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SOCY 101.
name: Race, Class, Gender, and Sexuality
description: Historical and contemporary power relationships in race, social class, gender, and sexual orientation.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SOCY 101.
name: Sociology of Families
description: Sociological perspectives related to various aspects of family behaviors, roles, and values.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Sociology of Religion
description: Sociological perspectives related to selected aspects of religious behavior. Includes references to non-Western religions.

name: Community Organization
description: An analysis of formal and informal organization, the interrelationships among public and private agencies, and means through which community action programs are initiated, coordinated, and maintained.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: An Introduction to Social Inequality
description: A sociological analysis of the distribution of wealth and income in selected societies.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Social Demography
description: Introduction to key areas of population studies. Methodological approaches, time trends, regional differences, and contemporary policy issues.

name: Ecology of Human Social Systems
description: Relationships among and changes in populations, social organization, technology, and the environment.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Bureaucracy and Modern Society
description: Bureaucracies in the public and private sector, their internal dynamics and relationship to the social environment.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Sociology of Aging
description: Analysis of aging as a process of socialization and the status of older people in society, their roles in the community, demographic aspects of aging, and the impact of aging upon social institutions.

name: Global Population Issues
description: Overview of global population history, theory, statistics, and issues related to recent population trends.

name: Individual and Society
description: Selected theoretical orientations, methodological procedures, and illustrative substantive data pertaining to the relations between the individual and society.

name: Sociology of Suicide
description: An introductory survey of the social aspects of suicidal behaviors and attitudes.

name: Sociology of Deviant Behavior
description: Theories, methodology, and substantive issues in the study of social deviance.

name: Sociology of Childhood
description: A consideration of the child in the family group, play group, school group, and community.

name: Sociology of Adolescence
description: Sociological perspectives and research findings related to adolescence.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SOCY 101.
name: Sociology of the Paranormal
description: A critical examination of factors that lead to the widespread acceptance of paranormal claims.

name: Introduction to Social Problems
description: Contemporary social issues such as poverty, health, the criminal justice system, globalization and the environment, their causes and possible solutions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SOCY 101.
name: Juvenile Delinquency
description: Social factors in the development, identification, and treatment of delinquents.

name: Urban Sociology
description: Analysis of urban trends, characteristics, and functions of cities with reference to the social psychological factors in urban living. Attention is directed to the emergence of urbanism in the United States, with particular reference to the Southern region, and to institutions, problems, and city planning.

name: Sociology of Crime
description: Social factors in the development, identification, and treatment of criminals.

name: Collective Behavior
description: An analysis of crowds, publics, social movements, and the mass society in terms of their institutional and social psychological consequences.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Race and Ethnic Relations
description: Theoretical and empirical approaches related to race/ethnicity and the current state of race relations in America, with some attention to global issues.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Sociology of Education
description: Analysis of educational institutions, organizations, processes, and their effects in contemporary society.

name: Sociology of Medicine and Health
description: Health and illness in relation to social institutions. The organization and professionalization of medicine and social barriers to medical care.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SOCY 101.
name: Society through Visual Media
description: Analysis of social phenomena and sociological questions through various forms of media, including films, TV, photography, and other visual media.

name: Sociology of Sport
description: Theories, methods, and substantive issues in the study of sport in contemporary societies.

name: Topics in Sociology
description: Reading and research on selected sociological topics. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Social Networks
description: Analysis of personal, social and organizational networks, their structural patterns, practical consequences, and principles of formation and change.

name: Political Sociology
description: Theory and research concerning the interrelationship between the polity and social structures.

name: Family and Social Stratification
description: An analysis of the contemporary American family emphasizing social stratification, mobility, occupations, and urbanization.

name: Social Stratification
description: Theory and research in social stratification.

name: Social Structures in Communities
description: Interrelationships of major social structures within communities.

name: Social Organizations
description: Selected theoretical orientation, methodological procedures, and illustrative substantive issues pertaining to organizations.

name: Sociology of Social Control
description: Theories and issues relating to the definition of and response to crime and/or deviance.

name: Advanced Social Structures
description: The analysis of core methodological and substantive issues in the study of social structures.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SOCY 310.
name: Life Course Demographics
description: People's demographic lives, structural contexts, and social change. Emphasis on the socioeconomic context in which lives unfold.

name: Sociology of Mental Health
description: Social factors in the development, identification, and treatment of mental illness.

name: Internal and International Migration
description: A survey of methods of analysis and research findings with emphasis on the social and economic concomitants of internal migration. Cultural, economic, and historical aspects of international migration. Effects of governmental policies on immigration and emigration. Examination of selected countries.

name: Urbanization
description: Analysis of urbanization using contemporary and historical data from developing societies. The demographic components of metropolitan growth and the changing structure of metropolitan communities.

name: Scientific Methods and Sociological Inquiry
description: Introduction to methods used to answer theoretical, empirical, and practical sociological questions, including scientific inquiry and research design.

name: Advanced Social Psychology
description: Advanced survey of social psychological perspectives and research on inequality, discrimination, power and status, cooperation and collective action, social norm and morality, networks and relationships.

name: Small Group Analysis
description: A behavioral analysis of small groups.

name: Power and Authority Structures in Groups
description: An exploration of theoretical perspectives, methodological approaches, and substantive issues in the study of interpersonal power and authority.

name: Social Processes of Deviance Control
description: A systematic analysis of the interrelation among the creation, involvement, recognition, and control of deviance.

name: Interpersonal Behavior in Families
description: Social psychological perspectives on family behavior.

name: Selves and Social Transaction
description: A systematic analysis of interrelationships among social acts, selves, roles, transactions, and language.

name: Sociology of Law
description: Review of theoretical and empirical developments in the sociology of law, including classical and modern sociological theories of law and selected sociological themes of law in various social settings.

name: Sociology of Science
description: Interrelationships among society, culture, and contemporary science.

name: Sociology of Education and Inequality
description: Advanced inquiry into the relationship between education and inequality.

name: Advanced Sociological Theory
description: Theoretical perspectives on society and social behavior.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SOCY 101, SOCY 391, and SOCY 392.
name: Real World Research Experience
description: Design and conduct of original research using sociological research methods to meet Carolina Core Integrative course requirement for the BA and the BS.

name: Advanced Sociological Research Methods
description: Advanced survey of methods used in sociological research.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SOCY 101.
name: Selected Topics
description: Readings and research on selected sociological topics. Course and content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SOCY 101.
name: Advanced Independent Study
description: Advanced Independent study. Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SOCY 101.
name: Special Topics
description: Reading and research.

name: Topics in the American South
description: Reading and research on selected interdisciplinary topics in Southern Studies. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated for credit under a different title.

name: Topics in South Carolina
description: Reading and research on selected interdisciplinary topics about South Carolina. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated for credit under a different title.

name: The Contemporary South
description: An investigation of Southern regional identity.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and program director is required for undergraduates.

name: Topics in Southern Studies
description: Reading and research on selected topics in Southern studies. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.

name: Topics in the American South
description: Selected topics related to the study of the American South. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.

name: Beginning Spanish I
description: Introduction to grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Restricted to those who have never studied Spanish or placed by examination into SPAN 109. Credit may be received only for one of the following: SPAN 109, SPAN 110; SPAN 111; or SPAN 121.

name: Beginning Spanish II
description: Introduction to grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Restricted to those who have completed SPAN 109. Credit may be received only for one of the following: SPAN 109, SPAN 110; SPAN 111; or SPAN 121.

name: Intensive Beginning Spanish
description: Intensive introduction to grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Admission only to highly motivated beginning students who obtain the permission of the department. Credit may be received only for one of the following: SPAN 109, SPAN 110, SPAN 111, or SPAN 121.

name: Elementary Spanish
description: Grammar and vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Assumes prior experience in Spanish. Admission only by proficiency examination. Credit may be received for only one of the following: SPAN 109, SPAN 110, SPAN 111, or SPAN 121.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in SPAN 109 and SPAN 110, or SPAN 111, or SPAN 121 or by placement examination.
name: Basic Proficiency in Spanish
description: Practice and further development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SPAN 122 or by Placement Exam.
name: Intermediate Spanish I
description: Further development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills. Use of authentic cultural materials.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SPAN 209 or by Placement Exam.
name: Intermediate Spanish II
description: Continued development of the four skills practiced in SPAN 209.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPAN 122 or placement at 209 level on Phase II placement exam.
name: Intensive Intermediate Spanish
description: Further development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills. Designed for highly motivated students. Credit not awarded for both SPAN 209-SPAN 210 and SPAN 211.

name: Selected Works of Hispanic Literature in English Translation
description: Selected major works, especially contemporary works, in all genres of Hispanic literature in English translation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPAN 210.
name: Service Learning in Spanish
description: Contract approved by instructor, director, and department chair required. May be repeated. Maximum of 3 hours may apply towards major or minor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: B or better in SPAN 210, SPAN 211 or SPAN 230 or by placement.
name: Advanced Spanish
description: In-depth study of advanced grammatical structures of Spanish to develop proficiency in all 4 skills and cultural competency. Gateway course for Spanish majors.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SPAN 302 or by placement.
name: Cultural Readings and Advanced Composition
description: Development of advanced composition skills in Spanish on a variety of topics related to cultural production of the Spanish-speaking world.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SPAN 302 or by placement.
name: Cultural Readings and Advanced Conversation
description: Cultural readings about the Spanish-speaking world, and advanced speaking skills practice through various strategies such as group discussions, debates, presentations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: B or better in SPAN 210 or SPAN 211; placement at 300 level on Phase II placement exam.
name: Working with Hispanic Clients
description: Crosscultural approaches to interactions with persons of Hispanic origin in a variety of professional settings. Readings, speakers, media. Taught in Spanish. Departmental permission required for transfer students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Placement by Phase II Exam.
name: Spanish for Heritage Speakers
description: Intensive grammar practice, enhancement of reading and writing skills for individuals raised in a Spanish-speaking household but with little or no formal Spanish instruction. Restricted to heritage speakers, as defined in Bulletin description.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPAN 303 or by placement. D or better for non-Spanish majors. C or better for Spanish majors and minors.
name: Introduction to Reading Hispanic Literary Texts
description: Approaches to reading literary texts through carefully selected readings from different genres.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SPAN 302 or by placement.
name: Business Spanish
description: Commercial organizations and business in Spanish-speaking countries, business correspondence, terminology, and techniques in commercial transactions. Standardized examinations available such as the Certificado de la Camara de Comercio de Madrid.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C+ or better in SPAN 302; placement at 300 level of Phase II placement exam.
name: Spanish Phonetics and Pronunciation
description: Analysis of and practice in pronunciation, listening comprehension, and dialect recognition based on study of the speech sounds, combinations, patterns, and processes of Spanish phonetics and phonology. Department permission required for transfer students.

name: Spanish Language Study Abroad
description: Intensive language practice in native environment with emphasis on oral skills. Instruction by native speakers; community contact, and home stay. May be repeated once for credit. Restricted to participants of the USC Spanish Summer Global Classroom Program.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPAN 302 or by placement.
name: Spanish for Healthcare Professionals
description: Health professionals' functional and lexical language ability, cultural information, etiquette and protocol necessary to interact with Spanish speakers.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SPAN 303 or by placement.
name: Special Topics in Hispanic Literature
description: Course content treating cultural and literary themes varies.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in SPAN 302; Placement Exam score of SD or S7.
name: Special Topics in Hispanic Language and Culture
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPAN 303 or by placement.
name: The Cinema of Spain
description: Investigation of Spanish cultures through the study of its films and the cinematic medium.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Placement at 300 level on Phase II placement exam, grade of C+ or better in SPAN 303, or consent of instructor. Department permission required for transfer students.
name: The Cinema of Latin America
description: Investigation of Latin American cultures through the study of films and the cinematic medium.

name: Special Topics in Hispanic Studies
description: Intensive study of selected topics of the Hispanic world. Taught in English.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: B or better in SPAN 210 or SPAN 211; Placement at 300 level on Phase II placement exam.
name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students. Department permission required for transfer students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Placement at 300-level on Phase II placement exam or C or better in SPAN 303. Department permission required for transfer students.
name: Spanish Culture
description: Survey of the cultures of Spain via readings, visual culture, and discussion.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Placement at 300-level on Phase II placement exam or C or better in SPAN 303. Department permission required for transfer students.
name: Latin American Culture
description: Survey of the cultures of Latin America via readings, visual culture, and discussion.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SPAN 312.
name: Spanish Literature
description: A survey of literature, such as novels, short stories and poems, from Spain.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPAN 312.
name: Latin American Literature
description: A survey of literature, such as novels, short stories and poems, from Latin America.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPAN 316.
name: Advanced Spanish for Business and the Professions
description: Vocabulary, concepts, and oral/written skills necessary to communicate effectively in the social, cultural, or economic infrastructure of Hispanic countries. Introduction to the use of technology for the acquisition and processing of materials relevant to students�€� professional goals.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in SPAN 312 or by placement.
name: Advanced Special Topics in Hispanic Literature
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated as content varies by title.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in SPAN 303 or by placement.
name: Advanced Special Topics in Hispanic Language and Culture
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated as content varies by title. This course will be taught in Spanish.

name: Advanced Special Topics in Hispanic Studies
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated as content varies by title. Taught in English.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: 3.00 GPA; 18 hours of 300-level Spanish.
name: Senior Seminar
description: A special seminar devoted to the in-depth study of selected subjects in Hispanic literature, culture, or language. Required for the intensive major in Spanish.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPAN 303 for Undergraduates, Phase II placement exam above SPAN 303.
name: Contemporary Spain
description: Analysis and discussion of 20th-century Spanish history and the sociocultural forces that have contributed to define this country�€�s national identity. Taught in Spanish.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: Placement at 300-level on Phase II placement exam or C or better in SPAN 303. Department permission required for transfer students.
name: Contemporary Latin America
description: Analysis and discussion of contemporary Latin American history and the sociocultural forces that have contributed to define this area's national identities. Taught in Spanish.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPAN 409.
name: Introduction to Professional and Technical Translation
description: Introduction to translation and practice of skills required for professional and technical Spanish/English translation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SPAN 303.
name: Introduction to Spanish Linguistics
description: Phonology, morphology, and syntax of modern Spanish.

name: The Structure of Modern Spanish
description: Description of the grammatical structures of Modern Spanish. Intensive study of the theory and practice of word formation and sentence structure of Spanish.

name: Contrastive English-Spanish Phonetics and Phonology
description: Introduction to the study of phonetics and phonology and their application to the sounds and sound systems of English and Spanish. Includes transcription practice and discussion of relevance to teaching.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SPAN 312 for undergraduates.
name: Introduction to Spanish Medieval Literature
description: Survey of Spanish literature from its first manifestations to La Celestina. Introduction; early works; the epic; 13th- through 15th-century prose and verse; Berceo, Alfonso X, Juan Ruiz, Marques de Santillana; others.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SPAN 312 for undergraduates.
name: Renaissance and Golden Age Literature
description: Survey of the works of Garcilaso, the Spanish mystics, Lope, Quevedo, Tirso, Calderon, Gongora and others.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPAN 312 for undergraduates.
name: Nineteenth-Century Spanish Literature
description: Survey of the works of the major literary figures of the period.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPAN 312 for Undergraduates.
name: Twentieth-Century Spanish Literature
description: Survey of major peninsular writers from the Generation of �€�98 to the present.

name: Colonial Spanish-American Literature to Neoclassicism
description: Survey of pre-Columbian poetry and of texts dating from the time of Columbus to the end of the Colonial period.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SPAN 312 for undergraduates.
name: Spanish-American Literature from the Independence Through Modernism
description: Survey of the most significant works of the Independence through Modernism.

name: Advanced Language Study Abroad
description: Intensive language practice in native environment with special emphasis on oral skills. Instruction by native speakers; extensive community contact and home stay. Prior placement test required.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SPAN 312 for undergraduates.
name: Spanish-American Literature from Modernism Through 1960
description: Survey of the most significant works of this period.

name: Contemporary Spanish-American Literature
description: Survey of the most significant works from 1960 to the present.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: D or better in SPAN 312 or graduate standing.
name: Special Topics in Spanish
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated as content varies by title.

name: Intensive Readings in Spanish
description: Intensive reading for non-majors. Graduate students fulfill their foreign-language requirement with successful completion of the course. Undergraduates may take the course as an elective only by permission.

name: Public Communication
description: Introduction to theory and practice of oral communication in public, social, and institutional contexts. Includes foundational and cumulative training in the invention, performance, and critical analysis of oral communication, with emphasis on argumentation, persuasion, audience analysis, delivery, and ethical forms of engagement.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Online Public Communication
description: Introduction to theory and practice of live and recorded online spoken communication in public, social, and institutional contexts. Training in invention, performance, and critical analysis of online spoken communication, including audience analysis, persuasion, delivery, and ethical engagement. Includes significant practice in preparing and presenting live online public communication.

name: Public Speaking Anxiety Reduction
description: Exercises and techniques to reduce and manage public speaking anxiety. Ideally taken concurrently with any course that requires multiple presentations.

name: Popular Communication and Public Culture
description: Examination of historical and popular communication conflicts, texts, and events. Offers an introduction to critical concepts and analysis of public speech, rhetoric, and cultural discourse.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Communicating Moral Issues
description: Moral issues confronting men and women in contemporary society and the challenges of communicating effectively about them. Topics will vary but may include access to health care, euthanasia, abortion, same sex marriage and the moral and environmental consequences of eating animals.

name: Business and Professional Speaking
description: Fundamentals of oral communication within business and professional settings. Includes performance.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Argumentation and Debate
description: Preparing and delivering the debate. Academic debate serves as a model.

name: Small Group Communication
description: The development of the skills and methods of effective participation in teams, committees, and other small groups.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Organizational Communication
description: Examines communication behavior and networks within organizations through the study of major theories of organizational communication, identifies and defines primary concepts, and applies them to organizational scenarios and case studies.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Literature and Performance
description: Introduction to the study of literature through performance; reading, analysis, and performance of prose, poetry, nonfiction, and drama.

name: Persuasive Communication
description: Analysis of the process and functions of persuasive communication.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101; ENGL 102.
name: Introduction to Rhetoric
description: Theories of human communication useful for understanding and informing the everyday work of writers. Emphasis on intensive analysis and writing.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Independent Study and Research
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Arguments in Cultural Studies
description: The study of texts and discourse from contemporary culture drawing from concepts such as politics, television, music, and other popular culture and entertainment.

name: Rhetorical Criticism
description: Interpretation and evaluation of communication texts and events such as speeches, media, and social movements. Employs a variety of critical methods and approaches.

name: Contemporary Political Rhetoric
description: Analysis and evaluation of speeches, political campaigns and controversies over political representation and recognition. Focus on case studies that illustrate the role of speech-making in political campaigns. Offered only in fall semesters in which national elections are held.

name: Great Debates
description: A study of debates at the Constitutional Convention, Lincoln-Douglas debates (1858), vice presidential and presidential debates, and other national debates.

name: Speechwriting
description: An exploration of the process of advanced policy advocacy emphasizing speechwriting strategies, issues management, and systematic advocacy campaigns.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101, ENGL 102.
name: Rhetoric of Science and Technology
description: Rhetorical study of science and technology in contemporary culture, emphasizing the ways scientific texts and technologies make their persuasive appeals.

name: Rhetoric and the Ancient Roots of Modern Life
description: Classical rhetoric and its ongoing influence in the modern world, emphasizing how the study and use of language in ancient Greece and Rome continue to shape modern communication.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101; ENGL 102.
name: Rhetoric and Popular Culture
description: Rhetorical study of popular culture, using the methods and theories of cultural analysis to examine how various popular cultural forms work as persuasion.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 and ENGL 102.
name: Women�€�s Rhetoric
description: Study of rhetoric by and about women as manifested in speeches, essays, and other rhetorical artifacts.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: African-American Rhetoric
description: African-American rhetoric as manifested in speeches, essays, and other rhetorical artifacts.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Special Topics in Speech
description: Reading and research on selected topics. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated once as topics vary.

name: Communication, Law, and Society
description: Examines the role of communication in legal and judicial contexts. Focus on case studies that illustrate the theoretical and practical significance of rhetoric in the work of the courts, lawyers, and public advocacy groups.

name: The Student-Athlete Experience
description: Examination of the functions and resources the university provides for students transitioning to college and the problems common to the first-year student-athlete experience.

name: Sport and Entertainment in American Life
description: The American sport and entertainment enterprise: background, influences, and trends; collegiate and professional sport organizations; ownership and unionization; media portrayals.

name: Sport and Entertainment Careers
description: Introduction of networking, interviewing, and career planning in the sport and entertainment industry.

name: Introduction to Sport Management
description: Introduction to sport management industry career fields.

name: Introduction to Live Entertainment Management
description: The study of underlying themes in entertainment management and its application to music, family shows, and other live entertainment business venues.

name: Introduction to Event and Venue Management
description: An overview of the history, impact, types, and trends of events and venues, the principles of event planning, the role of venues, and career options in each field.

name: Business Law
description: Formation of contracts and their operation as they apply to business; promissory notes and checks; agency and employment.

name: Computer Applications in Hospitality, Retail, and Sport Management
description: Administrative tasks for computer usage, including software and hardware selection, applications, and solutions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPTE 195, SPTE 201, SPTE 202, SPTE 203, SPTE 274 and MKTG 350.
name: Internship I in Sport and Entertainment Management
description: Supervised work experience in a sport or entertainment management area selected by the student with approval of advisor. Contract approved by advisor or department chair is required for undergraduate students.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPTE 202.
name: Artist Representation and Management
description: This course focuses on the role of the manager in the entertainment industry and his or her relationships with artists, agents, buyers and industry executives.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPTE 202.
name: Live Entertainment Tour Management
description: This course puts a fine point on performance tour management logistics, including booking, scheduling, shipping, budgeting, movement of equipment, and artist management challenges, including entertainment production.

name: The Business of NASCAR
description: The course is designed to present an overall view of the NASCAR industry through a series of guest speakers, who are subject matter experts in their respective NASCAR-related fields.

name: Collegiate Athletics
description: Students are provided with an overview of college athletics. Though the course will cover the NJCAA and NAIA, it will particularly focus upon the NCAA, and more specifically, upon the business of �€�Big-Time�€? intercollegiate athletics.

name: NCAA Compliance
description: Students will gain a basic understanding of NCAA Division I rules and regulations while learning how the rules are applied to member institution. An overview of the operations of an NCAA Division I compliance office and coaching regulations will be provided as well.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPTE 240 or equivalent.
name: Sport and the Law
description: Laws and regulatory bodies affecting the management of sport personnel, facilities, and events.

name: Resort and Club Recreation Programming
description: Management of club and resort sport complexes.

name: The Summer Olympic Games
description: Examination of the Summer Olympic Games and its impact on sport, entertainment, hospitality, tourism and the host community.

name: The Business of Baseball
description: Overall view of the sport of baseball from a business perspective.

name: The Sporting Goods Industry
description: Principles of manufacturing and retailing applied to the sporting goods industry.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPTE 240 or ACCT 324 or equivalent.
name: Sport and Entertainment Contracts and Negotiations
description: The formation and negotiation of contracts in Sport and Entertainment Management.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPTE 240 or ACCT 324 or equivalent.
name: Risk Management in Sport and Entertainment
description: Theoretical and practical approaches to managing risk in Sport and Entertainment venues and events.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MKTG 350.
