name: Sport and Entertainment Marketing
description: Marketing theory and practice and how it relates and applies to sport and entertainment.

name: Ethics in Sport and Entertainment Business
description: The objective of this course is to familiarize students with the ethical issues that exist in the business of sport and entertainment. Students will learn theories of ethics and how they relate to issues faced by managers in the sport and entertainment industry. Ethical theories and philosophies �€“ deontology, utilitarianism, and virtue - will be driving the discussions and understandings of ethical decision-making in this class.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Independent Study
description: Students will have an opportunity to explore a specific area of sport and entertainment management. Individual students will indentify an area of study related to sport and entertainment management and complete a research paper on this topic under the guidance of the instructor.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPTE 240.
name: Entertainment and the Law
description: Performing arts and entertainment industries�€� social, economic, and legal issues, in addition to the development and role of entertainment in society, will be analyzed�€“from its roots to the present.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPTE 202 and MKTG 350.
name: Promoting Entertainment Events
description: This course should provide students with an understanding of various methods of promotion and approaches to the application of advertising and publicity in the broad spectrum of modern media.

name: Sport and Entertainment in Popular Culture
description: Investigation of sport and entertainment as critical facets of American society.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MKTG 350.
name: Sport and Entertainment Services Marketing
description: Basic principles required to promote a service marketing strategy in sport and entertainment.

name: Spectator Facilities Management
description: Programming, marketing, public relations, fiscal considerations, operation, labor relations, personnel, and event management for spectator sports and entertainment events.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: FINA 363 or FINA 333.
name: Sport and Entertainment Business and Finance
description: Economic and finance theories applied to the management of sport and entertainment organizations.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPTE 380, SPTE 440.
name: Sports and Entertainment Event Management
description: Application of management principles to sports and entertainment events.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MKTG 350.
name: Sales in Sport and Entertainment Business
description: Students will be provided with an overview of the sales process and learn how the sales process applies to sport and entertainment while using hands on exercises to perpetuate the understanding of the importance of sales.

name: Special Topics in Sport and Entertainment Management
description: Current topics and trends in sport, live entertainment, and venue management. Content varies by title. May be repeated once.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SPTE 440 and SPTE 444; 114 credit hours.
name: Internship II in Sport and Entertainment Management
description: Placement with a sport or entertainment organization for a supervised learning experience in the student�€�s career specialization area.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Internships

name: Research Experience
description: Working with a faculty mentor, students develop a research project and related research skills.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: minimum GPA of 3.50 in major courses, 3.30 overall.
name: Senior Thesis
description: A senior thesis related to one of the advanced courses in the major program.

name: Trends and Issues in Sport and Entertainment Management
description: Trends and Issues in Sport and Entertainment Management.

name: Managing Part-Time Employees and Volunteers
description: Recruiting, hiring, training, and retaining part-time employees and volunteers in sport and entertainment.

name: The Business of Esports
description: This course is designed to provide students with an overview of the business of esports. It will focus on the history of video games from creation to the present and will also cover the various business elements of the modern, competitive esports environment.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in SPTE 202 and SPTE 380.
name: Performing Arts Management and Leadership
description: The study of performing arts management as it relates to nonprofits and organizational structure.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPTE 202 and SPTE 380; C or higher for SPTE majors.
name: Business of Broadway
description: The study of the management of Broadway productions from script to play, including the creative process, business ventures, production houses, and investor relations.

name: Special Topics in Global Sport
description: This course examines a variety of global sport and entertainment management issues. The emphasis will be on an understanding of the concepts related to the sport and entertainment management in an international setting. Content varies by title. May be repeated once.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Business Principles in Sport Management.
description: Business principles in the management of public and private sector sport programs.

name: Sports Economics
description: This course focuses on issues relevant to sport, entertainment, and related industries. The goal of the class will be for students to understand both basic and complex concepts within economics in a sport and entertainment context, in order to grasp the importance of economic decision-making.

name: Special Topics in Live Entertainment and Sport
description: Investigation of Special topics pertinent to the sport and entertainment management industry. Content varies by title. May be repeated twice.

name: Sport and Entertainment Event Development
description: Business concepts needed to develop sport and entertainment special events.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SPTE 203 or equivalent.
name: Venue Management: Principles and Practices
description: Managing public assembly facilities and venues.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MKTG 350.
name: Integrated Marketing Communication in Sport and Entertainment
description: Use of integrated marketing communication concepts, theories, and strategies in sport and entertainment.

name: Social Media in Live Entertainment and Sport
description: In-depth investigation of social networks, digital platforms, and online marketing for the live entertainment and sport industries.

name: Introduction to Statistical Reasoning
description: A course in statistical literacy. Topics include data sources and sampling, concepts of experimental design, graphical and numerical data description, measuring association for continuous and categorical variables, introduction to probability and statistical inference, and use of appropriate software. Credit given only for STAT 110 or STAT 112.

name: Statistics and the Media
description: Statistics and the Media. (3) Statistical and information literacy. Experimental and survey design; descriptive statistics; basic probability; simple confidence intervals and hypothesis tests; statistical software; collection, management, and evaluation of information; and presentation of statistics in the media. Credit given for only STAT 110 or STAT 112.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 111 or MATH 115 or STAT 110.
name: Elementary Statistics
description: Introduction to the fundamentals of modern statistical methods, including descriptive statistics, probability, random sampling, simple linear regression, correlation, tests of hypotheses, and estimation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 111 or higher.
name: Elementary Statistics for the Biological and Life Sciences
description: Introduction to fundamental statistical methods with applications in the biological and life sciences. Includes descriptive statistics; probability; one and two-sample models for population means; contingency tables (including relative risk, odds ratios, case-control studies, and estimation of sensitivity and specificity); linear regression; logistic regression; aspects of survival analysis, and ANOVA.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 111 or higher.
name: Elementary Statistics for Business
description: Fundamental statistical methods with applications in business. Includes descriptive statistics, graphical methods, probability, distributions, sampling, inference, contingency tables, and linear regression.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in MATH 122 or MATH 141; or both MATH 111 or higher and any statistical class.
name: Introduction to Experimental Design
description: Techniques of experimentation based on statistical principles with application to quality improvement and other fields. Full and fractional factorial designs for factors at two levels; dispersion effects; related topics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: MATH 142 or equivalent.
name: Statistics for Engineers
description: Basic probability and statistics with applications and examples in engineering. Elementary probability, random variables and their distribution, random processes, statistical inference, linear regression, correlation and basic design of experiments with application to quality assurance, reliability, and life testing. May not be taken concurrently with or after STAT 513, STAT 515, or STAT 516. Not for C.A.S., M.A.S., or Ph.D credit in Statistics.

requisiteText: Prerequisite or Corequisite: C or better in MATH 241.
name: Probability
description: Probability and independence; discrete and continuous random variables; joint, marginal, and conditional densities; moment generating functions; laws of large numbers; binomial, Poisson, gamma, univariate and bivariate normal distributions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in STAT 511 or MATH 511.
name: Mathematical Statistics
description: Functions of random variables, order statistics, sampling distributions, central limit theorem, quality of estimators, interval estimation, sufficient statistics, minimum-variance unbiased estimator, maximum likelihood, large-sample theory, introduction to hypothesis testing.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in STAT 512.
name: Theory of Statistical Inference
description: Hypothesis testing, Neyman-Pearson lemma, likelihood ratio tests, power, the theory of linear models including multiple linear regression and ANOVA, the Chi-square goodness-of-fit test, Chi-square inference for contingency tables, Bayesian inference, and advanced topics including survival analysis (only if time permits).

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in MATH 122 or MATH 141; or both MATH 111 or higher and any statistics class.
name: Statistical Methods I
description: Applications and principles of elementary probability, essential discrete and continuous probability distributions, sampling distributions, estimation, and hypothesis testing. Inference for means, variances, proportions, one-way ANOVA, simple linear regression, and contingency tables. Statistical packages such as SAS or R. May not be taken concurrently with or after STAT 509, STAT 513, or STAT 516. Not for CAS, MAS, MS, or PhD credit in Statistics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in STAT 515, STAT 509, STAT 512, or equivalent.
name: Statistical Methods II
description: Applications and principles of linear models. Simple and multiple linear regression, analysis of variance for basic designs, multiple comparisons, random effects, and analysis of covariance. Statistical packages such as SAS. Not for CAS, MAS, MS, or PhD credit in Statistics.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in STAT 512, STAT 516, or equivalent.
name: Advanced Statistical Models
description: Theory and applications of advanced statistical models. Includes implementation and assessment of generalized linear, nonlinear and nonparametric regression, mixed effect, repeated measures, multivariate regression, and spatial models.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in STAT 515, STAT 509 or STAT 512.
name: Nonparametric Statistical Methods
description: Applications and principles of nonparametric statistics. Classical rank-based methods, and selected categorical data analysis and modern nonparametric methods. Statistical packages such as R.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in STAT 515, STAT 509, STAT 512, or equivalent.
name: Sampling
description: Techniques of statistical sampling in finite populations with applications in the analysis of sample survey data. Topics include simple random sampling for means and proportions, stratified sampling, cluster sampling, ratio estimates, and two-stage sampling.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in STAT 516 or MGSC 391.
name: Forecasting and Time Series
description: Time series analysis and forecasting using the multiple regression and Box-Jenkins approaches.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or higher in STAT 511.
name: Applied Stochastic Processes
description: An introduction to stochastic processes, including conditional probability, Markov chains, Poisson processes, and Brownian motion. Incorporates simulation and applications to actuarial science.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 241.
name: Financial Mathematics I
description: Probability spaces. Random variables. Mean and variance. Geometric Brownian Motion and stock price dynamics. Interest rates and present value analysis. Pricing via arbitrage arguments. Options pricing and the Black-Scholes formula.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in MATH 514 or STAT 522.
name: Financial Mathematics II
description: Convex sets. Separating Hyperplane Theorem. Fundamental Theorem of Asset Pricing. Risk and expected return. Minimum variance portfolios. Capital Asset Pricing Model. Martingales and options pricing. Optimization models and dynamic programming.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: STAT 509 or STAT 515 or MGSC 391.
name: Statistical Quality Control
description: Statistical procedures for process control including CUSUM and Shewhart Control Charts, and lot-acceptance sampling.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: STAT 516.
name: Environmental Statistics
description: Statistical analysis of environmental data. Review of multiple regression and ANOVA, nonlinear regression models and generalized linear models, analyses for temporally and spatially correlated data, and methods of environmental sampling.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in STAT 301, STAT 515, STAT 205, STAT 509, STAT 512, ECON 436, MGSC 291, or PSYC 221.
name: Applied Multivariate Statistics and Data Mining
description: Introduction to fundamentals of multivariate statistics and data mining. Principal components and factor analysis; multidimensional scaling and cluster analysis; MANOVA and discriminant analysis; decision trees; and support vector machines. Use of appropriate software.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in STAT 512, CSCE 582 or STAT 582; or both STAT 511 and either STAT 509 or STAT 515; or equivalent.
name: Introduction to Bayesian Data Analysis
description: Principles of Bayesian statistics, including: one- and multi-sample analyses; Bayesian linear models; Monte Carlo approaches; prior elicitation; hypothesis testing and model selection; hierarchical models; selected advanced models; statistical packages such as WinBUGS and R.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in STAT 301, STAT 515, STAT 509, STAT 512, or equivalent.
name: Computing in Statistics
description: An introduction to statistical packages such as R and SAS with special focus on data management and computing procedures such as Monte Carlo simulation.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: STAT 540.
name: Advanced SAS Programming
description: Advanced programming techniques in SAS, including database management, macro language, and efficient programming practices.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in either CSCE 106 or CSCE 145 and either STAT 509 or STAT 515.
name: Bayesian Networks and Decision Graphs
description: Normative approaches to uncertainty in artificial intelligence. Probabilistic and causal modeling with Bayesian networks and influence diagrams. Applications in decision analysis and support. Algorithms for probability update in graphical models.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in STAT 301, STAT 509, STAT 513, or STAT 515.
name: Big Data Analytics
description: Foundational techniques and tools required for data science and big data analytics. Concepts, principles, and techniques applicable to any technology and industry for establishing a baseline that can be enhanced by future study.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in STAT 201 or higher.
name: Genomic Data Science
description: This course focuses on quantitative knowledge for interdisciplinary applications in genetics as well as hands-on experience in analyzing genetic data. In this course, students will have programming exercises in using analysis tools to conduct genome-wide analysis, annotation, and interpretation of genetic data using R/Bioconductor packages.

name: Data Analysis for Teachers
description: Introduction to statistics for elementary, middle, and high school teachers. The fundamentals of data collection, descriptive statistics, probability, and inference with special focus on methods of teaching statistical reasoning. For M.A.T. (excluding mathematics) / M.Ed. / M.T. and nondegree credit only.

name: Topics in Statistics
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of courses by title.

name: Statistics for Applied Management
description: Introduction to data collection, descriptive statistics, and statistical inference with examples from hospitality, retail, sport, and entertainment management. Focus on selecting, implementing, and interpreting the appropriate statistical methods using software such as Excel and SPSS. Not for minor or degree credit in Mathematics or Statistics. Does not prepare students for STAT 516, STAT 518, STAT 519 or STAT 525.

name: AP Statistics for Teachers
description: A thorough study of the topics covered on the AP Statistics Examination. A non-calculus-based introduction, including descriptive and inferential one- and two-variable statistics, and emphasizing activities illustrating statistical thinking. Current secondary high school teacher certification in mathematics. For I.M.A./M.A.T. (excluding mathematics)/M.Ed./M.T. and nondegree credit only. Restricted to graduate students.

name: Elementary Swahili
description: Grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Assumes no prior experience in the language. Offered only in fall.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: SWAH 121.
name: Basic Proficiency in Swahili
description: Practice and further development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills. Offered in spring and summer II semesters.

name: Intermediate Swahili
description: Development of reading, speaking, listening, and writing skills; introduction of East African culture. SWAH 201 offered in fall, SWAH 202 offered in spring.

name: Intermediate Swahili
description: Development of reading, speaking, listening, and writing skills; introduction of East African culture. SWAH 201 offered in fall, SWAH 202 offered in spring.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Laboratory Theatre Production
description: Procedures for implementation of processes involved in the Laboratory Theatre Production Program. Supervised preparation of all performance and production elements involved in the collaborative process of theatre production. Course content varies according to season production program. Permission of Instructor or by audition. May be repeated for credit.

name: Theatre Running Crew Laboratory.
description: Procedures and processes of running crews for the Mainstage Theatre Production Program. Collaborative teamwork through supervised participation in various theatre production running crews (management, scenic, lighting, sound, costumes and makeup). Course content varies according to season production program. May be repeated for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 120.
name: Theatre Performance Laboratory
description: Preparation and procedures of the rehearsal and performance processes for the Mainstage Theatre Production Program. Collaborative teamwork through supervised participation in an acting company. Course content varies according to season production program. By audition only. May be repeated for credit.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 121.
name: Theatre Production Studio
description: Procedures and processes for the Mainstage Theatre Production Program. Collaborative teamwork through supervised participation in various theatre production student crews (scenic, lighting, sound, costume, makeup, and promotions). Course content varies according to season production program.

name: Fundamentals of Acting
description: Introduction to the art and craft of acting. Practical exploration through improvisation and scripted scene work. Includes a brief history of the development of modern acting techniques.

name: Basic Stage Makeup
description: The study and application of the principles of the art of makeup for the theatre.

name: Shakespeare in Performance
description: Introduction to Shakespeare�€�s works on page, stage, and screen. Emphasis placed on performances of scripts. History of Shakespeare�€�s works/productions, stage/screen technique. Viewings of film adaptations required.

name: Understanding and Appreciation of Theatre
description: An introduction to the understanding and appreciation of theatrical experience. Attendance at theatrical performances required.

name: Introduction to Theatre Studies
description: Introduction to methods of analyzing and interpreting drama, with emphasis on play structure, genre, and style. Designed for the theatre major in preparation for theatre scholarship, performance, production, and design.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 120 and THEA 121.
name: Stage Management Laboratory
description: Supervised participation in theatre stage management. May be repeated once for credit.

name: Introduction to Stage Management
description: An introduction to the roles of the stage manager throughout theatrical productions that include pre-production planning, oversight of the rehearsal process, running technical rehearsals and performances, and completing post-production duties.

name: Make-up Design for Theatre and Film
description: Theory and practice of make-up design for theatre and film. The application of analytical and research skills in the visual development of the character.

name: Beginning Voice and Speech
description: Study and practical application of voice and speech fundamentals in performance. Emphasis on speaking with ease, power and clarity to impact an audience.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 240.
name: Voice and Speech Studio
description: Training in vocal skills needed by actors such as dialect, verse speaking and voice for a variety of media. Maybe repeated for credit.

name: Stage Costume Construction
description: An introductory course in the principles and practice of costume construction.

name: Stagecraft
description: A beginning course in the principles and practice of scenic technology.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 170 or declaration of major.
name: Beginning Acting
description: An exploration of the acting process through scene study. Focus will be on developing the actor�€�s personal technique, emphasizing emotional truthfulness and authenticity.

name: Elements of Design for Theatre Production
description: Foundational application of design principles and vocabulary as applied to the creative process in production design for theatre. Play analysis, creative and visual thinking, and graphic representation.

name: Introduction to Theatre Sound Design
description: Introduces the students to the basic principles of sound design and technology. Related topics include physics of sound, use and maintenance of equipment, script analysis, and creative thinking.

name: Introduction to Stage Lighting
description: Principles and practices of theatrical lighting design.

name: Literature and Performance
description: Introduction to the study of literature through performance; reading, analysis, and performance of prose, poetry, nonfiction, and drama.

name: Theatrical Imagery
description: The theory and application of visual imagery in theatrical design; identification and selection of historical motifs.

name: Japanese Culture and Society through Theatre
description: Introduction to Japanese traditional theatre and its influences on Japanese culture and society. Taught in English.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 170 or THEA 270.
name: Intermediate Acting
description: Development of acting skills through study of acting techniques emphasizing emotional truthfulness and authenticity. Application to scene study, monologues and auditions. Intensive script analysis for character development.

name: Acting from a Physical Point of View
description: Development of physical acting skills related to modern acting techniques emphasizing emotional truthfulness and authenticity. Promoting the experience of full body awareness and expressiveness in character development and storytelling. Includes performative states of relaxation, balance and presence and ensemble work.

name: Movement Laboratory
description: Training in specific physical skills for actors: stage combat, mime, folk dance, tap dance, etc. May be repeated for credit.

name: Inner Mastery Thought Movement
description: A mind/body integration course designed for performing artists.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 280.
name: Production Design for Theatre
description: Principles of production design in scenery, costumes, lighting and sound. Play analysis, periods styles, creative and visual thinking and graphic representation.

name: Independent Study and Research
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in THEA 225.
name: Advanced Stage Management
description: Delving deeper into the role of the stage manager in theatrical productions that includes problem solving, adapting to challenging situations, and distinguishing the various responsibilities of production assistants, assistant stage managers, and production stage managers and their collaborative contributions.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 240.
name: Advanced Voice and Speech for the Actor.
description: Advanced vocal techniques as applied to performance. Specific skills covered may include vocal flexibility and range, vocal dynamics, dialects, and voice-over technique.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in THEA 240.
name: Accents and Dialects for the Actor
description: Study and practical application of major accents and dialects used by actors in performance. Emphasis on acquiring the skills necessary for independent learning of an accent or dialect.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: C or better in THEA 240.
name: Voice Over and Voice Acting
description: Principles and practice of a wide range of voice-over including commercial and narrative styles. Development of character voice as applied to animation, gaming and/or other audio storytelling. Focus is on practical skills necessary for the profession.

name: Musical Theatre Workshop
description: Intensive musical theatre training in areas of song interpretation, musical theatre, dance, voice and acting.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 252.
name: Special Topics in Costume Technology
description: A specialty skills course for advanced students of theatrical costume design and technology. Topics will include tailoring, fabric modification, needle arts, millinery, etc. Course may be repeated as topics vary.

name: Computer Aided Drafting for Theatre
description: Develop basic and intermediate skills in using computer aided drafting programs for theatrical designs and technical drawings.

name: History of Cinema II
description: Survey of the international cinema from 1945 to the present.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 280.
name: Introduction to Costume Design
description: Introduction to the basic principles and elements of design as they apply to the costume designer. Script and character analysis, costume rendering, and production unity.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 270 and THEA 280, and 6 hours from 300 level class or above.
name: Theatre Capstone Course
description: Principles, procedures and practice of the creative and collaborative process. Aspects of the discipline with focus on creative and effective collaboration and communication skills among theatre artists, scholars and technicians. Practical and planning skills for professional success after graduation.

name: Selected Topics in Theatre
description: A series of courses, each lasting one-third of a semester. Topics and prerequisites are announced in the class schedule for each semester.

name: Rendering Techniques for the Theatre
description: Rendering techniques for the communication of concepts and mood in the design process.

name: Playwright�€�s Workshop
description: Principles and practice of playwriting. Writing, adapting, and revising plays. May be repeated with consent of department chair.

name: Drama in Education
description: Comprehensive review of drama strategies, methods and pedagogical practices to be applied to non-drama learning contexts. Practical experience with the necessary skills, philosophies and techniques of drama in education.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 170 and THEA 253.
name: Children�€�s Theatre
description: Special problems in producing plays for child audiences.

name: Applied Theatre Arts
description: Principles and practices of theatre-making within community contexts to address local issues and to provide aesthetic strategies for creative problem solving through theatre.

name: Theatre Management
description: Problems involved in organizing, administering, and promoting the non-professional theatre.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 230 and THEA 550.
name: Period Styles for Wig and Hair Design
description: Research and execution of period styles for wigs, hair, and facial pieces as related to theatrical and media design.

name: Theatre Graphics
description: Specialized graphic techniques used in the preparation of a theatrical production. Practice in the execution and interpretation of working drawings, perspective sketches, color renderings, scale models, etc.

name: Voice and Movement: Practice and Performance
description: A variety of vocal and movement techniques that apply to acting and coaching with special emphasis on the physical and vocal processes in performance.

name: Global/Contextual Issues in Theatre Education Practice and Performance
description: Survey and analysis of current drama teacher practice across international contexts in relationship to global, social and educational change.

name: History of Costume
description: A survey of clothing through the ages with emphasis on the dress of the actor in significant periods of theatrical activity. From ancient times to present day.

name: Costume Flat Patterning
description: The principles of pattern making for costume construction using flat-patterning techniques.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 253 or equivalent.
name: Advanced Stagecraft
description: Advanced principles and practices of stagecraft.

name: Performing Arts Safety
description: Study of health and safety hazards for actors, technicians, and audience members.

name: Scene Painting for the Stage
description: Techniques of scene painting. Application of principles of painting to the stage.

name: Stage Design
description: Survey of the history and principles of scene design. Assignments will involve drawings, watercolor sketches, and scale models.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 556.
name: Advanced Scenic Design
description: Advanced procedures and techniques of scenic design.

name: Costume Draping
description: Costume pattern making through basic draping techniques on industry standard dress forms. Analysis of fit and design, problem solving and interaction of fabric characteristics with style features.

name: Introductory Methods for K-12 Theatre Certification
description: Developmental approaches to drama instruction in K-12 classroom settings.

name: History of the Theatre I
description: A survey of plays, playwrights, actors, production, and the physical development of theatres from the time of the Greeks to 1660; reading of representative plays required.

name: History of the Theatre II
description: A survey of plays, playwrights, actors, production, and the physical development of theatres from 1660 to the present; reading of representative plays required.

name: History of Modern Theatre
description: History of Western Theatre since the early 20th century. Students will be introduced to major figures, plays, and movements and explore influences from the broader culture on theatrical expression.

name: African American Theatre
description: The major movements, figures, plays, and critical strategies that have marked the development of African American theatre in the 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries.
attributes: GLD: Professional and Civic Engagement Leadership Experiences

name: Dramatic Theory I
description: A survey of the major works of dramatic theory and criticism, with emphasis on theories of theatrical performance. from Aristotle through 18th-century neo-classicism.

name: Dramatic Theory II
description: A survey of the major works of dramatic theory and criticism, with emphasis on theories of theatrical performance from the 18th century to the present.

name: Dramaturgy
description: A study of dramatic structure as it relates to theatrical production. Emphasis on script reading and analysis. Production and new-works dramaturgy will be covered.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: B or better in THEA 240 and THEA 372 and THEA 370.
name: Advanced Acting I
description: Theory and practice in the development of a role and an understanding of the psychology of the audience-actor relationship.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: B or better in THEA 240 and THEA 372 and THEA 370.
name: Advanced Acting II
description: Technique of performing play scripts with heightened language and styles other than naturalism/realism. Some examples of genres that may be taught are Classical Greek, Elizabethan, absurdist.

requisiteText: Prerequisites: THEA 230.
name: Advanced Makeup for Theatre and Film
description: Makeup design for specific character types, prosthetics and three-dimensional makeup effects. Special attention to the process of sculpting and modeling for makeup prosthetics.

name: Rehearsal and Performance
